webTitle: League treats players like horses - Houllier

fields.headline: League treats players like horses - Houllier
fields.trailText: Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier reacted angrily yesterday after the Premier League insisted that his club must squeeze another fixture into next month's hectic schedule.
fields.body:
Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier reacted angrily yesterday after the Premier League insisted that his club must squeeze another fixture into next month's hectic schedule.

Told that their outstanding game at Ipswich Town must be staged on April 10, the Merseyside club now face a total of eight matches in 23 days.

"I do not agree with this fixture list at all," said Houllier. "I will not let my players be treated like horses. I am prepared to defend the interests of my players; as the manager I have to look after their welfare."

Liverpool have asked the league to consider moving the game back to early May, shortly before the season ends.

After Saturday's league game with Manchester United at Anfield, Houllier's side travel to Barcelona for the Uefa Cup semi-final first leg before facing Second Division Wycombe in the FA Cup semi-final at Villa Park on Sunday week.

The meeting with Wycombe is the first of four games in eight days for Liverpool, a sequence which includes the Ipswich game, a home match with Leeds United and an away derby with Everton. That is followed by the home date with Barcelona before a month which will make or break their season ends with league games against Spurs and Coventry.

Liverpool's midfielder Patrik Berger yesterday declared himself ready for a return after more than five months on the sidelines with a knee-ligament injury which threatened to end his career.

"I have played in a couple of reserve-team games and come through well," said the Czech Republic international. "I do feel that I'm just about ready to return to the first-team squad."

Torquay, bottom of the Third Division and with only nine games left to save themselves, have sacked their manager Wes Saunders after two seasons in the job. They immediately turned to their former player Colin Lee, dismissed as Wolves manager this season, and he will take charge as a consultant for Saturday's visit by Hull.

"I have already had applicants for the job but the fact that Colin can look after the side takes away some of the urgency of making an appointment," said the club's owner Mike Bateson. "Ideally I would like to appoint a manager with experience who will still be here next season, but that is ideally."

 The president and vice-president of the Italian third division club Pisa resigned yesterday after the club were banned from playing at home for four games and fined 4m lire (£1,300) because of the trouble that followed a missed Pisa penalty in Sunday's derby with Livorno, when 40 fans were injured and 70 arrested. The match was abandoned with the visitors leading 1-0, from a penalty.

webTitle: Another draw leaves Wales chasing a lost cause

fields.headline: Another draw leaves Wales chasing a lost cause
fields.trailText: Hartson 11 | Shevchenko 52
fields.byline: Martin Thorpe at the Millennium stadium
fields.body:
Wales can boast the magnificent Millennium stadium and the equally magnificent Ryan Giggs. Unfortunately they lack a world-class team to match, and last night they had to endure the familiar sight of their World Cup qualifying chances fast disappearing into the night as Ukraine outclassed them for large parts of an entertaining game.

Mark Hughes's side needed three points from this match to retain any realistic chance of challenging for second place, but not for the first time in this campaign they threw away a lead after John Hartson's third goal in two games, and had to settle for a fourth successive draw.

It was no help to Hughes to be without three of his more experienced midfielders. Leicester's Robbie Savage and Everton's Mark Pembridge were injured, and Charlton's John Robinson suspended. As soon as Giggs pronounced himself fit for this game he was immediately propelled into the position of potential savour.

As if to lift some of the weight on him, Wales took the lead on 11 minutes with a goal conjured up by the Barnsley full-back Darren Barnard, who swung in a cross from the left that Gary Speed flicked onto Hartson.

The big Coventry striker needed no second bidding, and with a lunge of a foot by the far post volleyed the ball past Olexander Shovovski.

That turned out to be Wales's only chance of the first half as they struggled to keep possession for any length of time. The test for the home side moved to the other end of the pitch, where a defence containing three players from the First Division pitted its wits against a Ukraine attacking force that blended movement, invention and versatility in a dangerous brew.

The strike force of Milan's Andriy Shevchenko and Tottenham's Sergei Rebrov roamed either side of the central striker Andrii Vorobiei as various midfielders and defenders joined in with a bewildering pattern of runs that pulled the Wales back line all over the wide pitch.

But with a dogged determination and a succession of last-minute interventions Wales held out.

Paul Jones did well to block a shot from Vorobiei, who had been put through early on. Shevchenko cut in dangerously from the left to shoot just wide, Vorobiei's shot was just cleared for a corner, and seconds before half-time Mark Delaney got a foot in to divert Serhiy Popov's goalbound shot over the bar.

However, few teams can concede so much possession and soak up so much pressure without buckling. And sure enough Ukraine equalised six minutes into the second half.

Rebrov had been replaced at half-time by Vasyl Kardash and the right-sided midfielder made an immediate impact. Linking cleverly down the left with Andrii Nesmachnyi, he played in the attacking full-back close to the by-line.

As Robert Page and Matthew Jones, the Leicester midfielder, both lunged in for the tackle, Nesmachnyi managed to squeeze the ball across the face of goal, where Shevchenko scored one of the easiest goals of his illustrious career, tapping the ball home from about a foot.

Wales suffered another blow when Jones, whose tenacious contribution in front of the back four had played a large part in Wales's first half clean sheet, was forced off after picking up an injury in the tackle.

But slowly Wales began to creep back into the game. A brave decision by Hughes to switch to 4-3-3, with Craig Bellamy up alongside Giggs and Hartson, gave Ukraine more to think about.

Passing and possession improved and Hartson twice brought saves out of Shovovski while Speed had a decent penalty shout turned down after what looked like a push.

Wales (4-1-3-2): P Jones (Southampton); Delaney (Aston Villa), Page (Watford), Melville (Fulham), Barnard (Barnsley) ; M Jones (Leicester); Bellamy (Coventry), Robinson (Wolves), Speed (Newcastle); Giggs (Manchester U), Hartson (Coventry).

Ukraine (4-3-2-1): Shovovski; Luzhny, Vaschuk, Holovko, Nesmachnyi; Popov, Tymoschuk, Yashkin; Rebrov, Shevchenko; Vorobiei.

Referee: E Romain (Belgium).

webTitle: No 10 seeks more control over ministers

fields.headline: No 10 seeks more control over ministers
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Downing Street moved yesterday to increase its authority across Whitehall by proposing that it houses a central unit to challenge and scrutinise all major departmental initiatives.
fields.body:
Downing Street moved yesterday to increase its authority across Whitehall by proposing that it houses a central unit to challenge and scrutinise all major departmental initiatives.

The idea is contained in a paper published yesterday by the prime minister's own think-tank, the performance and innovation unit. The paper proposes that a "challenge team" be set up at the centre of government, "largely made up of people with proven experience of delivery, to test and probe departmental plans and report on deliverability and potential risks".

The report complains that now departmental ideas are only examined by the Treasury to test their cost, or subsequently if the policy has failed.

The PIU report, largely written by its director Geoff Mulgan, also suggests the Whitehall centre could provide advice on implementation and timescales, and urges ministers to cut the number of initiatives. It says "policy makers and ministers should be ruthlessly economical with goals .. for any initiative."

A separate report from the PIU also published yesterday admits there is a crisis of leadership quality in the public services, and more work needs to be done to raise morale.

The report concedes: "The public services are not attracting or keeping the best leaders, and do not have sufficiently robust strategies for recruiting them to the posts that matter most; jobs and careers in the public services are undervalued, and top leadership jobs are, arguably, underpaid. Too few organisations seek actively to recruit the best leaders".

The report suggests that "human resources problems threaten to be the biggest impediment to successful delivery in the next 5-10 years".

It suggests amongst senior managers base pay rates in the wider public sector are roughly 25-30% below the comparable private sector rate and civil service rates (for those in executive agency postings) 40-50% below.

fields.headline: Join the text set
fields.standfirst: Fifteen billion mobile text messages a month show the service has become routine for many. But for those still to get - or send - the message,  Neil McIntosh offers a beginner's guide
fields.trailText: Fifteen billion mobile text messages a month show the service has become routine for many. But for those still to get - or send - the message, Neil McIntosh offers a beginner's guide
fields.body:
With the amount of hype surrounding the humble text message, it could be easy to forget that the explosion in the service's popularity has only really taken place in the past year.

In July 1999, when Online first reported on the growth of text messaging, one billion text messages were being sent each month.

By January last year that figure had grown to four billion, before a wave of publicity highlighted this once obscure service's usefulness.

Now, 15 billion messages are sent globally every month. As the figure continues to soar, newspapers tell of dramatic rescues by text message and mini-dictionaries detail a new language springing up in the text's confined spaces.

But what if you've missed the boat? Staring at your mobile, what if you don't have a clue how to join in? Feel left out no more - here is Online's guide to texting for the three most popular brands of mobile.

We have opted for popular, well-established models rather than the latest whizz-bang versions, but still cannot detail every nuance in each model. But we hope our step-by-step guide points you in the right direction.

Keying text
The procedure for entering characters into your mobile is much the same, whatever model you are using. When you arrive at the text writing screen (following the steps published on these pages), the characters printed on the keys of your phone become available. Thus, if you press the 2 key once, you get an A. Press the 5 key twice you get a K, and so on.

The 1 key usually throws up special characters like full stops and commas, while the * or # key normally allows you to switch between upper and lower case letters.

Some phones now also offer predictive text input - where you only need to press each key once, and the phone guesses the word you want to type.

Nokia Sending a text message
1 Press the Menu button and use the down key to scroll move to the messages screen. Press select.

2 Use the down key to move to Write messages and press select.

3 A blank screen appears. Enter your message. For lower case letters, press the # key in the bottom right hand corner of the keypad. For capital letters, press the # again.

4 The number of characters you have left in your message (the maximum is 160) is shown in the top right hand corner of the screen.

5 When you are finished, press the Options key. Select OK when Send is highlighted.

6 Enter the recipient's phone number. If you want to search for the number in the phone's memory, press Search and scroll through the numbers using the arrow keys until you find the right number. Press OK.

7 Press OK, and the message will be sent

webTitle: Characters in search of an author

fields.headline: Characters in search of an author
fields.standfirst: Send us a text message poem from your mobile phone and help pick our contest winner - it could even be you.  Victor Keegan  explains how our competition will work
fields.trailText: Send us a text message poem from your mobile phone and help pick our contest winner - it could even be you. Victor Keegan explains how our competition will work
fields.body:
You may or may not have a novel inside you but everyone, surely, has one text poem waiting to come out: a mere 160 characters in search of an author.

To find out, the Guardian is today launching the first text message poetry competition with Guardian Unlimited and in association with Consult Hyperion, which built the infrastructure.

It is open to everyone, particularly those who have never thought of writing a poem before. A prize of £1,000 will be given for the best entry, £500 for the second best and £100 for each of three runners-up. It is the first competition of its kind with a special interactive feature. The final short list of seven poems will be "texted" to all entrants - one poem a day for seven days - so participants themselves will be the ultimate judges.

Otherwise, there are no rules. It is up to participants whether they use ordinary language or interlace it with text messaging shorthand - and whether full stops are used or a symbol to indicate the end of a line. You can, as Andrew Wilson suggests stick to one theme, or try to pack in as many as you can. This is a new literary form and it must be left to define its own parameters. In this competition the medium really is the message.

Text messaging has already become one of the most successful activities of all time. A few years ago it had hardly been heard of. Yet last year more than six billion individual messages were sent between mobile phones in the UK alone. In January this year over 900m were sent. Mostly they involve the exchange of service information, facts, sport updates, share prices, trivia and gossip. In the process, text messaging has created a whole new layer of remote person-to-person social exchanges.

And we are only at the start of what is clearly going to be a massive communications revolution, in which virtually everyone in the industrialised world will have a mobile device - eventually capable of two-way video links - with them all the time.

Text messaging can also be used creatively, and the Guardian competition will test the possibilities. The procedure is simple. For two weeks from today, mobile phone users can submit poems of no more than 160 characters (the maximum possible with a text message) by sending them to 07753 828610 . You can send more than one but remember you will have to pay the usual cost charged by your service provider. A selection of poems from the entries will be featured every day on Guardian Unlimited along with the full terms and conditions of the competition.

If you can't send a text message then now is the time to learn. It is probably the simplest of all the information age techniques to master.

All entrants will receive an acknowledgement of their summissions on April 22 just before the final seven are judged. Only one notification per phone will be sent.

Before that Matt Locke, artistic director of The Media Centre in Huddersfield ( www.test.org.uk ) and Andrew Wilson, editor of Centrifugalforces ( www.centrifugalforces. co.uk ), who suggested the interactive element, will draw up a "long" shortlist of 100.

This will then be reduced to seven by an expert panel: UA Fanthorpe, described in the Financial Times as "the poet who can suddenly hit you below the heart"; Peter Sansom, former poet in residence with Marks and Spencer; and Justine Jordan, Guardian Unlimited books editor.

On April 22, all entrants will be texted a message to remind them that, starting the following day, they will be sent one of the final seven poems every day for a week at around lunchtime for judging. They should reply, immediately if possible, with a mark from 1 to 10 (numerals, please, not letters). Only those responding to the first request will be sent the remaining six entries.

Winners will be notified by phone on May 2 and the results, together with examples of other entries, will be published in Guardian Online on May 3.

No employees of the Guardian, Consult Hyperion or anyone connected to the competition or its promotion may enter. We reserve the right to adjust the rules if there is an unexpectedly large number of entries.

Step by step

1. Mar 29 to April 13: Text us a poem to 07753 828610

2. April 14: Sifting begins to produce a shortlist of 100

3. April 19: Judges meet to decide the final seven poems

4. April 22: Entrants to be reminded of the judging process

5. April 23: Entrants to be texted a poem a day for seven days. Give each a mark out of 10 (in numerals) and send it back

6. May 3: Results will be published in Online

Samples of poems received will be in next week's Online

fields.headline: Everyday words about everyday lives
fields.standfirst: Text message poet  Andrew Wilson  offers advice on capturing that luminous detail
fields.trailText: Text message poet  Andrew Wilson  offers advice on capturing that luminous detail
fields.body:
If you are at a bus stop, on a train or in a bar for more than five minutes, you are sure to see someone tapping away on their mobile phone, writing or reading a text message. Millions are sent every day, partly because they are cheap, but mostly because it is enjoyable.

It is exciting to see the little message symbol on the screen in the same way that it is exciting to get a letter. It is not going to put us on the spot, in the way answering a phone call could. There's time to consider what has been sent, try to read betweeen the lines, puzzle over double meanings: do they really fancy us, or are they just being friendly? Text messaging allows almost instantaneous correspondence that we wouldn't want to be overheard on the train: what our boss is really like; what we did, or wished we hadn't done, the night before.

Most importantly, text messages let us think about our reply, choose our words carefully. They let us try to say something clever or cool, use written words to strike a pose or have a calculated effect. Then the message gets sent, the words bounce around in the ether, and at the other end someone tries to work out what it means: do we really fancy them, or are we just being friendly? That gap between what we think our words mean, what we try to make them say, and what they say for themselves, is poetry.

More people are using words creatively and inventively than at any time in the history of the English language. We are all poets and we don't even know it. Yet, writing text message poems is as easy as writing text messages. I started my first one, Summer Dresses, while waiting for a bus, on one of the few hot days in Leeds last summer. Since then I've written quite a few, and begun to notice what the better ones have in common.

Text messages are short, so the subject has to be tackled in a way that will fit into 160 characters. There isn't space to tell much of a story. A text message poem has to find one truthful moment and describe it, whether it's seeing the red moon during the lunar eclipse - or not seeing it becaue it was cloudy; the way everyone stands up at once during a football match; a child asleep in the back of the car on the way home from a holiday. Ezra Pound called it the luminous detail. Find it, show it and let it speak for itself.

Mobile phones have become workaday tools. Text messages are written in everyday words about our everyday lives. Handled with care, that's good enough to be poetry. A poem doesn't have to be written in a different language - poetry speak - just because we want it to mean something. A poem will find a meaning anyway, whether we like it or not.

Different makes of phone have different sized screens, so there is no way to control how a poem is laid out to the reader. The only way to control the rhythm and pace of what is being read is by choice of words and punctuation.

Text messages have developed their own shorthand vocabulary in order to save space. There is nothing wrong with using these abbreviations in a playful, inventive way, but be aware of the effect that they will have on the reader. The eye will skim across an abbreviation without properly reading the words, and so speed up the pace of what comes next and give it a breathless, must-dash feel. This will be perfect if the poem is about being late for a date, but might not be appropriate if it's about burying your little brother's hamster at the bottom of the garden.

Text message poems have to be written on phone screens. Seeing the counter of remaining characters ticking down gives a sense of how to structure a poem so it fits. Poems written on paper then keyed in always seem to be 25 characters too long, then it's heartbreaking deciding which really good bit to leave out.

Anyone can write a text message poem. They are just everyday language used carefully. This is poetry, however you write it.

webTitle: Laboured Ireland make a mountain out of Andorra

fields.headline: Laboured Ireland make a mountain out of Andorra
fields.standfirst: Harte 33pen, Kilbane 75, Holland 79
fields.trailText: Given the poverty of Andorra's reputation it should have come as no surprise here in the Mini Estadi last night that there were times when there seemed to be more bodies in and around their penalty area than on an average evening on La Rambla.
fields.body:
Given the poverty of Andorra's reputation it should have come as no surprise here in the Mini Estadi last night that there were times when there seemed to be more bodies in and around their penalty area than on an average evening on La Rambla.

In the end Ireland saw off the group's wooden-spoon nation with something to spare, Ian Harte's first-half penalty supplemented by late goals from Kevin Kilbane and Matt Holland. But it would not be stretching the truth to say that Mick McCarthy's team could, and should, have massaged their egos with the type of landslide victory their superiority merited.

If Ireland mete out similar punishment when the Andorrans visit Lansdowne Road on April 25 they will be perfectly positioned to face Portugal on June 2 for a match that could be the pivotal fixture in dictating who qualifies automatically.

"It's been a good week," said McCarthy. "We've played two games, got six points and scored seven goals with none against. We've done our job and put ourselves in with a chance. I can't ask for any more than that."

In eight years of independence Andorra, 179 square miles with fewer than 65,000 inhabitants, have won only one international match while contriving to lose all their qualifying games for the last two major tournaments. On last night's evidence it was easy to see how.

The only nagging doubt was that the longer Ireland went without turning the gulf in class into the hard currency of goals, the greater the chance it would start playing on their minds. So it came as a relief when Roy Keane's surge into the penalty area, running on to Gary Doherty's neat flick, resulted in his being brought down by the Andorran goalkeeper Alfonso Sanchez just after the half-hour.

There are few better penalty takers than Harte and the Leeds full-back lashed a typically venomous effort into the bottom left corner. From then on it was a case of how many Ireland could rack up.

To reach half-time leading by a solitary goal was far from satisfactory, particularly given the multitude of squandered chances, but the play was so one-sided, with Shay Given spending most of the match somewhere close to the centre circle, that there was no cause for anxiety.

But for a frustratingly long period Ireland's pursuit of more goals continued to take them down cul-de-sacs. Robbie Keane may never play another game in which he fritters away more gilt-edged opportunities.

There was a good width and penetration to their play, but for all the Irish possession in telling areas the margin remained uncomfortably close until the 75th minute. Roy Keane sent over a precise centre from the left and, though Sanchez kept out Robbie Keane's downward header, Kilbane reacted quickest to stab in the loose ball.

Four minutes later, after yet more pinball in Andorra's area, Holland manoeuvred some room to lash in the third with a rising shot. Andorra's national slogan may be The Country of the Pyrenees but, for the Irish, this was more of a walk in the foothills.

Andorra (5-3-2): A Sanchez; Pol, T Lima, Jonas, Txema, Lucendo; Emiliano (Escura, 82min), I Lima, Oscar; Ruiz, J Sanchez (Jimenez, 87).

Republic of Ireland (4-4-2): Given; G Kelly, Breen, Cunningham, Harte; Duff, Roy Keane, Holland, Kilbane (Finnan, 85); Connolly (Doherty, 26), Robbie Keane.

Referee : I Ishchenko (Ukraine).

webTitle: Hendry shows no mercy to lost tourists

fields.headline: Hendry shows no mercy to lost tourists
fields.standfirst: Hendry 22, 33, Dodds 34, Cameron 65
fields.trailText: Scotland delivered, as no-one doubted, but failed to emulate the thrashing of San Marino produced by their group rivals, Belgium.
fields.body:
Scotland delivered, as no-one doubted, but failed to emulate the thrashing of San Marino produced by their group rivals, Belgium.

Once Scotland shook off their early anxiety, this was not a win to flatter a side riven with faults that would certainly be exposed by more expert opposition.

But since two of their goals came from the unlikeliest of sources, their captain and defender Colin Hendry, it was hardly a devastating show of firepower either.

San Marino conceded five goals during the last fifteen minutes of their 10-1 rout by Belgium last month. Last night, they kept a clean sheet during the same period: a feat that will no doubt lead to the erection of a small statue in the republic.

Scotland began with all but two of the side who lined up against Belgium on Saturday, Barry Ferguson out with a rib injury and the defender Tom Boyd's perhaps surplus to requirements against a side who largely lived up to the expectation of giving attacking football only the most cursory of glances.

They came, drunk in the pre-match atmosphere, looked proficient enough during their warm up and proceeded to play as if Neil Sullivan's goal was a misty isle on a congested tourist itinerary: to be viewed, but not visited.

That said, San Marino began with a spring in their step and when Andy Selva - their only professional - and Riccardo Muccioli strung a couple of passes together through the Scottish middle with five minutes gone, an uneasy silence descended on a reasonably full Hampden Park. And when, in the 12th minute, Muccioli threaded a pass to Selva, who beat the Scotland offside trap, the best opportunity of the game had Sullivan almost handle the ball outside his box.

Otherwise, the resolve of the tourists to pack their defence not only spoiled any notion of a contest but also drew the sting out of Scotland's self- belief.

Step forward captain Hendry. Ordinarily, he would be expected to be in the thick of things at Scotland corners. But as the home side tried to calm their nerves by making corners count, Hendry assumed the role of roving predator. First, after Matt Elliott had headed Craig Burley's corner on to the woodwork, Hendry was on hand to mop up with a curling left-foot shot into the far corner from eight yards out. Minutes later, he was cleaning up from the edge of the box with a thundering, half-volley with his right foot that took everyone by surprise. He had scored in only one other international, against Malta in 1993.

Within seconds of that, game over. Allan Johnston battled for possession on the right, Don Hutchison chipped the cross and Billy Dodds launched himself between Luca Gobbi and Simone Della Balda to head powerfully home. In the space of 10 minutes Scotland had gone from creaking to cruise control.

Such games inevitably settle into passages of patient but frustrating probing for the next chink in the visitor's armour; Scotland endured Dodds heading on to the post and Hutchison being denied by Frederico Gasperoni's left-foot before extending their advantage.

Johnston threw in the long cross, Kevin Gallacher - just on for Dominic Matteo - headed back into the danger zone and, as Craig Burley breezed forward to ruffle feathers, Colin Cameron made his latest, timed incursion tell with the side-footed shot.

Scotland (3-5-2): Sullivan; Weir, Elliott, Hendry; Johnston, Burley, Lambert, Cameron, Matteo; Dodds, Hutchison.

San Marino (4-5-1): Gasperoni; Della Balda, Bacciocchi, Matteoni, Gobbi; Manzaroli, Zonzini, Muccioli, Vannucci, Marani; Selva.

fields.headline: Blunders sink McIlroy's boys
fields.standfirst: Balakov 7, M Petrov 17, 76, Tchomakov 72 | Williams 15, Elliott 84, Healy 90pen
fields.trailText: Bulgaria 4 - 3 Northern Ireland
fields.body:
Northern Ireland's 2002 World Cup qualifying hopes were virtually ended last night when defensive frailties brought them a disappointing defeat at the Balgarska Armia stadium.

Sammy McIlroy's men have now collected only four points from five matches, and the Czech Republic, Bulgaria and Denmark are contesting the top two places.

The manager was scathing in his criticism of his back division, accusing them of "schoolboy errors" and claiming that all four goals should have been prevented.

"When you give away a penalty like we did in the opening minutes there is always an uphill struggle," he said.

Northern Ireland repeatedly put themselves under pressure with misplaced passes and sloppy clearances during an error-ridden first half and found it difficult coping with the pace and interchanges of the Bulgarian forwards.

Yet again they conceded an early goal when the midfielder Jim Magilton made a bad back-pass and the Preston centre-back Colin Murdock brought down Bulgaria's centre-forward Krassimir Balakov, who scored from the spot.

After a 15th-minute reply from Mark Williams, who rose above three defenders to head in a corner from Michael Hughes, another defensive blunder two minutes later let in Martin Petrov, who dribbled past Danny Griffin, stumbled, but still managed to get the ball past the keeper Roy Carroll from an acute angle.

Northern Ireland looked a much more confident and committed unit after the interval, until Carroll let a 40-yard free-kick from Krasmir Tchomakov spin through his hands into the net after 72 minutes.

Four minutes later Petrov struck again with a half-volley at the far post, but the match then took another bizarre turn as the Irish contrived a barnstorming finish.

Hughes attempted a shot which ballooned in the air and dropped for Stuart Elliott to beat the Bulgarian keeper with a looping header.

Then, in the first minute of injury-time, Biser Ivanov brought down David Healy in the box and the diminutive Preston striker scored from the spot. That brought his international goal tally to six in 10 games and put him, at age 21, in line to break Northern Ireland's 13-goal record held by Colin Clarke, the former Portsmouth centre- forward.

Bulgaria (4-3-1-2): Zdravkov; Kichichev, Pazain, Markov, Petkov (Stoilov, 58min); B Ivanov, Tchomakov, Hristrov (S Petrov, 67); Balakov; Berbatov, M Petrov.

Northern Ireland (4-4-1-1): Carroll (Wigan); Griffin (Dundee Utd), Williams (Wimbledon), Murdock (Preston), Nolan (Bradford; McCarthy , Birmingham, 90); Gillespie (Blackburn; Johnson , Blackburn, 86), Magilton (Ipswich), Lennon (Celtic; Kennedy , Watford, 86), Elliott (Motherwell); Hughes (Wimbledon), Healy (Preston).

Referee: V Hrinak (Slovakia).

webTitle: Rail firms say public must pay for safety

fields.headline: Rail firms say public must pay for safety
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The rail industry yesterday warned that the taxpayer will have to bear most of the cost of introducing a £3bn train protection warning system over the next 10-15 years.
fields.body:
The rail industry yesterday warned that the taxpayer will have to bear most of the cost of introducing a £3bn train protection warning system over the next 10-15 years.

On the eve of a report from Lord Cullen into safety following the Paddington and Southall rail crashes, the rail industry said that only higher fares or extra cash from the government could pay for such an investment.

Rod Muttram, chief executive of Railtrack's subsidiary company, Railway Safety, said that opposition from the public to higher fares would make it impossible for the 25 train-operating companies to pay for the project. Most of it would have to come from the public purse.

Railtrack admitted that its first step towards improving safety on the track has fallen behind schedule. It is already behind in its plan to fit trains with a train protection warning system by the end of 2002.

This less sophisticated system is being introduced as a temporary measure while a European standard system called ERTMS is developed.

Chris Leah, Railtrack's head of safety, said that the fitting of TPWS had been a far more complex task than was originally envisaged. So far only 1,200 signals out of 11,000 had been fitted.

He said: "We hope to be in a position to achieve our target date of the beginning of January in 2003 but it will be very tight."

Industry observers last night suggested that the train companies had tried to seize the opportunity of pre-empting the Cullen report by saying how much improved safety would cost.

Mr Muttram said that the industry was keen to introduce the highest levels of safety, "but we want people to understand how long it will take because everyone will want this intoduced overnight".

An automatic train protection system such as ERTMS would have prevented the Southall rail crash, in which seven people were killed, and the Paddington rail crash, where there were 31 victims.

Those injured in the two accidents have called for this type of protection to be introduced as soon as possible rather than relying on TPWS, currently being installed. It will stop trains automatically if they pass red signals, and is generally effective at speeds of up to 75 mph.

Mr Muttram said that to complete ERTMS fitment in 10 years would mean taking 10 trains out of service for every day during the period. He admitted that it could cause inconvenience to passengers, but the changes could only be introduced with the railway operating.

Mr Leah agreed that the cost of installing the system nationwide would be less expensive if large tracts of the railway were closed at a time, but this was politically impossible.

The first line to be equipped with the new system will be the west coast route between London and Glasgow. This is due to be installed by 2005 by which time Virgin Trains will be running services at speeds of up to 125 mph.

Mr Leah agreed that the cost of installing the system nationwide would be less expensive if large tracts of the railway were closed at a time, but this was politically impossible. The first line to be equipped with the new system will be the west coast route between London and Glasgow. This is due to be installed by 2005 by which time Virgin Trains will be running services at speeds of up to 125 mph.

webTitle: Signet profits jump but US fails to glitter

fields.headline: Signet profits jump but US fails to glitter
fields.trailText: The US jewellery market is losing its sparkle according to the retail group Signet, which yesterday admitted that customers are resisting the urge to buy gems as economic conditions worsen.
fields.body:
The US jewellery market is losing its sparkle according to the retail group Signet, which yesterday admitted that customers are resisting the urge to buy gems as economic conditions worsen.

Signet announced a 27% jump in annual pretax profits to £162m but noted a "sharp deterioration" towards the end of the year in the American market, which accounts for 71% of its sales.

The company's chief executive, Terry Burman, said Signet's American chains, Kay Jewelers and Jared, were proving resilient thanks to romantic advertising slogans such as "Every kiss begins with Kay".

However, he added: "We can't fight gravity. Market forces and the trading market are going to impact us."

Several rival jewellers, including the American market leader Zale, have recently warned of deteriorating demand as consumers take note of increasingly gloomy economic forecasts.

Bad news from the jewellery industry has sent Signet's shares down by a quarter this month. They edged up 2p to 65.5p yesterday.

Mr Burman said some gems remained popular with Americans - particularly sapphires and tanzanite, a blue stone noted for its bright shine that was originally found in Tanzania.

"Blue seems to be popular. It tends to co-ordinate with fashionable clothing colours."

In Britain, Signet's H Samuel and Ernest Jones chains gained from an increasing focus on diamonds. Their profits jumped 27% to £50m.

Mr Burman said a move upmarket had pleased customers: "H Samuel customers have responded very well to our diamond offering - more and more UK consumers are wearing diamonds."

He said diamonds were popular not only in rings but in pendants, earrings and bracelets: "We're not just talking about weddings and engagements - this is the fashion market, we're competing with handbags and scarves."

Signet, the world's largest speciality jewellery retailer, emerged from the remnants of the Ratner group. The company has 1,604 shops, including 999 in the US.

The company is enjoying a surge in the popularity of St Valentine's Day. Mr Burman said: "It's getting more and more popular both in the US and the UK. Five years ago, we'd only have seen a fraction of the demand we see now."

fields.headline: Sankai Juku
fields.standfirst:
Sadler's Wells, London
**
fields.trailText:
Sadler's Wells, London
**
fields.body:
Sankai Juku must have performed in London four or five times during the past decade. Watching their latest show, Hibiki, many of the elements that make up their unique performance ritual seem very familiar. The elemental minimalism of their stage design is, as always, exquisitely achieved. The dancers' minutely calibrated movements make them seem, as always, like priests in some painfully elevated trance. Time passes slowly, the seconds marked in this show by the drip, drip of water into huge glass dishes.

In Hibiki, Sankai Juku are as perfect as they always are within the formula they have set themselves. So is there any sense in considering whether this new show is any better or worse than the others? Or even if it's any different?

The curtain rises on a stage circled with 12 pools of water and with five dancers lying in foetal position in circles of golden light. One man, Ushio Amagatsu, stands erect, dancing like a statue in a zen garden come to life. Then the others rise to perform introvert, repetitive passages of dance. Their hands are clawed, their knees sag, their faces are sternly immobile. The music ranges from harshly amplified strings to lyric piano and churning industrial noise.

There are two dramatic changes of gear in the show. One occurs when four dancers appear in corsets and skirts, swarming round one of the pools of water, which has been bloodied with red paint. The men's shaven heads, pallid rice-powdered skins, and narcissistic gestures make them appear like 19th-century courtesans returned from some transsexual limbo. The other climax is a breathtaking light change in which the stage is pooled with gold and aquamarine, and patterned with an extravagant chiaroscuro effect. The dancers, gilded against the deep black of the backdrop, look like gods from another planet.

Little else in the show, however, worked any of the predictable Sankai Juku magic on me. I found its repetitions dull rather than focused and I resisted its efforts to nudge me into any contemplation of body, time or spirit. This surliness on my part may have been the fault of the choreography, which possibly had a more limited stock of images than usual, or of the stage design, which, though beautiful, may have been more static. Or it could simply have been that I was so sick of the unrelenting drip of rain outside, that I had no patience for the unchanging theatrical weather inside. Sankai Juku dramatically displace our normal readings of body language and create bizarre, wonderful images, but they expect their audience to fill in an awful lot of the spaces between. And if you're not in the mood, those spaces can seem like so much metaphysical hot air.

 Until Saturday. Box office: 020-7863 8000.

webTitle: Theatre review:  The House of Pootsie Plunket

fields.headline: The weird, icy world of Pootsie
fields.standfirst:
The House of Pootsie Plunket
Pleasance, London
***
fields.trailText:
The House of Pootsie Plunket
Pleasance, London
***
fields.body:
Canadian company Catalyst raised the temperature at the Edinburgh fringe a couple of years ago with this show inspired by Electra, a cool story of murder and matricide in the icy Canadian wastelands. But, as is so often the case, what was hailed as great in the critical fury of Edinburgh now looks only good in the cold light of day.

Jonathan Christenson and Joey Tremblay's play, which they also direct, may be a case of style over substance - but the style is quite something. Against four towering columns of ice and in front of the frozen tombs of her pioneering forebears (including her dead dad, Buster), Pootsie recounts how her family came to be regarded as the guardians of the great white north, and winter's first family.

But all is not well in the house of Plunket, as is evident by the red stain spreading over the columns of ice. Buster's mysterious death - he was found in the septic tank with a bullet through his brain - has already set tongues wagging. Now Buster's widow, Belle, a hot-blooded creature who hates the frozen north, has returned from her winter sojourn in warmer climes with a new lover in tow, Uncle Del.

Uncle Del has plans to melt the Plunket palace and create a lagoon in a new development where it will be perpetual summer. But to proceed with his dastardly plans, he and Belle have to win over Pootsie, and, more importantly, her brother Kirbus, a cowardly, callow but loving youth of somewhat arrested development, who is now head of the house of Plunket. Kirbus's signature is crucial.

The piece is never less than entertaining, and brilliantly creates its own weird, isolated world, peopled by the oddball, orange-haired Plunket siblings and the treacherous cartoon villains Belle and Del, who appear to be shaping up to become Ma and Pa Ubu. The acting is impeccable and the sound design is terrific too, dripping atmosphere as the Plunkets approach meltdown. But however well you do it, camp is a pretty limiting style to choose and, after 90 minutes, the lack of variety becomes wearing. It also militates against any real emotional involvement with the story or the characters. The evening is always a tease but never a tragedy. In the end, Catalyst have done what they've done really well - I only wish that they had attempted to do rather more.

 Until April 15. Box office: 020-7609 1800. The production then tours to Frome, Stockton and Glasgow.

fields.headline: MPs demand quick rate cut
fields.standfirst: Treasury select committee lays into Bank of England policymakers
fields.trailText: Treasury select committee lays into Bank of England policymakers.
fields.body:
MPs warned yesterday that the economy is in danger of sliding into recession unless the Bank of England abandons its hawkish stance on inflation and cuts interest rates immediately.

With global stock markets plummeting and the foot and mouth epidemic threatening to cost the economy billions of pounds, the chair of the influential Treasury select committee, Giles Radice, called for the Bank to reduce borrowing costs at its meeting next week.

"The time has come for cutting rates," said Mr Radice.

The committee accused the Bank's monetary policy committee of squeezing the economy too hard in an effort to establish its anti-inflationary credentials. Inflation has been below the government's 2.5% target for nearly two years, despite the Bank's mandate to avoid undershoots as well as overshoots.

"This may not have mattered when the risk was inflation," said Mr Radice. "Now that the downside risk is recession, they should act."

Yesterday's demand for lower borrowing costs came as another City institution slashed its forecast for economic growth. Economists at Deutsche Bank said they now expected the economy to expand by 2.1% this year, rather than 2.5% they was forecasting four months ago. A rate cut was now probable at next week's MPC meeting, they said.

"The US economy is clearly in worse shape than we forecast then, while the slowdown has spread to euroland," said Ciaran Barr, chief UK economist at the Bank. "As such, the downside risks are rapidly intensifying. In addition, the adverse impact from the foot-and-mouth epidemic could easily be at least 0.3% [off growth]."

Mr Barr said the MPC was unfairly criticised for missing the 2.5% target in the past two years, but that a persistent undershoot in the future would effectively be "sacrificing growth for inflation".

The MPs agreed that the Bank had done an impressive job in getting inflation down below target, given Britain's past record of soaring price pressures. But they expressed concern that the MPC might have been biased towards undershooting its target.

"We would therefore remind the governor of his assurance to us, in November 1998, that the MPC would be "just as ac tive, rigorous and aggressive in pursuing inflation at 2.5% if there is a balance of risks on the downside as we had been on the upside."

MPs rejected complaints from the Bank Governor, Sir Eddie George, that they had subjected new members of the MPC to personal abuse at their confirmation hearings before the committee. Mr Radice said that if MPC candidates could not take tough questions from MPs, they should not be in charge of setting rates.

"We are not looking for shrinking violets," he said. "They have to put across their message to the public, that's one of the most important parts of the job."

The committee added that interest rates could have been lowered earlier, if the Bank had changed its method of forecasting the exchange rate last year when sterling continually remained higher than it had expected.

"We question whether the MPC are learning from developments in the economy as quickly as they should," the report said.

DeAnne Julius, a leading dove on the MPC, has argued that inflationary pressures have fallen as a result of new technology.

webTitle: Wall Street bears back on the prowl

fields.headline: Wall Street bears back on the prowl
fields.trailText: A series of dire profit warnings and layoffs brought bearish behaviour back to Wall Street yesterday after a brief respite.
fields.body:
A series of dire profit warnings and layoffs brought bearish behaviour back to Wall Street yesterday after a brief respite.

US shares fell sharply after technology companies such Nortel Networks, the largest manufacturer of fibre-optic equipment, and Palm, the leading manufacturer of electronic organisers, warned of disappointing earnings. Walt Disney, the world's second biggest media and entertainment group, also blamed a difficult market environment for its unusual decision to cut 3% of its worldwide workforce.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down more than 200 points, or 2%, to just over 9,700 at midday after rallying 6% over the past three days. The broader S&P index also fell sharply while the technology-driven Nasdaq Composite Index declined more than 4% to less than 1,900.

The severity of the declines after a three-day rally prompted analysts to warn of continuing volatility after the classic dead-cat bounce of the past few days. Even after this week's rally, the Nasdaq is down 23% since January and more than 60% from a year ago. The Dow, after recovering from a near 20% loss, was down almost 10% yesterday.

Dick McCabe, chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch, said he expected the volatility to continue. "The market becomes more emotional at times like these. There are a lot of people who have seen their profits wiped out."

Yesterday's downturn came as a particular blow to Lucent Technologies, the telecommunications company, as it coincided with the company's much-delayed attempt to spin off its component and semiconductor manufacturing arm.

Shares in Agere Systems, the Lucent spin-off, opened up fractionally but only after the company had slashed its offering price to $6 from an earlier range of between $16 and $19. The flotation raised $3.6bn, about half the sum Lucent had originally hoped for. The parent company has already earmarked the funding to repay a massive debt load.

The company's prospects were hard hit by the decision of Nortel, Agere's second biggest customer, to issue its second profits warning in a month late on Tuesday.

Shares in the Canadian company fell as much as 17% after it further cut revenue and profits estimates. Several analysts downgraded Nortel after it said that its 2001 projections were unreliable and that it would fire an additional 5,000 people by mid-year. The announcement brings the total number of jobs cut at the company to 15,000 jobs this year.

Shares in Lucent also fell 13%, close to a four-year low, as a result of the warning and continuing fears over its ability to finance its heavy debt burden.

Palm shares almost halved to $8.63 after the company said it expected a loss in the fourth quarter and announced plans to sack 250 workers, or about 15% of its staff.

webTitle: Claims Direct tries to cut its way out of crisis

fields.headline: Claims Direct tries to cut its way out of crisis
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Claims Direct, the "no win, no fee" personal injury firm, yesterday tried to draw a line under a miserable year marked by a decline in customers, several profits warnings and a slide in shares by more than 90%.
fields.body:
Claims Direct, the "no win, no fee" personal injury firm, yesterday tried to draw a line under a miserable year marked by a decline in customers, several profits warnings and a slide in shares by more than 90%.

Shares in the company continued to slide yesterday after it issued its second profits warning in three months, saying full-year pretax profits would be substantially below market expectations.

The company said an advertising campaign on daytime television failed to arrest the decline in customer numbers and losses were expected to reach £20m.

Last year the firm averaged 4,000 customers a month. Revelations in November that clients had received derisory payouts caused a decline and in January only 2,500 customers signed up.

Finance director Paul Doona admitted the firm had failed to drive up the number of registrations, despite spending millions of pounds on TV advertising. He said customer numbers averaged 2,500 a month in the first quarter of the year.

The company would bounce back next year following cost-cutting measures, including cuts in staff at the company's head office, he insisted.

The company had written to its national network of 300 franchised claims managers, who conduct initial interviews with personal injury victims, offering them compensation to end their relationship with Claims Direct. More than 30 had already taken up the offer.

Chief executive Colin Poole also tried to soothe City nerves with the announcement of an insurance product that aims to protect the first £1,000 of a client's claim. The premium is £1,495, paid for by a loan to the customer. The loan is written off should a customer lose the case. If the company succeeds in pursuing the claim, it will seek compensation from the other party's insurer.

webTitle: House of Fraser considers merger or takeover

fields.headline: House of Fraser is in shopping mood
fields.standfirst: Group says there is scope to add 20 or 30 stores to portfolio
fields.trailText: Department stores group House of Fraser yesterday confirmed it was still interested in a merger or takeover, almost a year after it abandoned merger talks with rival Allders.
fields.body:
Department stores group House of Fraser yesterday confirmed it was still interested in a merger or takeover, almost a year after it abandoned merger talks with rival Allders.

Chief executive John Coleman said: "Consolidation would still be a good thing. We are about as small as you can be [to operate efficiently] and there are lots of smaller players out there who cannot afford the investment in a systems and supply chain that we've put in over the last five years. There would be significant costs you could take out. We could support another 20 or 30 stores."

House of Fraser was "an obvious leader" for consolidation in the sector, but it was not talking to any rival groups: "We don't think there is any rush because we see ourselves getting stronger."

His comments came as House of Fraser, which is Britain's third-biggest department store chain, posted full-year profits of £17.8m, up from £17m last year. The advance would have been stronger but for a mandatory tax change, which lopped £2.4m off the bottom line, and a £4.5m "disruption cost" caused by revamps at the group's Guildford and Oxford Street stores.

The £45m makeovers closed Guildford for most of the year and left one floor out of action in Oxford Street for the bulk of the year. A further £27m was spent upgrading other stores.

"It was a big year for capital spend," Mr Coleman admitted. This year he is turning his attention to upgrading the Birmingham store, which will soon face stiff competition from a new Selfridges, and opening five new stores before 2003. He is also seeking more store locations and hopes to announce three or four shortly.

House of Fraser, which now likes to dub itself the country's leading designer brand retailer, is constantly on the lookout for new labels to pull in shoppers, from luxury goods such as Fendi to young fashion brands like Porn Star and Playboy.

Like-for-like sales were up 5.6% in the first eight weeks of the new financial year, although the revamps are paying bigger dividends. Sales at the Oxford Street store were up 77.5% on 2000 levels.

Yesterday, the under-performing shares climbed 8p to a 12-month high of 72.5p. Nevertheless, many analysts remain unconvinced about the potential of the group, which has sold freeholds to finance investment and whose earnings do not cover its dividend this year.

Mr Coleman hit out at those analysts, saying the majority only thought about his company "for five minutes every six months" and that was not enough to "understand complex businesses like this".
fields.bodyText: Department stores group House of Fraser yesterday confirmed it was still interested in a merger or takeover, almost a year after it abandoned merger talks with rival Allders. Chief executive John Coleman said: "Consolidation would still be a good thing. We are about as small as you can be [to operate efficiently] and there are lots of smaller players out there who cannot afford the investment in a systems and supply chain that we've put in over the last five years. There would be significant costs you could take out. We could support another 20 or 30 stores." House of Fraser was "an obvious leader" for consolidation in the sector, but it was not talking to any rival groups: "We don't think there is any rush because we see ourselves getting stronger." His comments came as House of Fraser, which is Britain's third-biggest department store chain, posted full-year profits of £17.8m, up from £17m last year. The advance would have been stronger but for a mandatory tax change, which lopped £2.4m off the bottom line, and a £4.5m "disruption cost" caused by revamps at the group's Guildford and Oxford Street stores. The £45m makeovers closed Guildford for most of the year and left one floor out of action in Oxford Street for the bulk of the year. A further £27m was spent upgrading other stores. "It was a big year for capital spend," Mr Coleman admitted. This year he is turning his attention to upgrading the Birmingham store, which will soon face stiff competition from a new Selfridges, and opening five new stores before 2003. He is also seeking more store locations and hopes to announce three or four shortly. fields.headline: Shoot to fame
fields.standfirst:
The web is the latest showcase for Hollywood hopefuls, as two Oscar-nominated short films show, writes Matthew Ford
More net news
fields.trailText: The web is the latest showcase for Hollywood hopefuls, as two Oscar-nominated short films show, writes Matthew Ford
fields.body:
Once upon a time in Hollywood, tradition decreed that if you wanted success, you had to get out there and fight for it. But now the web may be making the battle to get noticed just that little bit easier.

Two of this year's Oscar nominated short films, The Periwig Maker and Una Historia de Futebol, were picked up, not through the traditional route of producers and agents, but straight off film websites. For aspiring directors entranced by the rags to riches mythology of the film world, the internet is providing both hope, and a new way to ensure their latest effort lands on the right desk.

Neither film won an Oscar, but both gained valuable publicity. If the films sparked interest among any member of the global Oscars audience they can click online and instantly view either of the films in their entirety. At Atomfilms.com audiences can see the nomination for Best Animated Short Film, directors Steffen and Arnette Schaffler's darkly poignant tale of pestilence and paternalism The Periwig Maker (based on Daniel Defoe's A Journal of the Plague Year).

Over on www.ifilm.com viewers can watch Paulo Machline's Una Historia de Futebol, one of the nominations for Best Short Live Action. A slice of popular subtitled nostalgia, the film is based around the mellow recollections of a group of ageing friends as they remember their childhood games of football in small town Brazil.

Traditionally the only option available to aspiring directors was to hassle agents and production companies who would routinely ignore almost everything that dropped on their desk.

But in a land where dot.com opportunities are never ignored for long, it was only a matter of time before someone would try and use the internet to close the gap between the thousands of hopefuls and the influential few. Webfilm portals soon sprang up, offering a tantalising glimpse of success for those willing to cough up the dollars necessary to get online.

But it is not just films being picked up from the web. Paramount recently announced it had snapped up Mark Smith's western script, The Devil's Kiss for Mel Gibson's Icon Productions from ScriptShark, an IFilm site that provides script analysis for amateur screenwriters. But the odds are still slim. Only 5% of the scripts submitted to ScriptShark are actually published on the web, and even then it is rare for anyone in the industry to pick anything up. The site only lists four success stories alongside the dozens of scripts on offer. But for those wannabes willing to do anything to catch a producer's eye, these must look like sweet odds indeed compared to their pre-internet options.

But for every reputable site like Atomfilms.com, IFilm.com, Inzide.com or ScriptShark, there are many others capitalising on the desperation of those trying to make it, and offering very little in the way of a return for their dollars.

However, there is always the option of building your own website. "We were so sick of the commissioning process," says writer Jane Sussman (Smack the Pony and The Fast Show), who co-wrote the comedy The Junkies, and received developmental money from Channel 4 after they saw it online. "We got fed up of waiting for something to happen and decided the only way to get on was to get it out there and make it ourselves."

The British independent filmmakers' mailing list www.shootingpeople.com is full of questions on how to get films online, and debate inspired by the web's potential for keeping filmmakers in control of their own publicity.

For those who haven't yet made it, the web can also offer a community, some critical redirection and a sense of purpose. The Francis Ford Coppola-owned www.Zoetrope.com offers a "virtual studio" and writer's workshop, where scripts can be posted and commented on by other writers. While this has the potential to be fairly crushing, it does introduce writers to the harsh realities of the industry, and helps give them focus. Alliance Atlantis recently bought two scripts from Zoetrope.com's screenplay workshop, and this should be enough to keep the hopeful hoping, and persuade newcomers that the site has an influential audience.

Perhaps online film's time is coming. The dot.com crash is beginning to fade from memory, investors are once again showing a cautious interest in internet film, and members of the Hollywood elite are following the indie hopefuls online. Despite being burned by the high-profile failure of his film site www.pop.com, Steven Speilberg is back screening short films starring Steve Martin and Gwyneth Paltrow at the blossoming film fan site www.countingdown.com.

But despite all the help the web can offer, success in Hollywood still depends on having killer ambition. If you can contemplate failure, you're never going to make it. As a cynical Paul Newman once commented, "Show me a good loser, and I'll show you a loser".

fields.headline: £1m Beckham helps develop computer game
fields.trailText: David Beckham is to develop a range of computer games based on his performances for Manchester United and England, writes John Cassy.
fields.body:
The earning power of footballer David Beckham was underlined yesterday when he signed an agreement to develop a range of computer games based on his performances for Manchester United and England.

The three-year exclusive agreement between Mr Beckham, his agents SFX and games publisher Rage is likely to be worth in excess of £1m to the 26-year-old, who will receive royalties on each game sold plus an initial payment.

The first units will go on sale in time for Christmas and will be a vital seller for the company, which yesterday announced an eight-fold increase in interim pretax losses.

"Through the association with David we believe we can create a long-term strong and global game franchise," said Paul Finnegan, managing director of Rage., whose development laboratories are based in Liverpool, above.

Mr Beckham is likely to receive £1 for every game sold.

The announcement took the attention away from a disappointing set of results for the six months ending December 2000. The loss of £7.9m and revenues of £2.7m were in line with analyst's revised expectations following a series of profits warnings last year, however.

Like many games companies, Rage is experiencing tough times. Shares closed down 1.5p at 5.5p.

fields.headline: Mushtaq's millennium blues
fields.standfirst:
Mushtaq
Ronnie Scott's, London
**
fields.trailText:
Mushtaq
Ronnie Scott's, London
**
fields.body:
In the mid-1990s Mushtaq was the MC for the incendiary Fun-Da-Mental, who made a considerable critical splash with their soundclash of styles including bhangra, ragga and rap. The Londoner currently operates a similarly open-minded musical policy, only now it is mainly reggae and rock. It's a far mellower blend, with the six auxiliary musicians (guitar, bass, drums, two keyboards, plus ragga chatter Jucxi) gelling and jamming like seasoned professionals. Mushtaq is probably no less politicised today; it's just that he's found a different context within which to express his various humanitarian concerns.

Mushtaq calls his music "millennium blues", but it is not quite that dark and urban, with precious little of the claustrophobic intensity of, say, Tricky's Pre-Millennium Tension. The material unveiled tonight from his forthcoming album, called simply Mushtaq, could have come from any period - which, depending on your viewpoint, makes it either timeless or old-fashioned. This is "classic" territory. Dey Don't Know features the descending sequence of electric piano notes from I Shot the Sheriff, while Supernatural is based around the chord progression to Nirvana's Smells Like Teen Spirit.

The best tracks are the ones where the purity and strength of an individual genre is preserved, such as the roots reggae of Rebel Music or the tough rhythms of Ordinary People (although even the latter has a snippet of the Specials' Ghost Town). When Mushtaq tries to appease an imaginary huge crossover audience, he merely offers ersatz versions of the original styles.

There are moments to treasure, such as the Hendrix-style guitar flare-up during Supernatural, but they are lost in the rush to mish and mash. Like any sane bloke, Mushtaq is a champion of multiculturalism, and yet he is in some ways its victim. He grew up surrounded by numerous ethnic communities, exposed to their record collections, and it has left him with too many choices. He sings in the voices of his many heroes but rarely his own. He cries his Freedom Song - "for all the people in here who consider themselves free from isms and schisms" - and it goes down a storm, but really Mushtaq needs to take it down the road to south London if he wants to make a difference.

fields.headline: Fidel's favourites bring it back home
fields.standfirst:
Manic Street Preachers
Manchester Apollo
*****
fields.trailText:
Manic Street Preachers
Manchester Apollo
*****
fields.body:
Much has been made of the Manic Street Preachers' attempt to forge a new musical and political militancy, through such antics as their recent gig in Cuba. You can hear it at this Manchester gig, too: the opening song, the nagging New York punk-rocker Found That Soul, is nothing like the polished rock that won the Manics mainstream popularity. But the band were never entirely safe: If You Tolerate This Your Children Will Be Next talks about shooting fascists - it's hardly Steps.

They're full of contradictions, but the Manics would not be the Manics if they didn't please themselves, even if such wilfulness comes at a price. The most interesting thing about the Cuba gig was that it was gloriously flawed, like the Manics themselves. As a symbolic protest against the influence of America it was a great gesture. Unfortunately, in Cuba people like bassist/ lyricist Nicky Wire, who runs around in white-pleated gym skirt and knee-high Argyle socks, are usually thrown into prison.

The Manics make mistakes because they take chances and are constantly changing. They are courageous, as much as a band can be. Consequently they get a hysterical reception, even though Why So Sad (too Herman's Hermits by half), the sentimental Let Robeson Sing and the spunky but tuneless Masses Against the Classes wouldn't feature in any of their opinionated fans' preferred set-list.

The show's a dog's dinner - but it's prime steak. La Tristessa Durera, with its rubbery, hard bassline, is precision songwriting: it alone makes the Manics' career worthwhile. You Love Us, Motorcycle Emptiness and Faster are trashy, gnarled eruptions, shot through with James Dean Bradfield's filthy, futurist guitar solos. It's as if punk never got hijacked by Americans in big shorts.

Even as Bradfield bounces joyfully around, his pit-village soul-scream brings an emotional desperation to every syllable. Meanwhile, Wire pulls strange, hilarious poses-cum-stretching exercises and rants absurdly. To broadsheet journalists who criticise his lyrics, he spits: "You just want to fuck me, but you can't."

They close with Design For Life - among the best singles of the past 10 years, and certainly the only one to celebrate the power of libraries. It ends with Wire unsensationally, methodically and maybe even sarcastically wrecking the stage, his frail arms lazily pushing over speaker stacks while Bradfield's last words, "love you two time, baby", echo insanely. Eventually, Wire stands there, job done, and raises a red feather boa above his head like a football scarf. It's the oddest thing: a rock cliche turned into something quite magnificent.

 Manic Street Preachers play Brixton Academy, London SW9 (020-7771 2000), tomorrow and Saturday, then tour.

fields.headline: Alan Holdsworth
fields.standfirst:
Ronnie Scott's, London
***
fields.trailText:
Ronnie Scott's, London
***
fields.body:
John McLaughlin was the Yorkshire-born jazz-guitar hero who won a big worldwide audience in the 1970s by applying a shrewd populism and world-musical curiosity to his blazing technique. Allan Holdsworth was the one who didn't - he became a hero mainly to guitar-techies. That doesn't mean Holdsworth isn't a highly musical artist, but rather that his music is of a diamond-hard purity of repertoire and method. It doesn't come to you - you have to go to it.

Holdsworth did take a few steps down McLaughlin's path 30 years ago, working for a while with international fusion stars such as Jean-Luc Ponty and Tony Williams. But his intensely focused preoccupation with long, dynamically steady and technically fearsome linear playing (he used to play the sax once, and it shows) has kept him in the position of being the remorseless guru of an uncompromising fusion-improv method all of his own.

Holdsworth's power trio is at Ronnie Scott's until the weekend - and, judging by the knowing shouts of welcome for his announcements of original themes from albums of long ago, so are a lot of serious devotees, of all ages. The trio opened with a typically labyrinthine extended guitar jam over a hard funk undertow - a seamless piece of sustained improvisation full of spinning, whirling lines. The piece endorsed the guitarist's contention that he has always heard music in dense clusters of sound rather than accretions of individual parts.

But there is an opposite side to Holdsworth's steely monasticism of approach, and that is the exploration of bugged-guitar electronic tone-poetry that can take on an orchestral complexity and richness. On 0274, a chordal slow feature, Holdsworth demonstrated his sonic range and meticulous care in making every sound count, even though the accelerated later stages sounded more like a chord progression than a theme.

A later electronic reverie was more atmospheric, shimmering with an echoing, empty-church eloquence. Electric bassist Dave Carpenter and drummer Joel Taylor were perfect, fill-every-chink, hi-tech foils for Holdsworth's remarkable virtuosity. It's unique music, and guitarists' heaven.

 Until Saturday. Box office: 020-7439 0747.

fields.headline: Marks & Spencer lays off 4,390 staff
fields.trailText: Troubled high-street retailer Marks & Spencer is cutting 4,390 jobs - most of them on the continent - as part of a radical restructuring of its business.
fields.body:
Troubled high-street retailer Marks & Spencer is cutting 4,390 jobs - most of them on the continent - as part of a radical restructuring of its business.

The chain, which has seen its sales dive, is closing its subsidiaries in mainland Europe and shutting its Direct catalogue business.

The move will mean 3,350 job losses in Europe, and just over 1,000 in the UK, including 350 at the company's head office on Baker Street, Marylebone, central London.

M&S chairman and chief executive Luc Vandevelde unveiled the cuts as he launched a strategy to turnaround the retailer's fortunes. He said M&S needed to be a "simpler, more focused" organisation.

The group is also selling off its Kings Super Markets and Brooks Brothers subsidiaries in the United States.

Mr Vandevelde said M&S would concentrate on putting in place a plan to revive its clothing ranges, and would expand in its growing product areas of food and home and beauty. "These changes put in place a clear, thorough and urgent plan for recovery based on the UK business," he said.

"At the heart is a determination to restore an unquestioned reputation with our customers for quality, value, service and innovation."

Mr Vandevelde said M&S would be "giving up our operations in Europe".

"Two thirds of our stores will be refurbished within two years, " he told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme. "It [M&S] will be very different. It will be a company completely focused on its customers in the UK."

He rejected a suggestion that the moves were a panic measure, saying: "It's a measure of determination. We want to give our company the best chance to succeed."

Mr Vandevelde said M&S total UK retail sales had increased by just 0.8% in the nine weeks to March 24. Like-for-like sales, which strip out the impact of new store sales, fell, however, by 0.5% over the same period.

The launch of the strategy comes just months after Roger Holmes started work as managing director at M&S. He joined the group last year from Kingfisher, where he ran Woolworths.

Mr Holmes has been conducting a review of the UK business ever since with Mr Vandevelde.

"At the heart is a determination to restore an unquestioned reputation with our customers for quality, value, service and innovation." Mr Vandevelde said M&S would be "giving up our operations in Europe". "Two thirds of our stores will be refurbished within two years, " he told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme. "It [M&S] will be very different. It will be a company completely focused on its customers in the UK." He rejected a suggestion that the moves were a panic measure, saying: "It's a measure of determination. We want to give our company the best chance to succeed." Mr Vandevelde said M&S total UK retail sales had increased by just 0.8% in the nine weeks to March 24. Like-for-like sales, which strip out the impact of new store sales, fell, however, by 0.5% over the same period. The launch of the strategy comes just months after Roger Holmes started work as managing director at M&S. He joined the group last year from Kingfisher, where he ran Woolworths. Mr Holmes has been conducting a review of the UK business ever since with Mr Vandevelde. webTitle: Harry Potter doubles profits at Bloomsbury

fields.headline: Harry Potter and the money mine
fields.standfirst:
Magic numbers

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Boy wizard Harry Potter has helped conjure up a doubling of profits at publisher Bloomsbury.
fields.body:
Boy wizard Harry Potter has helped conjure up a doubling of profits at publisher Bloomsbury.

The publication of Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, the fourth in the series and the fastest selling title in history, helped the small Soho publisher increase turnover by 143% to £50.7m last year.

Pretax profits for the year doubled to £5.7m, while the dividend climbed 32% to 5p per share.

Chairman Nigel Newton said he believed that the long-term earnings potential of Harry Potter could underpin Bloomsbury for years to come.

"The series is now established as a classic with a long-term life," he said. "The series is being compared to other classics such as Lord of the Rings and the Chronicles of Narnia which have had huge sales over many decades."

Bloomsbury refuses to break-out how much Harry Potter contributes to overall group revenues, which analysts have claimed makes the company difficult to value. Mr Newton would only admit that the children's character was "very important".

Analysts reckon it accounted for 30%-40% last year. Bloomsbury published 400 titles last year including the Booker prize winning Margaret Atwood novel The Blind Assassin.

Mr Newton is working digitising the company's backlist of content, including that of A&C Black, the reference publisher behind the Who's Who guide for which he paid £16.4m for last year.

He said prospects for the coming year were good with the paperback release of Goblet of Fire scheduled for July and the November release of a Warner Brothers film of Harry Potter, pictured, expected to reignite interest in the earlier books in the series.

Shares in Bloomsbury edged up 5p to 717p. Analysts at Investec Henderson Crosthwaite believe they are a good "defensive investment" ahead of any further economic downturn as books are seen as still selling during a recession.

fields.headline: Wanless canes Oxford
fields.trailText: Paul Wanless secured a three vital points for Cambridge at the bottom of Division Two.
fields.byline: Richard Rae at the Abbey stadium
fields.body:
Rupert Obholzer, you should have been here. The man who stopped the Boat Race just when they finally made it interesting could have rested easy at its meek and mild footballing equivalent.

Not that John Beck's Cambridge will care. One place above the Second Division drop zone, they have some tough fixtures in the run-in and an injury-time volley from Paul Wanless gave them three points they desperately needed, if hardly deserved.

Amid the misplaced passes and niggling fouls in a scrappy first half, Robert Quinn's 30-yard left-foot volley surprised Cambridge's goalkeeper Shaun Marshall almost as much as it did the crowd, though he recovered to touch it over.

At the other end John Taylor produced a sidefooted lob which almost dropped over Richard Knight in the Oxford goal. The striker had a better chance just before the interval but his header from close range lacked power.

In the second half Cambridge exerted some pressure - the sort which depends on the ball being banged forward. Both Manny Omoyimni and John Robertson should have won it for the visitors before the late, late strike from Wanless.

Oxford did have some cause for celebration yesterday, when the city council finally cleared the last obstacle in the way of the club moving to a new £15m stadium. Good news for travelling supporters of Third Division clubs.

Cambridge United (3-5-2): Marshall; Cowan (Oakes, 74min), Joseph, Fleming; Duncan, Dreyer, Ashbee, Wanless, Taylor (Richardson, 79); Youngs, Riza (Prokas, 90).

Oxford United (4-4-2): Knight; Richardson, Hatswell, Robertson, Patterson; Ricketts, Quinn, Powell (Beauchamp, 62), Omoyimni; Scott, Tait.

Referee: M Warren.
