fields.headline: Shaymen share the points and the gloom
fields.trailText: Shaymen share the points and the gloom as Halifax and Carlisle play out an agonising stalemate.
fields.body:
In the end, with nerves jangling and fingernails bitten down to bloodied stumps, a sodden corner of west Yorkshire sighed in grim resignation last night as Halifax and Carlisle played out an agonising stalemate.

The grisly gravity of this draw was clear. With the visitors unable to capitalise on their frenzied second-half pressure and Town's Steve Kerrigan heading against the bar in the dying moments, both sides remain too close for comfort to the Third Division's bottom club Torquay.

As tense occasions go, this was excruciating. Saturday's 3-0 win over Barnet had hoisted Paul Bracewell's Town off the bottom; he had arrived in October with the club adrift, so 23rd represents progress of a sort. On the back of such relative confidence, Halifax began brightly on the quagmire.

Neil Redfearn's stinging seventh-minute shot was claimed by Matt Glennon, who then watched the former Barnsley midfielder curl one just over. When Kerrigan shot weakly having been sent clear by Michael Proctor - an on-loan livewire from Sunderland - the locals cursed in frustration.

United's Richard Prokas was sold to Cambridge behind his manager's back for a paltry £5,000 last week, and his rugged presence was missed although United steadily found their feet. Mark Jules's last-ditch tackle denied Scott Dobie, who then drifted a lob just wide after Craig Mawson tore inexplicably out of his area.

Mawson was equally relieved after half-time as the ball dropped to Dobie, tipped to be the latest big-money exit from Brunton Park, on the penalty spot. But Craig Middleton appeared from nowhere to strangle the effort wide.

Town's earlier authority had evaporated and red-faced glances passed between their panicked defenders when Gordon Connelly drilled Dobie's knockdown wide.

Halifax Town (4-4-2): Mawson; P Mitchell, G Mitchell, Clarke, Jules; Middleton, Thompson (Richards, 80min), Redfearn, Reilly; Proctor, Kerrigan.

Carlisle United (3-5-2): Glennon; Whitehead, Carr, Morley; Birch, Cullen, Galloway, Connelly, Maddison; Stevens (Halliday, 74), Dobie.

Referee: P Rejer.

fields.headline: The Glenn Hoddle story
fields.trailText: 1957 Born October 27 in Hayes.
fields.body:
1957 Born October 27 in Hayes.

1974 Signed as apprentice by Spurs.

1975 Made professional debut at 18 as substitute against Norwich.

1976 Scored on full debut v Stoke.

1979 Scored on England senior debut against Bulgaria - the first of his eight England goals.

1981 Won FA Cup with Spurs, beating Man City.

1982 Scored in FA Cup final and replay against QPR to collect his second winner's medal. Runners-up medal in League Cup final against Liverpool.

1987 Played in FA Cup final defeat by Coventry. Moved to Monaco for £750,000. Won French League title within 12 months.

1988 Won last of 53 England caps in 3-1 defeat by the USSR - Bobby Robson's third successive humiliation of the European Championship finals in Germany.

1990 Retired through injury.

1991 Made comeback as non-contract player in Chelsea reserves. Appointed Swindon player-manager in April, replacing former Spurs team-mate Ossie Ardiles.

1993 Scored first goal in 4-3 play-off final win against Leicester. One month later quit Swindon to take over as Chelsea manager.

1994 Took Chelsea to FA Cup final but they lost 4-0 to Man United.

1995 Final league appearance in 2-1 win over Arsenal.

1996 Took Chelsea to FA Cup semi-final in which they lost 2-1 to Man United. Appointed England coach after Terry Venables stepped down.

1997 Steered England to victory in Tournoi de France. England topped their World Cup qualifying group after 0-0 draw in final match in Rome.

1998 June England went out of France 98 in the second round, losing to Argentina on penalties. Hoddle insisted that with a little luck England could have won the tournament.

August Hoddle's World Cup diary caused a storm.

September The FA's international committee gave Hoddle its backing over his book.

1999 Hoddle sacked after comments about disabled people.

2000 January Took over as Southampton manager.

Playing career

Tottenham 1975-87, Monaco 1987-90,

Swindon 1991-93, Chelsea 1993-95.

Honours

FA Cup winner 1981, 1982; Runner-up 1987. League Cup runner-up 1982. Uefa Cup winner 1984 (all with Spurs) French League winner 1988 (Monaco). First Division promotion 1993 (Swindon).

England: 53 senior caps, 8 goals. Under-21: 12 caps. B level: 2 caps.

Managerial career

Swindon 1991-93. Chelsea 1993-96, England 1996-99, Southampton 2000-01

Honours

1993 Won First Division promotion play-offs with Swindon.

1994 FA Cup runner-up with Chelsea.

webTitle: Elliott fronts up as Scots go on glory trail

fields.headline: Elliott fronts up as Scots go on glory trail
fields.trailText: Craig Brown looks ready to resort to blitzkrieg tactics tonight as Scotland attempt to surge to the top of Group Six with a hefty victory.
fields.body:
Scotland's expectation of surging three points clear in the Group Six table should translate into blitzkrieg tactics from their manager Craig Brown against San Marino tonight, with Matt Elliott moving from defence to join the strikers.

Brown is also aware that a rampaging victory at Hampden Park would go some way towards restoring morale after dropping two points against Belgium on Saturday through a stoppage-time equaliser. Goals are imperative tonight following Belgium's 10-1 win over the Sammarinese last month.

"We are really disappointed because we could have been smoking cigars and drinking champagne, but instead we have still got a very, very good chance," said Brown.

Assuming San Marino will pack their defence and operate with a single striker, Brown will trim his own back division in favour of more attackers.

Brown, who has yet to pick his side, added: "I hope to get some goals but they only lost 1-0 to Latvia in November. So, for Belgium to get 10 was exceptional. If we can get the ball in, then Elliott is the major threat. We don't need three centre halves against one striker, put it that way."

Elliott, a central defender with a penchant for going forward for his club Leicester City, added: "The ideal way to get over Saturday's result is to bang in a hatful of goals which would go some way to lessening the bad taste of Saturday's result. The performance as a whole was one of our more impressive .

"I imagine we will have a few corners and free kicks on the night. I might be used up front at some stage."

Brown is likely to draft in Colin Cameron, who can score from midfield, leaving Gavin Rae - in for the injured Barry Ferguson - on the bench.

The last time Scotland played San Marino in Glasgow, in 1995, the home side had already qualified for Euro 96 and a 5-0 win was achieved without much fuss.

When the countries last met, in the corresponding fixture in San Marino last October, Elliott's height allowed him to head Scotland's first goal, albeit not until the 71st minute, and two minutes later Don Hutchison wrapped up a 2-0 victory.

The Tartan Army grew highly impatient on that occasion but surely won't be on the edge of their seats for too long tonight.

webTitle: Owen a natural with hard questions

fields.headline: Owen a natural with hard questions
fields.standfirst: Striker is ready for Albanian test, writes  Richard Williams
fields.trailText: Richard Williams hears Michael Owen deconstruct the myth of the unreconstructed England international footballer.
fields.body:
And what, Michael Owen was asked, do the gilded youth of English football, with their exotic cars and their diamond ear studs and their personal websites, make of a country such as Albania, where the ride from the airport reveals medieval scenes of women in headscarves driving herds of sheep, and where even in the centre of the capital the unmade sideroads begin only 100 metres from the main square?

Not a fair question, really, to a 21-year-old who has lived his life to date in a sort of gilded prison, its limits defined by the valuation others put upon his talent. But, after a moment's pause, Owen had a respectable answer.

"I think most of us have seen things like this before on various trips to different parts of the world," he said. "Personally I've seen a lot worse. I've been down to South Africa with the Under-17s, and that was an experience."

He added perkily that football pitches everywhere are more or less the same size, and the ball is the same shape, but the questioning went on. Do the players ever stop and think about the economic reality of a place like Albania, and of the contrast with their own lives?

"Yes," he said, "I think everyone's aware of that. It brings it home that you're lucky to do what you love to do and get paid for it. Of course every morning you wake up and think you're fortunate, but it can take something else to make it really sink in."

Thanks mostly to the establishment of an archetype located somewhere between the buffoonery of a Paul Gascoigne and the banality of an Alan Shearer, English footballers of late have not been celebrated for their intellectual depth. Michael Owen is the proof that, when it comes to young international players, the receipt of large sums of money does not necessarily entail the wholesale destruction of brain cells. He is a bright and lively young man, and no wonder Sven-Goran Eriksson is showing signs of cherishing him.

Insiders say that the mood in the camp has been transformed, the atmosphere of paranoia dispelled by Eriksson and Tord Grip. No longer does the coach burst into the dressing room waving a tabloid newspaper and demanding to know who spilled the beans. Such an environment can only benefit someone like Owen.

His balanced outlook includes a willingness to assess his own defects, leavened with the occasional flash of humour. Asked whether his goal against Finland, taken with his left foot, was the result of work on the weaker elements of his game, perhaps motivated by criticism of his reliance on his right foot expressed by Glenn Hoddle, then England's coach and now Southampton's, he replied: "Before this season started I told people I wanted to improve my heading and my left foot, and since then I reckon I've scored more goals with my head and and my left foot than I have with my right. So the hard work is paying off."

Had he found that defenders were trying to shepherd him on to his weaker flank? "Perhaps. I scored two goals against Southampton with my left foot, so maybe that's what Glenn Hoddle had told his defenders to do."

In both Eriksson's matches to date, Owen has played as a shadow striker, slightly behind Andy Cole. And in both it has been he, rather than the nominated spearhead, who has scored, leading to suggestions that whereas Owen is a natural international goalscorer, Cole is not.

"Wherever I play," Owen said, "in the end it's always going to be about getting into the box and scoring goals. Andy Cole's a great player and, as the highest man up the field, he's very good to play off. I'm not going to tell him how to score goals. He knows that as well as anyone. He'll certainly score goals because he's been doing that all his career. The next chance he gets is when you'll see if he's got broad shoulders."

Owen began the season in excellent form for Liverpool before a head injury sustained against Derby put him out for several weeks. Other niggling injuries interrupted his return, which was also complicated by Gérard Houllier's need to keep four strikers happy and in tune. Owen played no part in the Worthington Cup final but has since made his mark.

"The recent games against Porto and Derby," he said, "were the strongest I've felt for a long time. I've never played as well for England as I did for Liverpool in those two games." Something for Eriksson and the rest of us to look forward to, then.

fields.trailText:
 Army caterers join slaughter
 Blair pleads for tourists to visit UK

Special report: foot and mouth

Email update
Sign up for our free daily foot and mouth roundup
fields.body:
EU vets have accepted a request by Britain to have the option to use foot and mouth vaccinations in Cumbria and Devon. Officials said that the programme could involve around 180,000 dairy cows in the two regions. The ministry of agriculture announced that legislation to enable these vaccinations is already being drafted.

Fears that animals could be buried alive were raised earlier today as the army intensified the mass cull against foot and mouth disease and military butchers joined the front line of the sheep slaughter in Cumbria.

Seven butchers from the army catering corps will join a further 13 civilian slaughter workers at the Great Orton airfield site near Carlisle, which is due to receive 2,000 live sheep by this afternoon.

However, the RSPCA said it had "grave concerns" about many aspects of the escalating slaughter. The RSPCA's chief veterinary officer, Chris Laurence, said: "Animals must be killed and not simply stunned without any further action to ensure immediate death.

"If the animal's nervous system is not destroyed in a process known as 'pithing' then it is possible the animal could gain some awareness and feel pain."

This, he said, leads to the potential "horror scenario" of animals being put into the burial pits while still having a degree of awareness.

The charity wants inspectors to be allowed to oversee the killing, to ensure it is done humanely. Mr Laurence added: "Ideally, we would want these animals to be killed on the farm where they would be spared the stress of a journey to the burial sites and exposure to an unfamiliar environment."

Major Guy Richardson stressed that the army butchers were all qualified slaughter workers who would be using conventional culling methods.

The defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, declared this afternoon that the army was fighting the disease on two fronts.

Soldiers on the ground, along with Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food officials, are desperately trying to clear a backlog of outbreaks whilst at the same time constructing a firebreak to prevent further spread of the disease in Cumbria.

Mr Hoon said: "The backlog is obviously a priority as is maintaining the front-line against the disease. The logistical problem is tackling the backlog as well as maintaining a line beyond which we do not want the disease to spread."

The minister refused to entertain the suggestion that the army's high profile involvement was a tacit recognition that the disease had spiraled out of control.

The minister has traveled to Carlisle with the army's commander-in-chief of British land forces, General Sir Michael Jackson, and the pair will be given a guided tour of the operation.

General Jackson said: "It is a rather different sort of conflict. It is not one involving human beings who cannot get on with each other, it is a very tragic disease in our own country."

The prime minister, Tony Blair, today urged the British public to take the lead by going to the countryside to show the world it was still open for business and help the country's beleaguered tourist industry.

fields.headline: Titchmarsh quits Ground Force
fields.trailText: Ground Force looks set to be axed after Alan Titchmarsh - middle England's gardening mentor - announced he was quitting the hit BBC show. By Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
The future of Ground Force is banging in the balance after Alan Titchmarsh - middle England's gardening mentor - announced he was quitting the hit BBC show.

The star - who also fronts BBC2's Gardener's World - said although he enjoyed the programme he had done enough of them.

Titchmarsh will leave after completing the shows to which he has already committed himself.

The garden makeover show was launched in 1997 on BBC2 but transferred to BBC1 after it proved to be a huge ratings hit.

At its peak two years ago, it was the second best rating BBC show after EastEnders as Titchmarsh and his co-host Charlie Dimmock blossomed in the public's affection.

It won over 12m viewers but audiences have since slumped to around 7.5m. And it can no longer claim the place in TV's top 10, slipping to number 16 in the BBC1's top 30 according to the latest official ratings from BARB.

Another eight shows are lined up for 2001 and a further eight will be filmed next year.

After that Titchmarsh said he will call it a day.

"When we got to 50 programmes I thought that was the time to stop, but they were desperate to carry on. I agreed to do another 16, then I'll go. That's it," he said.

"They'll probably bring in somebody else. I won't watch it - but I don't watch it now," said Titchmarsh, who presents the programme with Charlie Dimmock and Tommy Walsh.

"I hope to give a lot of people a lot of fun but I don't want to watch my own programmes. I hope it's still giving people a lot of pleasure. It's still in the top 10 - I can't grumble at that."

His decision could mark the end of gardening's place in the primetime BBC1 schedule.

Ground Force's success was due partly to its gameshow feel but TV bosses have been aware for some time that viewers will ultimately tire of it along with other makeover shows such as Changing Rooms.

Titchmarsh, also a best-selling novelist, will be fronting the coverage of the Chelsea Flower Show when it returns to BBC2 in May after the event was screened for several years on Channel 4.

He said the return to the Beeb would give coverage of the show "dignity and depth".

A BBC spokeswoman said Mr Titchmarsh would remain one of the key stars of the corporation's gardening output even after he leaves Ground Force in two years time.

"He has just renewed a contract for two years, so viewers can enjoy him on Ground Force for a long time to come. He is also presenting Gardener's World and there are plans for a major gardening series for BBC2 next year," she said.

fields.headline: Turncoat of turncoats
fields.trailText: As Mr Tony Blair would agree, we live in a cynical age characterised by those he and I call the sneerers.  Ask them what is fresh and delightful about our political scene and they will moan about the tired posturing of two power-hungry but ideologically vacuous dinosaurs scrapping over the decomposing bones of Thatcherism.
fields.body:
As Mr Tony Blair would agree, we live in a cynical age characterised by those he and I call the sneerers. Ask them what is fresh and delightful about our political scene and they will moan about the tired posturing of two power-hungry but ideologically vacuous dinosaurs scrapping over the decomposing bones of Thatcherism.

Well, let them sneer. We believe there is something novel and delicious about politics, and it is this: the dramatic re-inventions to be found among the ruling elite. Politicians always reposition themselves for reasons pure and impure, but never has such a chunk of the government and its apparat performed so many spectacular volte-faces for no other discernible reason than the acquisition and retention of power.

It is out of awe for this elasticity, and the genuine desire to honour our flexible friends, that we are holding the Turncoat of Turncoats contest, with odds supplied by Diary pundit Steptoe. The competition runs from now until the day on which Mr Tony decides to hold the election. All votes must be in by 6pm on the preceding Thursday, in order that the winner may be presented with the prize as they arrive at their polling station.

Please select whoever you think most deserves our special garment a red coat with 30 yellow circles on it to represent pieces of silver, which then turns inside out and becomes a bright yellow coat with 30 red rectangles representing red boxes. webTitle: Legal challenge launched as tube talks break down

fields.headline: Legal challenge launched as tube talks break down
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Talks between the government and Ken Livingstone's transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, on plans to part-privatise London Underground finally broke down yesterday with Mr Kiley launching a legal challenge seeking a judicial review of the government's plans.
fields.body:
Talks between the government and Ken Livingstone's transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, on plans to part-privatise London Underground finally broke down yesterday with Mr Kiley launching a legal challenge seeking a judicial review of the government's plans.

A final meeting between the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, and Mr Kiley failed to produce agreement.

Mr Kiley said government proposals for a public private partnership (PPP) would fragment the tube. He said he had not been able to agree on modifications to give him unified management control.

The timing of the legal action is likely to see a court case being fought during the last week of April or the first week of May. With 11 of the top 30 Labour marginal seats in London and the south-east, Mr Livingstone's team could inflict serious political damage.

Mr Kiley's meeting with Mr Prescott yesterday was the end of protracted negotiations in which both sides accused the other of reneging on agreements. Mr Kiley's sticking point has been the need for unified management control of the underground. He has said that PPP is prohibitively expensive, fatally flawed and dangerous, because it involves separating responsibility for maintenance from running of the trains.

He said: "After spending £100m, the creators of PPP have come up with something that defies basic common sense and repeats the mistakes that led to Hatfield."

The government is determined to transfer to the private sector the financial risk for the huge investment needed in the system and are adamant that the public sector cannot deliver efficient management of large capital projects.

Both sides had made concessions by the end of last week. But Mr Kiley wrote to Mr Prescott at the weekend saying: "The maintenance scope that the government team feels should be retained by London Underground is so severely limited that it does not even include the routine repair of track and signals, let alone all of those maintenance activities which are critical to safe and reliable service."

Government sources said Mr Kiley's team had made new demands late in the day that led them to question whether he was committed to making a deal.

Mr Livingstone said : "Bob Kiley, one of the world's greatest experts in managing underground railways, has reported that the government's PPP plans in their present form fragment the management of the underground, increase the risk to passengers and make it impossible for me to meet my statutory obligation to provide a safe, integrated, efficient and economic transport system for London. I take that advice seriously."

 A strike by the Rail, Maritime and Transport union over safety and jobs on the tube will go ahead tomorrow.

webTitle: Mayor recruits cartoonist to capital team

fields.headline: Mayor recruits cartoonist to capital team
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: The Guardian cartoonist, Martin Rowson, was yesterday recruited by London's mayor, Ken Livingstone, to capture "all the bizarre and surreal goings-on in London government". Rowson, 42, will be paid one pint of London Pride a year as cartoonist laureate for the capital.
fields.body:
The Guardian cartoonist, Martin Rowson, was yesterday recruited by London's mayor, Ken Livingstone, to capture "all the bizarre and surreal goings-on in London government". Rowson, 42, will be paid one pint of London Pride a year as cartoonist laureate for the capital.

He said: "I imagine it to be a situation as in Roman times when a slave had to follow his master around. I will probably be ignored for months."

His first official task will be to cover the mayor's question time on April 4.

He is not certain what tasks he will be set or how often he will have to attend the Greater London assembly. "It depends on how much goodwill they can extract from one pint of London Pride," he said.

"The last thing that politicians in this country can afford to do if they want to get re-elected is to admit they do not have a sense of humour.

"It is a very important part of the political process and of journalism. I am glad there is a politician somewhere who is willing to allow a cartoonist inside the loop, however dangerous that could be."

webTitle: Visit Britain despite foot and mouth, urges Blair

fields.headline: Visit Britain despite foot and mouth, urges Blair
fields.trailText: Tony Blair today urged the British public to take the lead by going to the countryside to show the world it was still open for business.
fields.body:
Prime minister Tony Blair today urged the British public to take the lead by going to the countryside to show the world it was still open for business.

Speaking to the British Chambers of Commerce conference in London, he said that rural hotels, pubs and tourist spots were being devastated by the ongoing foot and mouth epidemic. Overseas visitors were left with the impression that the countryside was out of bounds, said Mr Blair, adding that the impact of the disease on tourism was "tragic". He said the problem could only be overcome if thousands of people visited the countryside, and urged local authorities to take "a common sense view" of restrictions on access to footpaths imposed after the first outbreak of foot and mouth in February.

The countryside tourist industry - worth £12 billion a year in England alone - is already losing an estimated £100 million a week, and faces a nightmare Easter season if visitors stay away. Mr Blair told the conference that "they will only come if we get on top of the disease and if people here and abroad start to return to normal behaviour patterns. "It is tragic that some areas unaffected by foot and mouth have been affected as badly as those worst hit."

Mr Blair stressed that there was no trace of the disease in the majority of the UK and that many areas had suffered only isolated cases. "The way this has been presented on television abroad, as if the whole country was out of bounds, is leading to cancellations that are totally unnecessary," he said.

webTitle: Loosening the grip of private enterprise

fields.headline: Loosening the grip of private enterprise
fields.standfirst: The Labour government is undermining state services, but there are ways of challenging the private takeover of state services
fields.trailText: Bob Holman: The Labour government is undermining state services, but there are ways of challenging the private takeover of state services.
fields.body:
With an election near, New Labour will not welcome a recent publication by Michael Barratt Brown. The Captive Party shows how public services are increasingly in the grip of private enterprise.

I too believe in state social services. As a boy, I went to a secondary modern school, upgraded to a grammar. The teachers, mostly ex-servicemen, lacked degrees but they possessed a commitment to the education of working-class kids. They coached me through a state scholarship to university.

After college, my wife and I rented a new town dwelling. Like much public housing, it was of good quality. I was a child care officer in a local authority children's department, set up in 1948 for "children deprived of a normal home life". We hoped the children would be provided with substitute parents and educational services to compensate them for the separation from their own parents.

Recently, I attended a memorial service for Barbara Kahan, who was children's officer for Oxfordshire and later the foremost child care figure in Britain. She humanised services for children in care and pioneered means of keeping them with their own parents. She showed that statutory services could be efficient as well as personal.

Today the government underfunds and condemns state services. Last autumn, Paul Boateng, minister for young people, declared that social services departments have "let down children year and year upon year". Such attacks give credence to New Labour's policies of increasing the grip of private enterprise upon services. The private finance initiative - where the private sector owns and leases back public sector facilities to councils or the NHS - means that companies will make fat profits from local government and health. And, despite many criticisms of private sector performance in the criminal justice system, the privatising of prisons continues.

In 1970-71, specialist council social work departments were amalgamated into huge social services departments. Managers, not social workers, became the leaders with the values and strategies of private management wielding much influence. The result has been the decline of personal child care skills and the growth of bureaucracy. Top managers mouth concern for the poor while increasing inequality by taking enormous salaries. Huge fees are paid to private residential, fostering and staffing agencies. Social services departments will probably soon be incorporated into undemocratic care trusts and then privatised.

But why is a Labour government undermining state services? Private companies are not necessarily more efficient than the public sector - look at Railtrack and the huge problems over rail maintenance. They are not necessarily more caring of users - look at drug companies and the battle under way in the South African courts to force companies to allow cheap copies of life-saving drugs for people with HIV and Aids.

In his book, Barratt Brown identifies the many personal links between New Labour and big business. He shows that private enterprise dominates the 320 task forces established by the government. Should we be surprised if social services are seen as the next opportunity for private investment?

But there are ways of challenging the private takeover of state services.

First, professional groups, such as the British Association of Social Workers, should be more vocal in declaring the virtues of local government services.

webTitle: Surgeon's £500,000 over sex and race bias

fields.headline: Surgeon's £500,000 over sex and race bias
fields.standfirst: Agreement on payout ends tribunal case by consultant who complained of macho culture in hospital's plastic surgery department
fields.trailText: A consultant plastic surgeon who complained about sexist and racist behaviour among senior hospital colleagues is believed to have accepted £500,000 to settle an employment tribunal claim.
fields.body:
A consultant plastic surgeon who complained about sexist and racist behaviour among senior hospital colleagues is believed to have accepted £500,000 to settle an employment tribunal claim.

Derriford hospital at Plymouth, Devon, admitted that serious personality clashes between colleagues "within and outside" the plastic surgery department made it impossible to bring back Judy Evans, 49, who was suspended on full pay nearly two years ago. The hospital said that strife between doctors in the department was affecting its ability to recruit new staff.

A 14-day tribunal hearing was due to have started on Monday, but a deal was agreed by the end of the day. The tribunal had been expected to hear claims that a macho culture existed in Derriford whereby women and ethnic minorities were discriminated against.

Hospital managers have conceded the plastic surgery department was beset by difficulties and that its immediate future was threatened. Another plastic surgeon, Krish Kumar, is preparing a tribunal case against the hospital alleging racial discrimination.

Dr Evans's MP said yesterday that a string of allegations had been made to him by staff. John Burnett, Liberal Democrat MP for Torridge and West Devon, said he would be calling for a debate in the Commons. "I've had a series of consultants and other employees of the hospital come to see me with serious complaints about personnel management. These are serious matters which should not be swept under the carpet."

The row between Dr Evans and the hospital began with an incident in February 1999 when she backed a trainee plastic surgeon who complained that a male consultant had made a racist remark.

The trainee, a British woman of Nigerian ancestry, was allegedly told: "You are not operating on bloody Nigerians now. These are my patients - they are normal human beings."

Soon after, two consultants, including the surgeon said to have made the remark, made complaints about Dr Evans's work and she was suspended.

Dr Evans believed she had been victimised with an attack on her competence because she had stepped in to defend the black trainee.

An independent investigation found no problems with the bulk of her work - which was in skin cancer - but a higher than expected rate of complications in breast surgery, and in head and neck cancer. She had wanted to return to Derriford to concentrate solely on skin cancer.

Plymouth Hospitals NHS trust, which runs Derriford, declined to confirm the size of the financial settlement yesterday. However legal sources unconnected with the case said it was likely to have been £500,000.

The money will come from the public purse, as the NHS does not use an insurer. It will either come from the trust's budget or in a loan from central government. There is no cap on tribunal payouts in sex discrimination cases.

The trust now hopes to recruit three new consultant surgeons to plastic surgery. The male surgeon who allegedly made the racist remark has left. He is understood to have denied being a racist.

Chief executive Paul Roberts said in a statement: "Like the rest of the NHS the trust takes equal opportunities very seriously. These events have inevitably raised questions around equal opportunities, and I would wish to confirm my commitment to ensuring that our arrangements at the trust are in line with national guidance and rigorously applied."

In the same statement Dr Evans said: "I welcome what Paul Roberts has said. I have no doubts about his personal commitment to equal opportunities issues. I regard this episode as closed and look forward to the challenge of developing my career outside of Derriford hospital."

fields.headline: Education and egalité
fields.standfirst: One of France's top universities is to change its admission policy to encourage applications from socially disadvantaged students, says John Henley
fields.trailText: One of France's top universities is to change its admission policy to encourage applications from socially disadvantaged students, says John Henley in Paris.
fields.body:
A minor revolution is underway inside the cloistered halls of one of the very grandest of France's "grandes écoles", and it could have some far-reaching consequences in this most elitist of nations.

For generations, the Institut d'études politiques - almost universally known as Sciences-Po - in rue Guillaume on the Left Bank has drawn its fortunate students from the smartest lycées of the capital.

As a result, more than 80% of them are the sons (and occasionally the daughters) of industrialists, academics, senior management staff or professionals. Rather less than 5% have a parent who is a regular employee or a shopkeeper, still less a manual worker.

But the august institution's governing council has just voted, and by a large majority, to sign admission agreements with seven high schools in some of the most run-down and disadvantaged suburbs of Paris.

Promising pupils from such dives as Aulnay-sous-Bois and Seine-Saint-Denis will, from this summer, be admitted on the basis of an interview and their school record, rather than on Science-Po's legendary and terrifying entrance exam that until now has been attempted only by students educated in the capital's classiest arrondissements.

"We're doing something concrete to change the way this institution recruits France's academic elite almost exclusively from its social elite, in a self-perpetuating cycle that is both deeply unfair and in the long term, damaging for the nation," said Science-Po's courageous director, Richard Descoings.

To an even greater extent than Oxford and Cambridge in Britain, Sciences-Po has, along with a handful of other top finishing schools like the Ecole Normale Supérieure, the Ecole Polytechnique and the mighty Ecole nationale d'administration or ENA, furnished France's governing class for generations.

Graduates of the so-called grandes écoles can expect plum jobs in the civil service, public-sector companies and privatised industry. More than 80% of the country's top technocrats are have been to one or more of these schools, as have half the bosses of France's top 200 companies, three-quarters of prime minister Lionel Jospin's cabinet, six of the past eight prime ministers and two of the past three French presidents.

It is a system that has, over the years, supplied France with a reliable pool of top-level talent, able to push through ambitious schemes like the TGV and govern forcefully. But it is also a system that has widened social divides, creating a hermetically-sealed caste of mutually self-interested high-flyers who make a sad mockery of the "equality" the country boasts of in its national motto.

It has been criticised for years; in 1998, Jacques Attali denounced "a machine for reproducing elites" and pointed out that it was "essentially impossible today for a child who has attended a primary school in a disavantaged suburb to ever gain admission to a grande école".

But until this week, no one had tampered with it. So perhaps not surprisingly, Sciences-Po's initiative has not been universally welcomed. The directors of the other fast-breeders for bureaucrats have denounced it as an empty gesture, claiming their schools' privileged intakes simply reflect the structure of French society, and that it's not down to them to change that.

Some Sciences-Po students have even threatened to take the governors to court, arguing that by creating a two-stream admission procedure the school is effectively discriminating against its more traditional candidates.

But the initiative has been enthusiastically welcomed by the Socialist education minister, Jack Lang, who says he is committed to achieving a higher education system "based on both equality of access and intellectual rigour" and that he sincerely hopes Science-Po's move will be emulated by France's other elitist institutions.

"We no longer have the right, in France, to maintain this ossified system," the minister said. "Cultural diversity will enrich every student, and finally lead us to question an abnormal and outmoded system in which the country's decision-makers all emerge from the same mould."

Whether or not it is copied, Science-Po's daring adventure in democracy should be applauded, and loudly.

In a country that is changing faster than its self-satisfied governing class sometimes seems to realise, it is yet another sign that the country is no longer trying to seek refuge from the present in the certainties of the past.

webTitle: Berlusconi under fire from Italian intellectuals

fields.headline: Berlusconi under fire from Italian intellectuals
fields.standfirst: A group of leading thinkers has attacked Italy's controversial media magnate turned politician, who is favourite to win the election in May, writes Philip Willan
fields.trailText: A group of leading thinkers has attacked Italy's controversial media magnate turned politician, who is favourite win the election in May, writes Philip Willan.
fields.body:
The general election on May 13 is not a choice between right and left, but a crucial test for the survival of Italian democracy. This is the alarmist warning that was issued last month by four leading Italian intellectuals.

They appealed to their countrymen to vote against the centre-right coalition headed by Silvio Berlusconi in order to preserve the fundamental values at the basis of the Italian republic.

The appeal has now reportedly been signed by more than 1,000 intellectuals, including the actor Roberto Benigni, writers Antonio Tabucchi and Andrea Camilleri and the Nobel physicist Rita Levi Montalcini.

Posted on the website of the magazine Il Ponte, it warns that Mr Berlusconi's conflicts of interest, his conflicts with the judiciary and his grandiose spending plans will end up ejecting the country from the community of European nations.

The media baron turned politician is the clear favourite to become Italy's next prime minister but the battle for the votes of the moderate electorate, which will provide the key to victory in May, is becoming increasingly intense.

So, when a conservative political columnist and former editor of a Berlusconi-owned newspaper added his own voice to the chorus of criticism, Mr Berlusconi's camp began to register serious concern. The man who had thus betrayed his former master was Indro Montanelli, a 92-year-old literary institution who can hardly be accused of leftwing sympathies.

Mr Montanelli first came to prominence as a war correspondent in the second world war. A leading anti-communist propagandist, he was shot in the legs by the Red Brigades. In 1976 he famously advised his compatriots to hold their noses and vote for the Christian Democrat party.

Now he has recommended that they cast their votes for Francesco Rutelli, the former mayor of Rome, and his Olive Tree coalition, because they are less frightening than Mr Berlusconi and his cohorts.

He has also cast doubt over Mr Berlusconi's invocation of a new communist menace. "I am accustomed to fighting my battles against the living, not against the dead," he wrote in an editorial hosted recently on the front page of Il Giornale, a newspaper owned by Mr Berlusconi's brother Paolo, which he used to edit.

Real communists, intent on reviving Marxist ideology, were no longer to be found even in Russia, the former cold warrior observed. He waxed even more polemical in an interview with the Rome daily, La Repubblica, suggesting, paradoxically, that a Berlusconi government would be the best therapy for Italy.

"Berlusconi is a sickness that can only be cured by vaccination, with a strong injection of Berlusconi in Palazzo Chigi [the prime minister's office]," he said. "Only after that will we be immune."

Mr Montanelli's attacks pose an awkward problem for the Berlusconi camp, since he is probably the most influential Italian columnist - and particularly highly regarded in conservative circles.

The media magnate's most passionate supporters have already responded by sending a threatening letter to the Milan restaurant where the elderly journalist lunches and by shouting abuse at him over the telephone.

Others in the centre-right House of Liberties have reacted by suggesting that Mr Montanelli has gone gaga. Mr Berlusconi himself compared the journalist to Tartarin de Tarascon, an Alphonse Daudet character who ended up sincerely believing his own imaginary fables -- the two men had previously clashed over the precise circumstances under which Mr Montanelli resigned as editor of Il Giornale in 1993.

The former foreign minister, Antonio Martino, has urged caution, advising Mr Berlusconi to adopt the techniques of judo, using "the violence of others to make them fall with their own impetus".

Gianni Baget Bozzo, a Roman Catholic priest and adviser to Mr Berlusconi, is against turning the other cheek, however. He has described Mr Montanelli as a "whited sepulchre" who has been elevated to a status he does not deserve. "Every time Forza Italia [Mr Berlusconi's party] has lost, it has been as a result of the bad advice of those who recommended moderation", he said.

The outcome of the election may now hang on the credibility of these anti-Berlusconi appeals. Mr Berlusconi himself must hope that they do not distract the electorate from his confident campaign promises, while he forges ahead with an impressive charm offensive.

For the House of Liberties they are a last desperate ploy by an already beaten opponent, but an over-aggressive reaction risks convincing waverers that the alarm sounded by the anti-Berlusconi intelligentsia is justified after all.

fields.headline: Alan Mountjoy
fields.standfirst: He challenged the orthodoxy of underdevelopment and growth
fields.trailText: Alan Mountjoy, who has died aged 81, was a leading geographer on the study of development, from 1946 to 1985, at Bedford College, London University.
fields.body:
Alan Mountjoy, who has died aged 81, wrote about agricultural production, population and development, urbanisation, squatter settlements - and the economic geography of Egypt, Sudan, southern Italy, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Papua New Guinea. From 1946 to 1985, at Bedford College, London University, he was a leading geographer on the study of development.

He was internationally-known for his Industrialisation And Underdeveloped Countries (1963) - which later became Industrialisation And Developing Countries - and Africa: A Geographical Study (1966), co-authored, first, with Clifford Embleton and, later, with David Hilling. Both books were used in schools and colleges throughout the country, and many arriving for interview at Bedford College were there having read their "Mountjoy".

Through five editions, Developing Countries stayed in the catalogue for a quarter of a century. Produced in the wake of the postwar era of modernity, it was remarkable for its measured stance, stressing that industrialisation was not the universal panacea claimed by many at the time. The last of three editions of Africa: A Geographical Study appeared in 1988.

Mountjoy graduated with first-class honours in geography from Reading University in 1940, after which he joined the army as a signals officer. In 1943, after the north African campaign, he was posted to Oran, and travelled in Tunisia and Algeria, before joining the 78th "Battleaxe" division as a mortar officer, and later a company commander. He was awarded the Military Cross, and, posted to Egypt in 1944, was struck by the country's contrasting poverty and prosperity.

In 1946, he joined Bedford College as a lecturer. Drawing on his war experience, he finished a master's degree on Egyptian economic development at Reading in 1949.

Mountjoy's early teaching was on economic geography, including primary production, but his regional interests were to figure prominently. In 1956, he introduced a course on Africa and, in the mid-1960s, with other colleagues, a course on the economic and social geography of developing countries.

As postgraduate tutor in the late 1970s, he took pride in the cohort of students who registered for post graduate degrees which took in development studies. He served as external examiner at Khartoum University, a move that led to a succession of Sudanese completing their doctorates.

Mountjoy retired as reader, just as Bedford merged with Royal Holloway College and the department relocated from Regent's Park to Egham, Surrey, but he remained emeritus reader until his death. The Royal Holloway's department is still one of the most active in the field of development geography, in no small measure due to his pioneering work.

webTitle: Jewish and Palestinian students campaign against racism

fields.headline: Jewish and Palestinian students campaign against racism
fields.standfirst: Students from both groups put aside their differences at the NUS annual conference to campaign against racism in the UK
fields.trailText: Students from both groups put aside their differences at the NUS annual conference to campaign against racism in the UK.
fields.body:
Palestinian and Jewish students yesterday shared a platform at the National Union of Students (NUS) annual conference to campaign against racism in the UK.

Many of them have family or friends too close for comfort to Israel's conflict and have serious disagreements over the events 2,000 miles away. But so far, their main representative bodies have maintained a positive, if frosty, relationship.

The Union of Jewish Students (UJS) is dedicated to peace in Israel and Palestine through dialogue and the creation of two states.

That does not satisfy the president of the General Union of Palestinian Students (GUPS), Husam Zomlot. "Everyone says that, Ariel Sharon says that and he's a war criminal. I wish I would see the UJS put out a leaflet that says, 'These killings in Palestine are against all civilians'. I wish they would stop just repeating the government line."

Simon Petar, a member of the UJS who is on the NUS' national executive, agrees that the situation is inevitably strained. "To be honest with you, our relations with GUPS have been limited. That doesn't affect our relationship with students; we have extremely good relations with individual students from all backgrounds and campaign against all racism."

Despite the problems, the two groups have managed to work together. Yesterday, they shared a platform at the Blackpool conference, campaigning against racism in the UK. Both groups agree that any conflict between students in Britain has to be avoided and condemned at all costs.

For Palestinians and Jewish students with family in Israel, the last year has been an incredible strain.

"Instead of focusing on studying, you have to stay in contact with your family. People feel this idea that their nation is being destroyed while they work at university. I'm always saying, 'no, we are struggling to keep our society educated'. But you hear something on the TV and never know, could it be my mother?" said Mr Zomlot.

Mr Petar feels in a similar situation. "I have family and friends in Israel. What happens 2,000 miles away has an effect on British students."

webTitle: Blind  climber sets out to conquer Everest

fields.headline: Blind  climber sets out to conquer Everest
fields.standfirst: More on climbing
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Tourism in Kathmandu said Erik Weihenmeyer, 32, will be the first blind person even to attempt to climb Mount Everest, the world's highest mountain, which stands 8,850m tall on the border of Nepal and Tibet
fields.body:
An American who has climbed mountains around the world despite losing his sight at the age of 13 set out today to achieve his ultimate goal: becoming the first blind person to reach the summit of Everest.

Unlike most mountaineers who carefully coordinate their eyes, hands and feet as they climb, Erik Weihenmeyer, 32, will follow the sounds of bells tied to the jackets of his 12 teammates and their Sherpa guides, all of whom can see.

"Because Everest is so famous and you read and hear so much about it, I wanted to try it out," Weihenmeyer said, before he and the other mountaineers from the National Federation of Blind Allegro Everest Expedition boarded a helicopter and left Kathmandu for the mountain. "I have developed skills with my hands that most people have using their eyes, and I always climb with strong people," Weihenmeyer, of Golden, Colorado, said.

The Ministry of Tourism in Kathmandu said he will be the first blind person even to attempt to climb Mount Everest, the world's highest mountain, which stands 8,850m tall on the border of Nepal and Tibet. A big challenge will be the Khumbu icefall, where climbers use aluminium ladders and ropes as a bridge to cross the crevass. A slip would mean almost certain death on hitting the bottom or the razor-sharp ice that edges the crevasses. Like many other climbers, he will avoid unnecessary risks at the higher points by using bottled oxygen to supplement his breathing.

At the age of 13, Weihenmeyer lost his sight through a degenerative eye disorder. Three years later, he took up rock climbing. Since then he has climbed 6,150m Mount McKinley in Alaska, the 6,900m Mount Aconcagua in Argentina (believed to be the highest peak outside Asia) and the 5,860m Mount Kilimanjaro in Africa. He got married on top of the 3,940m Shira Plateau on his way to the Kilimanjaro summit two years ago, and he and his wife now have a nine-month-old daughter, Emma.

Weihenmeyer and his mountaineering friends have been preparing for their current adventure for the past three years by practicing on smaller mountains to familiarize themselves with the cold, high altitude and rarefied atmosphere of Everest. In January, he scaled Polar Circus, the 900m vertical ice wall in Alberta, Canada, and last year, the team failed to reach the summit of the 6,812m Mount Ama Dablam in Nepal. Deteriorating weather and food shortages forced the climbers to retreat from a height of 6,000m after spending eight days waiting for the weather to clear.

This time, the team will land at Lukla, a dirt airstrip in the foothills of Everest, and trek for nine days to the base camp at 5,300m. There, the climbers will stay for at least three days to acclimatize themselves. They hope to reach the summit in mid-May, when the weather is favorable. The popular spring climbing season in Nepal ends on May 31, when the monsoon dumps snow on the mountain, making such efforts difficult.

Since the first recorded conquest of Everest in 1953 by Sir Edmund Hillary and Sherpa Tenzing Norgay, more than 800 people have reached the tallest peak. About 180 people have died on its unpredictable slopes. Despite that death toll, Weihenmeyer is optimistic. "I feel lucky this time," he said.

webTitle: Harrow public school profiled in TV documentary

fields.headline: Harrow public school profiled in TV documentary
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: Harrow, the public school, is to feature in an eight-part weekly documentary to be screened in the London region, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
It has taught seven prime ministers and is steeped in four centuries of history, but it has always been impenetrable by the media - until now.

Harrow, the public school, is to open its doors to prying eyes for the first time in its 429-year history.

However, the behind-the-scenes look into one of Britain's most famous exclusive schools will only be screened to viewers in London.

The eight-part weekly documentary, aired in Carlton's London region from Tuesday May 8, has been compiled from two months of footage taken by production company Bazal.

Bazal, the UK arm of Endemol, was allowed unprecedented access to get a warts-and-all view of the institution that educated British prime ministers Sir Winston Churchill, Lord Palmerston and Sir Robert Peel.

"Never before will the public have been given such an intimate view of life at one of Britain's leading public schools," said Annette Clarke, executive producer at Bazal.

fields.headline: Teacher protests continue
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited Education
Special report: The teacher shortage
fields.trailText: Teachers' action over staff shortages is to continue in schools across the country despite a disagreement over tactics between the two unions involved.
fields.body:
Teachers' action over staff shortages is to continue in schools across the country despite a disagreement over tactics between the two unions involved.

The National Union of Teachers (NUT) is still demanding clarification from ministers on a proposed inquiry into teacher's workload. The National Association of Schoolmasters and the Union of Woman Teachers (NASUWT) favours starting talks now, but said it did not want to "get into a slanging match" with its fellow union.

Education Secretary David Blunkett has conceded to an independent evaluation of teachers' workloads conducted by the School Teachers Review Body - but only once they stop the protest.

The local education authority employers have offered overtime payments to teachers covering for absent staff, but the unions said this would not tackle the underlying problems of stretched resources and understaffing.

The Deputy Secretary of the NASUWT, Eamonn O'Kane, said: "We have the view that it is probably more advantageous to enter into discussions now. However, we understand there are problems with the suggestions the employers have made.

"The important thing is that this is only a difference of opinion on tactical moves - we wish to preserve a unity of purpose with the NUT. We hope to sort out a new timetable to start up new discussions that, hopefully, can accommodate everyone's needs."

The NUT is angry with the government for not clarifying the terms of the proposed evaluation of workload and cancelled a meeting of its national executive due to be held in London earlier today.

General Secretary of the NUT, Doug McAvoy, said: "The proposals from the employers and the government need clarification. The overtime payments and readjustment of time offer benefits in the short term, but could mean legitimising the making of excessive demands on teachers. They do not yet address the problems in primary and special schools."

Since the beginning of this month, members of both unions have been refusing to cover for vacancies or absences of other teachers for more than three days. The action, which follows votes by teachers across the country, started in London and Doncaster and has now spread to Kent, Leicester, Manchester, Middlesborough, Nottingham, Portsmouth, Reading and Southampton. So far only four schools have had to reduce their timetables: Holywells High School in Ipswich; Rangefield Primary in South London; and The North School in Ashford and Senacre Technology College in Maidstone, both in Kent.

Trouble is also brewing in Ireland's education system, with 600 schools closed for three days over the past fortnight due to industrial action by teachers. Talks are taking place between the Association of Secondary Teachers of Ireland and the department of education in the state's Labour Court. It is not only the teachers who are angry - 20 school children were arrested on Monday as hundreds of students protested at the current state of their education system.

webTitle: Lesbian teacher forced to quit by pupils' taunts claims discrimination

fields.headline: Lesbian teacher forced to quit by pupils' taunts claims discrimination
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: A lesbian teacher forced out of her job by a "campaign of harassment" by pupils sought a ruling from the court of appeal yesterday that she was entitled to compensation as a victim of sex discrimination.
fields.body:
A lesbian teacher forced out of her job by a "campaign of harassment" by pupils sought a ruling from the court of appeal yesterday that she was entitled to compensation as a victim of sex discrimination.

Shirley Pearce took her case to the appeal court after rulings from an industrial tribunal and the employment appeal tribunal that she had suffered homophobic abuse not because she was a woman but because she was gay, and her case was therefore not covered by the Sex Discrimination Act.

Her appeal is a test of whether the Human Rights Act, which came into force six months ago, makes it unlawful to discriminate on the grounds of sexual orientation.

The school is represented by Cherie Booth QC, who is expected to argue today that the harassment Ms Pearce was subjected to was based on her sexual orientation, not her sex, and that she was not discriminated against because a gay man would have been treated no differently.

Laura Cox QC, for the teacher, told Lords Justices Henry and Judge and Lady Justice Hale that claims for injury to feelings in sex discrimination cases resulted in awards "at the highest level". But her client had been denied compensation because the tribunals had been decided she had not been treated differently from a gay man. Ms Cox argued that the definition of "sex" in the act should include "sexuality" or "sexual orientation".

Ms Pearce, 53, was a science teacher at Mayfield secondary in Portsmouth. She was subjected to substantial sexual harassment for five years, an employment tribunal found in 1997. Ms Cox said: "That caused her such distress and hurt that she became unwell and had to take early health retirement."

She said the tribunal had found the school's response to pupils' conduct "unrealistic, cavalier and dismissive" and the head's attitude "appalling".

She added: "The appellant's complaint was of direct sex discrimination but the employment tribunal dismissed the complaint. She could not succeed because she had not demonstrated that a gay man would not have been subjected to abuse of the same kind."

Ms Cox said the tribunal and then the appeal tribunal had "failed to approach the issue correctly, by concentrating on the applicant's sexuality or orientation and lost sight of the fact that the appellant was a woman". The QC said that if the discrimination act did not protect a lesbian it would be incompatible with the rights act, which guarantees freedom of expression and respect for private life for all.

"This was homophobic abuse, in the school and outside her home, by individuals and groups shouting out. We know it affected the appellant's physical and psychological identity, and she could not carry on working. The school was well aware of the extent of the harassment."

The appeal tribunal, when it dismissed Ms Pearce's appeal last March, said that it felt very considerable sympathy for her, but thought it to be "counterproductive to bend an existing law into something which it is not".

It suggested the position might be different once the rights act came in force.

webTitle: Emap detects interest in US titles

fields.headline: Emap detects interest in US titles
fields.standfirst:
More net news
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Emap yesterday fuelled speculation of preparations for a retreat from America after announcing it had received approaches for its US publishing business. By David Teather.
fields.body:
Emap yesterday fuelled speculation of preparations for a retreat from America after announcing it had received a number of approaches for its ailing US publishing business.

The magazine and radio group further reduced its commitment to the internet and closed a number of websites with the loss of up to 100 jobs.

In a trading statement ahead of full-year results, Emap said the softening advertising market had put the US business - bought for $1.2bn (£860m) in December 1998 and now expected to fetch about £450m - under continued pressure. Most of the approaches are understood to have come from trade buyers in the US where the market is undergoing consolidation.

Kevin Hand, Emap chief executive, said no decision had yet been made about the future for the publisher of titles including Hot Rod and Guns & Ammo.

"There has been a lot of speculation about the US business in the press so it is not surprising that people have approached us. We will now consider our options," he said.

The US business has taken the biggest hit from a slow down in motor advertising and investors have been clamouring for a sale. Even if it did sell, Mr Hand said Emap would continue the drive to reproduce bestselling titles led by FHM in the US market.

Paul Richards, media analyst at WestLB Panmure, said that the statement was encouraging.

"The management are taking a firmer grip on the compan," he said. "They seem to be moving closer to the disposal of the US business which is positive news. Combined with the cutbacks on the internet and the reasonable trading this is pretty solid."

The trading update delivered positive news on radio and business magazines which have delivered strong underlying revenue and profit growth.

The full year results, to be delivered at the end of May, will be in line with analysts' expectations. Shares in the company, which have been languishing at three-year lows, climbed 11.5p to 741.5p.

Emap is again sharply reducing the amount it intends to invest in the internet.

The company said in December that spend would be cut from £250m to £120m over three years. About £50m of that cash was spent in the current financial year but only £25m will be spent in the next. The statement said break even was anticipated in 2002/3.

An email from Paul Keenan, the chief executive of Emap Digital, to the company's entire staff yesterday broke the news. The message listed the 13 sites for immediate closure including anglingtimes.com, countrywalking.com, golfer world.co.uk and screendaily.com.

There will also be "restructuring" of some higher profile sites including Q4music.com, mojo4music.com, fhm.com and nursingtimes.net.

The company aims to seek more economies of scale from central functions including commercial and marketing. The job losses represent up to 20% of the digital workforce and the scaling down will cost £10m.

Mr Hand denied Emap had found itself under pressure to take radical action from investors. He also shrugged off suggestions that shareholders were calling for his head.

"As far as the business is concerned we take our decisons in a pragmatic way," he said. "As for me personally, these things get exaggerated."

An email from Paul Keenan, the chief executive of Emap Digital, to the company's entire staff yesterday broke the news. The message listed the 13 sites for immediate closure including anglingtimes.com, countrywalking.com, golfer world.co.uk and screendaily.com. There will also be "restructuring" of some higher profile sites including Q4music.com, mojo4music.com, fhm.com and nursingtimes.net. The company aims to seek more economies of scale from central functions including commercial and marketing. The job losses represent up to 20% of the digital workforce and the scaling down will cost £10m. Mr Hand denied Emap had found itself under pressure to take radical action from investors. He also shrugged off suggestions that shareholders were calling for his head. "As far as the business is concerned we take our decisons in a pragmatic way," he said. "As for me personally, these things get exaggerated."

webTitle: Campaigners want tougher equal pay action

fields.headline: Campaigners want tougher equal pay action
fields.trailText: The government was yesterday urged to go further to close the pay gap between men and women as it unveiled plans to rely on exhortation rather than legislation to persuade employers to pay fairly.
fields.body:
The government was yesterday urged to go further to close the pay gap between men and women as it unveiled plans to rely on exhortation rather than legislation to persuade employers to pay fairly.

Campaigners questioned the decision to rule out legislation to compel firms to review their pay structures to root out inequalities in favour of a voluntary system.

Twenty-five years after the passing of the Equal Pay Act, the government yesterday set out measures intended to help close the pay gap, which still means women full-time workers on average earn four fifths of men's wages.

The employment minister, Tessa Jowell, announced the creation of fair pay "champions", including trade unionists and business leaders, who will promote pay equality. She also unveiled plans for annual awards for employers who conduct and act on pay reviews.

However, while equality campaigners praised government efforts to highlight the continuing pay gap, they warned that new legislation was needed to address bad employers who continue to flout pay laws.

Mary-Ann Stephenson, director of the women's rights pressure group the Fawcett Society, said: "There is no reason not to introduce compulsory pay audits now.

"The reason we, the trades unions and the equal opportunities commission have been calling for legislation is that companies have not been doing pay reviews under a voluntary system."

In a report published last month, the EOC's equal pay task force called for compulsory audits, saying no real progress could be made without them. The government opted for a voluntary approach, wary of prompting a backlash from business over excess regulation.

Business groups including the CBI, which has fiercely resisted compulsory audits, yesterday welcomed the an nouncement. John Cridland, CBI deputy director general, said: "This is a good set of proposals for tackling the gender pay gap which should be both workable for business and effective for women in the workplace."

Ms Jowell yesterday told an Industrial Society conference that women were still losing out in the labour market, having less responsibility, lower pay and fewer promotion opportunities than men.

fields.headline: Sorrell hints at acquisitions
fields.standfirst: Online interview: Martin Sorrell
fields.trailText:
Sir Martin Sorrell has hinted that WPP will make the most of the economic slowdown to look for cheap acquisitions, writes Claire Cozens.

Online interview: Martin Sorrell
fields.body:
Sir Martin Sorrell has given a strong hint that WPP will make the most of the current economic slowdown to look for cheap acquisitions.

Asked whether he was considering an acquisition of the Tempus Group, Sir Martin said the recent fall in share prices in the advertising and marketing sector and the resultant drop in the value of privately-owned companies would "offer opportunities".

"Some people at Tempus would favour an arrangement with WPP, others would not," he told MediaGuardian.co.uk today in a live online interview.

Sir Martin refused to be drawn on whether WPP was eyeing Grey as an acquisition target. "I thought IPG was going to buy Grey," he said.

But the WPP chief reiterated his concerns about the effects of the US economic downturn on the rest of the world.

"When the US sneezes, we all catch colds," he said.

Sir Martin acknowledged that the marketing industry had been short-termist in its attitude to the internet.

"It probably was treated as too much of a short-term goldmine," he said. "We did not come up with sufficiently innovative and creative solutions.

"Given the importance of advertising revenues to new media business models, the onus is on us to respond creatively and effectively."

Sir Martin also said he believed the UK adopt the euro "as soon as possible". But he declined to comment on whether Tony Blair should postpone the general election, saying he would rather "leave such decisions to the prime minister".

Asked about the anti-consumerist ethic described in Naomi Klein's best-selling book No Logo, Sir Martin said marketeers ignored such movements at their peril.

"I have not read the book but believe the movement is a serious and important one, not a passing fad, and one that our clients have to take notice of," he said.

And Sir Martin said companies should be taking PR more seriously as a marketing tool.

"PR has become much more specialised and therefore adds significantly more value," he said.

"Consumers tend to believe editorial publicity more than paid-for publicity. Trends over the last five to 10 years seem to indicate that clients are taking public relations and public affairs much more seriously.

"In any recession, it would be interesting to see whether the seriousness remains."

webTitle: Met to try a softer line on cannabis

fields.headline: Met to try a softer line on cannabis
fields.trailText: The Metropolitan police may become the first force in the country to officially relax its attitude towards cannabis possession, after a decision to pursue a radical policy in a London hotspot for drugs.
fields.body:
The Metropolitan police may become the first force in the country to officially relax its attitude towards cannabis possession, after a decision to pursue a radical policy in a London hotspot for drugs.

Working within discretionary powers given by the Home Office, the borough commander for Lambeth, Brian Paddick, has drawn up proposals to issue warnings to people caught with cannabis, rather than automatically making arrests and, in some cases, bringing charges.

Although the policy will affect only one borough, which includes Brixton, the Met commissioner, Sir John Stevens, is watching with interest to gauge public reaction. He is known to be sympathetic to initiatives that give officers more freedom to tackle serious crime.

If the scheme is a success other areas might follow suit.

Commander Paddick said yesterday the proposal did not mean cannabis was being legalised. The idea was to free his officers from spending hours mopping up minor drugs offences when they needed time to tackle the "cancer" of crack cocaine-related crime.

"I've never met anyone who had to commit crime to fund a cannabis habit, but crack cocaine users commit robbery, burglary and car crime."

He said he was not soft on cannabis use. "That completely misrepresents what we want to do. We believe this policy will continue to deter people buying cannabis on the streets, as they will still lose even small amounts of cannabis in their possession. The person has to accept the warning, [or] be arrested."

It takes two officers up to five hours to process a cannabis possession arrest. "With the new policy, we can deal with a similar matter in 10 minutes," said Cdr Paddick.

His proposal has been forwarded to the community police consultative group in Lambeth. Jennifer Douglas, its chairwoman, said: "It is a brave idea, and it is a good idea. There is a need for a new drugs strategy."

webTitle: Girl of 12 on theft charge held in cells all weekend

fields.headline: Girl of 12 on theft charge held in cells all weekend
fields.trailText: A 12-year-old girl accused of shoplifting spent three days in police cells after her mother refused to collect her and a succession of failures by social services left officers with no choice but to detain her, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
A 12-year-old girl accused of shoplifting spent three days in police cells after her mother refused to collect her and a succession of failures by social services left officers with no choice but to detain her, it emerged last night.

The girl, who cannot be named for legal reasons, was detained at Bluewater shopping centre, in Kent, on Saturday evening and charged with theft. She allegedly stole the items from seven shops during the afternoon. The girl's mother was contacted but, according to Kent police, the woman "refused to attend" and the girl was then denied bail by the police.

Despite repeated requests from the duty solicitor representing the girl, social services in Kent and Lewisham, south-east London, where she lives, failed to arrange for her to be released into the custody of a social worker or to her mother. A Lewisham social worker is alleged to have told the solicitor: "We're not a taxi service."

After spending the weekend in the cells or detention rooms at Bluewater and Gravesend police stations and at Dartford magistrates court, the girl was finally released into the custody of a social worker and returned to her mother on Monday afternoon.

Robin Murray, the girl's solicitor, said: "Where parents fail, through neglect or circumstances, social services are supposed to provide a safety net. Instead they provided a black hole, through which my client fell into a dungeon. I visited her in a detention room, which looks like a cell, smells like a cell and frankly is a cell. She was crying to herself, face down on the bed."

After being detained, the girl, who had travelled to Bluewater with older children, was visited by Mr Murray, who was told an interview had been conducted with an appropriate adult provided by Kent social services in attendance.

He was assured that the girl would be released to her mother or social services, and having told the girl this he left to see other clients at Gravesend police station. Around midnight, however, he was told that the girl was still in custody and had been transferred to Gravesend police station after Bluewater had closed.

On Sunday afternoon, Mr Murray was contacted by the duty inspector at Gravesend police station who, having noted Mr Murray's concerns from the previous evening, informed him that the girl was still in custody. "I called Lewisham social services straight away and was told by the duty social worker, 'We don't operate as an unpaid taxi service, it's not our problem'. "

A spokesman for Kent social services said they had contacted Lewisham social services on Saturday evening and were told that the girl would be taken care of.

Zena Peatfield, Lewisham's director of social care and health, launched an inquiry and said: "It appears in this instance we may have let this girl down very badly indeed."

fields.headline: Top managers 'should get bonuses'
fields.trailText: Top NHS and local government managers should be paid "substantial" bonuses to bring their salaries closer to private sector levels, a new report endorsed by the prime minister recommends. Simon Parker reports.
fields.body:
Top NHS and local government managers should be paid "substantial" bonuses to bring their salaries closer to private sector levels, a new report endorsed by the prime minister recommends.

The report from the Performance and Innovation Unit (PIU) - a Cabinet Office-based think-tank - suggests the move could help local government recruit and retain the best senior staff, as well as making it easier for employees to move between sectors.

The PIU suggests this could be done with large bonuses for successful managers, or by raising wages selectively when it is necessary to recruit staff.

Welcoming the report, the prime minister, Tony Blair, said: "I value the tremendous job being done by leaders in our hospitals and schools, local authorities and elsewhere. But I want to see more being done to develop and support effective leadership across the public sector as a whole."

The PIU says the public sector has problems recruiting and retaining the best leaders, but rejects "magic solutions" to the problem, such as the wholesale import of senior private sector staff.

Instead, its recommendations, which are likely to shape government policy, focus on a "new deal" for public service leaders.

The programme of change would ensure that high-level jobs give employees transferable management skills, promote good working conditions and place a new emphasis on involving leaders in the policy-making process.

The unit wants a high-profile group of public managers put together to champion careers in the sector, and says the government should consider an award scheme to recognise outstanding leadership.

The unit says ministers need to consider more carefully whether their policies are likely to constrain the ability of top managers to effectively lead the public sector.

In a paper published alongside its leadership report, the PIU goes further, rejecting the government's increasingly centralist approach to delivering services: "Delivery of public services always depends on the actions of people and institutions that cannot be directly controlled by central government departments and agencies."

"Although short-term results can be achieved through direction, in the long-run it is more efficient and effective to motivate and empower than to issue detailed commands."

The local government Improvement and Development Agency today welcomed the leadership research.

Director John O'Brien said: "We would support the thrust about leadership being critical It's positive that we're talking about issues like cross-sectoral leadership."

The report explored issues across the whole range of public services, but focuses particularly on health, local government and education.
