webTitle: Back on track in a new pair of boots

fields.headline: Back on track in a new pair of boots
fields.standfirst:
This week sees the introduction across England and Wales of important reforms to tackle juvenile crime and overhaul the neglected and failing youth justice system. In the last of a special series on the causes of teenage offending and measures to fight it, we examine the way an experimental scheme has brought new purpose to one young man's life.

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: At a leisure centre on an Oxford estate on Monday night, Steven was given a pair of boots. It would be premature to say that these boots have changed his life, but they have certainly improved it for now - and helped to make him a success story for a legal experiment.
fields.body:
At a leisure centre on an Oxford estate on Monday night, Steven was given a pair of boots. It would be premature to say that these boots have changed his life, but they have certainly improved it for now - and helped to make him a success story for a legal experiment.

Last summer he stole a bike from a friend's house. He sold it and then got caught. Thames Valley police gave him a final warning. But that week he stole and drove his father's car and took out hundreds of pounds from his cards at a cashpoint machine. He got caught then, too. The magistrates had three options: absolute discharge, custody, or a referral order in a scheme being piloted in 11 areas including Oxfordshire and expected to go nationwide next year.

Because Steven, 16, was in court for the first time and pleaded guilty, he was eligible and was given a referral order lasting six months.

In October he appeared before a youth offender panel of two community volunteers, Helen Morgan and Maxine Dancey. It was arranged through Gaynor Hall, his officer from the Oxfordshire youth offending team (YOT), who had his case from the point of his first arrest.

The theory is that the panel should discuss with the offender, and the victim, the most suitable action to take and agree a "contract". Oxfordshire has been a pioneer of "restorative justice" in the UK, where offenders make amends to their victims. As his father was the victim, Steven (not his real name) was ordered to do 20 minutes of housework a day, Monday to Friday, and an hour on Saturdays.

Turbulent

There were more problems in Steven's life that would make him at risk of reoffending, and the panel wanted to address those issues, too. These went back a long way. His mother died of cancer when he was a toddler. When his father's new wife moved in, their lives blew up. Steven was fostered for a year. His father took him back when he split up with his wife, but their relationship remained turbulent.

The panel referred Steven to a psychiatric nurse and to the youth mentoring scheme, where he would see a volunteer male adult twice a week. He wanted to go to a course on cars, teaching responsible road use. And he agreed to go back to school, which he had stopped attending.

Two months later, when the panel reviewed his case, it was mostly good news. Mostly. Steven was doing his chores and going to the motor course, had an appointment to see the mental health team and the mentoring was getting sorted out. But he just would not go back to school. He was diagnosed, belatedly, with dyslexia. He has a chronic lack of confidence. His teachers think him brilliant at art, but he found everything about school hateful.

A resourceful head of year at his school then found him a place on a another motor vehicle course, full time. But he got the letter late and thought he had missed the chance to register. He could not face sorting it out. "He was shattered, he did want to go but he couldn't get beyond being shattered," said Gaynor Hall.

When she arrived one morning to take him to register, he ran off. The next morning she got him out of bed and drove him to register. She still wasn't confident that when the course started he would go. In the meantime he had a horrendous fight with his father; they both got drunk and threatened to kill each other, and his dad called the police.

But when Ms Hall arrived 10 days later for the start of the course, she handed him a pair of boots he needed for it. His face, and attitude, were transformed.

"He was excited about doing the course. I think he realised it was for real," she said. He had found out there were people he knew on the course, and told Ms Hall he wanted to go there with them.

"Just getting a pair of boots was the difference between stopping him going or not," she said. The school paid the deposit on the boots. Ms Hall got them on loan for a month.

His father has started to say well done to him for the first time. On Monday night, at the leisure centre, his six-month referral came to an end. In a shabby room, with music from the gymnasium blaring through, Ms Hall and the panel sat in a circle with Steven and his dad and told him they were proud of him. And the school had found the money to give him the boots permanently.

"Just thanks for all your help," he said, quietly.

"The six-month referral order was just what we needed," said Ms Hall. "They gave us just enough time to do something meaningful with him. The fact that he's got up and got out and is doing something has made a big difference as far as his self-esteem is concerned."

Steven was her first referral order case, but throughout the county 150 have been issued since August. The Home Office has trained 45 panel members from Oxfordshire. Maggie Blyth, head of the county YOT, said they had not attracted enough young or ethnic minority panel members, and only a third of members were men.

A review of the orders by academics from Goldsmiths College in London and Leeds and Kent universities also pointed out that there were few manual workers or unemployed people on the panel.

There are some civil liberties concerns about referral orders, because the offender needs to admit guilt to be eligible. Around 40% of victims attend.

Risk

In the Oxfordshire YOT there are 70 people, from police, probation, health, education and social services, working in six teams. Standardised reports, called Assets, are produced, assessing the needs of the offender and the risk he or she poses to others, on each of the 2,000 young people arrested each year in the county.

The YOT scheme, like the referral orders, is labour intensive and reliant on professional and voluntary people sharing information, banging heads together and going the extra mile - what Ms Hall calls "a few little particulars and a lot of patience making things happen for these kids".

Cases can go wrong, avenues of potential can turn into cul-de-sacs, and luck can play a part. Steven said later he did not think he would reoffend: "Unless, unless - no, there's no reason."

His father is "95% certain" that he won't. Being up before the magistrates gave him a fright. Ms Hall is begging him to do his art GCSE and has suggested a college course in motor mechanics next year. He thinks there might be more money in painting and decorating.

There is a job application, filled in and ready to go, on his fridge. He no longer has a criminal record. He is free: an opportunity but also a challenge.

I think he realised it was for real," she said. He had found out there were people he knew on the course, and told Ms Hall he wanted to go there with them. "Just getting a pair of boots was the difference between stopping him going or not," she said. The school paid the deposit on the boots. Ms Hall got them on loan for a month. His father has started to say well done to him for the first time. On Monday night, at the leisure centre, his six-month referral came to an end. In a shabby room, with music from the gymnasium blaring through, Ms Hall and the panel sat in a circle with Steven and his dad and told him they were proud of him. And the school had found the money to give him the boots permanently. "Just thanks for all your help," he said, quietly. "The six-month referral order was just what we needed," said Ms Hall. "They gave us just enough time to do something meaningful with him. The fact that he's got up and got out and is doing something has made a big difference as far as his self-esteem is concerned." Steven was her first referral order case, but throughout the county 150 have been issued since August. The Home Office has trained 45 panel members from Oxfordshire. Maggie Blyth, head of the county YOT, said they had not attracted enough young or ethnic minority panel members, and only a third of members were men. A review of the orders by academics from Goldsmiths College in London and Leeds and Kent universities also pointed out that there were few manual workers or unemployed people on the panel. There are some civil liberties concerns about referral orders, because the offender needs to admit guilt to be eligible. Around 40% of victims attend. Risk In the Oxfordshire YOT there are 70 people, from police, probation, health, education and social services, working in six teams. Standardised reports, called Assets, are produced, assessing the needs of the offender and the risk he or she poses to others, on each of the 2,000 young people arrested each year in the county. The YOT scheme, like the referral orders, is labour intensive and reliant on professional and voluntary people sharing information, banging heads together and going the extra mile - what Ms Hall calls "a few little particulars and a lot of patience making things happen for these kids". Cases can go wrong, avenues of potential can turn into cul-de-sacs, and luck can play a part. Steven said later he did not think he would reoffend: "Unless, unless - no, there's no reason." His father is "95% certain" that he won't. Being up before the magistrates gave him a fright. Ms Hall is begging him to do his art GCSE and has suggested a college course in motor mechanics next year. He thinks there might be more money in painting and decorating. There is a job application, filled in and ready to go, on his fridge. He no longer has a criminal record. He is free: an opportunity but also a challenge.

fields.headline: Cyberbabe aims for popstardom
fields.trailText:
Tmmy, the latest manufactured pop act, will release her new single in May, but being a cyberbabe she won't be appearing live, reports Amy Vickers.
Tmmy.co.uk
fields.body:
There's a new manufactured pop act in town but this time, every single thing about the artist is manufactured.

Tmmy, pronounced Timmy, has all the right ingredients to become a pop sensation - good looks, angelic voice, big boobs and a gritty determination to succeed. At least that's what her CV says.

But there's only one catch - she won't be able to do live performances or interviews as she is what is now commonly referred to as a cyberbabe.

Created by the same company behind Ananova, 21-year-old Tmmy releases her first single at the end of May but if you can't wait until then, a sneak preview of her first song, You Make My Day, is available on her official website, Tmmy.co.uk

She studied media at college, and aims to have a number-one hit and play the Glastonbury Festival.

Digital Animations Group, the company behind Tmmy, have even given her characteristics and set goals. She dreams of a number one single and of touring the world but would love to appear on Vets in Practice or Pet Rescue, or failing that become a VJ on MTV.

At college Tmmy studied media and travelled during her summer holidays where she perfected both French and German, which of course she speaks fluently.

Pundits expect her to give Popstars's manufactured band Hear'Say a run for their money.

webTitle: Blair adds to criticism of race row Tory MP

fields.headline: Blair adds to criticism of race row Tory MP
fields.trailText: The prime minister Tony Blair today joined the chorus of criticism of Conservative MP John Townend, describing the use of racist language by any member of parliament as "entirely unacceptable."
fields.body:
The prime minister Tony Blair today joined the chorus of criticism of Conservative MP John Townend, describing the use of racist language by any member of parliament as "entirely unacceptable."

The row reached prime minister's questions after a speech by the retiring Tory MP for Yorkshire East to his constituency party in which Mr Townend praised Enoch Powell's infamous "rivers of blood" speech.

When asked this afternoon about the issue by the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, Mr Blair said it was both morally right and in Britain's self-interest to support racial equality.

He added: "Most people have blood from other races and countries in us."

Today Guardian Unlimited additionally revealed that the Mr Townend was the only MP to refuse to sign a Commission for Racial Equality pledge card to not use race as an issue during the election campaign.

Although the prime minister did not refer to Mr Townend by name, his comments added to the groundswell of criticism of the veteran hard-right MP.

Council, church and community leaders today queued up to condemn retiring MP's speech.

Ross Willmott, Leicester city council leader, said: "His comments undermine good race relations in Leicester.

"Its an affront to this city, particularly in the run up to a general election. There is no question that Leicester's diversity is a strength."

And the Bishop of Leicester, the Right Reverend Timothy Stevens, said: "Mr Townend could not be more wrong. The misgivings people had in the 1970s have been completely disproved. The city has been enriched both commercially and culturally by immigration."

Gerry Sutcliffe, Labour MP for Bradford South - a constituency with large Bangladeshi, Indian and Pakistani communities - described Mr Townend's speech as "outrageous" and called on William Hague to expel the MP from the Conservative party. "We all know that there are active organisations like Combat 18 and the BNP who continue to stir up their views and this just encourages them to publish further material to say that a long-standing MP also has these views."

Mr Sutcliffe, 47, admitted he thought the speech was a "wind-up" when he first heard of it.

He said: "If it had been anyone else, in any other party they would have been expelled. If he's harboured these feelings why does he feel it's appropriate to say them now? What sort of statement has he made for people who are British?"

webTitle: Speech row Tory refuses to sign race pledge

fields.headline: Speech row Tory refuses to sign race pledge
fields.standfirst: The document signed by party leaders
fields.trailText: John Townend, the Conservative at the centre of a race row, is the only MP to have refused to sign a pledge sent to all UK politicians promising not to play the race card during the general election campaign.
fields.body:
John Townend, the Conservative at the centre of a race row, is the only MP to have refused to sign a pledge sent to all UK politicians promising not to play the race card during the general election campaign.

The 66-year-old MP for Yorkshire East was today disowned by party leader William Hague for a speech in which he said illegal immigrants had undermined the character of Anglo-Saxon society and were behind a rise in crime.

Now it has emerged that of the 659 MPs who were sent a letter by the Commission for Racial Equality asking them to state they would not stir up racial prejudice during the campaign, Mr Townend is the only one to have refused to sign up to the pledge.

The prime minister Tony Blair, William Hague, Charles Kennedy and the leaders of the SNP and Plaid Cymru all signed the declaration at a ceremony in the House of Commons two weeks ago. It is being signed by members of the Welsh assembly and Scottish parliament next week and by local councillors up and down the country over the next month.

However, although some MPs have yet to respond to the pledge, only one has point-blank refused to sign it - Mr Townend.

Chris Myant, a spokesman for the CRE, said: "We are very pleased that Mr Hague has taken swift action in accordance with our compact to distance himself and the Conservative party from Mr Townend's speech."

But he added: "The pledge was also sent to all MPs, and although some have yet to respond, Mr Townend is the only member of parliament to tell us he definitely won't be signing up to it."

Mr Townend's speech, which is at the centre of today's row, was made at a constituency party meeting last month, accused immigrants of "seriously undermining" Britain's society and being behind an increase in crime.

Today Mr Townend accused his critics of "political correctness". He added "Immigration did change the character of Britain, nobody can deny that. It is a fact.

"Having absorbed that wave of immigration, that basically was legal - and then we stopped it by the Immigration Act - we now face another wave, and the vast majority of people in this country, including my constituency, are very worried about this.

"There is no doubt in this country there is a great political correctness which tries to push many of these things under the table."

Mr Hague disowned the MP's comments, saying: "John Townend's remarks on immigration and asylum in no way reflect the position of the Conservative party. They are totally unacceptable and I wholly repudiate them."

His comments were also rejected by Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, who distanced himself from the MP.

Mr Maude said: "I don't agree with a word of it. We don't have - and never have had, or not for 1,000 years - a homogeneous Anglo-Saxon population here.

"We have an extremely rich mix of ethnic backgrounds which has been enriched over the centuries by a flow of refugees and immigrants and this is what makes Britain special and wonderful."

However he stopped short of Labour demands for the Conservative whip to be withdrawn from Mr Townend - effectively expelling him from the parliamentary party.

A Labour spokesman said: "It doesn't matter how much Mr Hague says that his words don't reflect official Tory policy. Unless the whip is withdrawn, it gives the green light to other candidates to make speeches of this nature."

And veteran anti-racist campaigner Peter Hain, now energy minister, added: "No respectable party in modern Britain should allow any prominent figure within it to make a speech of this nature."

In his original remarks, Mr Townend praised Enoch Powell's notorious "rivers of blood" speech, made in April 1968, in which Mr Powell predicted social breakdown as a result of immigration.

Mr Townend said: "Our homogenous Anglo-Saxon society has been seriously undermined by the massive immigration - particularly Commonwealth immigration - that has taken place since the war.

"Illegal immigrants have got a new ploy. They call themselves asylum seekers. In my view the only way to deal with the problem is to send them back quickly.

"Many come from violent societies and inevitably crime is already beginning to rise in the areas where they are."

Mr Townend said that Mr Powell would have been made prime minister if people had known how accurate his forecast about the impact of immigration would turn out to be.

And he suggested Britain should withdraw from the United Nations' convention on refugees to slash the number of asylum seekers accepted in the country.

fields.trailText: William Hague's election credentials were besmirched last night by the discovery of an avowedly xenophobic speech by a senior Conservative backbencher endorsing Enoch Powell's predictions that mass immigration would cause social breakdown in Britain.
fields.body:
William Hague's election credentials were besmirched last night by the discovery of an avowedly xenophobic speech by a senior Conservative backbencher endorsing Enoch Powell's predictions that mass immigration would cause social breakdown in Britain.

John Townend, the veteran Tory MP for Bridlington in Yorkshire who is retiring at the coming election, was immediately denounced for "totally unacceptable" remarks on race by the Conservative leader after the Daily Mirror publicised a speech he made to local activists this month.

"Our homogenous Anglo-Saxon society has been seriously undermined by the massive immigration - particularly Commonwealth immigration - that has taken place since the war," he said, adding that Powell would have become prime minister if voters had realised the accuracy of predictions he made about immigration trends in his notorious "rivers of blood" speech in 1968.

"Illegal immigrants have got a new ploy," he said. "They call themselves asylum seekers. In my view the only way to deal with the problem is to send them back quickly. Many come from violent societies and inevitably crime is already beginning to rise in the areas where they are."

webTitle: 'On race we constantly get our hands scalded'

fields.headline: 'On race we constantly get our hands scalded'
fields.standfirst:
As the Tory party once more embroils itself in a race row, a former adviser to the Conservatives, Ed Vaizey, explains why the party needs to readdress the issue
Special report: The Conservative party
fields.trailText: The race card has been played even before the election has been called.  The Tories have a long and deeply undistinguished history in terms of racial politics, ranging from Enoch Powell's 1968 "rivers of blood" speech to the defeat of John Taylor in Cheltenham in 1992 amid racial slurs from his own party, and now to the remarks of John Townend (thankfully disowned by William Hague).
fields.body:
The race card has been played even before the election has been called. The Tories have a long and deeply undistinguished history in terms of racial politics, ranging from Enoch Powell's 1968 "rivers of blood" speech to the defeat of John Taylor in Cheltenham in 1992 amid racial slurs from his own party, and now to the remarks of John Townend (thankfully disowned by William Hague).

At heart, I do not believe that the Tory party is a racist party. The party I have been a member of all my adult life should have an affinity with all our ethnic communities. We believe in diversity, freedom of the individual, tolerance and hard work. At the same time, we have avoided absurd ethno-posturing. Quite rightly, we do not pursue policies of quotas or tokenism, only those of merit. But central office does have an active and dedicated cultural unit aimed at reaching out to people who feel alienated from our party. Which makes recent events all the more unfortunate.

We are drawn to the race issue like a small child to the fire, and we constantly get our hands scalded. Andrew Lansley, now a senior shadow cabinet member, was famously misquoted as saying that the Tories played the race card in the 1992 election. What he actually said was that race policy was a weak area for Labour which they failed to address in the eyes of the electorate. But still he was misquoted.

Now Tory strategists are mesmerised by the fact that the Tories' lead on asylum seekers and they believe they should play the issue for all it is worth. Wrong. A policy issue like this is like foot and mouth: nasty and infectious, it will lead to the mass slaughter of other perfectly respectable policies.

It is time for the Tories to revisit the issue of race, and to seize it, both from rightwing bigots and, frankly, from the left, whom it suits just as well to stoke up the fires of race hatred in order to secure their votes in ethnic communities.

There is a common sense Conservative approach which goes like this: immigration, economic or otherwise, is good, especially in a country where the birth-rate is declining. There is no such thing as a homogenous society - every nation benefits from the introduction of different cultures and different peoples, as we have through the centuries. The current asylum process does not work because it is slow, bureaucratic, linked to welfare and an encouragement to fraud, crime and cheating. We need to make it faster, simpler and tie it in with wholescale benefit reform.

Now will someone from the Tory party please get up and say it?

Who is John Townend?

webTitle: Haider in search of dragons to slay

fields.headline: Haider in search of dragons to slay
fields.standfirst: Following a poor showing in the recent elections, the Freedom party leader may become the forgotten man of Austrian politics. Just don't count on it, writes Kate Connolly
fields.trailText: Following a poor showing in the recent elections, the Freedom party leader may become the forgotten man of Austrian politics. Just don't count on it, writes Kate Connolly.
fields.body:
What made Jörgi Haider stand out from the other boys and girls in his village was that, while they wanted to be train drivers, cobblers and tailors when they grew up, he wanted to be a dragon slayer.

Sure enough, when his time came, Jörgi set out to kill the dragon - the nickname for the ruler of the land - and, wielding his lance, did a tour of the beer halls to drum up support for his theory that the dragon was to blame for everything. (As were the Chinese who ran a restaurant that threatened business at the traditional tavern).

He had soon won over the villagers as well as inspired some rather strong anti-foreigner graffiti in the village ...

This, at least, is how a cartoon book by Leo Lukas and Gerhard Haderer depicts the phenomenon of far-right Austrian leader Jörg Haider. Jörgi the Dragon Slayer spent months at the top of non-fiction best-seller lists in Germany and Austria when it was first published last year.

The book ends when the dragon slayer - attempting to slaughter, in fact, Proporz, the system of nepotism by which for years all important positions in Austria were divided up between the two ruling parties - himself turns into a dragon and all the people turn away from him ...

It may turn out to be a prophetic little book. Following the dismal results of Mr Haider's Freedom party (FPO) in Vienna city council elections on Sunday - it lost 8% to the socialists - the firebrand populist has been sidelined, even ostracised in some quarters.

And the coalition government, which comprises the FPO and the conservative People's party (OVP), is in a panic. Mr Haider, who resigned as leader of his party last year and retreated to the southern province of Carinthia where he is governor, emerged from his mountain retreat last month in an attempt to lift the FPO's position in the polls ahead of the Vienna elections.

In the run-up to national elections in October 1999 the FPO's candidate, Hilmar Kabas, came under fire for his anti-foreigner campaign, which called for a stop to "Überfremdung" - literally "overforeignisation" - a phrase deployed by Nazi propaganda minister, Joseph Goebbels.

Mr Haider's answer to the poor standing this time round was to take a similar line. Defending the idea of Haiderism, posters around the city linked "foreigners" with "crime" and played on fear of immigration and the dangers of Europe.

In aggressive speeches smattered with racist innuendo he gave the campaign an unmistakably anti-semitic tone by accusing the head of the Austrian Jewish community, Ariel Muzicant, of "stabbing Austria in the back" by condemning the year-old conservative-FPO coalition government on trips abroad.

He later upped the viciousness of his attack, suggesting Mr Muzicant was involved in dodgy business practices. "How can someone with the name Ariel have such dirt on his hands?" Mr Haider asked, referring to the brand of washing powder.

However, the weekend's poor results have been taken as a sign that voters have grown bored and disillusioned by Haiderism, not just in Vienna, where a 20% of Austrians live, but throughout the country. Heavy defeats were also suffered by his party in the states of Styria and Burgenland last year.

More signs that the FPO's defacto leader is losing his shine and status were seen in the comments of the scruffy Italian far-right leader, Umberto Bossi, who has formerly claimed that Mr Haider was his hero, but who this week was keen to distance himself.

"He is an old-fashioned nationalist," said the leader of Liga Nord, which, like the FPO, has provoked the ire of the EU, who are ready to impose sanctions if Bossi gets into power.

Jörg Haider, say commentators, may yet decide that being part of the national government is too damaging to his party, particularly while he still harbours ambitions to become chancellor. Sharing the responsibility for painful tax rises and cuts in social benefits that the new government has introduced does not make you popular.

Chancellor Schussel, accused of signing a pact with the devil when he agreed that the FPO and his OVP should form a coalition, is said to be panicking. Maybe the Austrian FPO supporters in this sleepy land - who in the Dragon Slayer are depicted wearing dressing gowns and yawning - have finally woken up.

But the fact remains the FPO is still Europe's most successful far-right party and the only one to have made it into national government.

Analysts have said it remains a group that can consistently poll high. "We can expect it to hover at around 20 to 21% from now on," said a Viennese analyst. It is in this solidity and sense of consolidation, say opponents, that the danger lies.

Vienna's socialist mayor, Michael Höupl has said that he is proud of the Viennese for shifting their votes towards his socialists, who polled 47% on Sunday. "Vienna is a city which is international, with no place for anti-semitism and xenophobia," he declared.

However, Mr Höupl would probably be the first to admit, it would be premature of him to say whether or not they will all lived happily ever after.

fields.headline: Police smash child porn network
fields.standfirst: Boy of 13 among more than 30 held in raids on paedophile suspects
fields.trailText: More than 30 people, including a 13-year-old boy and a man working for a national youth organisation, were arrested yesterday in dawn raids on the homes of suspected paedophiles who collect and distribute obscene computer images of children.
fields.body:
More than 30 people, including a 13-year-old boy and a man working for a national youth organisation, were arrested yesterday in dawn raids on the homes of suspected paedophiles who collect and distribute obscene computer images of children.

Twenty-five forces in England, Scotland and Wales took part in the operation, codenamed Appal and coordinated by Greater Manchester police. The move followed a four-month investigation by the force into paedophile activity on the internet during which officers observed, but did not take part in, sessions on dedicated chat channels.

More than 40 homes, from the north of Scotland to Dorset, were raided and computer equipment seized as Manchester officers warned those trading in the images - many of which showed children being abused - that they would be tracked down and charged.

"People have referred to this as the dark side of the internet," said Med Hughes, Manchester's assistant chief constable. "We are going to shine a beam of light into that, start opening up that world and prosecuting those responsible."

The Manchester force, which has a long-established obscene publications unit, with a staff of six, has linked up with SurfControl, a private company specialising in responsible internet use.

After a chance viewing of a TV programme about the unit, SurfControl made available to officers new software that dramatically increased the speed with which alleged offenders could be tracked down. Previously 60 staff hours spent on internet checks would produce 16 suspects; now 16 hours can produce 60 suspects.

"We are out there watching them," said Mr Hughes. "We have the tools to identify them and will root out paedophiles and those who like collections of indecent images of children. We'll come looking for them, and deal with them.

"Partnerships [with commercial companies] are a major issue in dealing with the menace of child pornography on the internet." He added that the computer industry had a responsibility for "unlawful activity".

The 13-year-old was arrested in Manchester and an 18-year-old man was held in Swansea. "A 13-year-old involved in this is potentially a victim as well as an offender," Mr Hughes said.

Manchester officers made two arrests in the Rochdale and Moston areas.

A man from Stretford, south of the city centre, was arrested before Operation Appal began because it was believed he posed a significant threat to children to whom he had access.

Terry Jones, an inspector of the force's obscene publications unit, said those who traded in computer images would find it increasingly difficult to hide from the police. "Our work identifies those people abusing one of the most vulnerable groups in our society," he said. "We will continue to track down those individuals who believe the internet gives them the anonymity to continue their trade in obscene pictures."

He added that areas of the net were "fairly clearly marked" to show that discussions would centre on paedophile activity. "People are now sharing this awful material and that gives us the opportunity to highlight those who may be a danger to society," he said.

In 1999, the force's unit made the first successful identification of an offender and a victim from abuse images seen on the net. A man was later jailed for 12 years for offences which included the rape of a child aged four. The unit also coordinated two operations in which 44 suspects involved in the distribution of indecent images of children were identified across the country.

In 1998, officers raided the Stockport home of Gary Salt and found 42,000 child sex images on a computer. The arrest of Salt, who was later jailed for 12 years, helped to unmask the members of the Wonderland Club, a worldwide internet paedophile ring. Seven British members of the ring were jailed last month.

fields.headline: Albania
fields.standfirst: You may not know a great deal about England's opponents for tonight's World Cup qualifier. If you want that to change, take a look at our guide to the best websites about Albania.
fields.trailText: You may not know a great deal about England's opponents for tonight's World Cup qualifier. If you want that to change, take a look at our guide to the best websites about Albania.
fields.body:
1. England are playing football against Albania tonight in a qualifying match for the 2002 World Cup

2. Albania is a small country in the Balkans bordered by Greece, Serbia, Montenegro and Macedonia.

3. Luckily, it has managed to avoid the regional conflicts, despite Serb aggression against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo and the actions of ethnic Albanian rebels in western Macedonia.

4. The people claim descent from the Illyrians, an ancient tribe colonised for 2,000 years by a succession of empires: Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Turkish.

5. Islam came with Turkish rule, something which divides the majority of Albanians (including those in the former Yugoslav republics) from their orthodox Christian neighbours.

6. However, prominent Christian Mother Teresa was born to Albanian parents - as, irrelevantly, was John Belushi, who became famous as one half of the Blues Brothers.

7. Albania gained independence before the first world war and became communist after the second - it was also during this time that Norman Wisdom became the country's only permitted film star.

8. Dictator Enver Hoxha allowed his movies on the basis that delivery boy Norman Pitkin's struggles against his boss Mr Grimsdale showed a member of the oppressed proletariat triumphing against capitalism.

9. To this day Wisdom works for Albanian charities, raising money for orphanages and helping to ease poverty - it is the poorest country in Europe.

10. Under the name Illyria, Albania was used as the setting for Shakespeare's Twelfth Night. The official language is Albanian and, aside from that, there is probably a lot you do not know about Albania.

webTitle: Murder that is a threat to survival

fields.headline: Murder that is a threat to survival
fields.standfirst: Biodiversity cannot be protected unless language genocide is halted, argues Tove Skutnabb-Kangas
fields.trailText: Biodiversity cannot be protected unless language genocide is halted, argues Tove Skutnabb-Kangas
fields.body:
Habitat destruction through logging, the spread of agriculture and use of pesticides, and the economic and political vulnerability of the people who live in the world's most diverse ecoregions are recognised as the main causes of the disappearance of biodiversity. What is less widely understood is the link between diminishing global biodiversity and the disappearance of languages.

While new trees can be planted and habitats restored, it is much more difficult to restore languages once they have been murdered. And languages are being murdered today faster than ever before in human history. Even the most optimistic prognoses claim that only half of today's 6,000-7,000 spoken languages will exist by 2100. The media and educational systems are the most important direct agents in language murder today. Most of the world's languages are spoken by relatively few people; the median number of speakers of a language is probably 5,000-6,000. There are fewer than 300 languages with more than 1m native users; half of all languages have fewer than 10,000 users, and a quarter of the world's spoken languages and most of the sign languages have fewer than 1,000 users. More than 80% of the world's languages exist in one country only. A simple comparison, based on numbers and extinction rates, shows that linguistic diversity (LD) is disappearing relatively much faster than biodiversity (BD). Optimistic estimates claim that 2% of biological species but 50% of languages may be dead or moribund - no longer learned by children - in 100 years' time. According to pessimistic but realistic estimates, 20% of biological species but 90% of languages may be dead or moribund in 100 years. People might say: so what? It might be better for world peace if we all speak a few big languages and understand each other. But language diversity is decisive for the future of the planet. LD and BD are correlated: where one type is high, the other one is too, and vice versa, even if there are exceptions. David Harmon of Terralingua, an international non-profit organisation devoted to preserving the world's linguistic diversity, has compared the 25 countries that have the most endemic languages with the 25 that have the most higher vertebrates. Sixteen countries (64%) are on both lists. According to Harmon, "it is very unlikely that this would only be accidental". He gets the same results with flowering plants and languages, butterflies and languages - a high correlation between countries with biological and linguistic megadiversity. New research shows mounting evidence that the relationship may also be causal: the two types of diversities seem to enforce and support each other. According to a recent United Nations environmental programme report, threatened languages store the knowledge about how to maintain and use sustainably some of the most vulnerable and most biologically diverse environments in the world. It has taken centuries for people to learn about their environments and to name the complex ecological relationships that are decisive for maintenance of biodiversity. When indigenous peoples lose their languages, much of this knowledge also disappears: the dominant languages do not have the ethno-biological and ethno-medical vocabulary, and the stories will not be translated. If the long-lasting co-evolution that people have had with their environments is suddenly disrupted, without nature (and people) having enough time to adjust and adapt, we can expect a catastrophe. If during the next 100 years we murder up to 90% of the linguistic (and thereby mostly also the cultural) diversity that is our treasury of this historically developed ecological knowledge, we are also seriously undermining our chances of life on Earth. Like the loss of BD, the loss of LD is dangerous reductionism. As we see in increasingly dramatic ways, such as the spread of species that are more resistant to antibiotics and herbicides, monocultures are vulnerable. The potential for the new lateral thinking that might save us from ourselves in time lies in having as many and as diverse languages and cultures as possible. We do not know which ones have the right medicine. For this, multilingualism is necessary. Indigenous and minority people need to have a chance to maintain their own languages and learn dominant languages. But instead of fostering and supporting multilingualism through the education system, schools participate in linguistic genocide, as it has been defined in the United Nations Genocide Convention (Articles IIb and IIe and its Final Draft Article III1). Pirjo Janulf shows in a recent study that of those Finnish immigrant minority members in Sweden who had had Swedish-medium education, not one spoke any Finnish to his or her own children. Even if these adults might not have forgotten their Finnish completely, their children were forcibly transferred to the majority group, at least linguistically. This is what happens to millions of speakers of threatened languages all over the world. There are no schools or classes teaching through the medium of the threatened indigenous or minority languages. The transfer to the majority language group is not voluntary: alternatives do not exist, and parents do not have enough reliable information about the long-term consequences of the various choices. There is also a wealth of research and statistics about the mental harm that forced assimilation causes in education and other areas. To stop linguistic genocide, linguistic human rights in education need to be respected. The most important linguistic human right for maintenance of LD is the right to mother-tongue medium education. But the existing and draft human rights instruments are completely insufficient in protecting linguistic human rights in education. When speakers of small languages learn other, necessary, languages in addition to their native languages, they become multilingual, and the maintenance of LD, necessary for the planet, is supported. When dominant languages such as English are learned subtractively, at the cost of the mother tongues, they become killer languages. The task for users of English is to stop it being a killer language and change it to an additive asset. Dr Tove Skutnabb-Kangas is associate professor at Roskilde University, Denmark, and vice-president of Terralingua www.terralingua.org Her latest book is Linguistic Genocide In Education ? Or Worldwide Diversity And Human Rights? (Lawrence Erlbaum)

fields.headline: How much can you pay for ...
fields.standfirst: Cyber chic shoes
fields.trailText: Cyber chic shoes.
fields.body:
It's official - men no longer hold the monopoly on ridiculous gadgets. Fashionistas with big bank balances and a weakness for computer games need despair no longer. Those clever people at Nintendo have combined the two in a pair of Gameboy shoes. I'm serious.

As part of their Nintendo style campaign, they have commissioned edgy designer Helen Red Richards to come up with a range of six shoes for the "Game Girl" about town. Inspired by the Japanese youth culture at Nintendo's heart, her collection of platforms are as vertiginous as their £1,500 price tag.

Set into the stacked sole of each is a Gameboy handset, carefully co-ordinated to match the colour of the shoe itself. There's the pink strappy number, the minimalist Perspex, the chunky green, the delicately beaded purple and the metallic turquoise ankle boot. The yellow ones have the added bonus of a rubber Pokemon set into the heel. There's one on each foot so you can either play alone or with a friend. It certainly beats playing footsie.

 Shoes made to commission through Nintendo, 020-7471 6680.

webTitle: How volunteers can help pick up the pieces after crime

fields.headline: How volunteers can help pick up the pieces after crime
fields.standfirst: A new good practice guide outlines the role volunteers can play to complement the work of criminal justice professionals and charities, writes David Batty
fields.trailText: A new good practice guide outlines the role volunteers can play to complement the work of criminal justice professionals and charities, writes David Batty
fields.body:
Volunteers working with probation services should be matched with victims and offenders from similar backgrounds or given tasks that suit their skills, according to criminal justice professionals and charities.

The call comes in a new guide on volunteering by the Probation Partnership Group (PPG), whose members include crime reduction charity Nacro and the Association of Chief Officers of Probation. It sets out best practice guidelines for nurturing good volunteers in the community justice sector.

Involving Volunteers in the Community Justice Sector: A Good Practice Guide recommends that organisations should match volunteers to victims or offenders of the same race, age or gender, or those with similar interests. For example, the Black Justice Project recruits black volunteers, while drug and alcohol projects sometimes recruit former substance abusers. The guide notes that ex-service users can have a crucial role in breaking offending behaviour as peer mentors, but says they must be thoroughly checked out.

The report also warns that it is usually inappropriate for volunteers to work with offenders convicted of major crimes such as sex offences or serious violence. They should never be asked to work with individuals whose offending specifically targets the social groups to which the volunteer belongs. But any volunteer may not wish to work with those convicted of racial or homophobic violence or other hate crimes and should be given sufficient information about offenders to make this decision.

In general, it is not appropriate to give volunteers tasks that are normally performed by paid staff. The guide warns that this can lead to disputes over responsibilities and professional boundaries. Good examples of voluntary work include one-off tasks such as escorting partners to visit prisoners, a mentoring role such as helping an individual to secure employment, providing help with basic skills such as numeracy or literacy, or an advisory position such as acting as a trustee or management committee member.

The report's author, Corrine Seymour, Nacro's head of training and development, said: "It's advantageous for volunteers to come from the same community as service users. Then they know where local support services and agencies are and can accompany the user to them.

"Matching people with similar interests is also important when you're trying to engage an offender or victim to change their behaviour. If you're working with younger people it's good to be interested in sport or music."

Mohamed Sadiq, a volunteer on Nacro's community remand project in Bradford, has found his passion for sport a major benefit when helping young offenders.

"I've worked with a lot of lads from inner city estates who are bored and don't know what to do with their lives," he said. "But most of them are interested in sports and because I play football, rugby, cricket and work as a lifeguard I can tell them where to train to get certificates and how to get funding."

The report also recommends recruiting volunteers who have the potential to develop skills, for example, as literacy tutors or mentors. Joanne Rice became a volunteer on Nacro's community remand project in Newcastle, because she is studying criminology and sociology at Northumberland University. Starting in April, she will be employed by the charity as a court officer, providing bail support mainly to young offenders.

Ms Rice said: "Volunteering has allowed me to build up practical skills that complement the theory I've learned in my degree. I've been able to go on staff training - and the experience helped me decide to go into probation work."

fields.headline: The original Jackie
fields.standfirst: Bestselling author Jacqueline Wilson tells  Dina Rabinovich how she gave her name to a girls' magazine and, below, offers young writers a chance to get published
fields.trailText: Bestselling author Jacqueline Wilson tells Dina Rabinovich how she gave her name to a girls' magazine and, below, offers young writers a chance to get published.
fields.body:
Two days after Jacqueline Wilson's marriage ended, she was scheduled to do four talks in one day at a Portsmouth library. Despite her shellshock, she kept the date and made it through to the last session. A child stood up and asked about Wilson's The Suitcase Kid, which tells the story of a child who moves between parents, a week with mum, a week with dad.

"Has your marriage split up?" the little girl asked Wilson. This wasn't the first time children had asked this sort of question. Wilson is often asked, bemusingly enough for this tiny woman in her mid-50s, whether Marigold - of the tattoos, chequered love life, mental health problems and drinking habit - from her book The Illustrated Mum is based on herself.

Wilson took a deep breath, determined to do the professional thing: give a straight question a straight answer. "Funnily, yes," she said. "But not when I actually wrote the book."

"Never mind, Jacqueline," the little girl told the bestselling author. "You've got more time to write your books now!"

"I thought, 'You wonderful, lovely child,' " Wilson tells me, sitting in the juice bar of a big London bookshop, her favourite meeting place in town. "I'm not sentimental about children, but, for the most part, they are so kind - as long as you're reasonably straightforward with them."

Wilson was writing about divorce long before her own. Her daughter was in her late 20s when Wilson's marriage ended; by coincidence, Wilson's own parents split up when she was in her 20s.

She does not see a parallel, though. "We were reasonably cosy as a family," she says of her 30-year marriage. "My parents were not cosy as a family at all. They were never happy, and had frequently gone their own ways."

Wilson is on tour publicising her latest book, The Cat Mummy. She has cropped grey hair, lacy black clothes and lots of elaborate jewellery; when she was a child, her mother always put her in velour coats, little hats and absolutely no jewellery. She has been writing novels since her teens, including more than 50 children's books.

Lately, her career has taken on the kind of proportions that would give Hear'Say a run for their money. Fans are queueing for up to five hours at book signings, and 10-year-old girls burst into tears. "I'm just so excited," one child wailed. Wilson's Double Act is being filmed for TV, and Tiger Aspect, the company that made Billy Elliot, is working on The Suitcase Kid.

Wilson's brand of fiction tackles death, divorce and manic depression, as managed by children, all written in a chatty, down-to-earth style. If you're a woman in your 30s, and this straight-dealing with personal issues sounds familiar - like a magazine you once read - it is no coincidence.

Wilson left school at 16; not because she was bullied, as so many of her characters are, but because she was "too bolshie" and didn't like being told what to do. She answered an advert in the London Evening Standard looking for teenage writers.

The employer was DC Thomson, which was planning a magazine for adolescent girls. Casting around for a good name, the company's two managing directors noticed the new kid in her trendy clothes from London and Jackie magazine was given its name. "I wasn't trendy," she laughs. "I was shy, from the suburbs, but they were doughty Scots in their 60s."

Wilson married at 19, and her daughter was born when she was 21. She wrote every minute she could, managing 2,000 words daily just during nursery hours. In the 70s she wrote a series of detective stories, which she is fiercely resisting her publisher's desire to reissue: "They were probably slightly more sexually explicit than I'd care to write nowadays. Occasionally, librarians pull them out and I have to whisk them away and say, 'No, no, no, these aren't suitable for the children.' "

Wilson strikes one as a fizzy mix of the reassuringly prim and proper and the anarchic - a spiky-haired Mrs Pepperpot. It's a style that works brilliantly with children, while leaving grown-ups a little unsure of their ground. A headteacher I know deplores Wilson's subject matter; but, in the flesh, Wilson could not be more protective of young children's sensibilities.

At school, her English teacher was always telling her she was far too colloquial and used too much slang. I told Wilson of the 10-year-old girls I know who imitate their favourite writer and get the comment in red ink: "Too chatty!" Wilson says she, too, has been sent some work marked: "Too Jacqueline Wilson-y!" Still bolshie, she laughs heartily.

The Guardian/BOL short story competition

The Guardian Parents page has joined the online entertainment and media retailer BOL to promote a competition, devised by Jacqueline Wilson, for children to write their own short story.

To enter, first go to BOL to read a new story by Wilson and discover her tips for aspiring writers. Entrants must be under 15 at the competition's closing date (May 11), and the story should be a maximum of 750 words in length; all other details and conditions can be found at the BOL homepage. The winning story will be published not only in Guardian Parents and at BOL, but also in Jacqueline Wilson's next book of stories!

Buy The Cat Mummy at a discount from BOL

webTitle: Former runaways explain why they left

fields.headline: Flight club
fields.standfirst: Nearly 130,000 children run away from home every year. Most end up on the streets - penniless, lonely and vulnerable.  Diane Taylor  asks former runaways what drove them to it
fields.trailText: Nearly 130,000 children run away from home every year. Most end up on the streets - penniless, lonely and vulnerable. Diane Taylor asks former runaways what drove them to it.
fields.body:
"It's so cold on the streets and so frightening," says Marie, a 20-year-old student who ran away from a Birmingham care home just before she was 16. She felt that she had no choice but to run away because the stepfather who had sexually abused her as a child, which led to her going into care in the first place, kept following her. He would appear and sit next to her as she sat on the bus to school, and hang around the care home.

"When I was 12 he was jailed for the abuse for a while, but it was all over the papers and everyone knew what he had done to me," she says. "In the end, I couldn't stand it and felt the only thing I could do was run away."

She finished her GCSEs, took a job washing up in a restaurant for three weeks to save enough money for a train ticket to London, and then ran.

"The worst thing was that no one would listen to me," she recalls. "I was scared and nervous when I got on the train, but I felt I couldn't go back to the situation I had left behind. Kids will only run away if the situation they are in is so bad that living on the streets seems like a better option. Something has got to be really wrong to make a young person do a thing like that."

Marie was so terrified when she arrived at Euston station that she simply walked the streets for three days - too frightened of what might happen if she lay down and closed her eyes. "I felt so alone in the world," she says. "Nobody in my care home bothered to report me missing. The streets are full of homeless young people crying out for love."

Marie was one of an estimated 129,000 young people who run away each year. The commonest reasons for children taking flight include desperation at not being listened to, rows with parents over the amount of freedom they are allowed, bullying at school, and drug problems or abuse at home.

A new paper from the Social Exclusion Unit, Consultation on Young Runaways, highlights the problem and puts a variety of solutions to the problem out to consultation. By the age of 16, one in nine children will have run away for at least one night, with a quarter of those ending up sleeping rough. Some have to survive through begging, stealing or prostitution, and many are sexually abused on the streets.

While children like Marie, who have been in care, make up a large proportion of runaways (approximately four in 10), the report finds that 21% are fleeing stepfamilies, and 13% one-parent families, compared to 7% who live with both birth parents. But, contrary to stereotype, poverty was found not to be a significant factor leading to young people running away: those from leafy suburbs are just as likely to flee as those from deprived inner-city areas. The majority of runaways are aged between 13 and 16 and are more likely to be girls than boys (although boys tend to run away earlier and more often). It is not only a problem of troubled adolescence: an estimated 18,000 children under 11 also run away each year, of whom about a third are under eight. Shockingly, a further 18,000 children a year are thrown out by their parents. The report also notes that the longer runaways are away, the more vulnerable they become.

There is no national network of services in place, so emergency organisations like Childline find it very hard to refer children who phone in a crisis to appropriate local services. The report proposes a series of measures both to prevent young people from running away in the first place, and to provide decent support services when they do.

Plans include an interview for each young person who has run away to identify the reasons for fleeing, and to try to tackle them rather than just dumping the children back in the situation from which they have fled; a network of refuges so that young people are not forced to live rough; and the establishment of a named person in each area to co-ordinate services for runaways.

Chris, now 20, ran away from numerous care placements about 20 times. He believes that refuges are essential, but also that fundamental changes in the care system are necessary. "I was frightened on the streets," he recalls, "but I also felt free. I shoplifted to survive. I received no support in care. Nobody listened and I was bullied. For me, living on the streets was better than that."

Much of the data in the government's new report comes from research carried out by the Children's Society, which has been working with young runaways for the past 20 years. The charity's Penny Dean welcomed the report, but is urging the government to implement some of the proposals - such as providing children with interviews - right away rather than await the outcome of the three-month consultation process. A Social Exclusion Unit spokesman has responded that this would not be possible.

"I really hope the government won't delay over this," says Dean. "Young runaways are a very hard to reach group who need a lot of support. A lot of these young people view statutory agencies with mistrust, and we need a mechanism to draw together expertise from the voluntary sector to deliver the services young people want."

She condemns the lack of funding for refuges - Centrepoint in London is the only one in Britain - and argues that, although the concept of children's refuges was established in the 1989 Children Act, the money to run them has not been forthcoming from the government. Without such refuges, there is no safety net to protect children from the dangers of the streets. Besides the government recommendations, the Children's Society is calling for more early intervention to prevent running away; support and mediation for parents and children where families have divorced, separated or reformed, and more ethnically sensitive services.

Dorit Braun, of Parentline Plus, expresses concern about the number of children who run away from stepfamilies. Jealousy of a parent's new partner can fuel conflict between children and adults in stepfamilies, she says. "Many children do adjust well, but a small minority don't. The young people and the adults in a stepfamily need to be given time to understand each other. The dynamics of a stepfamily are much more complex than those in an intact family, and stepparents can be viewed by children as interfering and making a difficult situation worse."

The government has highlighted a small project in Gloucester called Astra (Alternative Solutions to Running Away), which employs just three part-time workers, as a model of good practice. The project works with young people who have run away to prevent recurrences. Staff listen to young people's concerns and then try to work with them, their parents and other agencies (such as schools and social services) to find solutions with which both the young people and their parents or carers are happy. Police estimate that the project has reduced the number of repeat runaways by 61%.

One former runaway, Sally, 14, says the project has helped her resolve a difficult situation with her mother: "My mum didn't like my friends, the way I dressed or the fact that I wore make-up, and she didn't like me going out. One day, I just didn't go home from school. I was scared because I didn't know where I could go. In the end, I stayed at a friend's house. Astra talked to my mum and talked to me. Now she gives me a bit more freedom, I understand her better and she understands me better."

Now that Marie is settled in London, studying for a university degree and living in a flat that a Children's Society-supported tenancy project helped to secure for her, the days of trudging around the capital's West End with nowhere to go seem very far off.

"I love my home," she says. "I've got my own front room, my own bedroom, a cat, friends and a normal life. I don't ever want to go through what I went through again. And if young people like me had more rights, they wouldn't have to either."

webTitle: Andy Martin on training his sons as surfers

fields.headline: Pipe dreams
fields.standfirst: With his championship surfing ambitions on the rocks,  Andy Martin decided on the next best thing - turning his sons into wave-riding winners
fields.trailText: With his championship surfing ambitions on the rocks, Andy Martin decided on the next best thing - turning his sons into wave-riding winners.
fields.body:
My sons still call me "dude". While most parents fondly foresee their children becoming rocket scientists, professional footballers or virtuoso violinists, my burning ambition was to turn them into beach bums. I was intent on passing on the baton of my own frustrated surfing fantasies.

Born in east London, I grew up dreaming of giant waves flattening the capital, drowning teachers and relatives alike, while I alone surfed away to freedom atop a passing tree. It was a bitter day for me when they installed the Thames flood barrier. So it was that I married an Australian (who had gone to the irresistibly named City Beach High School) and went on a surfing honeymoon, scouring every west coast in Europe that was accessible to a Golf GTi for unattainable perfection. We kept the marriage a dark secret from fellow wave aficionados, since it was written in the surfing bible that thou shalt not marry. But there are limits to the principle of deniability: having children is one of them.

I remember when our first son was born: it was a big winter in Hawaii. It always is. And I was stuck in England. I began to see the surfing bible's point. Fatherhood and surfing, the dude and the dad, seemed tragically incompatible. We named him Spencer after the number-one surfer in England. Jack was born two winters later. Determined to stick to my own bachelor-born agenda, I kept sneaking off to the North Shore of Oahu and hanging out with the parentally challenged big-wave crew over there, but with a nagging sense of guilt. Not to mention the growing self-critical suspicion that I was never going to make it as a full-on, hardcore surfer. Maybe I had started too late or - perish the thought - I was just not cool enough.

Then I had my revelation: kids were not a problem, they were a solution. They could live the dream for me, while I bathed in their reflected glory. I saw myself doing for surfing what Richard Williams - the father of Venus and Serena - had done for tennis: manufacturing a couple of supercool wave-riding prodigies. I bought them their first baggy boardshorts, packed extra sunblock and took them off to Hawaii with me.

They were seven and five. It was not too late for their initiation. They swam in deep and devious currents and started to take note of the rhythm of the ocean, to feel the pulse of the planet. They became dedicated wave-watchers at Sunset and Pipeline beaches. Big Wednesday, January 28 1998, when the biggest swell for 30 years hit the North Shore, miraculously coincided with their last day in the islands. The most epic sports contest in the world - the Quiksilver Eddie Aikau big-wave event, which only takes place when the surf hits a 20ft minimum - was called on, then called off again. It was just too damn big, even for Waimea Bay, the ultimate wave coliseum. But the little dudes were able to watch with me, transfixed on the beach at Log Cabins, as an elite corps of tow-in specialists hitched a ride aboard massive thundering smokers bigger than behemoths and beyond awesome.

They were hooked. After this surfeit of man-eating 40-footers, maybe it was not surprising that Spencer was so willing to enrol for surf lifesaving classes ("nipper division") in Australia. In fact, he had to be reassured that the summer surf in Perth rarely broke the 2ft barrier and the chances of a rogue monster rearing up on the horizon were minimal. Spencer was soon regularly catching waves, kneeling on his "foamy" (an elementary surfboard).

It wasn't until last summer that my future would-be surf god officially mastered the art. He graduated with flying colours from the O'Neill Surf Academy in Croyde Bay, Devon. Unlike Hawaii, the north shore of Devon was not being pounded by an epic all-time swell. It was a doddle to a boy with Spencer's credentials. My first sustained attempt to conquer the ocean wave in Bali, many years before, ended with me being skewered on rocks. Spencer, in contrast, threw himself into the foam with complete confidence, overseen and assisted by Team O'Neill. On his very first wave he was up and riding. His second was a clean, unbroken wall. His third he rode all the way into the beach, with flawless balance and style. The training had paid off. I looked on with a mix of pride and jealousy. I had always wanted Spencer to be a better surfer than I am - but not necessarily that much better quite so soon.

When an old American surfing friend of mine saw a kid riding his first wave, he observed with a sigh: "He'll never make President now." True, but at least Spencer would have a decent shot at the ASP (Association of Surfing Professionals) world championship or even - who knew? - the Eddie Aikau. I could already see him pulling into yawning 25ft tubes.

This pleasant fantasy was cut short by a crisis. "Y'know Australia in the winter?" he said as we caught a 1ft wave in together (and I, to my eternal shame, fell off). "Well, this is colder." I had always thought of the verb "chatter", as applied to teeth, as an exaggerated metaphor. My boy's teeth were not just chattering. They were having a seminar; they were delivering a sermon denouncing the perils of cold water. I couldn't blame the guy: I have always been a strictly warm-water, softcore kind of surfer myself. I had to take him off to play hide and seek in the dunes and unfreeze.

Around the time my son started going blue, I began to realise that I would never be the Richard Williams of surfing. Maybe I should have been yelling, "Get back on that board or you're never going to make champion 10 years from now!" (or whatever motivational line the fanatical-father textbook suggests). But something held me back. It may have been the premature deaths of a couple of old surfing buddies and that Great White that went about chewing up a local on our old beach in Australia.

There is a pushy, aggressive side to surfing, but there is also a laidback, fatalistic side - let it all happen, what the hell, so be it, don't struggle. As the insipid English sun did its best to beat down on me, I began to understand the vanity of trying to get your kids to be what you are not and live out your dreams vicariously. I wonder now whether I had kids precisely because I would never make the grade as a surfer and I was relying on my offspring to be great surfers for me. They were supposed to rectify my mistakes. Their success would ease my failure. But maybe they didn't really want to be surfers after all. Let them be rock stars, then, or ace movie directors.

Now I am convinced that there is only one thing worse than trying to turn your children into what you want to be and getting them to lead your fantasy life on your behalf. And that is making them into what, in reality, you already are (be it dentist or dustman) and having them follow in your footsteps. Maybe both attitudes are just variations on a narcissistic cloning mentality. From now on I want my children to be anything they want to be, except like me - or my alter ego, my more tanned and muscular extrapolated persona.

Besides, children have their own fantasies going, notably about what their parents should be. One night Spencer asked me where I was going. I said: "To a heavyweight world championship boxing match in London." He said: "Good luck, dude. I hope you win." I fear that I am doomed to disappoint his ambitions for me.

webTitle: How much pocket money to give?

fields.headline: Cash questions
fields.standfirst: Fergie's girls get £1 a week pocket money. Is that stingy?  Larry Elliott on the difficulty of setting kids' allowances
fields.trailText: Fergie's girls get £1 a week pocket money. Is that stingy? Larry Elliott on the difficulty of setting kids' allowances.
fields.body:
When it comes to parental dilemmas, life at the Dallas-style ranch occupied by Andy, Fergie and princesses Beatrice and Eugenie is the same as for any other family. Loaded the Yorks may be, but they still have to grapple with the issues that matter. Pocket money, for example.

Asked in an interview published this week whether her girls were given pocket money, Fergie replied: "Yes, and they have to keep a little account of it. I do about £1 a week at the moment. It needs to go up a bit, but it's not just handouts when they need it. They really have a great sense of responsibility, especially Beatrice. She's much more responsible than I am."

There we have it: the whole conundrum in one brief paragraph. There's the idea that we give children pocket money to teach them how to manage their own little budgets. There's Fergie's guilt that she might be erring on the side of stinginess. There's the notion that they should account for every penny - something with which Fergie has had her own problems in the past.

Sadly, however, the Duchess of York has fallen into the trap of believing she is in control of the pocket-money process. She isn't. We are fighting a losing battle, as the hard evidence proves. While adults struggle to get a decent pay rise, the latest survey by the Halifax showed pocket money rising by an inflation-busting 6.8% to an average of £1.88 per week. Pocket money has risen faster than inflation for the past decade.

There is good reason for this. While it is possible to take a stand against consumerism, your child will not admire you as a dedicated opponent of multinational capitalism but revile you as a hardhearted beast who is making them the laughing stock of Year Four.

Nor does it cut much ice to tell your offspring that it is their patriotic duty to help Gordon Brown prevent the economy from lurching into another boom-bust cycle. Any reasonably savvy child of Beatrice or Eugenie's age (12 and 11 respectively) will know that Brown is the biggest skinflint going and has more in his piggy bank than every child in the country put together.

That said, a Blairite emphasis on "rights and responsibilities" sometimes pays off. The child gets a set amount - say £1 a week - as a right, but can earn more if they show responsibility by making beds, washing the car, or simply being good. However, it won't work unless you get the incentive structure right. Given the choice of lolling on the sofa watching The Weakest Link or skivvying for considerably less than the minimum wage, kids will invariably plump for indolence.

But when it comes down to it, there are certain facts of life you have to accept. The first is that your iron financial resolve will crumble the moment your child gets you inside a bookshop. Parents are suckers for the "this book would be useful for my project on the Romans" routine and will never make the little darlings pay for it themselves. Don't worry about this. Think of books as an investment: capital spending for the future. It is entirely different from spending on wasteful consumer goods such as greasy burgers and teeth-rotting fizzy drinks.

Furthermore, the normal rules of prudent spending sometimes have to abandoned. For the nation, this is during a war; for a family, it is during a long car journey. In any motorway service station, you will find parents paying over the odds for batteries for personal CD players, crisps and sweets. Experience shows that the way to prevent sibling skirmishes in the back from turning into full-scale bloodbaths is to be fully armed with a small arsenal of over-priced goodies.

So how do things work in our house? One daughter saves, the other spends. Eight-year-old Eowyn has grasped the basics of simple interest, insisting that late payment of pocket money should mean extra bunce, while Ursula, 10, has found that skilful use of Keynesian deficit spending - borrowing money - can help in her singlehanded crusade to keep the UK music industry afloat.

They are due a rise, but what should it be? An increase of 1.9% in line with underlying inflation seems a bit mean, so let's take the 4.4% increase in earnings, rounded up to 5%. From April 1, it's no longer a pound but a guinea. Each, of course.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The question: New research says parents favour sanctions - such as 'grounding' - to discipline unruly teenagers. Do they work?
fields.trailText: The question: New research says parents favour sanctions - such as 'grounding' - to discipline unruly teenagers. Do they work?
fields.body:
Madeline Portwood
Educational psychologist and mother

The first thing a parent has to decide is what's going to be meaningful to a teenager. If you ground them but they can stay in and play computer games, it won't necessarily be that meaningful to them. Parents make endless threats, but they must carry them out and they must be realistic. It's also important for teenagers to see sanctions as just. If the teacher behaves the same way to all the pupils, they accept it. If there is more than one child in the family, parents have to apply sanctions equally. As children get older, sanctions often become meaningless to them.
Verdict: Not often

David Spellman
Father and psychologist working with disturbed teenagers

I think you can turn sanctions round and offer rewards instead, which can motivate teenagers. Parents should reward the behaviour they want to see. There does seem to be a great preoccupation with punishment. It's quite clear to me that parents' relationships with teenagers are much better if they focus on the positive and acknowledge and appreciate their children. It is quite easy to get into a negative, punitive position as a parent which is often self-defeating. Every teenager is different and they can't just be lumped together into one group and all treated the same.
Verdict: No

Theresa Gill
Mother and nursery nurse

My oldest son is 13 and he hasn't really stepped out of line so far, but if he did get to that Kevin and Perry stage, I would withdraw luxuries such as his mobile phone, computer and football training. While he lives in my house, he has to obey the rules. Once he's 18 and out of the house, he can do as he pleases. My siblings and I were given quite a lot of freedom by our parents: their reasoning was that if we were going to do something anyway, they would rather we did it at home - and we've all turned out to be quite well balanced.
Verdict: Yes

John Peel
Father and radio presenter

I don't think we really employed sanctions with our children because I just don't think they work. They are sullen, unhelpful and resentful if you do that. I think that, actually, their reluctance to help out with things caused us more anxiety than the things they did that we wished they hadn't. It was more about galvanising them into some sort of action. One of the things I always tried to avoid was drawing a line in the sand. If a child has any sort of character, she or he will want to step over it. They are all nice people and we like being with them - you can't ask for more than that.
Verdict: No

Grant McNally
Social worker and father

I operate a contract system with my two boys who are 11 and 13. We have all signed it and breaches of behaviour result in a loss of privileges such as docking of pocket money or grounding. Some flexibility is important, but if the contract is altered too much, the boundaries start collapsing. My older son works well with it, but my younger son has behavioural problems and that makes things harder to manage. It is difficult when you try to be a non-authoritarian and inclusive parent and recognise children's rights. But parents have rights, too - like the right to a stress-free life.
Verdict: Yes

Tim Burke
Spokesperson for the National Youth Agency

Applying sanctions to a young person can be a bit like prison: it may work for some people on some occasions, but for many others it's counter-productive, especially when used inappropriately. Some degree of conflict between parents and teenagers is inevitable: young people need to push the envelope - it's part of growing up and finding out who they are. Self-imposed boundaries that they have arrived at through their own experience and reflection are more effective. Our organisation supports youth workers who help young people learn about themselves and about how to be members of their communities.
Verdict: No
