fields.headline: Foot and mouth vaccination
fields.standfirst:
The government is considering adopting a full-scale vaccination programme to combat the foot and mouth epidemic, and is seeking EU permission to create 'firewalls' against the spread. Derek Brown explains the relative merits of inoculation

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The government is considering adopting a full-scale vaccination programme to combat the foot and mouth epidemic, and is seeking EU permission to create 'firewalls' against the spread. Derek Brown explains the relative merits of inoculation.
fields.body:
Why vaccinate?
To contain the spread of foot and mouth. Those in favour of vaccination say that the present policy of mass slaughter isn't working - there are simply too many animals to be killed.

Does vaccination work?
Not invariably. Pigs are particularly unpredictable.

Would all animals have to be vaccinated?
That would be impossible, given that there are 60m cattle, sheep and pigs in Britain, not to speak of a million deer and countless other wild animals which can contract or carry the disease. What the pro-vaccine camp wants is a programme of "ring" vaccination, around infected farms and abattoirs. Animals within the cordon sanitaire would be vaccinated, and slaughtered later, when the disease is under control.

What are the disadvantages of vaccination?
It's expensive. Treatment needs to be repeated every six months, and given to each new generation of animals. It is not 100% reliable. The adoption of vaccination as a policy is a tacit admission that foot and mouth has not been eradicated.

Why do many farmers with healthy animals to protect still resist vaccination?
Their main argument is that it is impossible to distinguish between vaccinated animals, and those with the disease. That could mean the loss of Britain's disease-free status, and the destruction of the £1bn+ meat export trade. However, according to EU rules, a limited vaccination programme would not necessarily mean an export ban.

Hasn't the export trade gone already?
There is a total ban on export of meat and live animals, so long as the disease persists. That is why most farmers favour drastic action to end the crisis as quickly as possible.

fields.bodyText: Why vaccinate? To contain the spread of foot and mouth. Those in favour of vaccination say that the present policy of mass slaughter isn't working - there are simply too many animals to be killed. Does vaccination work? Not invariably. Pigs are particularly unpredictable. Would all animals have to be vaccinated? That would be impossible, given that there are 60m cattle, sheep and pigs in Britain, not to speak of a million deer and countless other wild animals which can contract or carry the disease. What the pro-vaccine camp wants is a programme of "ring" vaccination, around infected farms and abattoirs. Animals within the cordon sanitaire would be vaccinated, and slaughtered later, when the disease is under control. What are the disadvantages of vaccination? It's expensive. Treatment needs to be repeated every six months, and given to each new generation of animals. It is not 100% reliable. The adoption of vaccination as a policy is a tacit admission that foot and mouth has not been eradicated. Why do many farmers with healthy animals to protect still resist vaccination? Their main argument is that it is impossible to distinguish between vaccinated animals, and those with the disease. That could mean the loss of Britain's disease-free status, and the destruction of the £1bn+ meat export trade. However, according to EU rules, a limited vaccination programme would not necessarily mean an export ban. Hasn't the export trade gone already? There is a total ban on export of meat and live animals, so long as the disease persists. That is why most farmers favour drastic action to end the crisis as quickly as possible. webTitle: The real reason Labour wants to run for it

fields.headline: The real reason Labour wants to run for it
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Labour party
fields.trailText: One can only admire the plucky defiance of metropolitan pundits and politicians. But I can find no enthusiasm whatever for a May election. Why do we need one?
fields.body:
One can only admire the plucky defiance of metropolitan pundits and politicians. "Go, go, go!" the Sun yells. "Bring on the election," chants the New Labour cheerleader Sion Simon, joyfully waving his pompoms. But beyond the fertile Islington prairies and the green pastures of Clapham, where sheep may safely graze, I can find no enthusiasm whatever for a May election. Why do we need one?

One point often made by the go-go-go brigade in recent weeks is that Ted Heath went to the country in February 1974, during a miners' strike. This is a false analogy: Heath called that election not in spite of the emergency but because of it. The silly ass asked the electors: "Who governs Britain?" To which they replied: "Clearly not you, matey." Not a useful precedent for the Blairites to cite - especially since they are the self-same people who keep assuring us that there is no national crisis.

Another argument, now heard almost hourly, is that our international reputation will be in tatters unless the prime minister requests a dissolution of parliament. "This is how Britain will look to the world if Blair postpones the May 3 election," a front-page editorial in the Sun warns. "We would be saying: This nation is closed for business. We would be saying to foreigners: Do not come here and spend your money." John Prescott, John Reid and Clive Soley agree, as do most leader-writers. "There can be no delay at the polls," the Independent on Sunday insists. "It would send out a misleadingly alarming signal to the rest of the world."

The language is baffling (how can the PM "postpone" or "delay" an election that hasn't been called?), and the hyperbole downright ridiculous. Foreigners may well be frightened by our foot and mouth epidemic, but do the eccentricities of our electoral system influence their holiday plans? I'm reminded of FE Smith's allegation that the Welsh disestablishment bill had "shocked the conscience of every Christian community in Europe" - a comment which provoked GK Chesterton's famous retort: "Chuck it, Smith!" From Connecticut to Cape Town, if Messrs Prescott, Reid and Soley are to be believed, anxious souls are ready to cancel their London holidays if Blair decides to serve the full five years for which he was elected in 1997.

The idea is manifestly incredible. Why, then, must we have an early election? One genuine reason was blurted out by Jack Straw recently, when a BBC interviewer pointed out that Labour had not halved the time between arrest and sentencing of young offenders - even though this was one of the five "key pledges" printed on pocket-sized cards in 1997 so that voters "can see we keep our promises". Ah yes, the home secretary replied, but if you read the small print you'll find that we promised to achieve that only "over a five-year term".

But this alone is scarcely a sufficient explanation for the Blairites' urgent desire to go to the polls after only four years. A more obvious motive, which no minister dares admit, is fear of an economic downturn. Japan and the US are already on the brink of recession; in an era of globalised goods and capital it's difficult to see how Britain can escape infection for long. Gordon Brown's favourite mantra - "there can be no return to boom and bust" - might soon be greeted with the howls of derision it so richly deserves.

New Labour promised from the outset that it would not use budgetary policy to regulate demand. This left the Treasury with only one economic lever - control of interest rates. But Brown promptly abdicated responsibility for that too. His policy - or, rather, non-policy - consists of little more than watching the financial markets and hoping for the best. Thanks to this neo-liberal nonsense, we are almost wholly undefended against the virus now afflicting America and Japan.

Hence the note of panic one detects in ministers and their media friends as they plead with Blair not to "delay". To paraphrase Karl Marx: it's the economy, stupid. The modernisers of New Labour are exploiting an ancient British tradition which one might call the second-hand car dealer's dodge: complete the sale on a wheezing old jalopy before it breaks down.

Quite why a democracy should permit one side in an electoral contest to rig the ballot in this fashion has always mystified me. One of the original demands of the 19th century Chartists was for a new parliament to be elected every year on the first Monday in June. "We may nowadays laugh," Julius West wrote in his History of the Chartist Movement, "at the state of mind which could contemplate with equanimity, indeed with pleasure, the prospect of an annual general election." Maybe so, but the essential principle was sound enough and has lately been revived by Tony Wright MP. Under his fixed-term parliaments bill, introduced in the Commons on March 1, there would be an election every four years - no more, no less - except if the ruling party suffers a vote of no-confidence in the house.

Ministers will have some difficulty in arguing against the proposal, especially since they imposed just such a system on the Scottish parliament. If it's good enough for the Scots, why not for the rest of us? The bill's second reading is due on Friday April 6 - which may be yet another reason for Blair to dispatch MPs to the hustings before then. As Wright points out, the Labour party used to be committed to a fixed-term parliament. "I'm not sure why we are no longer in favour," he said recently, "apart from our being in power."

Er, quite.

Byers bullies sellers but fights shy of Bowers

A headline in the Sunday Telegraph reveals that "Taxpayer will fund Byers libel fight". Maddeningly, it doesn't say which particular taxpayer has been chosen for this honour. Geoffrey Robinson, perhaps?

In my rare sightings of him, Stephen Byers has always seemed an amiable if uninteresting chap: "Mandelson-Lite", as someone called him. Now that he is sending minatory letters to blameless booksellers, this verdict may have to be reviewed. It is only bullies such as Jimmy Goldsmith who threaten mere distributors. How can newsagents or bookshop managers possibly vet everything that they sell? If the trade secretary thinks he has been defamed he should sue Tom Bower, author of The Paymaster.

Bower claims that Geoffrey Robinson was paid £200,000 by one of Robert Maxwell's companies, Hollis. No great shame in that: if everyone who took the Maxwell shilling was obliged to retire in disgrace, there would be many empty desks in Fleet Street, the City and Westminster. Robinson's offence was to deny the Maxwell payment. Like Peter on the night of Jesus's betrayal, he swore: "I know not the man." Yea, and he denied him thrice - to the House of Commons, to the prime minister and in his memoirs.

And the cock crew. And a DTI investigator found documentary evidence of the £200,000 cheque. And Byers, who had previously promised to be "as open as possible on these matters", slipped a written answer into Hansard on December 21 1999 (when everyone was preoccupied with Christmas parties) saying that the Hollis inquiry was now over and no further action would be taken.

Byers is furious at Bower's suggestion that he "buried" the report, insisting that he delegated the decision to civil servants. If so, he could become the first cabinet minister in history to demand libel damages for an allegation that he was responsible for the actions of his own department. Is it any wonder that, so far, he has been all mouth and no writ?

fields.headline: BBC2 targets older viewers
fields.trailText:
4pm update: BBC2 will focus on 30 to 50-something viewers as new youth-oriented digital channel BBC3 develops, writes Jason Deans.

Mar 27: 'General' Root talks of ratings war

Mar 27: Jane Root Q&A

BBC2 spring season line-up
fields.body:
BBC2 is to concentrate on serving older, 30 to 50-something viewers as new youth-oriented digital channel BBC3 develops.

Mark Thompson, BBC director of television, confirmed this was likely to become BBC2's focus as BBC Choice developed into BBC3.

"But even if we're targeting people in their 30s, 40s and 50s, we'll still want a young, contemporary feel to the channel, because that's what the audience wants," Mr Thompson said.

He added that BBC2 stars such as Jamie Oliver and Gary Rhodes, for instance, were popular with women in their 50s.

Mr Thompson, speaking at launch of BBC2's spring/summer season, said this was not a "retreat" by BBC2 away from a younger audience, but a "focus on what has historically been our core audience".

"The BBC2 audience has always been slightly older than Channel 4 or BBC1 viewers. They are more interested in documentaries and history."

Mr Thompson said factual programming such as Horizon and Timewatch formed the core of the channel and would remain so.

"In amongst that core factual output there's still a commitment to original comedy, entertainment and drama," he added. "But the heart of the channel is factual.

"In the past I think [Channel 4 boss] Michael Jackson and myself may have underestimated the importance of these core factual programmes in an attempt to be funky and attract a younger audience."

Mr Thompson said that as BBC Choice evolved into BBC3, the new channel's focus would be on younger audiences and talent.

"You will see BBC3 carrying the baton in terms of edgy programming. But BBC2 will still do edgy stuff."

webTitle: Jessica Duchen meets pianist Mitsuko Uchida

fields.headline: Some of my best friends are pianos
fields.standfirst: Mitsuko Uchida talks to  Jessica Duchen
fields.trailText: Mitsuko Uchida talks to Jessica Duchen.
fields.body:
Pianist Mitsuko Uchida has strong opinions about tea. "I drink only Darjeeling, and I am very particular about where it comes from," she says. This is no ordinary stuff: it is harvested from the first flush of tea leaves in a particular field in the Himalayas, you can only buy it in Paris and you have to drink it black. "And if you don't like it, you accept it anyway," she beams. As it is with tea, so it is with music: she has fantastically high standards.

Though born in Japan, 52-year-old Uchida grew up and trained in Vienna; and, after an initial reaction against the city's stuffiness and traditionalism, she has made its music, especially Mozart and Schubert, the core of her repertoire. But the Mozart concertos she will be performing next week on London's South Bank - K413, 414 and 415 - won't look, at first, like concertos. She is playing them not with an orchestra, but a string quartet.

The chamber version of the concertos is Mozart's own, and every bit as rewarding as the original scoring for small orchestra. But are they still concertos? "I was thinking the other day what the definition of a piano concerto is," says Uchida. "The difference between Mozart's piano sonatas and piano concertos is that the sonatas are personal pieces: even the biggest and strongest you can still play just for yourself. His piano concertos are, as a genre, the most special, beautiful and strongest of his works, just half a notch behind his operas. But it's also true that these pieces were written to show off what he could do. And that gives it an extra kick."

For some musicians, Mozart is the most difficult of all composers to perform successfully - the ultimate test of both technical and spiritual accomplishment. Uchida doesn't necessarily see it that way. "Of course, Mozart is very, very, very difficult. But for me, personally, Beethoven might be more difficult - his difficulties lie somewhere else. Mozart's difficulties arise possibly because it is the least overblown of music. That makes it more difficult to perform because everything is so transparent and visible. It is seemingly simple, but only seemingly. It is horrendously complicated; it is as complicated as human emotions are.

"Mozart knew and saw and could transform all the various combinations of colours of emotion into sound and make them beautiful. That was his strength. Shakespeare used certain very simple words that any idiot can use and suddenly they were transported. Mozart does the same."

Uchida talks the way she plays. Much of the time her voice is very quiet: you have to sit forward and concentrate hard. Then, suddenly, she will let forth a sky-high flare of emphasis. In both conversation and performance the fierce, dynamic intelligence, lack of compromise, lucid argument and intimate, private yet entirely audible sensitivity to the inner life of music are the same. On the platform, she says, she does not think about projecting to the back row of the gallery. Instead, she wants to draw the audience down to her, to make the hall "shrink".

This is why she prefers to perform on one of her own concert pianos, housed (with several more) in a studio close to her home. "To be able to take your own piano to a concert hall is a luxury," she enthuses. "Because on my own pianos I can play so quietly that nobody thought it possible. The set-up is such that I can play quieter and quieter and it still has more to give. That never happens on any other instrument. The younger piano is 11 years old, the older one is a 1962 I have owned since 1982. They are friends of mine. I shall take one of them for the Mozart concertos."

The intimate atmosphere works. On the way to a concert, an audience member would normally say they're going to hear Kissin, or Pletnev, or whoever. But before an Uchida recital it's simply, "I'm going to hear Mitsuko." This is a pianist whose audience spontaneously calls her by her first name. Next week there's a chance to see why.

 Mitsuko Uchida and the Brentano String Quartet play Mozart at the Royal Festival Hall, London SE1 (020-7960 4242) on April 3.

fields.headline: Estonia set for online elections
fields.trailText: On the same day the cabinet minister, Mo Mowlam, said that Britain is not ready for an internet election, the Estonian government yesterday announced plans to move to electronic voting in time for the country's 2003 general elections.
fields.body:
On the same day the cabinet minister, Mo Mowlam, said that Britain is not ready for an internet election, the Estonian government yesterday announced plans to move to electronic voting in time for the country's 2003 general elections.

The Estonian ambassador to London, Raul Mälk, said his government hoped the move to online voting will attract greater participation in elections and political debate, especially among young people.

He said that after independence, the government thought everyone would take part in elections, and in early polls three quarters of the electorate voted. But in the last general election in 1999, only little more than half of the possible voters took part.

Exactly how the voting will take place - over the internet or on offline, networked computers at polling stations - will be detailed by the country's justice minister next week. The computerised system will replace a complex paper-based polling system.

The British government has no current plans to move to online or electronic voting, and the issue is not included in the prime minister's goal to offer all government services online by 2005.

Discussing her view that Britain is not ready to vote online, Mo Mowlam said yesterday: "The internet at the moment provides for the minority new ways of participating democratically, while the majority that are disconnected remain excluded."

The digital divide is also causing concern in the US. When the Democratic party ran its presidential primary election in Arizona online last year, the justice department expressed concerns about minority voters being locked out of the democratic process for economic reasons.

But Mr Mälk said the government of Estonia is not concerned about the digital divide affecting voting. "I don't agree that people will be disenfranchised. They can always go to the polling station and vote in the normal way," he said.

Britain is not alone in shunning online voting for the moment. In the US, two studies have advised the government to go slow on internet voting due to security concerns.

Kim Brace, the president of US firm Election Data Services said: "The advice has been not to allow online voting from an individual's home or office computer because of security issues. The county should control the computer, perhaps at a polling station."

Mr Mälk acknowledged that security is a major concern but believed a combination of digital signatures and smart card identification will eliminate fraud.

He said: "One of the worries is the opportunity for intrusion into a site. The Estonian prime minister was taking part in an online debate when a hacker captured the line and answered a question as though he was the prime minister."

The incident convinced the government of the prime importance of security. "When you have elections, you must be absolutely sure," he added.

fields.headline: Potter works magic for Bloomsbury
fields.trailText: 3.15pm: JK Rowling's latest Harry Potter bestseller pushed Bloomsbury Publishing's pre-tax profits up 120% to £5.8m, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Bloomsbury Publishing remains spellbound by the Harry Potter phenomenon, after the child wizard's latest adventures sent profits soaring at the book publisher.

Bloomsbury said the fourth book in the series, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, helped push pre-tax profits up 120% to £5.8m last year.

Turnover more than doubled to £50.8m as JK Rowling's bestseller, published in July last year, became the fastest selling book in history.

"The future looks bright for Bloomsbury. Harry Potter is a long-term asset that will continue to generate significant earnings well into the future," said Nigel Newton, chairman of Bloomsbury.

Mr Newton added that the forthcoming Harry Potter film, produced by US film studio Warner Brothers, is likely to boost sales even further.

"In the short term, the film of book one, due for release at the end of the year, will trigger a huge awakening of interest among those who have yet to read the books, expanding the market significantly," said Mr Newton.

Bloomsbury's other hits included Booker Prize winner the Blind Assassin by Margaret Atwood, and Anil's Ghost by Michael Ondaatje, author of the English Patient.

The group was surprisingly bullish about maintaining its earning growth, given the company's current success is entirely down to a single author.

"Our strong growth has spurred us on to seek greater growth for the future," said Mr Newton.

webTitle: UK TV posts record sales abroad

fields.headline: UK TV posts record sales abroad
fields.trailText: 3pm: The UK TV industry has achieved record sales abroad helped by programme format such as Millionaire, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The sale of successful formats such as Who Wants to be a Millionaire?, Survivor and Queer as Folk has helped the UK TV industry to achieve record sales abroad.

Revenues from the sale of UK TV programmes rose 5% to reach £380m last year, according to figures released today by the British Television Distributors' Association.

The biggest growth area was the sale of programme concepts for foreign broadcasters to adapt for their home markets.

Celador's Who Wants to be a Millionaire? has spawned local versions in 56 countries while Target's Popstars sold to 18 countries.

And the trend towards selling programme concepts rather than the finished product has also spread to drama. Channel 4 International's Queer as Folk and Granada's Cold feet were both made into successful US shows last year.

"These figures provide a clear indicator as to the changes in supply and demand in the TV industry," said Mike Phillips, director of international TV at BBC Worldwide and chairman of the BTDA.

"As channels proliferate, the competition for audiences becomes more intense. Broadcasters search for a home-run hit that can cut through the clutter. They also look for great formats and programme concepts that can be adapted locally."

webTitle: Police face the truth about cannabis

fields.headline: Police face the truth about cannabis
fields.standfirst:
The Scotland Yard chief who wants new terms of engagement in the war against drugs speaks for many colleagues, says crime correspondent Nick Hopkins.

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The Scotland Yard chief who wants new terms of engagement in the war against drugs speaks for many colleagues, says crime correspondent Nick Hopkins
fields.body:
"Arresting people for smoking dope is pointless."  "It's a waste of time, the war is lost."

Who said that? The male singers in S-Club 7? Howard Marks?

No. A high-ranking officer at Scotland Yard, prepared to voice his frustration in private, but not, as yet, in public. He is not alone in holding those views.

In policing terms, cannabis possession has not been a priority for years. But there isn't a senior detective in the country willing to put his head above the parapet to say it in such blunt terms, for fear of being shot down by politicians and the rightwing press, who are notoriously trigger-happy on the subject of drugs.

Commander Brian Paddick almost said the unthinkable yesterday. The man in charge of policing in Lambeth, south London, wants to change the way his officers treat the possession of cannabis.

Instead of arresting and charging users, confiscation and a verbal warning should be enough, he argues.

If Cdr Paddick pushes this commitment through, Lambeth will be the first area in the country to have an official policy to treat drug-users this way.

He is not making up rules on the hoof. The Home Office has been whispering encouragement to the police. "[Officers] can issue written warnings and may make a conditional offer of a fixed penalty," says the discretionary guideline on drug possession. It does not say explicitly: you can be soft on drugs. It's more of a nudge and wink.

The police have been right to treat the guideline with caution; government sensitivity to the issue might be gauged by the cool reaction to Cdr Paddick's initiative.

"This is a policing matter," said the Home Office, adding, somewhat disingenuously, "it's nothing to do with us."

The Association of Chief Police Officers was also reluctant to be seen supporting the move. Sir John Stevens, the Met commissioner, is, apparently watching from the sidelines "with a great deal of interest."

So, poor Cdr Paddick is out on his own, and every other senior police officer in the UK is waiting to see whether he gets buried in bad publicity before having the nerve to say in public what they have all agreed in private. If Cdr Paddick survives, then expect other forces to follow the precedent.

With cannabis possession accounting for up to 85% of more than 120,000 countrywide drug busts a year, it is easy to imagine how much time and money the police can save by easing up on users, and concentrating their efforts on more serious offences.

The police say they don't want to legalise cannabis, which is true. But they don't want to treat possession as a crime either.

Another detective, without Cdr Paddick's courage in going on the record, put it like this: "If we police cannabis possession in the way some people expect us to, every cell and every prison in the country would be full to bursting.

"The world moves on, we've got to move on. We must stop pretending this is a priority for us, because it isn't."

fields.headline: Games of two halves
fields.trailText: Tensions spilled over into sport in Northern Ireland last month, when a section of the crowd at a soccer friendly against Norway hurled abuse at home midfielder Neil Lennon for the "crime" of playing for Glasgow Celtic, a traditionally Catholic team.The incident has spurred the Irish Football Association (IFA) to publish a new code of conduct and introduce a registration system for fans.
fields.body:
Tensions spilled over into sport in Northern Ireland last month, when a section of the crowd at a soccer friendly against Norway hurled abuse at home midfielder Neil Lennon for the "crime" of playing for Glasgow Celtic, a traditionally Catholic team.The incident has spurred the Irish Football Association (IFA) to publish a new code of conduct and introduce a registration system for fans.

Northern Ireland is exempt from the 1991 Football Offences Act, tightened in 1999, which bans "indecent or racialist" chanting. The IFA wants the legislation extended to the province, where sectarian divisions are reflected across the sporting spectrum. Rugby union and soccer have in the past been majority Protestant sports, although this is changing slowly. The Gaelic Athletic Association retains a ban on members of the Protestant- dominated security forces, despite recent legislation aimed at recruiting more Catholic police officers.

webTitle: Donnygate fraudsters retain Labour party membership

fields.headline: Donnygate fraudsters retain Labour party membership
fields.trailText: Exclusive:Emotions are running high in Doncaster, where the councillors convicted of fiddling their expenses have been allowed to keep their Labour party membership, and where the local authority has clawed back only half the money that was fraudulently claimed.
fields.body:
The Doncaster Labour councillors found guilty of defrauding their own authority have never been expelled from the party, despite New Labour's boasts that it would sweep sleaze from town hall corridors.

None of the 18 councillors successfully prosecuted for falsifying their expenses has had their party card revoked. Even those that have been sent to jail have been allowed to retain their Labour membership.

It has also emerged that Doncaster council intends to recoup just half of the money owed to it by councillors who falsified their expenses - because it believes it cannot "realistically" recover more.

The authority estimates it was owed £7,920 but has attempted to claw back only £3,960, of which it calculates it has received £2,790.

Two of the councillors convicted over fraudulent expenses claims have yet to make an acceptable offer of repayment to the council.

The revelations come as police reveal that an imminent trial of leading Doncaster councillors on charges of receiving corrupt payments and of false accounting could last up to six months.

Ray Stockhill, the council's former deputy leader, Peter Birks, planning chairman, and John Dainty, the leader of the Conservative group, face charges of accepting bribes.

The Labour party's commitment to expel corrupt councillors stems back three years, when Tony Blair told a Labour local government conference that corrupt members would be sacked immediately under a tough "one strike and you're out" regime.

He told delegates in Scarborough in February 1998 that the party would set up hit squads to root out corrupt or incompetent councils. "If authorities cannot or will not take the lead, we will have the powers to intervene," he said.

"I know corruption is not widespread. That is precisely why one case is one case too many. For us in the Labour party, it's one strike and you're out."

A spokeswoman for the Labour party told SocietyGuardian: "The Labour party has suspended from office and representation all those members arrested and charged during the course of the Doncaster police inquiry.

"This inquiry is still ongoing, as are a number of prosecutions and the party, therefore, has no comment to make on any individual cases until the relevant procedures and inquiry have been completed.

"However, the party expects the highest standard of probity in its public representatives and will always take appropriate action where these standards are breached."

A spokeswoman for Doncaster council defended the council's decision not to recoup all the "expenses" owed to it by the councillors.

"We have to go for the maximum we realistically believe we can recover. The principle is you go for what you can expect to get back," she said.

But the council confirmed that its debt recovery "principle" did not apply to members of the public taken to court for council tax arrears. She said that in such cases, "we would seek full collection of council tax".

Margaret Pinkney, a 71-year-old widow who stood as an Independent councillor on an anti-corruption ticket in Doncaster three years ago, called the decision a "total disgrace".

She said: "Never mind them paying only half back, this is money they stole from the authority. We should have the full sum with interest on it.

"This wouldn't happen with people owing council tax arrears. There seems to be a different rule if you have represented the Labour party."

The first Doncaster councillor charged with fraud appeared in court in July 1998. Since then a further 17 Labour councillors have appeared before the courts. None of them has been expelled from the party.

To date prosecutions have been over relatively trivial misdemeanours such as fiddling expenses by using council money to pay for nights in hotels or claiming first class travel when only booking standard class.

Most of the disgraced councillors have either resigned or lost their seats at local elections, but three who were found guilty of defrauding the authority still retain their seats, and each draw £8,600 in annual expenses.

Cllrs Steve Judge, Michael McAteer and Mike Farrington still sit on the council because under section 80 of the 1972 Local Government Act a person can be disqualified and forced to give up their seat in the council chamber only if he or she received a court sentence of three or more months, suspended or otherwise.

Ms Pinkney said: "The perspective of the people out there is that we are a rotten council and, although I resent being included in that, I can fully understand the feeling in the town.

"Too often the people of Doncaster have been asked to put the past behind them but as soon as they do, another councillor is arrested and it all comes back again.

"In 1997, the people put great trust in Tony Blair, but now so many are disillusioned with him because he has failed to put his house in order.

"These Labour party members should have been dealt with and thrown out of the party as soon as they were found guilty. He must take responsibility for what has happened."

webTitle: Corruption in Doncaster's corridors of power

fields.headline: Corruption in Doncaster's corridors of power
fields.trailText: Up to now, the prosecutions of corrupt Doncaster councillors have been mainly for fiddling expenses, but soon the stakes will be raised. And for the first time, a Conservative councillor is going into the dock. Paul Humphries reports
fields.body:
For more than 10 years, Doncaster-based playwright Ron Rose, a Labour party stalwart, had been telling those in the upper reaches of the party that all was not well in the corridors of power at Doncaster.

One of his best friends, actor Tony Booth - Cherie's Blair's father - had even spoken with his son-in-law and told him of Mr Rose's allegations. But it came to nothing. Instead of the Labour party putting its own house in order, it was left to the statutory powers - in this instance the district auditor - to act.

There had long been rumours of massive council junkets. Foreign trips with club class flights were on offer to the elite group of councillors and senior officers, all paid for from the public purse. The drink flowed at free bars as councillors and their guests lived it up at the municipally owned Doncaster Racecourse.

Councillors would attend a three-day conference at a coastal resort and decide to stay on a few more days with the council taxpayers picking up the bill. Another councillor put a bill in for a conference he never even attended.

In 1997, following a report by the district auditor on the council's spending, the council leader, Peter Welsh, and his deputy, Ray Stockhill, resigned. Officers from South Yorkshire police fraud squad moved in and Operation Danum was set up, a long-running investigation that to date has taken in expenses, bribes, land deals and the awarding of contracts.

It was following the resignation of Mr Welsh that new leader, Malcolm Glover, pledged to restore the council's reputation. Tony Blair publicly backed his leadership on a visit to South Yorkshire in early 1998.

Unfortunately for Mr Blair, Mr Glover was arrested in November of that year. He was later found guilty on three counts of falsifying his expenses and given a suspended prison sentence.

Up to now, the prosecutions of councillors have been mainly for fiddling expenses, but soon the stakes will be raised. And for the first time, a councillor other than a Labour one is going into the dock. Conservative leader John Dainty faces two charges of receiving corrupt payments and one of false accounting. He denies the charges.

Former planning chairman Peter Birks faces an allegation of corruptly receiving a gift of his farmhouse home and false accounting. Mr Stockhill, the council's former deputy leader, is charged with one offence of receiving corrupt payments. Mr Stockhill is also charged with five offences of false accounting. Both Mr Birks and Mr Stockhill deny the charges

A further three councillors - Jack Meredith, Danny Buckley, and Ron Gillis face false accounting charges. They deny the charges. Councillors Peter Welsh and Keith Martin also face false accounting charges.

fields.headline: Root talks of ratings war with C4
fields.standfirst:
Q&A: Jane Root
BBC2 spring season line-up
fields.trailText:
12pm: BBC2 controller Jane Root has confessed she felt like a "world war one general" competing with Channel 4 on Friday nights, writes Jason Deans.
Q&A: Jane Root
BBC2 spring season line-up
fields.body:
BBC2 controller Jane Root has confessed she felt like a "world war one general" competing with Channel 4 on Friday nights.

She said competition with the firepower of the rival station's big US hits Frasier and Friends was so intense she felt virtually helpless.

"With comedy on Friday night I was feeling like one of those world war one generals, sending new sitcoms over the top and saying to the producer 'Don't worry, it's only up against Frasier'.

"To keep doing the more experimental stuff I had to find another place for it."

BBC2 has now retreated from the Friday night battle with Channel 4 and is developing Monday night as its comedy zone.

So far it has had success with new shows such as Two Pints of Lager and a Packet of Crisps starring Royle Family actor Ralph Little, which pulled in 3m viewers.

In an interview with MediaGuardian.co.uk, Ms Root has also revealed how she feared losing out when BBC director general Greg Dyke decided to remake BBC1 starting with the move of the Nine O'Clock News to 10pn.

"I must admit I didn't think it would necessarily be positive for BBC2 - I thought we might lose out in an all-out war between BBC1 and ITV."

webTitle: Hoddle's on his way to Tottenham ...

fields.headline: Hoddle's on his way to Tottenham ...
fields.standfirst: ... but are Spurs gonna do it again? Sean Ingle isn't too sure
fields.trailText: ... but are Spurs gonna do it again? Sean Ingle isn't too sure.
fields.body:
Now Glenn Hoddle is on his way to White Hart Lane, are the Tottenham really gonna do it again?

Well, maybe. But don't expect a return to the glory days of push and run football, nine-goal thrillers and Chas'n' Dave classics any time soon. Hoddle the manager is a lot different than Hoddle the player.

Southampton's success this season - they currently lie eighth, heading for their highest-ever finish in the Premiership - is due to their strength at the back. Their recent record of seven successive clean sheets in the league would make even George Graham blush. Meanwhile, Marian Pahars, their most exciting player, is confined to the wing in Hoddle's preferred 4-5-1 formation.

The Saints aren't always pretty but they are effective. When Hoddle took over at the Dell just over a year ago, the club were sinking in the relegation mire. Now they are spying a place in Europe. If Hoddle can do the same at Spurs, the hate and the hurt of the Graham era will soon evaporate.

And Hoddle's appointment should have one immediate benefit: the retention of Sol Campbell. Everyone knew that Campbell and Graham didn't get on, and because of that Campbell was ready to leave. With Hoddle on board, and Enic dangling a £65,000-a-week salary in front of Campbell's face, expect the Spurs captain to finally commit his future to the club.

Yet at every turn, Tottenham's born-again saviour faces problems. There's the thorny issue of money - or rather the lack of it. New chairman Daniel Levy might be a Spurs supporter, but he's no Jack Walker. And Enic's record at Rangers, AEK Athens, Vicenza, Basle and Slavia Prague is hardly reassuring: the company are hungry profit-seekers, not long-term investors.

Without a hefty cash injection it's hard to see how Hoddle will address the gaping holes in the Spurs squad - particularly the poverty in the Spurs midfield. At the moment Steffen Freund holds, Tim Sherwood harries, while Oyvind Leonardssen and Darren Anderton are always injured. The young players have potential, but more - much more - is needed to turn Spurs into a top five club again.

There's also doubts over Hoddle's man-management skills. During the World Cup 1998 he often appeared aloof and arrogant: he ridiculed David Beckham in training and alienated several players. Although it was Hoddle's ill-advised comments on reincarnation which forced him to resign as England coach, it was the backdrop of uninspiring displays against Sweden and Bulgaria - due in part by losing the players' trust with his World Cup diary - that made the resulting political storm impossible to weather.

Hoddle will argue that his mistakes have made him a better manager. And he's probably right. It's also true that he has nearly all of the credentials needed to manage Spurs. The club's supporters will hope that Hoddle will finally be able to turn his undoubted talent into trophies - but the rest of us will need more convincing that Tottenham's brave new world is just around the corner.

fields.headline: BBC2 showcases Boyle films in £88m line-up
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: BBC2 is to give TV premieres to films from the director of Trainspotting and the Beach in its £88m spring and summer season unveiled today.
fields.body:
The latest films from Danny Boyle, director of Trainspotting and the Beach, are to be given their TV premieres on BBC2 as the station unveiled its £88m spring and summer season.

The channel will continue its emphasis on gardening shows with the return of the Chelsea Flower Show with presenters including Alan Titchmarsh and Charlie Dimmock.

The season also includes award-winning hit US show Malcolm in the Middle, in which American family life is seen comically through the eyes of a boy.

Boyle's films, Strumpet and Vacuuming Completely Nude In Paradise, have been scripted by Jim Cartwright, who wrote the acclaimed movie and play Little Voice.

Strumpet stars Christopher Eccleston in a tale about three unlikely companions trying to make it in the music business.

Vacuuming features Timothy Spall as a salesman in line for a top award whose efforts are hampered by his mild-mannered trainee.

Other dramas include Perfect Strangers, the new project from writer/director Stephen Poliakoff, whose Shooting the Past series won a string of awards.

The Chelsea Flower Show comes back to BBC2 in May after finding a home on Channel 4 and will also be featured heavily on radio and BBC online.

One of its hosts, Diarmud Gavin - presenter of Home Front in the Garden - will also front another new series, Planet Patio.

Masterchef, formerly presented by Loyd Grossman on BBC1, transfers to BBC2 with Gary Rhodes as its new presenter.

Factual series include Ancient Apocalypse in which science and sophisticated computer graphics show how past civilisations were wiped out.

Endgame in Ireland gives a definitive history of the peace process.

"BBC2 is currently on a four-year high, proving that our ambition - to produce big ideas and tell big stories, but with a different twist - is working," said Jane Root, BBC2 controller.

"This spring and summer we're giving audiences more of what they want and what we're best at - good quality programmes that don't talk down to viewers, but are rewarding, pleasurable and fun."

fields.headline: It's official: advertising is hard work
fields.trailText:
1.45pm: An industry body has been awarded government funding to look into the problem of overwork in adland, writes Claire Cozens.
Nov 14: IPA reports on women in advertising
fields.body:
They may be famed for their expensive, champagne-fuelled parties but advertising executives are working too hard.

An industry body has just been awarded government funding to look into the problem of overwork in adland.

The department for education and employment is providing funding for an Institute of Practitioners in Advertising research programme on work/life balance.

The long hours and high pressure of a job in advertising were highlighted in last year's IPA Women in Advertising study.

A lack of family-friendly employment policies in agencies was blamed for the high turnover of female staff.

"The whole issue of work/life balance is something the government is very keen to look at," said an IPA spokeswoman.

"We are keen to encourage a more enlightened approach and are looking at drawing up guidelines for the industry to use."

The government funds will be used to pay for a study carried out by Flametree, the work/life consultancy, into best practice.

The data will be made public this summer.

The results will be supplied a new working party set up by the IPA to look at how the industry can retain its top talent.

The working party will be chaired by Christine Walker, founder of Walker Media and one of the few women to have made it to the top in advertising.

Related story

webTitle: Boot Camp marches to Sky One

fields.headline: Boot Camp marches to Sky One
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Sky One has won a bidding war with the BBC for gameshow Boot Camp, in which contestants undergo gruelling army training.
fields.body:
A new reality gameshow - where contestants undergo gruelling training at an army boot camp - has been snapped up by Sky One after a fierce bidding war with the BBC.

The series, called Boot Camp, will be shown for the first time in the US this week and is expected to be a huge hit, with contestants competing for a cash prize.

It is part of Sky's spring and summer season, which will also include the TV premiere of Erin Brockovich - for which Julia Roberts took an Oscar - on Box Office next month.

In Boot Camp, eight men and eight women will be put through their paces by drill instructors for weeks on end.

The contestants then vote out their fellow players until just one is left to take the prize.

A spokesman for Sky said: "The contestants will think they are lucky to get through each time but they will become more exhausted after going through even more training."

Sky One, which also screened the hit US show Temptation Island, may consider making its own UK version of Boot Camp.

BSkyB is putting an emphasis on its homegrown productions to shake off the perception it only screens US imports.

New dramas include Do or Die - featuring Patsy Palmer and the Full Monty star Hugo Speer in the Australian criminal underworld - and the Bombmaker, a production about terrorism, starring Dervla Kirwan and Samantha Bond.

Interactivity is also a key element in Sky's new season.

"People want to use their TV in new ways," said the Sky spokesman. "Look at the success of interactive football and interactive cricket."

Hotter Sex - a series examining the sex lives of the British - will to carry out an interactive survey of viewers' relationships.

Other Sky Box Office premieres include Star Wars: episode 1 - the Phantom Menace, and the late Stanley Kubrick's final movie Eyes Wide Shut.

fields.headline: Gap names marketing chief
fields.trailText:
1pm: Gap Inc has hired Lowe Lintas veteran Peter Hempel as marketing chief for its Gap brand, writes Julia Day.
Feb 7: Gap hires first three-brand marketing chief
fields.body:
Gap Inc has hired Peter Hempel, a Lowe Lintas & Partners advertising executive, to be the marketing chief for its Gap brand.

Mr Hempel, 42, joins Gap from Lowe Lintas & Partners's New York agency.

He had worked there for more than 14 years, most recently as executive vice-president and general manager of account management.

At Gap he will oversee all aspects of global marketing for Gap, GapKids, babyGap and GapBody. He will report to Gap president Ken Pilot.

Amy Schoening was appointed last month to the newly created position of Gap Inc chief marketing officer.

Ms Schoening was previously executive vice-president of marketing for the Banana Republic stores.

Her appointment left Gap Inc's brands - Gap, Old Navy and Banana Republic - without individual heads of marketing.

But Old Navy has subsequently hired Tom Clendenin, previously an executive at cable sports network ESPN, to head marketing for its brand.

Earlier this month, Gap named Nancy Green vice-president of women's merchandising for the Gap brand.

Related story

fields.headline: Watchdogs agree to co-operate
fields.trailText:
1pm: 'Double jeopardy' TV regulation, which led to viewers getting different rulings from watchdogs, is to end, reports Jason Deans.

Dec 12: What the new super-regulator will do
fields.body:
"Double jeopardy" TV regulation, which has led to disgruntled viewers getting different rulings on a show from different watchdogs, is to end.

The Broadcasting Standards Commission, Independent Television Commission and Radio Authority said today they have torn down the fences between themselves and started to confer on complaints.

Their efforts are the first sign of regulatory "detente" ahead of the creation of a super-watchdog, Ofcom.

In the past the ITC and the BSC have issued conflicting rulings on a variety of shows including a Channel 4 cookery programme which featured placenta burgers.

Viewers still have the option of complaining to separate bodies but they will effectively make joint adjudications.

Talking to each other about complaints is just one of a number of co-operative measures included in a memorandum of understanding signed by all five broadcasting and communications watchdogs in preparation for the creation of Ofcom.

"The five bodies have pledged to establish mechanisms to ensure that complaints are handled so as to avoid double jeopardy wherever possible," the memorandum said.

A BSC spokesman confirmed the regulator had already started talking to the ITC and RA about responding to complaints.

"One organisation may handle a complaint, or we may agree to work along the same lines," he added.

"Mrs Brown can write to us, the ITC or the RA if she wants and we can all deal with the complaint. The idea is just to talk to each other more."

Last year's communications white paper set out plans for the three broadcasting regulators, Oftel and the Radiocommunications Agency to be merged into a single body.

But the new regulator will not be set up until a Communications Act is passed after the general election.

In the meantime, the five regulators have agreed to collaborate to "avoid unjustified duplication of expenditure".

webTitle: Foot and mouth and the media

fields.headline: Day 37: foot and mouth and the media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk keeps you informed with a daily briefing on the press coverage of foot and mouth
fields.trailText: MediaGuardian.co.uk keeps you informed with a daily briefing on the press coverage of foot and mouth.
fields.body:
The foot and mouth crisis is showing signs of slipping down the news agenda. It still features on the front pages of the broadsheets, but the Mirror is the only tabloid to splash on the story, turning the spotlight of blame on Chinese restaurants.

The Sun
The Sun takes a militaristic tone with its "Battle to Save the Lakes" spread. It describes "desperate efforts", "frantic battles" and "Domesday scenarios" as the Lake District "paradise" attempts to fight off the disease. The tourist industry is drawing up a "top-secret blueprint" for half-price holiday offers as army butchers are brought in to assist in the slaughter. Its leader again urges Tony Blair not to call off the May 3 election.

The Mirror
"Sheep and Sow Source" screams the Mirror's front page headline alongside a picture of a noodle dish, referring to agriculture minister Nick Brown's claim that the origins of the outbreak may lie in pigswill infected by illegally imported meat from Chinese restaurants. Again, the crisis merits the language of war - ministers and MPs are told it is their "patriotic duty" to holiday in the UK this Easter.

Daily Mail
Revelling in its anti-government stance, the Mail's foot and mouth spread champions vaccination as the "only alternative to end the slaughter" as "Brown's policy fails". The government's mistakes are highlighted in a day-by-day account of contradictory quotes.

The Guardian
The Guardian's front page lead sets out the government's plans for a full-scale vaccination programme and restrictions on the movement of animals, which, the paper says, "will change market towns forever". Inside, a piece on the trade in illegal meat brings a series of astonishing revelations - meat from bush rats, antelopes, cow's nostrils, monkeys, elephants and dried caterpillars is being smuggled into Britain in containers and even hand luggage.

The Independent
Tourism is at top of the Indy's agenda with Tony Blair set to tell the country to "return to normality" and visit the countryside to show foreign visitors Britain is a safe holiday destination. Inside, the backlash from angry Chinese restaurateurs eager to deny any involvement in the crisis is given prominence.

fields.headline: Walt Disney cuts 4,000 jobs
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Walt Disney, the world's second-largest media company, said last night it was cutting 4,000 jobs - 3% of its worldwide workforce, writes Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
Walt Disney, the world's second-largest media company, said last night it was cutting 4,000 jobs - 3% of its worldwide workforce - as the slowdown in the US economy continued to bite.

The cuts are the latest evidence of belt-tightening by some of the world's largest companies at the start of an economic slowdown in the US.

Ken Green, a company spokesman, said that all business areas of the company would be affected, from employees in Disneyland Paris to those at the company's flagship ABC news channel in the US. Disney has already cut hundreds of internet-related jobs over the past few months in an attempt to stop its online operations haemorrhaging money.

In a letter to the company's 120,000 employees yesterday, Michael Eisner, the chief executive, said the media and entertainment giant needed to cut costs to cope with the downturn in corporate advertising and consumer spending.

"We need to face up to the increasingly pressing challenges of the softening economic environment," he said. "We must also uphold investors' confidence in our future while maintaining our core commitment to quality and creativity."

The California-based company expects to save between $350m and $400m a year from the redundancy programme. As many as possible of the employees - mouseketeers, as they are known - would be offered voluntary redundancy, the company said. The costs of the redundancy package, which will include severance pay, benefits and outplacement services, are expected to add up to $250m.

Last month the company warned that earnings would increase by single-digit percentage points this year.

In February, Disney opened a 22-hectare, $1.4bn theme park in Anaheim called Disney's California Adventure. Wall Street analysts have been sceptical about the hope that extra revenue from the new park would make up for the downturn in consumer spending and advertising revenues.

The announcement last night came after a rally in the US stock market. Figures released yesterday suggested that US consumer confidence, which has followed share prices earthwards over the past few months, finally started to improve in March.

webTitle: Law review to encourage council homes transfer

fields.headline: Law review to encourage council homes transfer
fields.trailText: The government is pressing ahead with a new single tenancy for almost 5m social housing tenants to sweep away the current archaic and chaotic legal set-up.
fields.body:
The government is pressing ahead with a new single tenancy for almost 5m social housing tenants in a move that could encourage the sell off of council homes to housing associations.

The government has asked the law commission to conduct a major review of housing law to sweep away the archaic and chaotic legal set-up that has spawned 13 separate forms of tenancy.

The new long-term tenancy, which the government wants to set out in a housing bill in summer 2003, will equalise the rights between council and housing association tenants in England and Wales, and thereby allay the fears of council tenants facing transfer.

Part of problem is that housing association tenants have less legal rights than council tenants. This threatens to hamper government attempts to force 2m council homes to transfer to housing associations.

A significant minority of transfer proposals have so far been scuppered by council tenants voting against the idea, and ministers fear more will follow unless tenants worries about losing rights can be allayed.

Council tenants that transfer to new landlords retain the right to buy their properties at discounted rates. But the new single tenancy is unlikely to extend the right to buy to traditional housing association homes because this could threaten the viability of associations.

Housing minister Nick Raynsford has backed the new draft plans for change and has asked the law commission to work up the proposals in time for the proposed housing bill.

The new tenancy, which will be available to private as well as social landlords, is likely to simplify the duty for landlords to repair their properties and clear up the legal confusion about when tenancies begin and end.

In addition to single long-term tenancy, Mr Raynsford wants a new short-term tenancy that will reduce the duties of landlords as an incentive to bring empty homes back into use.

Russell Campbell, chief solicitor with charity Shelter and a member of an advisory board for the review, said: "We have seen these kind of proposals before but they tend to gather dust. What is welcome in this context is that we have a clear time for progress and a commitment in black and white for a bill."

Mr Campbell confirmed that making transfer easier was one of the drivers for change but pointed out the proposals would help tenants by ending confusion and setting out more clearly their rights on repairs and security of tenure.

He conceded that the new short-term tenancy would help free up more homes, but he was worried about the loss of rights this could involve. "We are all in favour of making housing law simpler, we are not in favour of rights being reduced, we will be resisting where we can," he said.

Mark Weeks, national coordinator of Defend Council Housing, predicted that the new single tenancy would be "levelled down to the rights of a housing association tenancy rather than levelled up to secure council tenancy."

He claimed it would not help the transfer programme because tenants would see it as "cynical move".

John Bryant, policy officer at the National Housing Federation, said: "The desire to spike the guns of the Defend Council Housing campaign is a factor in this, but transfers are already moving quickly."

Mr Bryant welcomed the proposed simplification as "long overdue".

fields.headline: Napster copyright row reignites
fields.trailText:
11.30am: Napster's bid to block copyrighted songs have been branded an 'utter failure', reports Amy Vickers.
Mar 14: Napster in last-ditch rescue bid
fields.body:
The war of words between the record industry and Napster intensified today when the Recording Industry Association of America hit out at the song-swapping service.

It branded Napster's attempts to block copyrighted songs an "utter failure" and upped the pressure on courts to shut down the internet service by filing a new court order for Napster to change the filter software it is using to charge users to download tracks.

The RIAA is furious because it says users are still able to download tracks for nothing.

"Napster seems to have adopted the most porous filter available. It's not working, it never will work and Napster should be ordered to implement an effective filter or to change its filtering method," said Hilary Rosen, president of the RIAA.

The association also maintains that many of the songs Napster claims to have filtered are still available on the site.

A bewildered Napster hit back by saying it was doing the best it could and had so far managed to block 275,000 songs.

It defended itself by saying that the record companies had not co-operated sufficiently to allow it to comply with the original court order from three weeks ago.

Napster has also had problems identifying song titles that users had deliberately misspelt to avoid filters.

Napster's chief executive Hank Barry stressed that "Napster is aggressively complying with the injunction with significant measurable results".

However, pressure is growing on Napster, which is due back in court on April 10.

In its court filing, RIAA said it had searched for the 212 copyrighted works it originally asked Napster to block in its lawsuit and found every song still available on the site.

Napster, however, is determined not to allow legal red tape to get the better of it. It is encouraging hard-core fans to rally round and descend on Washington next Tuesday when senators meet to discuss the legal battle.

But with usage down by a quarter since it brought in controls, Napster seems to be gradually losing its once unequivocal support.

fields.headline: NatMags relaunches Bride & Groom
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The National Magazine Company is relaunching Bride & Groom as Cosmopolitan Bride, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The National Magazine Company is rebranding Bride & Groom, the magazine it acquired last year from AIM Publications, as Cosmopolitan Bride.

NatMags believes the magazine, which was number four in a crowded market, will have greater market leverage as a brand spin-off from Cosmopolitan than as a standalone magazine.

Cosmopolitan Bride will be run from the company's specialist bridal division.

This was created from AIM Publications, which NatMags purchased last year and renamed NatMags Specialist Media.

"Research shows there is great potential for a wedding magazine that looks and feels like Cosmopolitan and we are very excited about it," said Duncan Edwards, deputy managing director of Natmags.

A new editor for the magazine is to be appointed in the next few weeks.

fields.headline: 'Spy' meeting shown on Russian TV
fields.standfirst: A television programme showing three men negotiating a financial transaction in a Moscow bar has further ignited the US-Russian spy scandal, says Amelia Gentleman
fields.trailText: A television programme showing three men negotiating a financial transaction in a Moscow bar has further ignited the US-Russian spy scandal, says Amelia Gentleman.
fields.body:
The Zoo Bar, hidden in the basement of one of the distinctive Stalin skyscrapers which dominate the Moscow horizon, was the venue for a meeting between two American military attachés and their Russian contact, shown on prime-time nationwide television.

Little was audible above the buzz of pop music, except the occasional snatch of conversation; the men were apparently discussing the purchase of classified military maps.

Another strip of grainy, black and white film also broadcast showed a Russian agent apparently telephoning his American handler, the US naval attaché, from a public pay phone in the capital and hurriedly arranging a rendezvous.

This strange insight into the work of American intelligence officials was released yesterday as the Russian ministry of foreign affairs issued the names of the first four US diplomats ordered to leave Russia in the next few days.

The broadcast appeared to be labouring the point that America is just as culpable in the raging spy row as Russia. While officials in Washington vent their rage about the work of Robert Hanssen - the FBI agent recently arrested on suspicion of spying for Moscow over the course of 15 years - and argue that a growth of Russian espionage activity triggered the crisis, this footage was apparently issued to inform the Russian population that US officials are themselves very busy recruiting new Russians informants.

The fallout from last week's US decision to expel four Russians from Washington and ask another 46 to leave the country by the summer continues - rippling out into different spheres of diplomatic relations. The Russian ministry of foreign affairs has responded in kind demanding the removal of an equal number of embassy workers - according to the well-worn traditions of tit-for-tat diplomacy - but the neo-cold war chill has crept into other arenas.

The foreign ministry accused George Bush's administration of "immoral behaviour" yesterday for its decision to hold talks in Washington with Ilyas Akhmadov, foreign minister of the separatist Chechen government, which is not recognised by Russia.

In the wake of Saturday's bomb attacks in Stavropol, which killed 23 and injured more than 100 others and which have been blamed on Chechen terrorists, the ministry's statement was fierce. "The latest bloody crimes by the Chechen terrorists in the Stavropol region allow one to describe this Washington 'show' as simply immoral," the statement read.

There was also speculation that the bizarre case of an American research student, charged with possessing a small amount of marijuana might also have been swept up by the mood of diplomatic retaliation.

When he was originally arrested in January, John Tobin, 24 - a trained interrogator and a US army intelligence unit completing a graduate studies programme in southern Russia - was suspected of espionage. Later Russian officials decided there was no basis for a spying case, but his drug charges were intensified on Monday, leaving him facing 15 years in prison if he is found guilty of involvement in a drug ring.

Even a row over the rent of the US ambassador's Moscow residency appears to have been sparked by the spy scandal. Russia's deputy foreign minister Ivan Sergeyev, said last week that the rent on the building in central Moscow was far too low and that the US, if market rates were imposed and backdated, owed Russia around $6m (£4.2m).

This morning, both American and Russian officials made diplomatic statements suggesting that they wished the row to come to an end. Foreign minister Igor Ivanov and US secretary of state Colin Powell spoke by telephone, with both sides suggesting a desire to restore constructive relations.

US state department spokesman Richard Boucher said Russia's reciprocal expulsion of US diplomats was "unwarranted", but added the US aimed to cooperate with Russia. "Obviously we have an important national interest in maintaining cooperative and protective relations with Russia. We do intend to work to advance those interests," he said.

The foreign ministry in Moscow stated that Russian officials welcomed "the announcement by a representative of the US state department of the American side's desire to put today's difficult moment in Russian-American relations behind us, and work toward their improvement and development".

"We are ready for an immediate and constructive discussion of all burning international and bilateral issues with the US administration," a ministry statement said.

It remains unclear whether these soothing words will prove enough to smooth over the fractures caused by the worst spy row since the end of the cold war.

fields.headline: The human touch
fields.standfirst: Francesca Okosi, bringing a buzz to personnel
fields.trailText: Francesca Okosi, bringing a buzz to personnel.
fields.body:
For a time in the 1980s, urban local government was a fashionable place to work. Labour councils had become the frontline of resistance to a Conservative dominated parliament, and many young leftwingers wanted a piece of the action. It was then that a 22-year-old business studies graduate, Francesca Okosi, decided she needed a break from the world of marketing and took a temporary personnel job with the east London borough of Newham.

Thirteen years on, Okosi is still in local government human resources, but has risen to the heights of her profession. She currently heads the personnel department of Brent, north London; has a reputation for speaking out on equalities issues; and has been described by Personnel Today magazine as "one of the most able exponents of human resources in the public sector".

Okosi's talents have also been recognised by her peers, who recently made her vice-president of the local government Society of Chief Personnel Officers (Socpo), whose annual conference opens today in Brighton. Next year, she will become the first black woman to hold the society's top job.

This is all a long way from her original goal of becoming a big success in marketing. "I entered local government at a time when I had very strong views about public services and communities," she says. "It's become like a drug since then, really."

The politics are still there - Okosi jokingly describes herself as a "loony lefty" - but these days her views are expressed largely through her interest in the way that human resources can help regenerate poverty-stricken communities. In Brent, she says, local communities are suffering from unemployment, while the council and local NHS organisations are facing skills shortages. The council is trying to bridge the gap by training the jobless for public service, killing two birds with one stone. "Even if we can't provide people with employment," she asks, "shouldn't we be giving them work experience and other opportunities and working with our partners to do that?"

With local government currently undergoing the widest ranging reforms it has faced, Okosi also sees a key role for personnel chiefs in helping their councils deal with change. Labour's "best value" regime requires improvements in local government services and cares little whether a council, voluntary organisation or private sector company actually does the work.

Human resources professionals have to provide the staff and training to support this process, but they also have to undergo it themselves. That means difficult changes in the way they work. Money is already tight because the government wants funds concentrated on frontline services, and personnel departments are an easy target for cuts. The outsourcing of local government services also means there are fewer council employees to be managed - and so less need for human resources. Okosi admits that this could mean cuts in the number of personnel officers, but she insists that those who are left will still have an important job to do. "The role of human resources may change," she says. "It needs to focus on how it helps individual organisations in the private, public or voluntary sectors to fulfil their responsibilities to the local community."

Helping Socpo's membership deal with this shake-up is one of Okosi's main aims for her term as vice-president. The task may sound daunting, but Okosi gives the impression that her eye for a challenge is what keeps her faithful to the public sector. Her CV includes a spell helping tackle a major social services strike in Newham, east London, from where she moved to nearby - and by then already troubled - Hackney, taking a post as a senior social services personnel officer in 1990. "I like challenges, I think that's what made me go to Hackney," she says. "I like to go to places people tell me not to."

Between 1997 and 1999, she also spent an unhappy period as head of human resources at Merton, south London. She believes now that the authority had really wanted a straightforward administrator, a role she was clearly not suited to. As she says: "I want to be in an organisation that's buzzing."

That may be why she has chosen to become Socpo's vice-president at a time when the society is in a state of flux. Socpo recently decided to expand its membership from its traditional base of chief personnel officers to encompass all local government human resources specialists, including those who have transferred to the private sector and now provide services to councils.

Under current president Terry Gorman, Socpo has been making steady progress on improving its visibility and clout within local government. At the society's conference, sponsored by the Guardian, he will today officially pass the baton to new president Keith Handley, of Bradford council, who will work in tandem with Okosi.

Combine all this with her job in Brent, and you might think Okosi has more than enough on her plate to satisfy her addiction to challenge and change. Yet she already has one eye on the future. "I'm slowing down as I get older," she concedes. "In Brent, I do want to see what I'm doing coming out the other end. But I'm coming to a point where I have to ask myself: what next?"
