She currently heads the personnel department of Brent, north London; has a reputation for speaking out on equalities issues; and has been described by Personnel Today magazine as "one of the most able exponents of human resources in the public sector". Okosi's talents have also been recognised by her peers, who recently made her vice-president of the local government Society of Chief Personnel Officers (Socpo), whose annual conference opens today in Brighton. Next year, she will become the first black woman to hold the society's top job. This is all a long way from her original goal of becoming a big success in marketing. "I entered local government at a time when I had very strong views about public services and communities," she says. "It's become like a drug since then, really." The politics are still there - Okosi jokingly describes herself as a "loony lefty" - but these days her views are expressed largely through her interest in the way that human resources can help regenerate poverty-stricken communities. In Brent, she says, local communities are suffering from unemployment, while the council and local NHS organisations are facing skills shortages. The council is trying to bridge the gap by training the jobless for public service, killing two birds with one stone. "Even if we can't provide people with employment," she asks, "shouldn't we be giving them work experience and other opportunities and working with our partners to do that?" With local government currently undergoing the widest ranging reforms it has faced, Okosi also sees a key role for personnel chiefs in helping their councils deal with change. Labour's "best value" regime requires improvements in local government services and cares little whether a council, voluntary organisation or private sector company actually does the work. Human resources professionals have to provide the staff and training to support this process, but they also have to undergo it themselves. That means difficult changes in the way they work. Money is already tight because the government wants funds concentrated on frontline services, and personnel departments are an easy target for cuts. The outsourcing of local government services also means there are fewer council employees to be managed - and so less need for human resources. Okosi admits that this could mean cuts in the number of personnel officers, but she insists that those who are left will still have an important job to do. "The role of human resources may change," she says. "It needs to focus on how it helps individual organisations in the private, public or voluntary sectors to fulfil their responsibilities to the local community." Helping Socpo's membership deal with this shake-up is one of Okosi's main aims for her term as vice-president. The task may sound daunting, but Okosi gives the impression that her eye for a challenge is what keeps her faithful to the public sector. Her CV includes a spell helping tackle a major social services strike in Newham, east London, from where she moved to nearby - and by then already troubled - Hackney, taking a post as a senior social services personnel officer in 1990. "I like challenges, I think that's what made me go to Hackney," she says. "I like to go to places people tell me not to." Between 1997 and 1999, she also spent an unhappy period as head of human resources at Merton, south London. She believes now that the authority had really wanted a straightforward administrator, a role she was clearly not suited to. As she says: "I want to be in an organisation that's buzzing." That may be why she has chosen to become Socpo's vice-president at a time when the society is in a state of flux. Socpo recently decided to expand its membership from its traditional base of chief personnel officers to encompass all local government human resources specialists, including those who have transferred to the private sector and now provide services to councils. Under current president Terry Gorman, Socpo has been making steady progress on improving its visibility and clout within local government. At the society's conference, sponsored by the Guardian, he will today officially pass the baton to new president Keith Handley, of Bradford council, who will work in tandem with Okosi. Combine all this with her job in Brent, and you might think Okosi has more than enough on her plate to satisfy her addiction to challenge and change. Yet she already has one eye on the future. "I'm slowing down as I get older," she concedes. "In Brent, I do want to see what I'm doing coming out the other end. But I'm coming to a point where I have to ask myself: what next?"

webTitle: Former Saint Hoddle in talks at Tottenham

fields.headline: Former Saint Hoddle in talks at Tottenham
fields.trailText: Tottenham have confirmed they are in talks with Glenn Hoddle following the former White Hart Lane midfielder's resignation from Southampton this morning.
fields.body:
Tottenham have confirmed they are in talks with Glenn Hoddle following the former White Hart Lane midfielder's resignation from Southampton this morning.

A statement from Spurs read: "The board of Tottenham Hotspur plc confirms that, following the consent of Southampton Football Club, discussions are taking place with Glenn Hoddle to become the football manager of Tottenham Hotspur Football Club. A further announcement will be made when appropriate."

Hoddle's decision to leave Saints and join Tottenham has left Dell chairman Rupert Lowe furious at the hasty way in which the former England coach "turned his back" on the club that revived his career.

Lowe revealed Hoddle had phoned at 10pm last night to tell him that, after talks with Spurs, he had decided to succeed George Graham at White Hart Lane.

The Saints chief had hoped that Hoddle, who has steered the south-coast club to eighth place in the Premiership, could be persuaded to stay on at The Dell, particularly as a new stadium is being built.

But the lure of Spurs, where Hoddle enjoys legendary status from his playing days, proved too strong to resist, leaving Lowe a frustrated man.

Lowe said: "At 10pm yesterday I received a phone call from Glenn saying he wished to end his employment at Southampton with immediate effect and join Tottenham Hotspur as their manager.

"Notwithstanding Tottenham's recent confirmation that David Pleat was to take over the management until the end of the season, I was surprised by the speed at which negotiations had proceeded from what I hope had been a standing start to conclusion in a little over five hours.

"I was also disappointed that Glenn had chosen to turn his back on the club that gave him the opportunity to resume his career in top-flight management and on a squad which he had welded into an exciting team and who, in return, had given him their unconditional loyalty as evidenced by the string of recent important contract extensions.

"I am also sure that our fans will share my regret at what has happened as they too have given Glenn every support and been an important component in his success.

"I am also saddened that Glenn has chosen to leave the team with a European place in sight and a new stadium only five months from completion.

"Whilst Glenn has 15 months of his contract outstanding he has no doubt considered all these factors in the short space of time available to him and I do not propose to hold him against his evident will to move elsewhere."

Southampton are holding Hoddle's registration until such time as compensation is agreed for the 15 months remaining on his contract.

John Gorman, Hoddle's deputy at Saints, emerged from a meeting with Lowe at The Dell to reveal that he would be teaming up with Hoddle again.

"I've just been in with the chairman. I've asked for permission to go with Glenn and the chairman has accepted that," said Gorman.

"It still needs confirmation from Tottenham regarding my position. It still has to be done properly and officially but I'll probably cease to be at this club from today.

"I'm leaving a fantastic club and I'll be a bit sad but, hopefully, I'm going to join another great club - one that's close to my heart as well as Glenn's.

"I'm delighted that Glenn has asked me to go and join him," Gorman told Sky Sports.comTV. "It's fantastic for me if I get the chance to join Tottenham."

fields.headline: My New Media
fields.standfirst: Heather Rabbatts
fields.trailText: Heather Rabbatts
fields.body:
Favourite website?

Well, this is a slightly partisan answer because I'm a governor of the BBC, but I do think the BBC news site is very good. It's been the leader in translating news which it gathers through traditional media and puts it online in an accessible way. It's an unusual trick that not many people have pulled off.

Last online purchase?

Air tickets from EasyJet. It was late at night, it was easy and accessible.

Most recent technological faux pas?

My biggest difficulty is controlling my son's mobile telephone bill.

Ever been in a chat room?

No. I like talking to people as opposed to talking in cyberspace.

Main news source on web?

Reuters and FT.com. You can flick between them and get a very complete picture as opposed to reading a paper which only gives you one view.

Most useful websites?

UK government sites. The DTI and Number 10 sites are both good. I can find out what the government is sponsoring and how they are trying to take forward the area of endeavour my business is involved in.

Which site is least likely to succeed?

Websites which try to be wholly dependent on advertising won't succeed. Often you're just bombarded with adverts and you can't even see what the site is supposed to be about. Also, I think people want a tactile experience when they buy certain things, so while you might buy functional things over the web, I don't think that whole designer clothing thing is going to work. Time spent on the web?

I'll use it for a couple of hours a day, but I'm not someone who surfs the web as a pastime.

Least useful site on the web?

There was one which enabled you to put your boyfriend or girlfriend on it and then flirt with them online. I thought the pleasure of flirting was in the real human interaction.

Do you use a screensaver?

No. I've got a very functional relationship with technology. It isn't about being entertained.

Most irritating thing about web?

Information overload and too many emails. When people used to send telegrams across the world, they crafted their words carefully, but now that we have email we've become so much more sloppy. We should maintain certain disciplines about how we use the technology.

Do you still bother with old media?

There are intrinsic qualities in the experience of old media which I want to maintain, like holding a book and turning the pages.

 Heather Rabbatts is the chief executive of www.impower.co.uk

webTitle: Polly Toynbee: Blair's community spirit needs a focus

fields.headline: Blair's community spirit needs to find its focus
fields.standfirst:
Once the church provided it, now Labour must offer a new social glue

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Once the church provided it, now Labour must offer a new social glue.
fields.body:
Never has a government worried so much about "community". What is it? Can governments regenerate it for social good? Labour has been searching in the grassroots for clumps of it. Does it reside in the Rotarians, mothers unions, Women's Institutes, five-a-side leagues, mosques or churches? How elusive these social pressure points are, some eccentric, others empty vessels, unrepresentative of anything but themselves. In this pluralist, diverse society there are few easy entry points into the beating heart of any locality. What is urban freedom for many, a blessed escape from old lace-curtain community, is also desolate isolation for others.

Yesterday the American guru of community led a breakfast seminar in 10 Downing Street. Harvard Professor Dr Robert Putnam, author of Bowling Alone gave his causes of the collapse of community: television, two-career families, urban sprawl with commuting and the failure of the second world war generation to pass on war-time civic values to their baby-boomer children. Community is in decline - unions, churches, clubs, bowls, political parties, voting, even visiting bars. Where there is community, there is less crime, better school performance, more happiness. Belonging to one community group delivers the same volume of happiness as doubling your income.

Belonging to one group is so good for you that it reduces by a half the chance of dying in the next year, two groups reduces death risk by three quarters. (Putnam's numerical sociology sometimes verges on numerology.)

One answer, he says, is faith-based communities which "enhance civic life" and he welcomes President Bush's intention to use them. "Faith-based organisations have a proven ability to reweave the fabric of distressed communities and they deserve support from government." And tomorrow the prime minister will promise it to them here. Addressing a conference of the Christian Socialist Movement, with other faiths in attendance, he will praise the good churches can do in community renewal and the value of church schools. Competing with William Hague, he will claim Labour values are closest to Christian values. True, according to Mori. The Church of England is no longer the Tory party at prayer: only 26% of its members vote Tory, 48% Labour. Among Roman Catholics only 17% are Tory, with 48% Labour. In this country the far right evangelicals are still a minority.

But mixing God and politics is a perilous business. If the PM's text is not well-worded he may risk the WI slow hand-clap. These are socialists who may question his Christian values from the left: members are pressing for a narrowing of the now widening gap between rich and poor. But outside the hall, the great agnostic/atheist British majority has a queasy distaste for politicians airing religious sentiments: it only fuels their cynicism.

At a breakfast this week, the Bishop of Liverpool and the Reverend Steve Chalke explained their pitch to the prime minister for tomorrow's conference. Churches do community best, with the best volunteers and the best schools, the "faith dollar" goes further and they want more social funding. Chalke wants the prime minister to stop "hard left Labour councils" refusing to fund faith groups on the grounds that church groups only employ their own church members and Christian school teachers. Faith groups only work, he says, because they are all believers. He is not polite about "state" employees, as if they were clock-watching time-servers.

Churches attract politicians. Their edifices suggest an important place in communities, for lack of anything else tangible to grasp, despite often empty pews and aged congregations. But founding a national social policy around a church attendance currently at 7.5% (generous estimate) looks implausible. It is another colossal difference with the US which ought to make British politicians more wary of using US social thinkers. Robert Putnam is left of centre and knows Britain (unlike Hague's guru, Marvin Olasky, a bible-belt, anti-welfare anti-abortionist). But even so, Putnam's prescriptions sound essentially alien. His vision of community, for all his denials, looks like a return to the 1950s, women back to Kinder, Küche, Kirche. His social determinism is out of step with modern times: it looks cynical to want poor people to join churches not because religion is true but because it is good for them.

The reason Labour's social policies may work where the old slum clearances failed over the years is because they focus on the people. Funding renewal through partnerships that join up all the local state agencies with voluntary groups is a way of reaching out through every tentacle to all that moves and breathes. Some churches do run brilliant social programmes for drug addicts, the homeless, the young and the old. But religious groups must take their place along with the other voluntary groups - funded and judged according to their results.

There is a lot of hocus-pocus talked about community, as if it were magic to be sprinkled about like holy water. Nostalgic for old community values, Putnam recalls the glory days of Elks, Salvation Army, choral societies, scouts and churches. But times change. Creating a new sense of community requires building on people's lives as they are now, the things people want enough to need to band together communally. Community activity always depended on women, but they have now gone out to work instead.

But seek out where strangers do still meet and it is still largely parents - mainly mothers - outside school gates, playgroup or playground, at the checkout or the baby clinic. Ask communities now what they need most locally and the first answer is childcare - a guaranteed creche and nursery place for every child. Harriet Harman's recent childcare commission toured the country and that was the universal answer.

So if Labour wants to foster a new community spirit, start with beautiful children's palaces, attractive welcoming places, offering every service from ante-natal to after-school clubs. At a stroke it would bring together all parts of the community under one roof, in centres run by and for local parents, the only way to unite all classes, each contributing according to income. These would be the missing social heart-beat in each area, nurturing a multitude of voluntary and self-help groups, clubs, classes and community action, run by faith or non-faith volunteers side by side with professionals.

Now that would be community, but it doesn't come cheap. One estimate suggests £10bn for 10,000 centres. Money well spent, it would transform individual lives, binding together isolated families and socially divided communities everywhere. Kick-starting community requires less government angst and more government action. What a manifesto pledge that would be.

fields.headline: Q&A: Jane Root
fields.standfirst: The controller of BBC2 reveals what's in the pipeline at the channel.
fields.trailText: The controller of BBC2 reveals what's in the pipeline at the channel.
fields.body:
Q: You have just returned from a five-week "advanced management programme" at Wharton business school in the US. What useful tips did you pick up?
A: The big thing I learned is that you go there and you think the BBC and Britain are unique. Then you spend five weeks with people who run companies and bits of companies all round the world and you see they all face the same problems. How to make the money go round, how to hold on to talent, how to have a good short-term tactical plan and, at the same time, a long-term strategy. I was amazed by that and I think Michael [Jackson] felt the same when he went.

Q: What impact has the move of the BBC1 news from 9pm to 10pm had on BBC2?
A: I was involved in the discussions in that really scary and exciting week when the decision was made. I must admit I didn't think it would necessarily be positive for BBC2 - I though we might lose out in an all-out war between BBC1 and ITV. But we're 0.8% up so far this year, compared with the same period last year. I think it's brought a new clarity to both BBC1 and BBC2. It means you can do really big things at 9pm on both channels. Look at Monday night - you had comedy on BBC2 and NCS: Manhunt on BBC1. Both big but complementary programmes.

Q: What's going on with BBC2's zones? Comedy has moved from Friday to Monday and history from Saturday to Friday.
A: With comedy on Friday night I was feeling like one of those world war one generals, sending new sitcoms over the top and saying to the producer "Don't worry, it's only up against Frasier." To keep doing the more experimental stuff I had to find another place for it. And it's proved to be really the right thing to do.
History is a good thing to play against Friends and Frasier on Friday and on Monday we've found a night when there's no other comedy. We've launched stuff like Two Pints of Lager and a Packet of Crisps, which got over 3m on Monday night.

Q: When Greg Dyke unveiled his TV channel strategy last year, some observers thought BBC2 might lose its youth-orientated programming, such as comedy, to the new digital channel BBC3 and more highbrow factual stuff to its sibling BBC4. How do you respond to this?
A: BBC3 and BBC4 are digital start-up channels and they won't be playing the same game as we are at the moment. Maybe they will in two or three years but that's a long time in TV.
For the next couple of years, BBC2 will continue to do what it is doing at the moment, which is to be a pleasurable, enjoyable, mainstream channel.
We do things like history and science in an accessible and sophisticated way. We do "modern classics", which is doing modern versions of classic genres, such as drama, arts, history, comedy - I talk to producers a lot about that idea and how to refine it.

Q: Why did you want to bring the Chelsea Flower Show back to BBC2 from Channel 4?
A: I made a big personal bid to get that one back. I felt we were the channel that did gardening and it felt weird that the prime event of the gardening year was not there.

Q: What will viewers notice that's different about the Chelsea Flower Show coverage from previous years?
A: Diarmuid Gavin, one of our key new faces, will be there along with Alan Titchmarsh and the rest. I kind of missed seeing Alan there.

Q: Loyd Grossman described the changes to the Masterchef format - such as reducing the competitive element and introducing more practical cookery tips - as "moronic" when the show moved from BBC1 to BBC2 and he quit. How do you respond to that?
A: Loyd did a fabulous job over the years but it was time to move on. I wanted something people cooking at home could get into more, to modernise the food. I felt if it was going to come over to BBC2 I wanted it to be a part of the BBC2 family of cooking shows. Having Gary Rhodes in there as the new presenter is part of that.

Q: What other shows will move from BBC1 to BBC2 as part of the repositioning of the channels?
A: There is nothing else planned at the moment. We've done most of the big moves between the channels - Have I got News for You?, Omnibus, Masterchef. And with Masterchef, we were looking for a new-format cookery show anyway.

Q: Last year you spoke about giving countryside issues a new hearing with the series presented by Clarissa Dickson-Wright. Now the countryside is in crisis, what new approaches are you planning to offer viewers?
A: Clarissa's doing another series. The countryside is already a big issue with us at BBC2; it's been a big issue since I've been here. That's why I did Clarissa and the Countryman - I wanted to tackly countryside issues seriously.

Q; What are the challenges ahead for BBC2?
A: The modern classics thing is working brilliantly with things like A History of Britain and I Love the 1980s. We are lining up a whole range of things that will take that forward - some very big history and science programmes.
We have become a well-educated country, with sophisticated tastes in terms of things like DIY and shopping. BBC2 is very much in tune with that social change.

Q: Have you personal favourites in this spring/summer schedule or projects you fought particularly hard to bring to the screen?

fields.headline: Polls apart
fields.trailText: It has not been a very good year for representative democracy. The monarchy seems to have refreshed its image to such an extent that we are reduced to discussing whether it would be all right to have a monarch who is a Roman Catholic.
fields.body:
It has not been a very good year for representative democracy. The monarchy seems to have refreshed its image to such an extent that we are reduced to discussing whether it would be all right to have a monarch who is a Roman Catholic. Seemingly, the problem is not the concept of a dynastic head with a hereditary claim to extreme wealth and political clout; it's the fact that it has to be a Prod.

Admittedly, the election of George Bush has not exactly boosted the case for a presidency. The whole point of elected heads of state is supposed to be that they are chosen by a majority. And that they are not the idiot children of previous heads of state. When the most powerful man in the world makes David Beckham look like Chomsky, one might hanker after one of those progressive Nordic monarchs who cycle to work and give cannabis to the poor. One suspects that Bush only stood for election because he misread the word as "electrocution" and knew that's something he likes.

Over here, Prince Charles has been giving Maundy Money to the agricultural industry. He is also making great play of the Prince's Trust, appalled as he is by the thought of people idling their days away, never doing an honest day's work in their lives. But media affection has largely abandoned him in favour of his elder boy, who is off to college to study one of those courses they invent for people whose parents were cousins. Meanwhile, Prince Edward has been in Austria, perhaps to present Iron Crosses as part of the Duke of Windsor's Award Scheme. And the Queen Mother is as indestructible as Captain Scarlet.

Meanwhile, our politicians are arguing the toss about when elections should take place. Not since James Callaghan's loony-right tactics in the crazy 1970s has so much airtime been given to a prime minister's dilemma about the timing of a general election. And the fact that Blair's decision will be based entirely upon his own interests is not even spoken of as a matter of questionable rectitude.

Perhaps the media are a bit more honest these days. At one time, the idea that the last budget before an election is a massive bribe was considered a gross accusation. Today, all that the Tories and Labour can throw at each other is that each wants a date that best suits them. Clearly, the Tories think that they are about as unpopular as they are likely to get and Labour thinks a recession is on the way.

Of course, when the Tories speak of the indecency of discussing the vulgar matter of elections at a time of national crisis, one has to remember that they find the whole business of universal adult suffrage unseemly anyway. Small wonder that they don't balk at the idea of a law to cancel local elections. And when William Hague manages to work the ideas of a crisis cabinet and a greater role for the army into the same thought, you know he's considering all his options.

Even the Liberals have been reaching for their smelling salts at the very mention of so coarse an issue as polling day, although they are beavering away trying to secure a deal on a more representative system, or rather, a referendum on a more representative system. What one would make of a popular vote against a more representative system, I don't know. Wouldn't it cancel itself out?

Labour, meanwhile, has to justify the fact that it's got a whole year of running the country to play with and doesn't want it. If they're that bored with the reigns of power, I'm happy to take over between now and next May. The government says Mr and Mrs Abroad would be shocked by the general election being cancelled, despite the fact that it's not actually booked and it's not due.

I should have thought many foreigners are more bemused by the fact that the right to exercise the vote is a moveable feast in this country.

Why tourists or anyone else might be reassured by a deferment of one month is unclear. The crisis won't be over, so it looks like a feeble attempt at a tactful interlude, like waiting until after your neighbour's funeral before asking his wife for your shears back.

That's not to say I think a wounded government should be forced to carry on and do its time. The liveliest part of our democracy is the fact that our rulers can be brought down unexpectedly by civil disobedience. But anyone with undying faith in the parliamentary road to progress must be saddened by the thought of cabinet ministers with their diaries out saying: "When's good for you?" and: "Hang on, that's half-term," and: "Gordon, how much money have we got left?"

webTitle: When the last cow has gone

fields.headline: When the last cow has gone
fields.standfirst:
When Andrew O'Hagan went to Sainsbury's at the start of his investigation into British farming, talk was of real food and a new breed of rural producer. In the third instalment of this major study, he heads west to find out just what that has meant for one farm in Devon

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: When Andrew O'Hagan went to Sainsbury's at the start of his investigation into British farming, talk was of real food and a new breed of rural producer. In the third instalment of this major study, he heads west to find out just what that has meant for one farm in Devon.
fields.body:
The day before I set off for Devon, there was a not entirely encouraging headline in the London Evening Standard: "Stay Out of the Countryside." Just when it seemed there was little room for disimprovement in the predicament of British farmers, news came of the biggest outbreak of foot and mouth disease in more than 30 years - 27 infected pigs were found at Cheale Meats, an abattoir in Essex.

Infected animals were quickly discovered on other farms. Suspicious livestock began to be slaughtered in their hundreds. Such was the smoke from the incineration site in Northumberland that the A69 had to be closed for a time. British exports of meat and livestock (annual export value £600m), as well as milk (400,000 tons are exported each year), were banned by the British government and the EU.

"It is like staring into the abyss," Ben Gill, president of the National Farmers' Union, said. "On top of the problems we have had to face in the last few years, the impact is unthinkable."

The National Pig Association estimates that the relatively small outbreak of swine fever last year cost the industry £100m. The last epidemic of FMD, in October 1967, led to the slaughter of 442,000 animals - a loss of hundreds of millions of pounds in today's terms, only a fraction of which made it back to the farmer in compensation. Last month's ban affected more than half of Britain's farmers and no one doubts that many will be ruined.

The county of Devon seemed dark green and paranoid when I travelled there the day after the ban was introduced. Yet I'd planned my visit as an opportunity to gaze at a vision of farming success. Stapleton Farm, my destination, produces quality brands of yoghurt and ice-cream. It was the one named by the Sainsbury's executives, the day I walked with them around the flagship store on the Cromwell Road, as an example of the new kind of partnership that can exist between supermarkets and farmers. Their optimism seemed hard to recapture now.

Passing through Bideford, Charles Kingsley's "little white town", you get a sudden rush of the way things used to be. Local records tell of how, in the 18th century, a bell would ring in Bideford market at 1pm, calling the local people to buy wheat. Traders were not allowed to buy until after 2pm, to prevent dealers overcharging the poor. The New Market, which opened in September 1960, sold 2,317 animals on its first day - dairy cows, calves, sheep and pigs.

According to a correspondent in Devon Life, Bideford livestock market has weathered several outbreaks of foot and mouth disease. Peter Kivell, a local farmer, remembers the call in the small hours in October 1967, announcing the first case in the area: "I spent the rest of the night wondering how we'd manage."

The low green valleys of the West Country have been subject to far less of the subsidy-mad prairie-isation you see in other counties, yet still there has been a vast downsizing of the rural economy. In 1995, 78,402 animals were sold in Bideford market; in 1998, 48,826. Many farmers now run their farms at subsistence level.

Stapleton Farm is not far from Bideford, nearer Great Torrington, and there isn't a cow to be seen. No livestock, no fields, no manure, no tractors, just a small manufacturing unit that couldn't be doing better. This is the enterprise Sainsbury's put me on to when I asked about the partnerships with farming that mattered to them. This is the new thing.

I found Carol Duncan in a Portakabin she uses as an office. She was surrounded by Sainsbury's invoices and office stationery. Like her husband Peter, she considers herself a modern rural producer. "I was delighted when we managed to get rid of the very last cow off this farm," she said. "That's the thing about cows, you know, they just poo all the time."

Peter's father and grandfather had run the farm in the traditional West Country way; they had livestock and worked the fields through thick and thin. "But from an early age I wasn't interested in that kind of farming," Peter said. "I wanted to be inside reading books. And I was interested in the different things you can do with milk. In the 1960s we farmers needed to diversify. The traditional way had been to stand around waiting for the government price review. I wanted to change things. My father would say: 'Who's going to milk the cows?'

"We started with three churns. Carol was an art teacher and that kept us going through the difficult years. We made yoghurt and started selling it to independent schools - if you're paying £16,000 a year for a school, you want to make sure your children aren't eating rubbish."

"We had to fight for our markets," Carol said. "In 1994 the price of milk in Devon went up by 29%. We had to increase the price of the yoghurt by 5% and we lost some of our German contracts. I went out and fought to get them back. It was horrible: 200-year-old cheesemakers were shut down and hardly a Devon clotted cream-maker was left standing. We thought we were going out of business."

"We started exporting our stuff," Peter said, "to Belgium especially. We supply an upmarket supermarket chain called Delhaize."

"Until this morning," Carol interjected. "We've just been banned from exporting."

"We're hoping it will only be a matter of weeks," Peter said, "but this sort of thing can ruin people. We're praying it doesn't spread."

The Duncans have more than 30 people working at Stapleton - chopping, grating, mixing, packaging, labelling, loading. The old farm buildings where the yoghurt and ice-cream are produced look typical enough among the high hedges of north Devon, yet inside each shed are silver machines and refrigerated rooms that are miles away from the world of cows.

Peter tells the story of the Sainsbury's development manager coming down to see them in 1998 as if relating a great oral ballad about a local battle or love affair. "The woman came down. I thought she seemed so fierce. They had already taken samples of our yoghurt away. They said they liked them. But when the woman came that day she just said: 'I suppose you'd like to see these' and it was the artwork for the pots. They'd already decided we were going into business. I nearly fell off my chair."

Carol laughed. "Yeah, and they said, how many of these could we produce a week?" They started aiming for 10,000 pots a week in a hundred stores. "It was incredibly hard work," Peter said. "We were putting yoghurt into pots by hand and pressing the lids on. Then they wanted more. We had to get better machinery. So it was off to the bank for £80,000. Come February 1999, we were doing 50,000-60,000 pots a week."

"We think Sainsbury's are geniuses," Carol added. "We give them yoghurt and they sell it."

Stapleton Farm processes all its own fruit by hand; the milk comes from three local farms. Recently, they started giving the milk farmers half a penny more per litre, because of the hard time the farmers are having. "It's been a music hall joke for years," Peter said, "about farmers complaining. But now the worst has come true."

"The ladies who work for us are all here to earn money to feed their kids," Carol said. "The farms they live on are struggling. It's a struggle for us, too, but it's our little dream."

The Duncans' dream has been one of survival and self-sufficiency, and being free of that last cow. But as environmentalists, they may have trouble living with the price of their own success: expansion. Supermarkets want to be able to rely on volume and if Stapleton Farm's yoghurt continues to grow in popularity, it will have to get bigger; the charm of its smallness cannot last. The week I met the Duncans, they were reeling from having bought a £68,000 machine that wasn't yet working. Doing well entails spending more, so demand can be met. They are heavily in debt but also rejoicing in their success.

"Starting to do business with Sainsbury's feels like being mown down by a bus," Peter said.

"Yes," Carol said, "but I was so relieved when we got rid of that last cow and that old farm. That's the thing with a lot of the farmers around here: they have the potential to get into tourism, get into the farm cottages side, caravans and all that. Farmers just have the wrong attitude."

"No," Peter said, "not all of them. The problem was the Marketing Boards, which gave farmers the wrong idea. They thought someone would just take their produce away and turn it into money. No other country in Europe was like that. That is why we are so far behind."

Carol heaved a sigh. "I'm so pissed off about the foot and mouth disease. We had a whole lot of ice-cream going into Spain next week. Not now. I hope it doesn't spread to here."

I asked the Duncans if they were worried about having all their eggs in one basket. What if people get fed up with Devon yoghurt? What if Sainsbury's find somewhere cheaper, or better able to meet the volume required? Or if it falls for the new kid on the block? Carol met my gaze evenly. "We'll survive," she said.

In the factory, Peter stopped in the middle of a chilled room, with the sound of clicking going on further along the line, the sound of mass production. "This was a cattleshed when I was little," he said. "I remember it clearly."

We stood beside a pallet of strawberry yoghurts bound for Sainsbury's. It had the special label attached. I asked who paid for the Sainsbury's packaging. "Oh, we do," he said.

That afternoon Tim Yeo, the shadow agriculture spokesman, said the government had responded in chaotic fashion to a chain of farming crises. "I wish he would shut up," Nick Brown replied. "He is trying to make political capital out of a terrible situation." And when I was barely out of the West Country, news broke of another farm where livestock was found to have contracted foot and mouth. The farm was in Devon. And the farmer owned 13 other farms.

"I was delighted when we managed to get rid of the very last cow off this farm," she said. "That's the thing about cows, you know, they just poo all the time." Peter's father and grandfather had run the farm in the traditional West Country way; they had livestock and worked the fields through thick and thin. "But from an early age I wasn't interested in that kind of farming," Peter said. "I wanted to be inside reading books. And I was interested in the different things you can do with milk. In the 1960s we farmers needed to diversify. The traditional way had been to stand around waiting for the government price review. I wanted to change things. My father would say: 'Who's going to milk the cows?' "We started with three churns. Carol was an art teacher and that kept us going through the difficult years. We made yoghurt and started selling it to independent schools - if you're paying £16,000 a year for a school, you want to make sure your children aren't eating rubbish." "We had to fight for our markets," Carol said. "In 1994 the price of milk in Devon went up by 29%. We had to increase the price of the yoghurt by 5% and we lost some of our German contracts. I went out and fought to get them back. It was horrible: 200-year-old cheesemakers were shut down and hardly a Devon clotted cream-maker was left standing. We thought we were going out of business." "We started exporting our stuff," Peter said, "to Belgium especially. We supply an upmarket supermarket chain called Delhaize." "Until this morning," Carol interjected. "We've just been banned from exporting." "We're hoping it will only be a matter of weeks," Peter said, "but this sort of thing can ruin people. We're praying it doesn't spread." The Duncans have more than 30 people working at Stapleton - chopping, grating, mixing, packaging, labelling, loading. The old farm buildings where the yoghurt and ice-cream are produced look typical enough among the high hedges of north Devon, yet inside each shed are silver machines and refrigerated rooms that are miles away from the world of cows. Peter tells the story of the Sainsbury's development manager coming down to see them in 1998 as if relating a great oral ballad about a local battle or love affair. "The woman came down. I thought she seemed so fierce. They had already taken samples of our yoghurt away. They said they liked them. But when the woman came that day she just said: 'I suppose you'd like to see these' and it was the artwork for the pots. They'd already decided we were going into business. I nearly fell off my chair." Carol laughed. "Yeah, and they said, how many of these could we produce a week?" They started aiming for 10,000 pots a week in a hundred stores. "It was incredibly hard work," Peter said. "We were putting yoghurt into pots by hand and pressing the lids on. Then they wanted more. We had to get better machinery. So it was off to the bank for £80,000. Come February 1999, we were doing 50,000-60,000 pots a week." "We think Sainsbury's are geniuses," Carol added. "We give them yoghurt and they sell it." Stapleton Farm processes all its own fruit by hand; the milk comes from three local farms. Recently, they started giving the milk farmers half a penny more per litre, because of the hard time the farmers are having. "It's been a music hall joke for years," Peter said, "about farmers complaining. But now the worst has come true." "The ladies who work for us are all here to earn money to feed their kids," Carol said. "The farms they live on are struggling. It's a struggle for us, too, but it's our little dream." The Duncans' dream has been one of survival and self-sufficiency, and being free of that last cow. But as environmentalists, they may have trouble living with the price of their own success: expansion. Supermarkets want to be able to rely on volume and if Stapleton Farm's yoghurt continues to grow in popularity, it will have to get bigger; the charm of its smallness cannot last. The week I met the Duncans, they were reeling from having bought a £68,000 machine that wasn't yet working. Doing well entails spending more, so demand can be met. They are heavily in debt but also rejoicing in their success. "Starting to do business with Sainsbury's feels like being mown down by a bus," Peter said. "Yes," Carol said, "but I was so relieved when we got rid of that last cow and that old farm. That's the thing with a lot of the farmers around here: they have the potential to get into tourism, get into the farm cottages side, caravans and all that. Farmers just have the wrong attitude." "No," Peter said, "not all of them. The problem was the Marketing Boards, which gave farmers the wrong idea. They thought someone would just take their produce away and turn it into money. No other country in Europe was like that. That is why we are so far behind." Carol heaved a sigh. "I'm so pissed off about the foot and mouth disease. We had a whole lot of ice-cream going into Spain next week. Not now. I hope it doesn't spread to here." I asked the Duncans if they were worried about having all their eggs in one basket. What if people get fed up with Devon yoghurt? What if Sainsbury's find somewhere cheaper, or better able to meet the volume required? Or if it falls for the new kid on the block? Carol met my gaze evenly. "We'll survive," she said. In the factory, Peter stopped in the middle of a chilled room, with the sound of clicking going on further along the line, the sound of mass production. "This was a cattleshed when I was little," he said. "I remember it clearly." We stood beside a pallet of strawberry yoghurts bound for Sainsbury's. It had the special label attached. I asked who paid for the Sainsbury's packaging. "Oh, we do," he said. That afternoon Tim Yeo, the shadow agriculture spokesman, said the government had responded in chaotic fashion to a chain of farming crises. "I wish he would shut up," Nick Brown replied. "He is trying to make political capital out of a terrible situation." And when I was barely out of the West Country, news broke of another farm where livestock was found to have contracted foot and mouth. The farm was in Devon. And the farmer owned 13 other farms. © Andrew O'Hagan. This is an edited version of an article that first appeared in the London Review of Books. To subscribe to the LRB, call 020-7209 1141.

webTitle: Ministers failed to heed warnings, experts say

fields.headline: Ministers failed to heed warnings, experts say
fields.standfirst:
Pigswill: Key advisers feared suspect meat in feed

Special report: foot and mouth

Foot and mouth: free daily email service with latest updates
fields.trailText: Ministers failed to act on warnings from government advisers in 1997 that pigswill - or catering waste and by-products - should be banned because they believed foot and mouth could never again appear in Britain, government sources said last night.
fields.body:
Ministers failed to act on warnings from government advisers in 1997 that pigswill - or catering waste and by-products - should be banned because they believed foot and mouth could never again appear in Britain, government sources said last night.

The spongiform encephalopathy advisory committee warned that discarded meat should not be fed to animals within a species to avoid the outbreak of another potentially disastrous epidemic following the banning of meat and bone meal in 1996.

Although pigs cannot, in theory, catch BSE, the committee was concerned that other diseases, or variants of them, could be triggered off by a piece of suspect meat hidden in pigswill, which is fed to fewer than 2% of the 11m pigs slaughtered in Britain annually.

In 1997, few specialists thought foot and mouth could return to Britain after 30 years. But there was concern that infected meat could transmit either swine fever or other diseases.

Harriet Kimbell, a law professor and member of Seac, said yesterday that the committee had successfully called for a ban on abattoir waste being fed to pigs in 1997. Sub sequently, they discussed the wider use of pigswill, often unspecified meat collected as waste from restaurants, school canteens, and food companies and boiled as a cocktail to produce a thick, lightish liquid.

"Although the issue was debated, the recommendation was not quite so clear-cut to stop it although some members thought they had recommended that pigswill would stop," she recalled. "Since 1997, Seac has said in general terms that material should not be recycled within a species because - say - contaminated pork would pass to pigs."

Swill was once part of everyday life. Every school canteen had a "pig bin", where leftovers would be dumped before being recycled into swill. Pigs ate it because their robust digestive systems can take meat and all kinds of plants. Farmers liked it because it was cheap.

In 1980 the use of waste food from airlines was banned, and the number of licensed operators fell to 1,300 by 1987, when a new order also required for swill internally generated on the farm to be cooked. By 1990 this had fallen to just over 300.

For the past two years all businesses that process, transport or feed swill have been required to be licensed and their premises inspected regularly by vets.

The tougher regulations have deterred most farmers and they instead use manufactured farm feed consisting of cereals fortified with soya protein. Pigswill is now fed to only around 120,000 pigs annually, and used on a small proportion of the 3,000-odd pig farms, concentrated mainly in East Anglia and East and North Yorkshire. The small fattening unit of Bobby and Ronald Waugh, at Heddon-on-the-Wall - the likely source of the outbreak - is therefore an exception in an industry which prides itself on far higher standards than rivals abroad.

Maff regulations stipulate that swill must be catering waste - from kitchens, restaurants and food factories - and "non mammalian animal by-products", such as poultry and fish waste.

It can only be fed to pigs after it has been "fully processed" - to at least 100C for one hour - at premises approved and licensed by the ministry.

Movement from the "holding premises" to another pig unit, which is not licensed, also should be approved, according to regulations updated two years' ago.

The processing of catering waste imported on planes, ships or trains, is also illegal.

Some farmers' leaders now believe the government's ban on swill is being used as a diversion to avoid facing other tough questions about imported pig meat.

Richard Longthorp, an East Yorkshire pig farmer and a board member of the Pig Producers' Association, said last night: "Ministers are engaged in a cynical attempt to find a scapegoat for their own incompetence, jumping up and down about pigswill. But what are they doing about imports, legal or otherwise? That is the key issue. How the hell did this get into Britain in the first place?"

fields.headline: Marketing Week
fields.standfirst: Publication date: March 29
fields.trailText: March 28: Reebok is to open its first standalone European retail store in the UK next month.
fields.body:
Reebok is to open its first standalone European retail store in the UK next month at Lakeside shopping centre in Essex.

The Rugby Football Union is to open rugby-themed high street coffee shops and has earmarked Leicester, Richmond, Bath and Bristol as possible locations.

Alex Rodrigues, Ericsson UK consumer products marketing chief, is moving to the company's Singapore operation. He will be replaced by Steve Walker, Ericsson UK marketing director of future technology and business development.

Psion's entire marketing department, including marketing director Alasdair Seton-Marsden, could be axed as part of an £11m restructure that will result in 100 job losses in the UK.

Avon has promoted Andrea Slater, general manager of overseas business development, to UK vice-president of marketing. She will replace Bob Briddon, who has become vice-president of US marketing.

Yahoo! UK and Ireland has teamed up with Air Miles to launch an online loyalty programme called Yahoo! Points.

Jaguar is consolidating its entire £90m global account into Young & Rubicam following months of speculation.

Sainsbury's is reviewing the £10m direct marketing account for its financial arm, Sainsbury's Bank, currently held by WWAV Rapp Collins Media.

Vodafone has appointed Tempus Group to co-ordinate and manage its multi-million-pound global communications.

Yves Saint Laurent is understood to have moved its European media account, worth £3m in the UK, out of OMD.

fields.headline: Marketing
fields.standfirst: Publication date: March 29
fields.trailText: March 29: Vodafone is set to appoint Wieden & Kennedy as its global creative agency.
fields.body:
Vodafone is set to appoint Wieden & Kennedy as its global creative agency as it develops the first global mobile service brand.

Vizzavi, the multi-access portal owned jointly by Vivendi Universal and Vodafone, is expected to appoint Optimedia to handle its European media business, worth about £100m.

England cricket legend Ian Botham's nickname - Beefy - and his picture will appear on a new range of frozen meat products by Perkins Frozen Foods, to be launched next month.

Shell is to scrap its Smart consumer rewards programme, one of the UK's longest running loyalty schemes, and replace it with an initiative to be launched in June.

Several of the UK's major tobacco manufacturers are believed to be considering plans to offer shares to their customers to circumvent legislation restricting direct marketing by tobacco firms.

Wella is to spend £27m on a major haircare range, called Vivality, as it bids to leapfrog rivals such as Lever Faberge and Bristol-Myers Squibb to take third place in the shampoo sector.

Interbrew UK has promoted Richard Evans to marketing director, responsible for the UK's best-selling premium lager, Stella Artois, and other brands including Boddingtons, Heineken and Vodka Source.

Danone is reviewing its global biscuit advertising account. Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper currently runs the UK's Jacob's Bakery account.

Nestle has scrapped its pro-biotic LC1 Go! live yoghurt drink less than three years after it was launched with a £2m TV ad campaign.

The Rugby Football Union has bolstered its commercial department as part of a restructuring aimed at making the sport more attractive to potential sponsors.

fields.headline: SES buys US rival in £3.5bn deal
fields.trailText:
10.30am: Societe Europeenne des Satellites today swooped on an American rival by buying GE Americom for £3.5bn, writes Dan Milmo.

Mar 27: SES to buy General Electric satellite arm

Mar 19: SES shows its strength

Mar 14: ITV signs satellite deal with SES
fields.body:
Societe Europeenne des Satellites, the company that beams BSkyB and the BBC to digital homes in the UK, has today swooped on an American rival in a £3.5bn deal.

Luxembourg-based SES confirmed the acquisition of GE Americom, which distributes hundreds of US TV channels, including Disney and NBC, to cable networks.

The deal will make SES the first commercial satellite operator to build a genuine global footprint, allowing it to beam TV, radio and internet services around the world.

"The relationship with GE is an ideal complement to our existing network of strong regional partners," said Romain Bausch, chairman of SES.

"The combination of global coverage and our unique regional presence gives us a distinct competitive edge to the advantage of our customers."

The group will change its name to SES Global as part of the deal and will also list on the New York stock exchange.

It is believed one of the obstacles to SES acquiring a major US player was the government of Luxembourg, which owns 30% of the company and did not want to dilute its holding.

The Luxembourg-based group decided to go for General Electric's GE Americom after running the rule over several targets, including General Motors' PanAmSat.

SES, which is Europe's leading direct-to-home satellite TV broadcaster, will use the GE acquisition as a springboard for its broadband internet strategy.

GE Americom also supplies telecoms and internet services for big-name clients such as AOL Time Warner and Disney, and will boost broadband revenues at SES, which stand at just £26m.

Some industry observers fear consumers will baulk at the higher price of satellite broadband services.

However, the possibility of bundling television, radio and internet onto one distribution platform will appeal to media companies.

"The new SES Global organisation will be well positioned to build the future of broadband satellite communications through a global satellite fleet," said Mr Bausch.

General Electric will receive £1.9bn in cash and a 22% share in SES Global as part of the deal.

Today's deal will need clearance from regulators on both sides of the Atlantic, and European competition watchdogs are still poring over GE's recent acquisition of US competitor Honeywell.

SES offers radio, television and high-speed internet services in North Africa, Asia and Latin America and to 87m homes in Europe.

Following the GE Americom deal, it now owns 28 satellites and part-owns 13 more.

This month, the company sealed a £100m, ten-year deal with ITV to broadcast the network's programmes on a digital satellite platform.

fields.headline: Council pioneers witness support programme
fields.standfirst: Hundreds of tenants are forced to become homeless or live in fear when they become the victim of a hate crime. Waltham Forest hopes its new support scheme will change all that. David Batty reports
fields.trailText: Hundreds of tenants are forced to become homeless or live in fear when they become the victim of a hate crime. Waltham Forest hopes its new support scheme will change all that. David Batty reports.
fields.body:
When Michael Verrier and his partner were forced to flee their home three years ago after homophobic neighbours threatened to kill them, they were left homeless for a month while the council found them new accommodation.

But despite appearing as witnesses in the London borough of Waltham Forest's court case against their attackers, the couple felt they were the victims of rough justice. The north-east London council re-housed them in a decrepit flat where they were subjected to another two-and-a-half years of abuse, while their abusive neighbours were allowed to stay put.

"The flat was cold, damp and mouldy as the water pipes were broken and the central heating didn't work. We got rubbish and rotten fruit pushed through the letterbox, graffiti over the front door and our car was vandalised. But we got no support from the council - the only other property they offered us was opposite the ringleader of the kids harassing us. So when they asked us to give evidence in court a second time we said no," said Mr Verrier.

The couple's experience is not an isolated case. Hundreds of tenants are forced to become homeless or live in fear every year, but local authorities have no statutory duty to prioritise their housing needs. Waltham Forest council hopes to change that with a new support scheme for victims and witnesses of hate crimes, enabling them to be swiftly and safely relocated.

The witness mobility scheme, launched this month, was developed after the council successfully evicted nine households found guilty of breaching their tenancy agreements by perpetrating racial harassment in 1998 and 1999. The cases showed witnesses had to be re-housed quickly and safely, and offered practical and emotional support, if they were to give evidence in court.

In partnership with the Metropolitan police, registered social landlords (RSLs) and voluntary groups, the council provides rapid re-housing, benefit assessments within a week, a befriending service, access to other support services - such as counselling and childcare - and taxis to and from court.

Caroline Jones, Waltham Forest equalities manager for community services, said the scheme has helped victims of hate crimes, domestic violence, rape and child abuse. During the six-month pilot last year, the police re-housed two witness households, RSLs re-housed three and the local authority two.

"Local authorities are under increasing pressure to tackle these crimes. But before we started the scheme, there was no help for people involved in civil cases while support for those giving evidence in criminal cases was very ad hoc," said Ms Jones.

"We've published a pack outlining the scheme as several other councils are interested in adopting it, including Devon, Cornwall, Oldham and Trafford, as well as the Northern Ireland housing executive. But we want the government to make it a statutory duty to move vulnerable witnesses."

Housing providers in the scheme give priority to harassed witnesses, offering them a property similar in size and quality to their existing home. Tenants can be re-housed in stock belonging to any of the agencies involved in the scheme, even outside of the borough - and London - if that is the safest option. Housing associations involved include Circle 33, Metropolitan, London and Quadrant, Family, Solon and Springboard.

Chief executive of Waltham Forest housing association, Linda Milton, who represents registered social landlords in the project, said: "It was very difficult for a small organisation with limited housing stock like ourselves to re-house people quickly in suitable accommodation. Tenants suffering racial harassment often had to decide whether to put up with the abuse for some time or move to an area which meets few of their cultural needs."

"It's all about listening to the experiences of victims," he said. "We were given counselling and the council made sure the flat was in a good state of repair. If they or the police came to us now we would be prepared to go to court."
fields.bodyText: When Michael Verrier and his partner were forced to flee their home three years ago after homophobic neighbours threatened to kill them, they were left homeless for a month while the council found them new accommodation. But despite appearing as witnesses in the London borough of Waltham Forest's court case against their attackers, the couple felt they were the victims of rough justice. The north-east London council re-housed them in a decrepit flat where they were subjected to another two-and-a-half years of abuse, while their abusive neighbours were allowed to stay put. "The flat was cold, damp and mouldy as the water pipes were broken and the central heating didn't work. We got rubbish and rotten fruit pushed through the letterbox, graffiti over the front door and our car was vandalised. But we got no support from the council - the only other property they offered us was opposite the ringleader of the kids harassing us. So when they asked us to give evidence in court a second time we said no," said Mr Verrier. The couple's experience is not an isolated case. The witness mobility scheme, launched this month, was developed after the council successfully evicted nine households found guilty of breaching their tenancy agreements by perpetrating racial harassment in 1998 and 1999. The cases showed witnesses had to be re-housed quickly and safely, and offered practical and emotional support, if they were to give evidence in court. "Local authorities are under increasing pressure to tackle these crimes. "We've published a pack outlining the scheme as several other councils are interested in adopting it, including Devon, Cornwall, Oldham and Trafford, as well as the Northern Ireland housing executive. fields.headline: Second suicide bomb hits Israel
fields.trailText: A second Palestinian suicide bomber attacked Israel this morning, killing two   teenagers in the north of the country one day after a Palestinian man blew   himself up outside a bus in Jerusalem.
fields.body:
A second Palestinian suicide bomber attacked Israel this morning, killing two teenagers in the north of the country one day after a Palestinian man blew himself up outside a bus in Jerusalem.

This morning's explosion happened as a group of Israeli teenagers were waiting for a ride to school. The bomber and two students were killed and four people were hurt, one critically. The Islamic militant group Hamas claimed responsibility for the blast, and said seven more bombers were ready to strike.

Two further bombs were discovered and safely exploded in the Israeli towns of Netanya and Petah Tikvah.

The Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, called for an emergency session of his security cabinet this afternoon and has vowed to avenge the recent killings.

Police have said they expected an increase in the pace of bombings during the Arab League summit which was to conclude in Jordan later today, but the Israeli government has been reluctant to respond during the summit.

However, Israel's police commissioner said little more could be done to prevent suicide attacks.

"We are faced with a very big offensive of the terrorist organisations to carry out attacks," said the police commissioner, Shlomo Aharonishki. "The last few days show that in spite of all our stepped-up efforts ... they succeeded in getting in."

Today's blast went off shortly after 7.30am (5.30am GMT) in the parking lot of a gas station.

"I saw three young fellows lying on the ground. They looked in really bad shape," said a customer at the station, who was only identified by his first name, Maoz. "Another was wounded, but was still standing up."

White plastic bags covered the three bodies lying on the ground near the gas pumps. Troops sealed off the area, searching for additional explosives.

Earlier this month, four people, including a Palestinian suicide bomber, were killed in a blast in Netanya. Yesterday, Palestinian militants carried out back-to-back attacks in Jerusalem, including a bombing near a bus that killed the assailant and injured more than two dozen by-standers.

In a phone call to a Western news agency, Hamas claimed responsibility for today's blast and yesterday's suicide bombing in Jerusalem.

In the West Bank town of Hebron, an 11-year-old Palestinian boy, Mahmoud Darawish, was killed in an exchange of fire yesterday with Israeli forces at a refugee camp.

Seven Palestinian-owned cars and five Palestinian shops were torched yesterday in Hebron's Abu Sneineh neighbourhood, apparently by Jewish settlers avenging the killing of a 10-month-old Israeli girl earlier this week by Palestinian snipers.

webTitle: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.
fields.body:
Time and Time again

Yes, we're all tired of computer retailer Time, whose antics so frequently adorn these pages. But now it has surpassed itself and it would be miserly to deprive you of the tidings. Gary Tonge bought himself a computer system from a Time store in Leeds. He wrote out a cheque for £1,489 and was told to expect delivery within three weeks. The monitor turned up along with some software and an invoice for £181, but six calls to the £1-a-minute helpline failed to elicit the rest of the equipment. Two months later, Time decided that it had no record of the purchase and told Tonge that the shop he'd bought it from had closed down. Two faxes of the receipt and a bank statement showing the debit left our old friends unmoved, although they did send off a refund of the £181. Now they say they don't even have a record of Tonge's requests for a refund, despite his regular phone calls and his return of the incomplete system.

 Consumer knows where to prod Time's heartstrings and four months after Tonge's cheque was cashed he received a refund. "We will liaise with Mr Tonge until the situation is resolved to his satisfaction," promises the press office. A word of warning for the future: if you're ordering goods worth more than £100 try to pay by credit card. The Consumer Credit Act allows you to claim against the card issuer in cases like this.

No change from Ryanair

As the government ponders whether to postpone the May elections, sporting fixtures are cancelled and funeral pyres flame the night sky, one company appears to be unaware of the foot and mouth epidemic. Eilish Slater of Chingford, Essex, had booked a flight to Cork to visit her parents' dairy farm. Now, of course, she can't travel and risk infecting the herd, but Ryanair is having none of it. It won't allow her to delay her departure or give her a refund of her £116 fare.

 Ryanair is one of the least-loved airlines, according to our postbag. In September it was hauled before the office of fair trading for disclaiming responsibility for baggage with wheels or handles (ie most suitcases), in breach of airline regulations. Aer Lingus and BA are both offering refunds or postponements for flights to Ireland from the UK, but this was Ryanair's response to our enquiry: "If a passenger has booked a changeable ticket we will change their ticket. If a passenger has booked a non-changeable ticket we will not change their ticket. When a passenger books a ticket with us they are advised the terms and conditions applicable to the ticket purchased." The air transport users' council points out that airlines are under no obligation to cancel non-transferable tickets because of the crisis. "We are very pleased that two airlines have chosen to do so," says a spokesman. "It's unfortunate that Ryanair declines to follow suit."

BA's identity crisis

While on the subject of airlines, Bill Kirton's multiplying identity on BA's records was described here earlier this month. BA had confused his Executive Club account with that of another Bill Kirton, declined to respond to his protests, then later renamed him William Davis. BA ignored our pleas for an explanation, but it seems heads rolled after we ran the piece. Kirton has now had his account restored and received an apology.

But what's this? David Miller of London, who is also a BA Executive Club member, informs us that for the past four years his account has been confused with a G Miller of the same neighbourhood. "In 1997 he cleared my account of airmiles for a trip to Nice and although I received a refund the problem is recurring," he says. "I've basically given up trying to get any action out of BA."

 This time we only have to wait two weeks for a reply from BA. "We've set Mr Miller up with a new account and credited him with the lost airmiles," says a spokeswoman. "We're now investigating to see how these cases could have arisen."

 Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 020-7713 4731, send a fax on 020-7239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com.

webTitle: In brief: Russell Crowe starts work on his Beautiful Mind

fields.headline: Russell Crowe starts work on his Beautiful Mind
fields.standfirst: Plus: Oscar night receives mixed reviews; Billy Crystal speaks up for Steve Martin; vintage posters make a mint; Soderbergh's one-hour film-making lesson
fields.trailText: Plus: Oscar night receives mixed reviews; Billy Crystal speaks up for Steve Martin; vintage posters make a mint; Soderbergh's one-hour film-making lesson
fields.body:
 Fresh from snatching the best actor Oscar from under the moustached nose of Tom Hanks, Russell Crowe arrives in Princeton, New Jersey today to begin work on his new film, A Beautiful Mind. Directed by Ron Howard, the film stars Crowe as true-life maths genius John Forbes Nash, whose brilliant career was blighted by schizophrenia. The scheduled one-week location shoot has electrified the refined Ivy League college town. "Many people on the campus are very excited about the film," says Princeton spokeswoman Marilyn Marks. "Some of the theatre students are even being given the opportunity to work as production assistants." Joining Crowe on set will be former best actor rival Ed Harris, a losing nominee for his role in Pollock.

 The Oscar night postmortem continues. Hot on the heels of the news that Sunday's telecast had the lowest ratings in years (see earlier story) came some sniffy reviews from America's critics. Chief among the detractors was Barry Garron of the Hollywood Reporter, who described the event as: "One of the few Academy presentations that ended on time and still managed to be too long." Meantime the jury was still out on Steve Martin's debut turn as the night's emcee. "If Steve Martin proved anything last night it's how good Billy Crystal is in the role of Oscar host," wrote Adam Bruckman in the New York Post. "Martin seemed to be little more than a caretaker assigned to fill in until Billy decides to return." Variety, however, took a kinder line. Martin, it reckoned, was: "Skillful and at ease as he joshed with the celebrities."

 Talking of Billy Crystal, the man himself avoided the ceremony in favour of watching the event on TV at home. Speaking yesterday, he paid tribute to his successor: "Steve is a good friend of mine and I was really happy he did well." Crystal recently completed directing the comedy America's Sweethearts, starring Julia Roberts and John Cusack. Sharp-eared listeners to Sunday's ceremony may have heard Martin describe Roberts at one stage in precisely those terms. Surely the new host wasn't sneaking in a sly plug for the old one.

 A set of vintage movie posters passed down from an Arizona cinema owner yesterday raised a whopping £158,000 in auction at Christie's in London. The lot's biggest prize was a mint condition poster for the Boris Karloff chiller The Mummy from 1932, which sold for £80,750. The 65 posters, which all hailed from the golden days of a small cinema in Jerome, Arizona, that closed way back in 1933, were auctioned off by the son in law of the original owner.

 It would seem that the only person unimpressed by Steven Soderbergh's recent achievements in direction (two nominations; one Oscar) is the man himself. The maker of Traffic and Erin Brockovich reckons there's nothing to it and says that he can teach most novices how to direct a film in just one hour. "I can get you on your feet in 60 minutes, guaranteed. The rudimentary aspects of how to put a scene together can really be taught to anyone with a brain in about an hour and the rest of it is a question of whether or not you're an artist in that particular venue."
