webTitle: The route to literary success: be young, gifted but most of all gorgeous

fields.headline: The route to literary success: be young, gifted but most of all gorgeous
fields.standfirst: Agents accused of touting talent to publishers like a ' beauty pageant'
fields.trailText: Agents and publishers yesterday confirmed what embittered old stagers have long suspected: literary success is now as much about looks as the quality of your books. The "gorge factor" - whether a new author is seen as gorgeous or not - has become a key criterion in deciding whether a book gets the kind of marketing push that will give it a chance of selling.
fields.body:
Agents and publishers yesterday confirmed what embittered old stagers have long suspected: literary success is now as much about looks as the quality of your books. The "gorge factor" - whether a new author is seen as gorgeous or not - has become a key criterion in deciding whether a book gets the kind of marketing push that will give it a chance of selling.

With publishers no longer giving literary authors the luxury of three or four books to find a readership, a culture of hyping photogenic young things has gripped the industry.

Helen Richardson, publicity chief of Orion Books, who have not shied from promoting pretty faces themselves, sparked the debate at the London Books Fair by accusing agents of "touting their new discoveries around publishers in a well-run beauty pageant".

Her admission came as a procession of older novelists, led by Deborah Moggach, Margaret Drabble and Anita Brookner, bemoaned the new "ageist and lookist" attitudes among publishers. "The younger and more beautiful an author, the more promotable they are as a writer. It has nothing to do with writing," Moggach, 52, complained. Even some of those writers lucky enough to be both young and gorgeous are joining the backlash against the tyranny of literary totty. The New Puritans, led by the novelist Nick Blincoe, say they are sick of being marketed as cool and fashionable when they want to be seen as authentic voices of their generation.

The gathering yesterday heard how publishers were now judging writers on how many features they might generate in newspaper lifestyle sections, rather than promoting the older "gargoyles" who count themselves lucky if they make it onto the review pages.

Even Zadie Smith, 25, the award-winning author of White Teeth, was made over - temporarily ditching her specs and Afro look - according to Neil Taylor, publishing director of Orion.

"Looking at how Zadie changed over those months, you can see how writers can allow themselves to be sold as beautiful. I didn't see too many White Teeth reviews without a photograph," he said. "Looks do make a difference, we all know that. Captain Corelli's Mandolin was a word-of-mouth success only because of Louis de Berniere's looks. If Louis wasn't short, fat and bald he would have been in the papers all the time."

Clare Alexander, the editor-turned-agent of Booker winner Pat Barker among others, confessed that when Alex Garland, whose debut The Beach was an instant bestseller, and Donna Tartt, the equally good-looking author of The Secret History, walked into her office she was "delighted - [they were] both young and beautiful. I would be lying if I said it didn't make my job a lot easier. The best marketing of all though is the work itself, and it has to be good. You can't get away with looks alone, it all comes down to the writing in the end."

She warned, however, of the consequences of publishers falling into the trap of buying on "beauty contests". She said: "Writing is a craft. It often takes six or seven books for a writer really to come into their own. Pat Barker did not really begin to sell until well into her Regeneration trilogy. I can't see too many publishers today losing money like they did with Pat's early books. Look at the bestsellerlists, and you will find most of the writers there are in their late 40s or 50s."

Ms Alexander said the obsession with youth was a British phenomenon, and blamed our "tabloid-driven press" where the books pages "are not what they used to be. Because there are fewer reviews than there used to be there has been a drive to get authors into the features pages and the glossy magazines. Obviously if they are young and gorgeous they have got a head start."

Hype has its limits, though, argued Mr Taylor, who cited the disastrous reviews garnered by Amy Jenkins' heavily marketed debut Honey Moon, whose publication was preceded by acres of adoring press coverage. He accused the creator of the TV hit This Life of "single-handedly killing off chick-lit [twentysomething female-oriented fiction].

"At least we can thank her for that. What really annoys me is the resources which go into promoting books of no real worth or merit by these so-called celebrity authors. The lesson of the Amy Jenkins debacle is the public is smarter than we give them credit for."

Mr Taylor, who edited The Long Firm by the equally photogenic Jake Arnott, said proper, talented writers who just happened to be good-looking were now being tarred with the bimbo brush. "The BBC made a documentary about Jake and the book and it was clear they assumed we were selling it on his looks and not his writing, which is wonderful. He was portrayed as young and beautiful when he is actually nearly 40."

Blincoe said the New Puritans came about as a reaction to the industry's obsession with youth and trendiness. "Inevitably, it is easier to get the press and the style magazines interested in a young first-time writer with all the trendy trappings, but that is not why people read books. They want stories from an authentic experience and they are not getting that right now. I've been a publisher myself, and it is amazing how when someone was describing a writer to me, they'd say he or she was 'a great stylist and really gorgeous too' as if that was important.

"That isn't to say that we New Puritans aren't young and beautiful and trendy ourselves, because we are of course."

Martin Latham, of Waterstone's booksellers, said readers were not particularly interested in the "fanciability factor" in a writer. "I know it sounds strange, but they are actually interested in the book, in stories. People don't buy a Tim Willocks book because he once slept with Madonna. Publishers have played some outrageous tricks on the public, from ghost writers to all those books with bimbos in Lycra on the covers to sell books, and people have got wise to them."

Cool and fashionable - the most marketable

Zadie Smith, 25

The winner of the Guardian First Book award has been shortlisted for just about every literary prize on the planet for her "breathtaking" debut novel, White Teeth, a dazzling romp through multicultural north London. Her youth has also helped turn her into an international publishing sensation. So far her beauty has not been a hindrance.

Jenny Colgan, 28

Her first novel, Amanda's Wedding, a twentysomething urban comedy, earned her a £1.2m advance from HarperCollins which included a film rights deal with Warner Brothers.

Classified by snooty critics as another one of the trivial "Chick Lit" brigade, she coined the alternative term Bliggers, meaning Brit Lit It Girls. Bliggers, she claims, are between 25 and 35 and rather than writing aspirational Bridget Jonesy nonsense, are trying to reflect the real-life dilemmas of urban, professional women. Currently living in LA where she is working on her third novel.

Louise Bagshawe, 29

While Jenkins seems to court publicity, Bagshawe runs from it. There was a sharp intake of breath when she landed a £70,000 two-book deal at just 23. But it was money well spent because her debut novel, Career Girls, sold over 200,000 copies as did her next three books. Last year she was valued at £2m.

Jake Arnott, 40

A little old to be truly classified as a handsome young thing, nonetheless Arnott was well-preserved enough to adorn newspapers and magazines everywhere when his first book, The London Firm, was published to great acclaim two years ago. As one reviewer declared: "It doesn't matter he's no young prodigy. He's 38, so what? Those eyes, that look - part brute, part boy."

Tobias Hill, 30

Went to Hampstead comprehensive in London with Zadie Smith, though no one has yet thrown any big-money advances his way despite his Byronic good looks. This may be because he made his name as a poet, who publishers seem to believe deserve to starve. Embarrassingly good reviews for his novels, Underground (1999) and The Love of Stones, seem to have made little difference.

Amy Jenkins, 34

Son of a well-connected cartoonist, his first novel, The Beach - about the dark side of a lotus-eating year backpacking in Thailand - was reprinted 25 times in less than a year. fields.bodyText: Agents and publishers yesterday confirmed what embittered old stagers have long suspected: literary success is now as much about looks as the quality of your books. The "gorge factor" - whether a new author is seen as gorgeous or not - has become a key criterion in deciding whether a book gets the kind of marketing push that will give it a chance of selling. With publishers no longer giving literary authors the luxury of three or four books to find a readership, a culture of hyping photogenic young things has gripped the industry. Helen Richardson, publicity chief of Orion Books, who have not shied from promoting pretty faces themselves, sparked the debate at the London Books Fair by accusing agents of "touting their new discoveries around publishers in a well-run beauty pageant". Her admission came as a procession of older novelists, led by Deborah Moggach, Margaret Drabble and Anita Brookner, bemoaned the new "ageist and lookist" attitudes among publishers. "The younger and more beautiful an author, the more promotable they are as a writer. It has nothing to do with writing," Moggach, 52, complained. Even some of those writers lucky enough to be both young and gorgeous are joining the backlash against the tyranny of literary totty. The New Puritans, led by the novelist Nick Blincoe, say they are sick of being marketed as cool and fashionable when they want to be seen as authentic voices of their generation. The gathering yesterday heard how publishers were now judging writers on how many features they might generate in newspaper lifestyle sections, rather than promoting the older "gargoyles" who count themselves lucky if they make it onto the review pages. Even Zadie Smith, 25, the award-winning author of White Teeth, was made over - temporarily ditching her specs and Afro look - according to Neil Taylor, publishing director of Orion. "Looking at how Zadie changed over those months, you can see how writers can allow themselves to be sold as beautiful. I didn't see too many White Teeth reviews without a photograph," he said. "Looks do make a difference, we all know that. Captain Corelli's Mandolin was a word-of-mouth success only because of Louis de Berniere's looks. If Louis wasn't short, fat and bald he would have been in the papers all the time." Clare Alexander, the editor-turned-agent of Booker winner Pat Barker among others, confessed that when Alex Garland, whose debut The Beach was an instant bestseller, and Donna Tartt, the equally good-looking author of The Secret History, walked into her office she was "delighted - [they were] both young and beautiful. I would be lying if I said it didn't make my job a lot easier. The best marketing of all though is the work itself, and it has to be good. You can't get away with looks alone, it all comes down to the writing in the end." She warned, however, of the consequences of publishers falling into the trap of buying on "beauty contests". She said: "Writing is a craft. It often takes six or seven books for a writer really to come into their own. Pat Barker did not really begin to sell until well into her Regeneration trilogy. I can't see too many publishers today losing money like they did with Pat's early books. Look at the bestsellerlists, and you will find most of the writers there are in their late 40s or 50s." Ms Alexander said the obsession with youth was a British phenomenon, and blamed our "tabloid-driven press" where the books pages "are not what they used to be. Because there are fewer reviews than there used to be there has been a drive to get authors into the features pages and the glossy magazines. Obviously if they are young and gorgeous they have got a head start." Hype has its limits, though, argued Mr Taylor, who cited the disastrous reviews garnered by Amy Jenkins' heavily marketed debut Honey Moon, whose publication was preceded by acres of adoring press coverage. He accused the creator of the TV hit This Life of "single-handedly killing off chick-lit [twentysomething female-oriented fiction]. "At least we can thank her for that. The lesson of the Amy Jenkins debacle is the public is smarter than we give them credit for." Mr Taylor, who edited The Long Firm by the equally photogenic Jake Arnott, said proper, talented writers who just happened to be good-looking were now being tarred with the bimbo brush. fields.headline: Hoddle joins Spurs
fields.trailText: Glenn Hoddle has quit Southampton to become manager of Tottenham Hotspur.
fields.body:
Glenn Hoddle has quit Southampton to become manager of Tottenham Hotspur.

Hoddle made the decision to return to White Hart Lane at 10pm last night after just five hours of talks with Spurs, Southampton chairman Rupert Lowe revealed today.

Lowe said: "At 10pm yesterday I received a phone call from Glenn saying he wished to end his employment at Southampton with immediate effect and join Tottenham Hotspur as their manager.

"I am saddened that Glenn has chosen to leave the team."

But Lowe insisted Hoddle would not be released from his registration with Southampton until Spurs had paid suitable compensation.

He said: "Negotiations remain outstanding as to the compensation payable to this club and his registration will not be released until this is satisfactorily concluded. To this end I will be seeking advice from the Premier League.

Hoddle will be joined at White Hart Lane by his assistant John Gorman, who said: "I've just been in with the chairman. I've asked for permission to go with Glenn and the chairman has accepted that."

"It still needs confirmation from Tottenham regarding my position," he added. "It still has to be done properly and officially but I'll probably cease to be at this club from today.

"I'm leaving a fantastic club and I'll be a bit sad but, hopefully, I'm going to join another great club - one that's close to my heart as well as Glenn's.

"I'm delighted that Glenn has asked me to go and join him," Gorman told Sky Sports.comTV. "It's fantastic for me if I get the chance to join Tottenham."

webTitle: Blair's community spirit needs a focus

fields.headline: Blair's community spirit needs a focus
fields.standfirst: Labour wants to rekindle community spirit but is it right to mix religion and politics?
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee: Never has a government worried so much about "community". What is it? Can governments regenerate it for social good?
fields.body:
Never has a government worried so much about "community". What is it? Can governments regenerate it for social good? Labour has been searching in the grassroots for clumps of it. Does it reside in the Rotarians, mothers unions, Women's Institutes, five-a-side leagues, mosques or churches? How elusive these social pressure points are, some eccentric, others empty vessels, unrepresentative of anything but themselves. In this pluralist, diverse society there are few easy entry points into the beating heart of any locality. What is urban freedom for many, a blessed escape from old lace-curtain community, is also desolate isolation for others.

Yesterday the American guru of community led a breakfast seminar in 10 Downing Street. Harvard Professor Dr Robert Putnam, author of Bowling Alone gave his causes of the collapse of community: television, two-career families, urban sprawl with commuting and the failure of the second world war generation to pass on war-time civic values to their baby-boomer children. Community is in decline - unions, churches, clubs, bowls, political parties, voting, even visiting bars. Where there is community, there is less crime, better school performance, more happiness. Belonging to one community group delivers the same volume of happiness as doubling your income.

Belonging to one group is so good for you that it reduces by a half the chance of dying in the next year, two groups reduces death risk by three quarters. (Putnam's numerical sociology sometimes verges on numerology.)

One answer, he says, is faith-based communities which "enhance civic life" and he welcomes President Bush's intention to use them. "Faith-based organisations have a proven ability to reweave the fabric of distressed communities and they deserve support from government." And tomorrow the prime minister will promise it to them here. Addressing a conference of the Christian Socialist Movement, with other faiths in attendance, he will praise the good churches can do in community renewal and the value of church schools. Competing with William Hague, he will claim Labour values are closest to Christian values. True, according to Mori. The Church of England is no longer the Tory party at prayer: only 26% of its members vote Tory, 48% Labour. Among Roman Catholics only 17% are Tory, with 48% Labour. In this country the far right evangelicals are still a minority.

But mixing God and politics is a perilous business. If the PM's text is not well-worded he may risk the WI slow hand-clap. These are socialists who may question his Christian values from the left: members are pressing for a narrowing of the now widening gap between rich and poor. But outside the hall, the great agnostic/atheist British majority has a queasy distaste for politicians airing religious sentiments: it only fuels their cynicism.

At a breakfast this week, the Bishop of Liverpool and the Reverend Steve Chalke explained their pitch to the prime minister for tomorrow's conference. Churches do community best, with the best volunteers and the best schools, the "faith dollar" goes further and they want more social funding. Chalke wants the prime minister to stop "hard left Labour councils" refusing to fund faith groups on the grounds that church groups only employ their own church members and Christian school teachers. Faith groups only work, he says, because they are all believers. He is not polite about "state" employees, as if they were clock-watching time-servers.

Churches attract politicians. Their edifices suggest an important place in communities, for lack of anything else tangible to grasp, despite often empty pews and aged congregations. But founding a national social policy around a church attendance currently at 7.5% (generous estimate) looks implausible. It is another colossal difference with the US which ought to make British politicians more wary of using US social thinkers. Robert Putnam is left of centre and knows Britain (unlike Hague's guru, Marvin Olasky, a bible-belt, anti-welfare anti-abortionist). But even so, Putnam's prescriptions sound essentially alien. His vision of community, for all his denials, looks like a return to the 1950s, women back to Kinder, Küche, Kirche. His social determinism is out of step with modern times: it looks cynical to want poor people to join churches not because religion is true but because it is good for them.

The reason Labour's social policies may work where the old slum clearances failed over the years is because they focus on the people. Funding renewal through partnerships that join up all the local state agencies with voluntary groups is a way of reaching out through every tentacle to all that moves and breathes. Some churches do run brilliant social programmes for drug addicts, the homeless, the young and the old. But religious groups must take their place along with the other voluntary groups - funded and judged according to their results.

There is a lot of hocus-pocus talked about community, as if it were magic to be sprinkled about like holy water. Nostalgic for old community values, Putnam recalls the glory days of Elks, Salvation Army, choral societies, scouts and churches. But times change. Creating a new sense of community requires building on people's lives as they are now, the things people want enough to need to band together communally. Community activity always depended on women, but they have now gone out to work instead.

But seek out where strangers do still meet and it is still largely parents - mainly mothers - outside school gates, playgroup or playground, at the checkout or the baby clinic. Ask communities now what they need most locally and the first answer is childcare - a guaranteed creche and nursery place for every child. Harriet Harman's recent childcare commission toured the country and that was the universal answer.

So if Labour wants to foster a new community spirit, start with beautiful children's palaces, attractive welcoming places, offering every service from ante-natal to after-school clubs. At a stroke it would bring together all parts of the community under one roof, in centres run by and for local parents, the only way to unite all classes, each contributing according to income. These would be the missing social heart-beat in each area, nurturing a multitude of voluntary and self-help groups, clubs, classes and community action, run by faith or non-faith volunteers side by side with professionals.

Now that would be community, but it doesn't come cheap. One estimate suggests £10bn for 10,000 centres. Money well spent, it would transform individual lives, binding together isolated families and socially divided communities everywhere. Kick-starting community requires less government angst and more government action. What a manifesto pledge that would be.

fields.headline: Stefano Hatfield: View from America
fields.standfirst: He is an expert on advertising in Europe and America and has won plaudits for his insightful musings about the industry over the past 10 years. Every Wednesday morning, Stefano Hatfield, now based in New York heading Ad Age Global, will bring our readers a taste of Madison Avenue. This week, he asks whether Britney Spears was the best choice for Pepsi's Oscars night advertising extravaganza.
fields.trailText: March 28: Surely Pepsi's pouting Britney alienated much of the female TV audience on Oscars night, writes Stefano Hatfield.
fields.body:
Oscars night is American television's biggest night of the year for pulling in female viewers.

Men have their January testosterone-fest the Super Bowl but - true to stereotype - women still tune in to the Academy Awards to see who was wearing what and who made a Gwyneth of themselves.

Oscars night is an advertiser's dream.

Bizarre then that the most hyped new commercial of the night was the Pepsi campaign featuring a particularly babelicious Britney Spears, complete with Pepsi bottle-top belly adornment.

Surely a pouting, strutting, sexy-ish Britney is destined to alienate a large chunk of that female audience. She's not exactly America's sweetheart, a title held currently by Julia Roberts.

But, if you have to have a bright young thing rehashing old Michael Jackson routines - fireworks, dry ice, a shimmying chorus - rather Britney than her chief rival for princess of pop, Christina Aguilera.

Britney's is a much safer image than Aguilera, despite the constant shedding of all that clothing.

There is no doubt she is currently massive. The pre-event advertising trailed the launch of the commercial almost as much as the awards show, where the movies themselves had been the subject of individual big money ad campaigns attempting to sway the minds of the few thousand eligible academy voters.

Rarely have so many advertising dollars been squandered chasing so few - although advertisers still taking space in the dying XFL on NBC may beg to differ.

The Britney Pepsi ads are a good example of advertising that tries to work on many levels.

Yes, it is a Pepsi ad in a long-running vein. There's no big idea, just a major celebrity endorsement as Pepsi continues with its strategy of "owning" music while rival Coke "owns" sport.

Last Sunday, on ABC, Britney was reaching out to a second audience - Pepsi staff and bottlers everywhere. She was dressed as a Pepsi employee, the on-screen audience transfixed by her gyrations in a Pepsi bottling plant.

In the cola wars, half the battle is getting your own staff and suppliers on board.

The idea is for everyone at work the next day to be buzzing about the Pepsi ads their neighbours, friends and family have pointed out to them. It's a little like the chairman's wife syndrome in corporate advertising. (Yes, it does still exist).

Forget about the strategic and creative thinking, the only focus group that can sometimes matter is the wife or immediate family of the client company's senior executives.

Maybe that's why we suddenly saw the new American advertising icon and former presidential candidate Bob Dole put in a surprise appearance at the end of the last commercial of the night.

I am sure the Britney commercials hit a particular mark - they tried hard enough and at least they replaced the always ambiguous "Joy of Cola" with the "Joy of Pepsi".

But on the night they were blown away by a delightfully original New Jersey skit on Budweiser's "Whassup?" campaign - "How you doin'?" - from DDB Chicago and the team behind the Sopranos.

Next year, however, advertisers and broadcasters alike will be hoping for more of a blockbuster year than this, when the pre-night favourite was Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, a foreign, subtitled movie.

That it did not win was irrelevant to the ratings, which were down 16% on last year to 23.7m households.

Even Gladiator lacks the viewer appeal of say, Titanic, when the whole country had seen it at the movies already. Oscars night needs blockbusters and a little controversy. Britney's belly may be a joy for Pepsi, but it's not enough for the rest of us.

 Stefano Hatfield is managing director and editorial director of Ad Age Global.

Rarely have so many advertising dollars been squandered chasing so few - although advertisers still taking space in the dying XFL on NBC may beg to differ. The Britney Pepsi ads are a good example of advertising that tries to work on many levels. Yes, it is a Pepsi ad in a long-running vein. There's no big idea, just a major celebrity endorsement as Pepsi continues with its strategy of "owning" music while rival Coke "owns" sport. Last Sunday, on ABC, Britney was reaching out to a second audience - Pepsi staff and bottlers everywhere. She was dressed as a Pepsi employee, the on-screen audience transfixed by her gyrations in a Pepsi bottling plant. In the cola wars, half the battle is getting your own staff and suppliers on board. The idea is for everyone at work the next day to be buzzing about the Pepsi ads their neighbours, friends and family have pointed out to them. It's a little like the chairman's wife syndrome in corporate advertising. (Yes, it does still exist). Forget about the strategic and creative thinking, the only focus group that can sometimes matter is the wife or immediate family of the client company's senior executives. Maybe that's why we suddenly saw the new American advertising icon and former presidential candidate Bob Dole put in a surprise appearance at the end of the last commercial of the night. I am sure the Britney commercials hit a particular mark - they tried hard enough and at least they replaced the always ambiguous "Joy of Cola" with the "Joy of Pepsi". But on the night they were blown away by a delightfully original New Jersey skit on Budweiser's "Whassup?" campaign - "How you doin'?" - from DDB Chicago and the team behind the Sopranos. Next year, however, advertisers and broadcasters alike will be hoping for more of a blockbuster year than this, when the pre-night favourite was Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, a foreign, subtitled movie. That it did not win was irrelevant to the ratings, which were down 16% on last year to 23.7m households. Even Gladiator lacks the viewer appeal of say, Titanic, when the whole country had seen it at the movies already. Oscars night needs blockbusters and a little controversy. Britney's belly may be a joy for Pepsi, but it's not enough for the rest of us.  Stefano Hatfield is managing director and editorial director of Ad Age Global.

fields.headline: Ericsson's marketing chief on the move
fields.trailText: 10am: Ericsson's UK marketing director Alex Rodrigues is relocating, as the mobile phone giant axes 1,200 jobs in the UK, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Ericsson's UK marketing director Alex Rodrigues is to leave for Singapore as the mobile phone giant takes the axe to 1,200 jobs in the UK.

Mr Rodrigues, marketing director for Ericsson UK mobile phones, is to take up a position running the company's accessories business across the Asia-Pacific region.

He will be replaced by Steve Walker, Ericsson's UK marketing director of future technology and business development.

Mr Walker's new title will be director of marketing and new business for consumer products.

But there is widespread speculation that Ericsson's marketing teams will come under close scrutiny and will possibly be restructured as the company tries to slash £1.36bn from its annual costs.

Yesterday it announced the closure of plants in Carlton, Nottingham and Scunthorpe.

The value of other non-manufacturing roles such as marketing will be reassessed as Ericsson faces up to slower than expected mobile phone sales.

Last month Ericsson global vice-president of marketing Jan Ahrenbring left the company and was replaced by Philip Vanhoutte.

webTitle: Should the National stage commercial productions?

fields.headline: A nice little earner
fields.standfirst: Should the National stage commercial productions?  Stephen Moss  reports
fields.trailText: Should the National stage commercial productions? Stephen Moss reports.
fields.body:
Should the National Theatre have put on My Fair Lady in a co-production with commercial producer Cameron Mackintosh? And should its artistic director, Trevor Nunn, personally profit from the show's transfer to the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, in July? Criticisms of Nunn and the National were voiced in press reports over the weekend, and yesterday Nunn broke his silence on the issue to condemn what he called "the age-old journalistic device of slur through innuendo".

Nunn focused on a report in the Observer in which two regional theatre heads - Jenny Stephens at the Swan Theatre in Worcester and Venu Dhupa at Nottingham Playhouse - attacked the National for putting on such blatantly commercial work. "There is nothing wrong with being accessible," said Stephens, "but you should be innovative too if you are being subsidised by the public."

Dhupa singled out the way in which Nunn will benefit financially from the transfer to the West End. "I could not live with that on my conscience," she said.

Nunn is furious at the suggestion that personal profit was a motive for directing My Fair Lady. "It has been the custom and practice in the theatre for several decades that those individuals creatively responsible for a work that transfers from the subsidised sector to the commercial sector should be free to negotiate their arrangements with the commercial producer," he says. "I have been determined from the outset that whatever happens in such royalty negotiations, the result must be to the advantage of the National Theatre. Therefore, my contract with the National provides that if one of my productions transfers, my representative would negotiate unfettered ... Any monies to be received by me are to be divided between the National Theatre and myself in such a way that, of all the production royalty recipients, the National is the highest. Through this arrangement, the National Theatre is rewarded potentially at a higher level than might otherwise have been achieved."

Yet since the National will receive £14.2m from the Arts Council next year, it should also be obliged to account to the public. Despite Nunn's remarks yesterday, there remains a reluctance to discuss precise figures. Cast members can expect to earn more during the West End run than they will get on the South Bank, while Nunn and the National are likely to receive a royalty and a share of profits. If the show runs for several years, as has happened with transfers such as An Inspector Calls and Copenhagen, those profits could be very substantial.

My Fair Lady, which opened a fortnight ago to largely favourable reviews, cost around £1.25m to stage. Mackintosh, who owns the rights to the show, put up half. He will pay the entire cost of the West End transfer, which is estimated at £2.5m. It will have a 17-week run at the National before transferring to the Theatre Royal. The first three months of the West End run are already virtually sold out, with takings nudging £5m.

The utilitarian argument for the co-production is that everyone benefits. The National has a sell-out four-month run and a nice little earner thereafter; Nunn has extra income to supplement what a spokeswoman for the National implied to the London Evening Standard this week was the laughable salary of "less than £120,000 a year"; and Mackintosh has a bankable show that gets the kick-start of a high-profile debut at Britain's premier theatrical venue.

Mackintosh and Nunn demonstrated the potency of their theatrical magic in 1985 with Les Misérables, which was staged by the Royal Shakespeare Company, with Nunn as artistic director, before transferring to the West End. It has been earning the RSC almost £1m a year in royalty fees ever since. Nunn has done pretty well out of it too: the Observer estimated his royalty earnings last year at £1.4m, though a large slice of that is accounted for by Cats, which is soon to celebrate its 20th year in the West End and was produced entirely within the commercial sector.

"Cameron Mackintosh doesn't benefit from My Fair Lady's run at the National, and he bears all the costs of the transfer," says the National's head of press, Lucinda Morrison. "We are not a repertory theatre, and we can't keep productions in the repertoire forever. It is in our interest to transfer successful productions. We get the best deal we can and take no further risk."

"The National will be on a very healthy royalty," says Nick Allott, managing director of Cameron Mackintosh Ltd. "It's an excellent example of the public-private partnership, which the government is so keen on."

Nunn, who has had to withstand constant criticism of his alleged commercialism at the National, gave an impassioned defence of his record yesterday. "Subsidy has not been used to produce commercial theatre," he said. "On the contrary, the investment in the show made by the National Theatre will provide an opportunity for the National subsequently to benefit, thus helping its subsidy position." He refers to the "13 major awards" won in the past year and recites the roster of forthcoming productions, though no mention is made of the production of another musical, South Pacific, which he is scheduled to direct for the National this autumn. That show will give further ammunition to his critics, especially if there is more backing from Macintosh and another West End transfer.

Nunn's unpopularity in some theatrical quarters has certainly contributed to the back-biting over My Fair Lady. "This wouldn't have been raised if there wasn't so much dissatisfaction with the way Nunn has been running the National," says one theatre critic. "There is a feeling among some writers that the National is not for them. Nunn is good at big, showy shows, but has no particular flair for contemporary theatre."

"I think it's fine for him to produce My Fair Lady," says Tom Morris, artistic director of Battersea Arts Centre, "but what is worrying is the way he seems to lack conviction in his support for the young artists he wants to bring on. I'm delighted that the National does high-quality popular shows, and he's certainly very good at these, but I wish he'd spend a bit more of his energy supporting the next generation of artists."

The arguments over Nunn's artistic stewardship are pressing, given that his contract expires next year. It is not yet clear whether he will offer himself for another five years in the most exposed job in British theatre, though he has backtracked on earlier statements that he would definitely step down. Nunn appears to have a unique ability to polarise theatrical opinion, and the arguments over My Fair Lady may yet prove to be merely a rehearsal for the bigger showdown ahead. And, no, it won't be lovely.

fields.headline: Mayoral race trails Oscars hype
fields.standfirst: At least one difference between this election and the Academy awards, says Duncan Campbell, is that none of these candidates will be asked who made their dress
fields.trailText: At least one difference between this election and the Academy awards, says Duncan Campbell, is that none of these candidates will be asked who made their dress.
fields.body:
Now that all the winners have departed from the Shrine auditorium with their Oscars, Los Angeles gets down to the much simpler business of choosing its next mayor. With the voters going to the polls on April 10, speculation about who will take on the job held for the last eight years by Richard Riordan is growing.

There are six candidates out of a total of 25 running who have any chance of winning or at least going to a run-off ballot, but so far no runaway favourite has emerged. As polling day approaches, the commercials are coming thick - in some cases really thick - and fast.

The clearest indication of the way in which the race may go probably came last week when the LA Times suggested in a leader that the choice essentially lay between the city attorney, James Hahn, and the former speaker of the state assembly, Antonio Villaraigosa.

Hahn comes from a prominent LA political family and his father held the post of city supervisor and had a particular rapport with the city's African American community. That affection seems to have passed on to the younger Hahn because he is riding high in the polls amongst African American voters.

Hahn, who is currently running highest in the polls, is best known in recent times for introducing controversial gang injunctions whereby named members of gangs were subjected to curfews and restrictions on meeting in public. Civil rights groups protested against the injunctions as unconstitutional but such was the weariness with gangs in some parts of LA that few major objections were raised.

Villaraigosa would be the first Latino mayor since 1872 and it is for this reason that there is particular interest in the race. Latinos now make up around a third of the city's population although they have traditionally voted in smaller percentages. This year may be different.

Villaraigosa has the backing of both governor Gray Davis and most of the unions in the city and he is counting on an army of union activists to get the votes out on the day. There is another Latino candidate, Xavier Becerra, but he is low in the polls.

Not that Hahn and Villaraigosa are going to have it all their own way, which is why the vote will almost certainly go to a run-off on June 5 with no-one able to claim more than 50% of the vote first time around. Steve Soboroff, a wealthy businessman, who made his money in property and as a broker is spending heavily and hoping that what worked for fellow-republican George Bush will work for him. He presents himself as "a problem solver, not a career politician".

One early favourite who now seems to be trailing is Joel Wachs, an experienced councillor who would, if elected, be the first openly gay mayor of a major US city. He has been advertising heavily, too, and promising to get rid of Bernard Parks, the beleaguered chief of police if he wins. Kathleen Connell, the only woman standing, is very much an outsider but has also been running commercials, claiming that she is the candidate who understands the current energy crisis in the state.

There is one crucial difference between the mayoral race and the academy awards. None of the candidates will be asked who made their frock as they arrive to hear the results on polling day.

fields.headline: Consignia sets up agency roster
fields.trailText: Consignia has drawn up a roster of agencies and earmarked £30m to market newly privatised postal services, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Consignia, formerly the Post Office, is putting £30m behind a roster of design and web agencies to make the new brand consumer-friendly and competitive in the newly opened market.

The move comes the week the postal service changed its name, became a public limited company and lost its monopoly over the 80m letters delivered daily in the UK.

The agencies have been appointed to work on accounts worth £30m over five years.

They will work on literature and point of sale, internal communications, information design, new media and consultancy across all Consignia's divisions including ParcelForce, the Royal Mail, and Post Office Counters.

"Royal Mail is one of the UK's most well-known brands and enjoys massive trust amongst its customers," said Sarah Larvor, head of brand at Royal Mail.

"We will be looking to our agencies to help us grow and support the brand and keep it relevant in an increasingly competitive market."

OgilvyInteractive, part of the Ogilvy & Mather advertising network, has been appointed to look at interactive strategy and the web.

Its sister agency, OgilvyOne, is already on the Royal Mail direct marketing and relationship marketing agency rosters.

The other agencies appointed to the new roster are Boag Associates, Bi-Design, Brandhouse, Carter Wong Tomlin, Conran Design Group, c eye, Design Group, First Impression, Rufus Leonard, Start Design, Traffic Interactive Ltd, True and an in-house agency.

fields.headline: Aguilera and Britney go head-to-head in cola wars
fields.trailText:
Coca-Cola has signed New York pop star Christina Aguilera to star in a new TV advertising campaign for £50m, reports Julia Day.
Stefano Hatfield: View from America

Feb 14: Kylie to star in Pepsi advert

Feb 7: Britney to front global Pepsi campaign
fields.body:
Britney Spears and Christina Aguilera are already millionaires but now the two of them have netted a staggering £115m to front what is set to be the biggest cola war in years.

Coca-Cola has signed New York pop star Christina Aguilera to star in a new TV advertising campaign for a fee reputedly worth £50m.

The deal follows last month's £65m contract between PepsiCo and Aguilera's arch-rival Spears, whose campaign for the rival cola brand broke during Sunday night's Oscar ceremony.

There is believed to be no love lost between the two pop divas who started their showbusiness careers together, appearing on a US Disney Channel show.

Coke's advertising campaign will break in the US this summer. Aguilera's debut single Genie in a Bottle was US number one for five weeks.

Spears is reportedly being paid £65m over a five-year period for promoting Pepsi.

The first of her adverts broke on Sunday during the Oscars coverage and featured US senator Bob Dole watching her performance.

fields.headline: Stalker's 20-year obsession
fields.trailText: Scotland Yard is hunting an obsessive who is said to have written thousands of pornographic letters to famous women including Joan Bakewell, Diana Rigg and Sue McGregor. By Nick Hopkins.
fields.body:
Scotland Yard is hunting an obsessive who is said to have written thousands of pornographic letters to a number of famous women, including Joan Bakewell, Diana Rigg and Sue McGregor.

Always writing in longhand and using airmail envelopes, the man has tormented his victims over the past 20 years by sending anonymous letters, describing his sexual fantasies in explicit detail, to their home addresses and agents.

Other women who have been targeted include the actress Nyree Dawn Porter, who became a household name in 1967 when she played Irene in the television adaptation of the Forsyte Saga, and Dee Dee Wilde, the founding member of the 70s dance troupe Pan's People.

Police only realised the same person was writing the letters when another actress, Moira Lister, complained about a note she received while she was performing in the West End last December.

The letter was sent to the Forensic Science Service where an expert in calligraphy found that the handwriting matched other offensive letters that had been kept on file from investigations around the UK. All the letters bear Bolton, Lancashire or Manchester postmarks

An inquiry eventually linked the same writer, assumed to be a man, to dozens of famous women, many of whom were not prepared to be named.

Three victims will talk for the first time about the letters on a Crimewatch UK programme which is due to be broadcast tonight.

"This just has to come to an end," Joan Bakewell says. "We've been harassed and patient long enough. It is time this person realises how upsetting this is."

Sue McGregor, a presenter of Radio 4's Today programme, adds: "This has gone on long enough, it is more than a nuisance and it is actually against the law."

Porter says the writer clearly "needs help".

Police have given some of the offensive letters to Crimewatch in the hope that viewers will recognise the handwriting.

"The handwriting is quite distinctive and there will be plenty of material for comparison purposes against any suspect," said Keir Hartley, the expert who analysed the letters. "We have been able to link dozens of letters that have been written by the same hand."

DS Shirley McGlone, who is in charge of the inquiry, yesterday described the case as "very unusual."

A Crimewatch spokesman confirmed that some of the women had been receiving mail for more than 20 years.

"It is thought that thousands of letters may have been sent over this time. Due to the extreme language involved, a very limited number of words were appropriate for TV viewing."

"The writer seems to be fascinated with women of a certain type from a certain era," said a police spokeswoman.

All the letters bear Bolton, Lancashire or Manchester postmarks An inquiry eventually linked the same writer, assumed to be a man, to dozens of famous women, many of whom were not prepared to be named. Three victims will talk for the first time about the letters on a Crimewatch UK programme which is due to be broadcast tonight. "This just has to come to an end," Joan Bakewell says. "We've been harassed and patient long enough. It is time this person realises how upsetting this is." Sue McGregor, a presenter of Radio 4's Today programme, adds: "This has gone on long enough, it is more than a nuisance and it is actually against the law." Porter says the writer clearly "needs help". Police have given some of the offensive letters to Crimewatch in the hope that viewers will recognise the handwriting. "The handwriting is quite distinctive and there will be plenty of material for comparison purposes against any suspect," said Keir Hartley, the expert who analysed the letters. "We have been able to link dozens of letters that have been written by the same hand." DS Shirley McGlone, who is in charge of the inquiry, yesterday described the case as "very unusual." A Crimewatch spokesman confirmed that some of the women had been receiving mail for more than 20 years. "It is thought that thousands of letters may have been sent over this time. Due to the extreme language involved, a very limited number of words were appropriate for TV viewing." "The writer seems to be fascinated with women of a certain type from a certain era," said a police spokeswoman.

fields.headline: Well-bred opposition's bark has no bite
fields.trailText: Can we have an election soon, please? Not to get rid of the government, but to obtain a new opposition? This lot simply aren't up to it.
fields.body:
Can we have an election soon, please? Not to get rid of the government, but to obtain a new opposition? This lot simply aren't up to it.

Last week they had an entire hour to go at Stephen Byers, the minister who has been accused of helping cover up Geoffrey Robinson's hitherto unknown payments from the late Robert Maxwell. They failed to lay a glove on him.

Yesterday they had another full hour to pop at Robin Cook - alleged to have played fast and loose with a select committee report which had been wrongly leaked to him - and Keith Vaz, a junior Foreign Office minister who is charged with all kinds of skulduggery, whatever that might be.

There they were, the two of them, spread out before the Tories like big, juicy bones in front of a pack of junkyard dogs. Or rather, in front of a group of rather superior Afghan hounds, languid and well-groomed, who would never dream of doing anything so ungentlemanly as to chew on a mere bone. Why, such behaviour might get them blackballed from the Kennel Club!

As for Messrs Cook and Vaz, they reminded me of my favourite story about the comedian WC Fields, a notorious reprobate and drunkard in real life. It was his practice, while on the lot, to drink and play cards most of the night, then sleep through the morning in his caravan.

One day the studio head Louis B Mayer arrived and demanded to watch Fields working on set. The crew, equally fearful of both men, dispatched the youngest lad available to bang pitiably on the door. "Mr Fields, Mr Fields, Mr Louis B Mayer is here and he insists on seeing you," the poor lad quavered several times, without result.

Finally there was a heaving and sighing from inside the caravan. "Give Mr Mayer an evasive answer," the famous voice boomed. "Tell him to go fuck himself."

And that's the answer Mr Vaz and Mr Cook gave, in effect.

They talked about Zimbabwe and had a silly, inconclusive argument about whether the ministers were doing enough against Robert Mugabe, and whether Margaret Thatcher had ignored the many previous massacres in Matabeleland.

Someone said he was just back from Kosovo and had nothing but praise for our forces there. (It will be worth reporting when an MP returns from visiting our lads in the field and reports that they are a bunch of lazy, feckless, drunken, womanising cowards.)

Mr Vaz seized on this. "May I thank you for your kind words about British forces. I shall certainly pass them on to the defence secretary," to Tory sniggers. (As if Mr Hoon would say, "Thank goodness you told me, Vaz. I thought they might be a bunch of lazy, feckless" etc.)

Next Andrew Mackinlay, a one-man awkward squad from the Labour backbenches, demanded to know how many ministers had visited Belgrade since October last year. The answer of course is none.

"May I say," Mr Mackinlay boomed at the wretched Mr Vaz, "that is a most unsatisfactory answer ... either there is a shortage of Foreign Office ministers, or priorities are wrong. When is he going?"

Mr Vaz looked flummoxed for once. Roger Gale, a Tory who used to produce Blue Peter for the BBC, then brought scoffs and jeers on himself when he asked a supplementary question before Mr Cook had had time to give him the original answer. Wrap that man in sticky-backed plastic!

Mr Mackinlay cheerfully bounced to his feet again. "We have to provide the opposition as well in this place!" he yelled, and he was absolutely right.

fields.headline: Increasing pressure
fields.trailText: Council tax in England is rising by an average 6.4%, according to government figures. The typical Band D property - the usual barometer - will incur a levy of £901 in 2001-02, although the average payment for all householders will be lower, at £740.
fields.body:
Council tax in England is rising by an average 6.4%, according to government figures. The typical Band D property - the usual barometer - will incur a levy of £901 in 2001-02, although the average payment for all householders will be lower, at £740.

Total budgeted local authority spending for the new financial year is £60.3bn, of which council tax will raise £15.2bn, or just over a quarter.

The highest levy for a Band D property (assessed in 1991 as worth between £68,000 and £88,000) will be the £1,172 in Liverpool, despite a zero increase. The lowest will be the £410 in Westminster, London, despite a 9.3% increase.

Hilary Armstrong, local government minister, has said that councils ought to have been able to keep rises below last year's average 6.1% increase. Since 1997, grants to councils had risen 14% in real terms, compared to a 7% cut in the previous four years.

But local authority leaders are denying blame. Sir Jeremy Beecham, who chairs the Local Government Association, points to national factors such as the teachers' pay rise and relentless pressure on social services. "The announced increase in council tax can be laid firmly at the feet of increased costs... that local government has little control over," he says.

Archie Norman, the Conservatives' shadow environment secretary, claims: "This is the ultimate stealth tax hike - local residents foot the bill and local councillors take the blame."

fields.headline: New plan for firewall vaccination
fields.standfirst:
Special report: foot and mouth

Foot and mouth: free daily email service with latest updates
fields.trailText: The government last night cleared the way for a full-scale vaccination programme to combat the foot and mouth epidemic by seeking EU permission to create "firewalls" against the spread of the disease. Nick Brown, the minister of agriculture, said the final decision had yet to be made.
fields.byline: Paul Brown, Michael White and Patrick Wintour
fields.body:
The government last night cleared the way for a full-scale vaccination programme to combat the foot and mouth epidemic by seeking EU permission to create "firewalls" against the spread of the disease. Nick Brown, the minister of agriculture, said the final decision had yet to be made.

In a second move that will change market towns for ever, the government also announced restrictions on the movement of animals - mainly sheep whose undocumented sale and resale helped to spread the disease.

In future they will not be shipped round the country from market to market but will have to stay on one farm for 20 days to prevent the rapid spread of disease. Pigswill will also be banned.

In a long Commons statement, Mr Brown ran through the massive programme now under way to curtail the epidemic. With the crisis unabated, Tony Blair and his ministers are still hesitating between a May 3 and June 7 general election and for the first time yesterday Downing Street admitted that options for postponing the May 3 local elections are being considered.

In a further sign that the government is having to rethink its strategy, Mr Brown gave his strongest hint that the census will not go ahead on April 29, four days before the planned local elections.

He told MPs: "The census is not under way yet, but we are keeping the issue under review. Nothing should be done that will risk the spread of the disease and that includes inappropriate movements on farms." The census was last delayed in 1941.

Facing a subdued and despairing Commons, the minister stressed that "vaccination is not an easy option" and could delay full return to disease-free status and the export market. He said his representative on the EU's standing veterinary committee was seeking a "contingent decision" permitting vaccination "so that it can be deployed immediately if we conclude that it is the right approach".

Without endorsing any of the theories behind the out break - which Mr Brown called "unprecedented internationally" in its speed and scale - the minister conceded that one explanation could be "illegal commercial imports of meat where the contents have not been declared".

Controls, currently made on only 20% of meat imports, will be tightened. That was as close as he got to acknowledging reports that waste from a Chinese restaurant were used in pigswill at the farm in Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland, where the original outbreak is believed to have gone unreported for up to three weeks.

With MPs muttering in dismay, the minister pinpointed sheep "criss-crossing the country in hundreds of separate movements". Tracking sheep movements had proved difficult, if not impossible.

As Tory MPs repeated claims that the disease had emerged before the first reported case on February 19, Mr Brown derided "urban myths" about the outbreak, including reports that ministry officials knew about the disease earlier but concealed it.

Mr Brown was attacked by his Tory shadow, Tim Yeo, for failing to act promptly enough to halt the spread of the disease - 693 confirmed cases by last night, including 44 yesterday, with only 423,000 of the 719,000 animals authorised for slaughter killed so far.

That drew Tory taunts that at the current slaughter rate of 31,000 a day, it will take more than a week to clear the backlog alone.

Mr Brown said the slaughter delay was mainly in Cumbria. "I believe that our policy of containment of the disease is the right one and that the massive logistical exercise required to implement it is being reinforced. The measures we have announced today will ensure we learn the lessons and minimise the risks of such a tragedy in the future."

Mr Brown revealed that the government had set aside a further £200m for sheep farmers who were applying for their animals to be slaughtered as part of the welfare scheme. Hundreds of sheep are lambing on the fells but cannot be moved because of restrictions. Farmers will get 90% of pre-foot and mouth prices.

Officials later said that vaccinated animals, killed to slow the spread and create "firewalls", need not be slaughtered, but that could delay restoration of the country's disease-free status from three months to 12. Officials say the overall cost of vaccination would be £5 a shot.

In the high court yesterday, Peter Kindersley, the publishing entrepreneur who is also a farmer, asked for a judicial review of the government's slaughter policy for healthy animals, claiming it was illegal.

In Northern Ireland, where there has been only a single case of foot and mouth, farmers were given the go-ahead to export dairy and meat products from most of the country to the EU next month, provided there are no further outbreaks.

As Tory MPs repeated claims that the disease had emerged before the first reported case on February 19, Mr Brown derided "urban myths" about the outbreak, including reports that ministry officials knew about the disease earlier but concealed it. Mr Brown was attacked by his Tory shadow, Tim Yeo, for failing to act promptly enough to halt the spread of the disease - 693 confirmed cases by last night, including 44 yesterday, with only 423,000 of the 719,000 animals authorised for slaughter killed so far. That drew Tory taunts that at the current slaughter rate of 31,000 a day, it will take more than a week to clear the backlog alone. Mr Brown said the slaughter delay was mainly in Cumbria. "I believe that our policy of containment of the disease is the right one and that the massive logistical exercise required to implement it is being reinforced. The measures we have announced today will ensure we learn the lessons and minimise the risks of such a tragedy in the future." Mr Brown revealed that the government had set aside a further £200m for sheep farmers who were applying for their animals to be slaughtered as part of the welfare scheme. Officials later said that vaccinated animals, killed to slow the spread and create "firewalls", need not be slaughtered, but that could delay restoration of the country's disease-free status from three months to 12. Officials say the overall cost of vaccination would be £5 a shot. In the high court yesterday, Peter Kindersley, the publishing entrepreneur who is also a farmer, asked for a judicial review of the government's slaughter policy for healthy animals, claiming it was illegal. In Northern Ireland, where there has been only a single case of foot and mouth, farmers were given the go-ahead to export dairy and meat products from most of the country to the EU next month, provided there are no further outbreaks. fields.headline: Heavy duty
fields.standfirst: It's massively unpopular, hugely expensive to collect - and a large slice of it has to be paid back in benefits. So why are we still paying council tax? Chris Wheal investigates
fields.trailText: It's massively unpopular, hugely expensive to collect - and a large slice of it has to be paid back in benefits. So why are we still paying council tax? Chris Wheal investigates.
fields.body:
Voters in Bristol have made clear what they think of the council tax. Given a choice in a referendum, they ignored the wishes of their local council and opted for the lowest option open to them - a zero rise in the tax when the new financial year starts next week.

Perhaps that is hardly surprising. Council tax is a highly visible tax: while most of us pay VAT and income tax without ever really noticing a bill, council tax demands come though our doors and the payments appear on our bank statements.

But voters, if they only knew it, have another reason to hate the council tax: it is hopelessly inefficient. Pound for pound, it costs more than twice as much to collect as income tax. Hordes of council workers are employed to collect it, while another small army sits in the town hall distributing benefits to pay for it - meaning that money goes from the council and back to the council.

The average Bristol home pays £695.55 in council tax, although the standard measure, Band D, is £999.12. In 1999/2000, Bristol council was due £121m in council tax. Audit commission performance indicators suggest it collected just 94.7% of that, giving an income of £114.6m. This was out of a total budget of £341m, so it represented roughly a third of spending. Set against that, it paid out £24m in council tax benefit. This means that the total income from local taxation was a little more than £90m - just over a quarter of the total budget.

Bristol says it is unable to come up with figures for council tax collection costs, despite having apparently completed an official return requiring that figure. According to that return, the council spent almost £3.3m collecting council tax. With a net collection of £90m, that represents a collection cost of 3.6p for every £1. In the same year, the inland revenue managed to collect income tax at a cost of 1.23 pence in the pound.

Therefore more than two-thirds of Bristol's budget came from central government, with access to funds collected at 1.23p in the pound. The rest, a little over a quarter of the total, was collected locally at three times that collection cost. If Bristol had received all its cash from central government, funded by income tax, and had only paid the inland revenue's collection costs, it would have had an extra £2.1m to spend on local services.

Other authorities are not even so shipshape and Bristol fashion. They are worse. The audit commission calculates the cost of collecting council tax by household. Bristol comes in at under £18. Apart from the City of London, which collects from very few houses and so has enormous overheads, the highest cost councils are Southwark, south London, at £33.65; neighbouring Lambeth, at £29.94; Haringey, north London, at £29.26. Bexley council, in south London, manages a sharp £6, with the top five councils coming in at under £8.

The Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR) has figures for the total council tax collected in England and how much it costs to do so. In 1999-2000, councils collected £10.9bn at a total cost of £309m. In other words, the average cost of collection is 2.8p for every £1 raised.

On that basis, council tax is the second most expensive tax we pay. If you exclude customs duties, which are there for a special purpose and, arguably, are more to do with law enforcement than revenue generation, council tax is the most expensive tax to collect - almost twice as expensive as any other form of taxation.

Add to that the fact that, according to the DETR, councils disbursed £1.9bn council tax benefit in that same year - and the cost of administering the benefit was £216m, or 11p for every £1 - and question has to be asked: is it all worth it?

Brian Briscoe, chief executive of the Local Government Association, says it is. He claims it is unfair to compare collection costs of a property-based tax with others. "Property taxes are always more difficult to collect," he says. "Council taxes are collected from individuals, who move around. Property taxes are more expensive because employers and businesses do a lot of the work done by the inland revenue and customs & excise."

And Briscoe insists that the council tax regime - collecting the tax and paying out a benefit designed especially for it - is not a mere job creation scheme for council staff. "We're trying to encourage councils to work together on back-office systems to reduce the costs of collection," he says. "Every local authority in the country would rather spend some of that cost on providing better services."

Briscoe dismisses any notion that local taxation should be abolished. He defends council tax as a necessary link between local voters and the services their elected councillors deliver. A local tax is a vital part of democracy, he insists. In fact, he believes that the local tax should represent a higher proportion of council income, claiming that the sometimes huge sums which councils get from central government undermine the link between voters and local leaders. "It disconnects the people when they vote from what happens on the ground," he says.

In the good old days, Briscoe recalls, councils collected their rates and the business rates. Some councils - Hertfordshire for one, he reckons - collected so much in local taxation that they did not receive a penny from central government. Now councils collect the business rate replacement, but hand over all the cash to Whitehall to have it redistributed as grant. And that grant formula, based on a set of statistics that the government of the day has been known to change to favour councils of its own political complexion, in effect sets the local councils' budgets.

Briscoe maintains that if councils did collect a bigger proportion of their income, costs would not rise accordingly. Ideally, however, he would favour a different form of taxation. "I would prefer there to be a local income tax, collected locally," he says. "Then the link between local government and the taxpayer would be stronger.

"More of the tax should be raised locally so that more of the tax is related to the amount spent locally."

fields.headline: What do women want?
fields.standfirst: More than Tessa Jowell is offering them
fields.trailText: Suddenly a crucial issue is back on the agenda: equal pay. An equal opportunities commission (EOC) taskforce reported last month.
fields.body:
Suddenly a crucial issue is back on the agenda: equal pay. An equal opportunities commission (EOC) taskforce reported last month. Yesterday, the employment minister, Tessa Jowell, responded by announcing a pay audit of every government department and agency, with each being required to draw up plans to close the pay gap. She set out plans for the appointment of fair pay "champions" from the business and trade union world to promote pay equality and confirmed there would be annual Castle awards (named after Barbara Castle, who steered the 1970 Equal Pay Act through the Commons) for employers who have made major progress towards closing the gap.

What more, some may ask, could women want? Quite a lot. Yesterday's package falls pathetically short of what is needed. As the EOC report confirmed, the UK has the worst record in Europe on equal pay - a gap of 18% between the earnings of men and women. It calculated that between one quarter and one half of this gap was a direct cause of discrimination - the rest being caused by occupational segregation (60% of women workers being in the 10 lowest pay categories like catering, retail and cleaning) and a high concentration in part-time work.

The 1970 act has achieved progress: a narrowing of the pay gap from 37% in 1970 to 18%, and an increase from one third to one half of working age women in employment. Yet at all levels of society, unequal pay perniciously persists. Millions of women who carry just as much responsibility as male counterparts are being paid much less. Business was given 30 years to correct this unacceptable practice, but failed. The EOC was right to insist that employers should be required to carry out mandatory pay audits - and ministers were wrong to reject it. Of course there are good employers, but there is also a hardcore of hardliners who will not be moved by exhortations to carry out voluntary audits. The public service, one of the worst offenders, should have been ordered to follow the EOC line. It took a 14-year fight through the European Court before speech therapists forced the NHS to put things right. Other groups are still awaiting justice. Once again ministers have been too eager to secure the business vote. This was political madness. Women voters have far more clout. They might even decide to use it.

fields.headline: Ballot box blues
fields.standfirst:
The turnout at the next election is likely to be the lowest since the second world war, but this may not affect Labour's expected victory

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: The turnout at the next election is likely to be the lowest since the second world war, but this may not affect Labour's expected victory.
fields.body:
Turnout is likely to be low at the next general election, particularly in safe Labour seats, but does Labour need to worry?

Turnout tends to be low if people think that there is going to be an easy victory. The highest turnouts have all come at very closely fought elections, notably 1950 and 1951, when turnout exceeded 80%. Similarly the close races in February 1974 and April 1992 stimulated high turnouts of 79% and 78%.

If Labour support evaporates in the next few weeks, as it did during the petrol protests last autumn, the prospect of a close race may galvanise voters. But at present I would expect a low turnout, below the 71.6% recorded in 1997, which was itself the lowest in the post-war period.

The problem will be compounded in safe Labour seats. At least in 1997 there was the excitement of at last getting rid of the Tories. But that motive no longer holds. Received wisdom suggests low polls are worse news for Labour than for the Tories. It is at best a half truth. Labour supporters are slightly less likely to turn out and vote than Tory or Liberal Democrat supporters - one reason why the Labour lead at the next election is likely to be distinctly lower than their lead now in the opinion polls, just as it was in 1997.

But lower turnout among Labour supporters is a longstanding feature that held true in previous general elections and there is little evidence that the gap widens when overall turnout falls (at least in the case of general elections). When overall turnout falls, as it did between 1992 and 1997, it tends to fall equally among all groups of party supporters. So turnout tends not to affect the swing. Only once - in 1970 - has there been a clear case where the Labour turnout slipped markedly more than turnout for other parties. It is is a rather important exception since it lost Labour an election they had been confident of winning.

A low turnout caused by feelings that the result was a foregone conclusion would not in itself constitute a worry for Labour, since it will affect Tory supporters in much the same way. But could 2001 see a rerun of 1970, with disillusioned traditional Labour supporters failing to turn out?

On the face of it this is pretty unlikely. In 1970 Harold Wilson's government was plagued by charges that he had betrayed socialist principles and by failures to look after working-class interests when in office. It was this kind of accusation that led Tony Blair to get his betrayal in first as soon as he won the party leadership, abolishing clause four and moving the Labour party to the centre of the political spectrum. Traditional Labour supporters may not be enthused by New Labour's performance in office, but the performance cannot have been much of a surprise to them.

Our research on the 1997 election shows that they were already clearly aware how much Labour had moved to the centre; back in 1997 there was not the same growth in enthusiasm for New Labour among traditional working-class supporters as there was among middle-class converts.

So in a sense any harm that would have fallen New Labour on this score will al ready have happened in 1997. This is a completely different scenario from 1970, which followed the 1966 election where there had been substantial working-class enthusiasm for Labour. We must avoid double-counting. Any electoral damage to Labour from this source will already have happened in 1997.

But our research on 1997 also suggested a more worrying development for New Labour. Historically there has been a tendency for enthusiasm for a party, and turnout, to be strongest among its core social groups. For example rightwing voters in the Tory core of the managerial and entrepreneurial classes tend to have greater enthusiasm, and higher turnout, than other rightwing voters who have identical policy preferences and values but do not belong to the core social group. A natural interpretation of this phenomenon is that it reflects social processes - community norms and social pressures - that encourage people to turn out and support their group's party.

This pattern has historically been apparent both among core Labour and among core Tory supporters. In 1997 the pattern remained unchanged on the Tory side but disappeared on the Labour side. By distancing itself from the traditional working class (and from the trades unions), it is likely that the social bonds linking the party to its traditional supporters were weakened. The effect of this was largely masked in 1997 by the widespread unpopularity of the Tories and it may well be masked in 2001 too, but we would argue that the nature of the bond between Labour and its supporters has been changing.

The kind of model of the voter that contemporary politicians have adopted is very much an individualistic one and it ignores the role of social processes in maintaining commitment and promoting participation. But if Labour is no longer the party of the working class or of the unions, these social processes may no longer operate so effectively in maintaining working class and trade union participation in elections. Historically, this country has seen much smaller differences between social groups than is evident in countries such as the United States. But the Americanisation of British politics may well lead to widening gaps between the turnout of the core Tory groups and traditional working-class groups.

These changes are likely to be slow and long-term. They do not threaten Labour in the short-term. They may be a problem if New Labour falls on hard times, but they perhaps raise greater worries about the future health of British democracy than they do about New Labour's electoral prospects.

 Anthony Heath is professor of sociology at Oxford University. The Rise of New Labour: Party Policies and Voter Choices by Anthony Heath, Roger Jowell and John Curtice will be published by Oxford University Press next month.

webTitle: Hague scraps gloom and doom manifesto draft

fields.headline: Hague scraps gloom and doom manifesto draft
fields.standfirst:
Special report: election countdown
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague has ordered Conservative central office to ditch the first draft of the Tory general election manifesto because its pictures are too gloomy.
fields.body:
William Hague has ordered Conservative central office to ditch the first draft of the Tory general election manifesto because its pictures are too gloomy.

With days to go until the manifesto is due to be sent to the printers, photographers have been despatched across Britain to take pictures of smiling families in an attempt to show that life will become cheerier under the Tories.

Mr Hague was said to be horrified when he picked up the first draft of the manifesto, written by the shadow social security secretary, David Willetts. The Tory leader admired Mr Willetts's eloquence, but baulked at dark images of miserable families and gloomy nurses suffering under Labour.

The pictures were chosen by election planners at central office to tie in with the Tories' pre-election poster campaigns, which depict stressed nurses and depressed victims of over-stretched public services.

A Tory close to Mr Hague said: "We took one look at the pictures last week and decided to scrap the lot of them. It looked far too gloomy. We think we'll do much better in the election if we send out a positive message of how life will get better under the Tories."

The Tories have selected new pictures to reflect party policy, ensuring that no images of raucous youngsters appear. "There will be pictures of smiling babies with happily married parents to demonstrate our support for the family," the Tory source said. "We will have pictures of the countryside, though this will have to be dealt with sensitively because of the foot and mouth crisis."

The upbeat presentation shows that the Tories are taking a leaf out of the book of Ronald Reagan, who domi nated US politics in the 80s by focusing on the positive side of life in America.

"Ronald Reagan and, most recently George W Bush, made a point of making voters feel happy," the source said. "We want to rekindle the spirit of Reagan's famous 'It's morning again in America' slogan, which helped him romp home to a second victory in 1984."
