A Tory close to Mr Hague said: "We took one look at the pictures last week and decided to scrap the lot of them. It looked far too gloomy. We think we'll do much better in the election if we send out a positive message of how life will get better under the Tories." The Tories have selected new pictures to reflect party policy, ensuring that no images of raucous youngsters appear. "There will be pictures of smiling babies with happily married parents to demonstrate our support for the family," the Tory source said. "We will have pictures of the countryside, though this will have to be dealt with sensitively because of the foot and mouth crisis." The upbeat presentation shows that the Tories are taking a leaf out of the book of Ronald Reagan, who domi nated US politics in the 80s by focusing on the positive side of life in America. "Ronald Reagan and, most recently George W Bush, made a point of making voters feel happy," the source said. "We want to rekindle the spirit of Reagan's famous 'It's morning again in America' slogan, which helped him romp home to a second victory in 1984."

fields.headline: Trouble with Hague
fields.standfirst: He's seen as bald with a funny accent, admits shadow minister
fields.trailText: He has some of the sharpest suits in the business and a style guru who relentlessly monitors his appearance. Despite these efforts William Hague will always be lampooned, a colleague admitted yesterday.
fields.body:
He has some of the sharpest suits in the business and a style guru who relentlessly monitors his appearance. Despite these efforts William Hague will always be lampooned, a colleague admitted yesterday.

Tim Loughton, the loyal if rarely noticed shadow environment minister, voiced the private thoughts of virtually every Tory MP when he spelt out the reasons why Mr Hague is unpopular with the media. "I think it's as petty as the fact that he's a baldy and he has a funny accent," Mr Loughton said in an interview with the YouGov website.

His remarks were meant to be a declaration of loyalty, because he insisted that the Tory leader would overcome such "snide cynicism" through sheer force of personality. However, central office will not take kindly to such a brutal reminder that Mr Hague, as a "baldy", suffers from the Neil Kinnock problem.

Amanda Platell, the Tories' communications director, has gone to great lengths to try to sharpen Mr Hague's image, and dreamt up his Bruce Willis-style look which means that Mr Hague has his hair razor-cut every 10 days.

webTitle: Francis Wheen: The real reason Labour wants a May election

fields.headline: The real reason Labour wants to run for it
fields.standfirst:
Special report: election countdown
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: One can only admire the plucky defiance of metropolitan pundits and politicians. But I can find no enthusiasm whatever for a May election. Why do we need one?
fields.body:
One can only admire the plucky defiance of metropolitan pundits and politicians. "Go, go, go!" the Sun yells. "Bring on the election," chants the New Labour cheerleader Sion Simon, joyfully waving his pompoms. But beyond the fertile Islington prairies and the green pastures of Clapham, where sheep may safely graze, I can find no enthusiasm whatever for a May election. Why do we need one?

One point often made by the go-go-go brigade in recent weeks is that Ted Heath went to the country in February 1974, during a miners' strike. This is a false analogy: Heath called that election not in spite of the emergency but because of it. The silly ass asked the electors: "Who governs Britain?" To which they replied: "Clearly not you, matey." Not a useful precedent for the Blairites to cite - especially since they are the self-same people who keep assuring us that there is no national crisis.

Another argument, now heard almost hourly, is that our international reputation will be in tatters unless the prime minister requests a dissolution of parliament. "This is how Britain will look to the world if Blair postpones the May 3 election," a front-page editorial in the Sun warns. "We would be saying: This nation is closed for business. We would be saying to foreigners: Do not come here and spend your money." John Prescott, John Reid and Clive Soley agree, as do most leader-writers. "There can be no delay at the polls," the Independent on Sunday insists. "It would send out a misleadingly alarming signal to the rest of the world."

The language is baffling (how can the PM "postpone" or "delay" an election that hasn't been called?), and the hyperbole downright ridiculous. Foreigners may well be frightened by our foot and mouth epidemic, but do the eccentricities of our electoral system influence their holiday plans? I'm reminded of FE Smith's allegation that the Welsh disestablishment bill had "shocked the conscience of every Christian community in Europe" - a comment which provoked GK Chesterton's famous retort: "Chuck it, Smith!" From Connecticut to Cape Town, if Messrs Prescott, Reid and Soley are to be believed, anxious souls are ready to cancel their London holidays if Blair decides to serve the full five years for which he was elected in 1997.

The idea is manifestly incredible. Why, then, must we have an early election? One genuine reason was blurted out by Jack Straw recently, when a BBC interviewer pointed out that Labour had not halved the time between arrest and sentencing of young offenders - even though this was one of the five "key pledges" printed on pocket-sized cards in 1997 so that voters "can see we keep our promises". Ah yes, the home secretary replied, but if you read the small print you'll find that we promised to achieve that only "over a five-year term".

But this alone is scarcely a sufficient explanation for the Blairites' urgent desire to go to the polls after only four years. A more obvious motive, which no minister dares admit, is fear of an economic downturn. Japan and the US are already on the brink of recession; in an era of globalised goods and capital it's difficult to see how Britain can escape infection for long. Gordon Brown's favourite mantra - "there can be no return to boom and bust" - might soon be greeted with the howls of derision it so richly deserves.

New Labour promised from the outset that it would not use budgetary policy to regulate demand. This left the Treasury with only one economic lever - control of interest rates. But Brown promptly abdicated responsibility for that too. His policy - or, rather, non-policy - consists of little more than watching the financial markets and hoping for the best. Thanks to this neo-liberal nonsense, we are almost wholly undefended against the virus now afflicting America and Japan.

Hence the note of panic one detects in ministers and their media friends as they plead with Blair not to "delay". To paraphrase Karl Marx: it's the economy, stupid. The modernisers of New Labour are exploiting an ancient British tradition which one might call the second-hand car dealer's dodge: complete the sale on a wheezing old jalopy before it breaks down.

Quite why a democracy should permit one side in an electoral contest to rig the ballot in this fashion has always mystified me. One of the original demands of the 19th century Chartists was for a new parliament to be elected every year on the first Monday in June. "We may nowadays laugh," Julius West wrote in his History of the Chartist Movement, "at the state of mind which could contemplate with equanimity, indeed with pleasure, the prospect of an annual general election." Maybe so, but the essential principle was sound enough and has lately been revived by Tony Wright MP. Under his fixed-term parliaments bill, introduced in the Commons on March 1, there would be an election every four years - no more, no less - except if the ruling party suffers a vote of no-confidence in the house.

Ministers will have some difficulty in arguing against the proposal, especially since they imposed just such a system on the Scottish parliament. If it's good enough for the Scots, why not for the rest of us? The bill's second reading is due on Friday April 6 - which may be yet another reason for Blair to dispatch MPs to the hustings before then. As Wright points out, the Labour party used to be committed to a fixed-term parliament. "I'm not sure why we are no longer in favour," he said recently, "apart from our being in power."

Er, quite.

Byers bullies sellers but fights shy of Bowers

A headline in the Sunday Telegraph reveals that "Taxpayer will fund Byers libel fight". Maddeningly, it doesn't say which particular taxpayer has been chosen for this honour. Geoffrey Robinson, perhaps?

In my rare sightings of him, Stephen Byers has always seemed an amiable if uninteresting chap: "Mandelson-Lite", as someone called him. Now that he is sending minatory letters to blameless booksellers, this verdict may have to be reviewed. It is only bullies such as Jimmy Goldsmith who threaten mere distributors. How can newsagents or bookshop managers possibly vet everything that they sell? If the trade secretary thinks he has been defamed he should sue Tom Bower, author of The Paymaster.

Bower claims that Geoffrey Robinson was paid £200,000 by one of Robert Maxwell's companies, Hollis. No great shame in that: if everyone who took the Maxwell shilling was obliged to retire in disgrace, there would be many empty desks in Fleet Street, the City and Westminster. Robinson's offence was to deny the Maxwell payment. Like Peter on the night of Jesus's betrayal, he swore: "I know not the man." Yea, and he denied him thrice - to the House of Commons, to the prime minister and in his memoirs.

And the cock crew. And a DTI investigator found documentary evidence of the £200,000 cheque. And Byers, who had previously promised to be "as open as possible on these matters", slipped a written answer into Hansard on December 21 1999 (when everyone was preoccupied with Christmas parties) saying that the Hollis inquiry was now over and no further action would be taken.

Byers is furious at Bower's suggestion that he "buried" the report, insisting that he delegated the decision to civil servants. If so, he could become the first cabinet minister in history to demand libel damages for an allegation that he was responsible for the actions of his own department. Is it any wonder that, so far, he has been all mouth and no writ?

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Those who subscribe to the prejudice that local councils are composed of people whose infantile views on public spending make them - worryingly - not decent or clever enough to be MPs should stop reading now.
fields.body:
 Those who subscribe to the prejudice that local councils are composed of people whose infantile views on public spending make them - worryingly - not decent or clever enough to be MPs should stop reading now. For you sneerers would love the chance to seize on the burghers of north Lincolnshire, who have recently spent £100,000 on a push-button voting system for their council chamber. Be gone then, for you know nothing of the ways of local government. Would you believe that until now councillors were forced to raise their hands to vote, with the mayor given the prehistoric task of counting said hands to gauge the result? I know, it seems laughable to us too. Bravo then, Scunthorpe, home of the future!

 For some reason, papers relating to DTI secretary Stephen Byers's libel action against the Daily Mail have been sent to the Diary. There may be some sort of story in them, but frankly they are too dreary to wade through. Perhaps tomorrow.

 Today's poorly disguised pull-through to the website - currently accessible at Guardian Unlimited Politics' Turncoats - comes in the placing of an exclusive story (about ourselves, though hotly pursued by almost every other national paper) that we will shortly be launching a glossary of Diary characters on the site. From Helen Brinton to Andrew Neil, Mr Tony to Diary vicar Steve Chalke, they'll all be there just as soon as we write descriptions complete with Diary previous for each one.

 Well done yesterday's Independent for another important attempt to set an agenda, any agenda. "Read the first newspaper to be published with NO advertising," screamed the front page blurb, adding only "In association with The MarketPlace at Bradford & Bingley." And what better comment on this landmark exercise than that of B&B commercial director Ian Darby, who observed misty-eyed from his position on the front page: "Now, you can enjoy as much choice and independent advice on the high street as you expect every day from your newspaper." Marvellous. Incidentally, the Diary is willing to dispense with the usual petty plugs in return for one really lucrative commercial sponsor. Will sacrifice byline for corporate logo if the money's right.

 The fall of an elderly woman down the stairs at Notting Hill Gate underground station yesterday forces a call to London Transport press officer Heather Preston. Could Heather explain to why both downward escalators in the station have been shut for maintenance for more than 18 months? Only I think that, were I to chuck in this job, I could develop an interest in escalator engineering, sit my City and Guilds in the requisite subjects, start the job, take the few weeks holiday owed to me, and still turn the entire thing round in less time. "I don't know anything about mechanical engineering," sighs Heather. "But it may be they needed to get some special parts made. I'll ask." You're kind, Heather, but is there any point?

 An endearing advertisement graces the Employment Wanted section of the Toronto Financial Post Classifieds. "Having successfully completed a 10-year sentence for importing 75 tons of marijuana into the United States," it begins, "I am now seeking a legal means to support myself. My previous business experience consists of owning and operating a successful fishing business - multivessel, one airplane, one island and processing facility. Simultaneously owned and operated a fleet of tractor-trailer trucks conducting business in the western US. During this time I also participated in the executive level management of 120 people worldwide in a successful pot smuggling venture with revenues in excess of $100m annually. References available from friends, family, the US District Attorney etc." Splendid.

fields.headline: Bargaining on the bill
fields.standfirst: May general election could cause NHS reform uncertainty
fields.trailText: May general election could cause NHS reform uncertainty
fields.body:
If Tony Blair presses ahead with a general election on May 3, he faces a battle royal in the House of Lords to salvage the health and social care bill - the legislation he introduced to implement and advertise the government's NHS reform plan.

The bill completed its committee stage in the upper house last Thursday with only minor amendments to the most controversial clauses. Its report stage - the last opportunity for peers to force changes on key proposals such as abolition of community health councils (CHCs) and eligibility for free nursing care - is due on Thursday next week.

But the last date for Blair to brush aside concern about the foot and mouth crisis and plump for a May 3 election is next Tuesday. If he takes the plunge, the health bill will enter the uncertain "wash-up" procedure that decides what happens to uncompleted business before parliament is dissolved.

There are two main options. The government could subject the bill to a "strike-out" procedure, allowing the enactment of clauses that are not contested. For this to be effective, there would have to be horse trading with the opposition parties, letting all sides claim some influence on the outcome.

But if a prospective deal was not to ministers' liking, the government could decide to allow the bill to fall, and return with something similar after the election, assuming that Labour wins.

Earl Howe, the peer leading for the Conservatives on the bill, says the Tories would "play hard to get" during the pre-dissolution negotiations. They would not object to uncontroversial measures such as pilot schemes for pharmacy services. But they would be likely to put up stiff resistance to abolition of the CHCs and would probably refuse to go along with the government's "stingy" definition of free nursing care and with the clauses allowing the release of confidential patient records.

Lord Clement Jones, for the Liberal Democrats, says the government would be facing two or three defeats at report stage and ministers could not insist on getting everything through unscathed under pressure of dissolution. "I expect the government to be content to let it drop and bring back a number two bill [a repeat measure] after the election," he says.

A senior government source dismisses that idea. "We want the bill done and dusted during the wash-up," he says. "It's more likely that we'd manage to get an agreement in the upper house - probably requiring concessions on our part as well as theirs - than that we'd use the Parliament Act to force this through in the next parliament."

Tory and Lib Dem peers would be asked to decide whether they wanted Labour to go into the election blaming the opposition for blocking free nursing care in nursing homes that had been due for implementation in the autumn before the cold weather comes.

fields.headline: Vaz criticised over Balkans
fields.standfirst: Full text of the committee's report
fields.trailText: Keith Vaz, the minister for Europe embroiled in controversy with the parliamentary standards watchdog and links with the Hinduja brothers, is today sharply criticised by MPs on quite a different issue - failing to grasp "policy issues" relating to the Balkans.
fields.body:
Keith Vaz, the minister for Europe embroiled in controversy with the parliamentary standards watchdog and links with the Hinduja brothers, is today sharply criticised by MPs on quite a different issue - failing to grasp "policy issues" relating to the Balkans.

He is singled out in a report by the Labour-dominated Commons foreign affairs committee which adds that it was "deeply regrettable" Mr Vaz had not even visited the region.

Mr Vaz's "evidence session with us did not reveal a detailed grasp of the policy issues which the area faces", the committee says. It adds pointedly: "As the minister told us, and we know ourselves, the situation in the Balkans is 'very complex and and very difficult'. Visiting the region puts this situation into context".

It also rebukes Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, for not visiting Yugoslavia.

The committee's report was seized on by the Tories who said it showed that Mr Vaz was unfit for office. "This report is an indictment of Mr Vaz's work rate and intellectual calibre. It is also an indictment of Tony Blair's judgment," said the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude. In the Com mons yesterday, Mr Maude provoked an angry foreign secretary over the Balkans by saying that while there should be "resolute support" for Macedonia, there should be no question of Kosovo being denied the right of eventual "self determination".

Mr Cook snapped back: "The last message the government of Macedonia wants to hear at the present time is a call for the independence of Kosovo which has just been made by you."

Western leaders do not say it openly now but there are are few who doubt that Kosovo will one day achieve independence from Serbia.

fields.bodyText: Keith Vaz, the minister for Europe embroiled in controversy with the parliamentary standards watchdog and links with the Hinduja brothers, is today sharply criticised by MPs on quite a different issue - failing to grasp "policy issues" relating to the Balkans. He is singled out in a report by the Labour-dominated Commons foreign affairs committee which adds that it was "deeply regrettable" Mr Vaz had not even visited the region. Mr Vaz's "evidence session with us did not reveal a detailed grasp of the policy issues which the area faces", the committee says. It adds pointedly: "As the minister told us, and we know ourselves, the situation in the Balkans is 'very complex and and very difficult'. Visiting the region puts this situation into context". It also rebukes Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, for not visiting Yugoslavia. The committee's report was seized on by the Tories who said it showed that Mr Vaz was unfit for office. "This report is an indictment of Mr Vaz's work rate and intellectual calibre. It is also an indictment of Tony Blair's judgment," said the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude. In the Com mons yesterday, Mr Maude provoked an angry foreign secretary over the Balkans by saying that while there should be "resolute support" for Macedonia, there should be no question of Kosovo being denied the right of eventual "self determination". Mr Cook snapped back: "The last message the government of Macedonia wants to hear at the present time is a call for the independence of Kosovo which has just been made by you." Western leaders do not say it openly now but there are are few who doubt that Kosovo will one day achieve independence from Serbia. What's going on? webTitle: Public faces £1.2bn bill for Channel tunnel rail link

fields.headline: Public faces £1.2bn bill for Channel tunnel rail link
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The taxpayer could be faced with a £1.2bn bill following a decision by the government to bail out the cash strapped Channel tunnel high speed rail link from Folkestone to London, an official spending watchdog reported yesterday.
fields.body:
The taxpayer could be faced with a £1.2bn bill following a decision by the government to bail out the cash strapped Channel tunnel high speed rail link from Folkestone to London, an official spending watchdog reported yesterday.

The national audit office criticised the government for making "questionable assumptions" when the restructuring of the link was made in 1998 after the financial collapse of the project.

The report said that much depended on reaching passenger number targets by the Eurostar trains which will run on the 100km link due to be completed by 2006.

The report said: "On the basis of recent Eurostar UK performance, the link represents poor value for money in terms of estimated economic benefits."

It said that at the worst the government could have to lend £1.2bn to London and Continental Railways, the company building the link.

The NAO said that the Department of Transport reckoned that the scheme would produce benefits of £3 bn for a total public sector contribution of £2 bn. But it accused the department of using out-of-date economic growth assumptions to estimate time-saving benefits.

It had incorrectly assumed that all Eurostar services would benefit from average time savings of around 30 minutes. The department should also have included costs of £130m, which have now grown to £170m, for works needed at King's Cross, London, where the line will terminate and on the M2 in Kent. These costs were removed from the 1998 assessment.

The report said that if passenger level targets for Eurostar fell 4% below forecast passenger numbers, the benefit of the link would fall below zero.

The report said that the department's calculations on passenger numbers were not consistent with London and Continental's estimates. The department predicted 25.8m passengers within 30 years, needing 59 trains, but Eurostar forecast only 46 trains.

David Davis, chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, said that the original deal signed in 1996 was flawed because of over optimistic forecasts of revenue for Eurostar..

webTitle: MPs win right to scrutinise key arms sales

fields.headline: MPs win right to scrutinise key arms sales
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: Ministers have privately granted a major concession over British arms sales by agreeing to prior parliamentary scrutiny of export licences to any country that is subject to an arms embargo.
fields.body:
Ministers have privately granted a major concession over British arms sales by agreeing to prior parliamentary scrutiny of export licences to any country that is subject to an arms embargo.

The concession will be the first time the executive has ceded responsiblity for arms sales to parliament and it follows US practice.

The change will not be included in the arms exports controls bill to be published on Friday by the Department of Trade and Industry -seen as the government's belated response to the Scott report on arms sales to Iraq - but talks have already been held between key ministers and select commitee heads who have been pressing for scrutiny of the licences.

Ministers intend to make the concession on prior scrutiny during the eight-week consultation period following publication of the bill.

It is understood that Sir Ted Rowlands, chairman of the special Commons select committee on arms exports, is willing to accept a deal whereby select committees are allowed to scrutinise arms export licences to countries subject to embargoes. These embargoes would either be UN, EU or British based.

Although it would be expected that few export licences would are granted to countries subject to embargoes, in practice many embargoes are deliberately fudged, poorly policed or contain loopholes. Many of the biggest controversies over arms sales have concerned arms weapons to Zimbabwe, Indonesia and Morocco - all countries subject to some form of arms embargo.

Following the consultation, the deal could be included in the revised draft of the bill.

The four select committees have produced a succession of reports demanding prior parliamentary scrutiny in line with practice in the US and Sweden. The government had previously told the committees in a formal response that there "was no role for advance scrutiny of individual casework decisions, which are quintessentially matters for ministerial decision in accordance with delegated powers conferred by parliament".

In evidence to the committees, the foreign secretary, Robin Cook had said that if parliamentary scrutiny were extended to all arms export licences, as many as 12,000 licence applications would be subject to the process annually, causing intolerable delay.

The committees formally responded earlier this month by saying they would no longer seek to scrutinise the granting of export licences to countries in Nato or to other friendly nations. The committee also agreed not to seek to examine dual-use licences, so halving overall the number to be looked at.

The Defence Manufacturers Association has warned that any prior parliamentary scrutiny would represent a major threat to their ability to engage in the export of legitimate defence capability to many significant defence markets around the world.

Ministers are still working on technical sections of the arms exports bill covering weapons of mass destruction, but they are lobbying the leader of the house, Margaret Beckett, to ensure that the bill is included in the next Queen's speech, redeeming a long standing pledge.

The bill will propose that the punishment for brokering or trafficking arms to embargoed destinations will be up to 10 years in jail.

webTitle: Airlines to take over air traffic control

fields.headline: Airlines to take over air traffic control
fields.standfirst:
Prescott bows to pressure and agrees £800m partnership deal

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The government yesterday bowed to political pressure over its controversial proposal to sell off the air traffic control service, and chose a consortium of seven airlines as the safest way to police the skies.
fields.body:
The government yesterday bowed to political pressure over its controversial proposal to sell off the air traffic control service, and chose a consortium of seven airlines as the safest way to police the skies.

With time running out on a possible election call next week, the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, yesterday announced the Airlines group of companies as winner in a £800m deal expected to be formalised on June 1.

Further work has to be completed before the airlines become the government's strategic partner. This incudes getting EU approval and also agreement with foreign airlines, some of whom are worried about favourable treatment for British carriers.

After mounting criticism against Serco, the management utilities company, whose safety record was criticised by industry experts, the government finally decided to go with the airlines group. Another reason was a commitment by the group to a "not for profits" approach.

The group - British Airways, Virgin Atlantic, bmi British Midland, easyJet, Monarch Airlines, Britannia Airways and Airtours - said it would put in £1bn of investment over 10 years.

Lord Macdonald, the transport minister, still has to tell the Lords about the plan. He had promised a three-month moratorium on the plan in December, but the fierce opposition to the scheme, which led to the biggest Labour revolt in this parliament, is spent.

Suggestions of a conflict of interest between the airlines and the air traffic system were rejected by Lord Macdonald. "We believe that the interests of the airlines and passengers in terms of punctuality and overall safety will be very well served with our strategic fit," he said.

He would not be drawn on comparisons with the railways, or on Labour's objections to the privatisation of the national air traffic services (NATS) while the party was in opposition. "Railtrack was the creation of privatisation. This is a public-private partnership. The structures that have been created through PPP mean there are partnership directors on board."

Mr Prescott said that the airlines group had satisfied the government it would "maintain the highest safety standards achieved by the air traffic service". He said the group's strategic investment plan would provide NATS with the investment it needed "to meet the demands of steadily increasing air traffic".

Mr Prescott said the PPP would be regulated by the civil aviation authority, which would ensure that NATS continued to operate safely while reducing users' costs. He also said that the partnership would provide the opportunity for NATS to emerge as a "major worldwide player in its field".

The government will retain a 49% stake in the company, with the airlines taking a 46% share. Employees will have a 5% stake. The legislation provides for the group to increase its share at a later date. The airlines will not be able to sell out to another firm - a condition that protects it from "predation" from outside.

Sir Michael Bishop, chairman of the group, said its aims and those of NATS were "inextricably linked", and that the £1bn investment would give air traffic controllers the "modern tools they so desperately need to replace their outdated systems".

The group is not expected to make significant changes to NATS personnel, although it will tighten up on key management positions. Sir Roy McNulty, NATS chairman, said he was delighted with the choice of partner.

The 3,500 controllers are alleged not to be happy with the change but consider the group to be the "safest bet".

Paul Noon, leader of IPMS, the controllers' union, said: "The government has chosen a 'not-for-commercial-return' bid, and we welcome that. But we do not welcome the PPP. It is a major distraction at a time of momentous change for air traffic control."

He said the controllers would work with the airlines to make sure they carried out their commitments, especially on safety - which suggests the controllers will not press ahead with a strike.

webTitle: Met to try a softer line on cannabis

fields.headline: Met to try a softer line on cannabis
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: The Metropolitan police may become the first force in the country to officially relax its attitude towards cannabis possession, after a decision to pursue a radical policy in a London hotspot for drugs.
fields.body:
The Metropolitan police may become the first force in the country to officially relax its attitude towards cannabis possession, after a decision to pursue a radical policy in a London hotspot for drugs.

Working within discretionary powers given by the Home Office, the borough commander for Lambeth, Brian Paddick, has drawn up proposals to issue warnings to people caught with cannabis, rather than automatically making arrests and, in some cases, bringing charges.

Although the policy will affect only one borough, which includes Brixton, the Met commissioner, Sir John Stevens, is watching with interest to gauge public reaction. He is known to be sympathetic to initiatives that give officers more freedom to tackle serious crime.

If the scheme is a success other areas might follow suit.

Commander Paddick said yesterday the proposal did not mean cannabis was being legalised. The idea was to free his officers from spending hours mopping up minor drugs offences when they needed time to tackle the "cancer" of crack cocaine-related crime.

"I've never met anyone who had to commit crime to fund a cannabis habit, but crack cocaine users commit robbery, burglary and car crime."

He said he was not soft on cannabis use. "That completely misrepresents what we want to do. We believe this policy will continue to deter people buying cannabis on the streets, as they will still lose even small amounts of cannabis in their possession. The person has to accept the warning, [or] be arrested."

It takes two officers up to five hours to process a cannabis possession arrest. "With the new policy, we can deal with a similar matter in 10 minutes," said Cdr Paddick.

His proposal has been forwarded to the community police consultative group in Lambeth. Jennifer Douglas, its chairwoman, said: "It is a brave idea, and it is a good idea. There is a need for a new drugs strategy."

fields.headline: Voting for oblivion
fields.standfirst:
The Lords reject a reprieve for hunting

Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Offered a chance of saving the sport of hunting with hounds, the House of Lords has spurned it.
fields.body:
Offered a chance of saving the sport of hunting with hounds, the House of Lords has spurned it. On Monday it rejected the so-called third way option, which would have allowed hunting to continue subject to external regulation. Peers chose instead to vote for a status quo which is plainly unacceptable to the Commons.

If there is to be a May election, then this is all, in a way, immaterial. The bill to ban hunting with hounds, endorsed by the Commons by a substantial majority, cannot go through. But the bill will be revived after the general election. If Labour gets back by anything more than a slim majority, the Commons will once again vote for an outright ban. The contrary view of the Lords will be overridden. Several ministers, from Tony Blair downwards, have been showing signs of apprehension about that outcome. They do not want to see those who hunt defined as criminals. They were hoping that devotees would signal their willingness to see the more objectionable practices policed and excluded. Even the Countryside Alliance, an organisation which has spuriously sought to portray the survival of hunting as essential to the survival of rural Britain, was swinging round to a compromise. Yet the lords voted in substantial numbers to leave blood sports alone.

One argument repeatedly adduced was that, with the countryside in crisis, it was especially wrong to ignore the outrage of many country people about the possible banning of a favourite pastime. But that argument cuts two ways. Urban Britain is being asked to come up with solutions for the countryside's woes with appropriate financial recompense. And yet there is no acknowledgment here of the revulsion which much of urban Britain - as well as, on the evidence of the polls, much of rural Britain also -feels for a sport it rightly sees as cruel. By remaining so obdurate in the face of public opinion, the friends of hunting with hounds may have done for it.

webTitle: Taxpayer to fund cost of minister's legal action

fields.headline: Taxpayer to fund cost of minister's legal action
fields.trailText: Stephen Byers, the trade secretary, will be reimbursed by the taxpayer for legal action he has taken to put pressure on booksellers and the Daily Mail over the publication and distribution of Tom Bower's book on the former paymaster general, Geoffrey Robinson.
fields.body:
Stephen Byers, the trade secretary, will be reimbursed by the taxpayer for legal action he has taken to put pressure on booksellers and the Daily Mail over the publication and distribution of Tom Bower's book on the former paymaster general, Geoffrey Robinson.

Sir Michael Scholar, permanent secretary at the ministry, yesterday gave the go-ahead to reimburse hundreds of pounds spent by the minister seeking to stop the distribution of the investigative journalist's book which was serialised by the Mail last week.

Mr Byers had engaged London lawyers, Goodman Derrick, to issue letters to booksellers warning them not to stock the book, without waiting for the approval of his permanent secretary.

The decision to pay the money from public funds led to a furious response from the Conservatives who accused Whitehall of leaving taxpayers footing the bill for a government "cover-up".

Last week Mr Byers demanded that the Mail pay a substantial sum to charity for publishing allegations that he " buried" a controversial DTI investigation into Mr Robinson's bankrupt company, Hollis Industries.

So far Mr Byers has not issued a writ but only threatened publishers.

fields.headline: Corus listens - then closes
fields.standfirst: The jobs frontline Steelmaker to study union plan
fields.trailText: Corus, Britain's biggest steelmaker, last night said it expected to proceed with a controversial plan to close plants and make 6,000 people redundant despite agreeing to study a union rescue plan.
fields.body:
Corus, Britain's biggest steelmaker, last night said it expected to proceed with a controversial plan to close plants and make 6,000 people redundant despite agreeing to study a union rescue plan.

The chairman, Sir Brian Moffatt, earlier surprised and pleased the unions by holding four hours of constructive talks at its London headquarters, ending weeks of verbal confrontation. Corus said afterwards that no one should be misled into thinking there had been a big change of heart. Trading conditions were deteriorating rather than improving.

"We have agreed to keep the door open to any schemes but that has always been there. We have heard nothing that changes our mind about the size of the cutbacks nor the timescale," said a spokesman.

The unions, led by the Iron and Steel Trades Confederation, believed they had made a genuine breakthrough. Michael Leahy, general secretary of the ISTC, said: "Corus is now engaged in a debate about the future of the industry and we are hoping to make significant progress over the next four weeks.

"For the first time they are listening and we welcome that. We have started a genuine debate and there is definite hope."

The unions took along to the meeting a £90m rescue plan under which a variety of funding would be used to keep plants and jobs operational for 12 months ahead of a possible market upturn.

Stephen Byers, the industry secretary, had given his final blessing to the plan only on Monday night. The European Union, Welsh assembly and Corus were expected to chip-in with cash.

Corus made clear yesterday it would not be participating financially and only saw the support package as a way of retraining some of the 6,000 staff before their departure from the steel industry.

The Corus spokesman said the most important aspect of the talks for the company was a joint statement signed with the unions. It accepted "that iron and steelmaking capacity reductions are necessary at Llanwern, and this would have knock-on effects at Ebbw Vale, Shotton, Bryngwyn and Lackenby [Teesside]."

A working party comprising Corus executives, union officials and the Department of Trade & Industry are to develop an application to the European commission, to be submitted as soon as possible.

A spokesman for the DTI welcomed the outcome and added: "The government has indicated its willingness to support a scheme of retraining by approaching the European commission and other member states and asking for their approval. We are happy to take part in a working party to develop such a scheme."

Labour MP Denis MacShane, chairman of the steel group of MPs, welcomed what he saw as a more consensual approach by Corus.

"This is an important development which shows that Corus is beginning to listen properly to the arguments put forward by the unions, ministers and MPs," he said.

"We have argued that with a package of government training aid and other help it would be possible to keep men on the payroll instead of going in for 1980s-style mass closures."

The unions had been publicly optimistic about the meeting with Corus but privately expected rejection. They had been prepared to call for immediate industrial action but this has been put off.

webTitle: Report finds government too focused on hospital care

fields.headline: Report finds government too focused on hospital care
fields.trailText: Health improvement and disease prevention initiatives have failed to flourish because of the government's overwhelming concentration on hospital care, an MPs' report suggests. Patrick Butler reports.
fields.body:
Health improvement and disease prevention initiatives have failed to flourish because of the government's overwhelming concentration on hospital care, an MPs' report suggests.

The report by the Commons health select committee examined whether the health secretary, Alan Milburn, has achieved his self-imposed pledge to take public health "out of the ghetto".

It says that while ministers had a well-intentioned commitment to push public health issues "up the agenda", in practice acute care issues such as beds and staff shortages still dominated policy.

It adds that there is "confusion" surrounding the leadership of the public health function from ministerial level down through regional and local levels.

The report says: "We found that the present policy agenda is heavily dominated by the NHS plan with its overwhelming concentration on acute care, hospitals and beds, and numbers of doctors and nurses.

"We accept these are issues of vital importance to the NHS but we think the case for re-balancing health policy is strong."

The government should make health improvement "a central priority" and give more power to the public health minister to reduce health inequalities, the report concludes.

It says: "Our final verdict must be that many of the [government's] itiatives have been taken with the best of intentions, but their multiplicity and lack of rigour threatens to undermine them.

"We have found blurred lines of responsibility leading to disputes over who should have responsibility for public health function."

The role of regional and local public health professionals should be clarified, while stronger partnership working between health, local government and the voluntary sector should be encouraged, it says.

It says public health has been for too long dominated by an abstract scientific approach. There should be an emphasis on practical implementation of theory to "bring about change," say MPs.

Mr Milburn said in a lecture in March 2000 that the "time had come to take public health out of the ghetto".

He said: "For too long the overarching label 'public health' has served to bundle together functions and occupations in a way that actually marginalises them from the NHS and other health partners."

fields.headline: National Trust review threatens jobs
fields.trailText: It has always been viewed as a somewhat genteel organisation, with its fair share of patrician staff, wealth and a mass of historic buildings.
fields.body:
It has always been viewed as a somewhat genteel organisation, with its fair share of patrician staff, wealth and a mass of historic buildings.

But the National Trust has now embraced its aim of becoming "fit for the 21st century" with unquestionably modern efficiency.

As a result of a four-month cost-cutting review, 340 employees have been told they must relocate to new headquarters in as yet-unspecified Bath or Chippenham in the west country - or lose the jobs some have held for up to two decades.

The shake-up, announced to staff in a three-hour meeting on Monday, means that some 150 employees must move from the charity's Georgian headquarters in St James's, central London, or accept a severance package.

The second national centre at Westbury will close, forcing 115 staff in the finance section to move, as will the third in Cirencester, where all 75 employees dealing with conservation and farming will have to relocate if they want to keep their jobs.

In addition, four regional offices will shut, with Devon and Cornwall merging and the West Midlands office subsuming surrounding offices.

The trust, which, with an annual income of £200m is one of the Britain's richest charities, estimates that 80 people, out of the 4,000 it employs, will be made redundant.

But many of those told to relocate, particularly in London, are expected to leave.

"A lot of people have ties here and most don't want to move, particularly not if its to Chippenham," said one of those at the meeting.

The announcement, unveiled by the trust's director general, Fiona Reynolds, is understood to have been met without enthusiasm by many workers. "We're all very shocked," said one person who refused to be named. "But we were told if we don't move then we lose our jobs. There's no choice."

Only a core of 41 staff, including the director general, will remain at the central London headquarters after the move, phased in over the next two years, is completed in spring 2003.

Another source said: "People were taken aback by this. A lot of people have worked for the National Trust for 10, 15, 20 years and, though they knew the review was going on, they've been quite shocked by the reality of this happening.

"People weren't angry but there was a lot of wariness about the whole thing."

The operational review was commissioned by the trust's former director general, Martin Drury.

Ms Reynolds, who, before taking the post in January headed the Cabinet Office's women's unit for 2 years, has already stressed the need for the charity to shed its "remote" image.

She said yesterday: "The review will be able to provide us with the management structure we need to protect and nurture many good and successful things about the trust while moving forward to meet the challenges of the future."

Nevertheless, after initial costs for severance pay - which will range from one to 15 months' salary - and relocation are met, the shake-up is expected to make annual savings of six figures.

Founded in 1895, the National Trust reported general funds of £738,292m in the last financial year.

fields.headline: Vodafone 'texts' youth with £2m advertising campaign
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Vodafone is seeking to cash in on text messaging mania with a £2m advertising campaign aimed at young people, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Vodafone is seeking to cash in on text messaging mania with a £2m advertising campaign that shows a group of trendy young things "texting" their friends.

The UK's biggest mobile phone operator is targeting the youth market for the first time with the campaign, which features cartoon-style characters clutching their mobiles in a bar.

Unusually the adverts make no direct reference to Vodafone. But a small, text-style message in the bottom left hand corner of the advert reads, "U&YR M8S CAN TXT CH@ vod4fon3".

"We are implementing a specific youth programme because the audience consumes its media in a very different way," said Paul Donovan, managing director, commercial of Vodafone UK.

"We are showing that Vodafone is a fun and engaging brand with saliency for 16 to 24-year-olds."

The adverts are designed to promote Vodafone's text messaging service and Fone Fun, which allows Vodafone customers to personalise their phones by downloading ring tones and graphics.

They were created by BMP DDB and will appear in upcoming issues of youth-oriented style magazines such as Loaded, FHM, Mixmag and Company.

They will be supported by cinema and radio adverts as well as promotions on beer mats.

fields.headline: BBC and ITV fight over Toy Story
fields.trailText: 8.30am: A bidding war between ITV and the BBC is expected for the rights to screen Disney blockbuster Toy Story, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
A bidding war between ITV and the BBC is expected for the rights to screen blockbuster Toy Story after Disney decided to lift its own "ban" on the networks.

After years of refusing to sell its top movies to either station, the Hollywood giant has decided to give them the opportunity to bid for a package of top films.

As part of its new Classic Treasures package, the US media giant will be offering titles including Toy Story, Toy Story 2, A Bug's Life, Pocahontas, Mulan and the Hunchback of Notre Dame.

These films have grossed more than £1.4bn in cinemas worldwide and have been watched by more than 121m people in Europe alone.

"For many years broadcasters have recognised the unique value that our ground-breaking animation can bring to a schedule," said David Hulbert, president of Walt Disney Television International.

"Now for the first time we are able to deliver a collection of animated films that will guarantee huge family audiences to broadcasters throughout Europe."

Disney's two smash hit Toy Story movies will be shown on UK terrestrial TV for the first time as part of a package of movies being offered to broadcasters.

The move follows a change of strategy by Disney, which has previously only sold its more recent animated titles to pay-TV broadcasters and not to free-to-air channels.

Disney's distribution arm Buena Vista International Television will be talking to UK broadcasters about the movie package at the Mip-TV programming market in Cannes next week.

fields.headline: The hardline legacy of Fallon
fields.trailText: There have been no escapes from the special hospitals since 1994. So why is the government spending £30m on improving perimeter security? For many, the move symbolises the hospitals' retreat into a more custodial and inward looking culture. "We believe that this is not only diverting money from treatment to security, but it is going to make security worse," says John Gunn, chairman of the faculty of forensic psychiatry at the Royal College of Psychiatrists (RCP).
fields.body:
There have been no escapes from the special hospitals since 1994. So why is the government spending £30m on improving perimeter security? For many, the move symbolises the hospitals' retreat into a more custodial and inward looking culture. "We believe that this is not only diverting money from treatment to security, but it is going to make security worse," says John Gunn, chairman of the faculty of forensic psychiatry at the Royal College of Psychiatrists (RCP).

The move to reinforce the perimeter walls and fences - including erection of a second boundary at Broadmoor - stems from a security review ordered in response to the Fallon inquiry into the running of wards for personality disordered patients at Ashworth. The review was carried out by a five-man team led by Sir Richard Tilt, former director general of the prison service.

Critics maintain that the team, which included no clinicians, was dominated by prison service thinking and failed to grasp that the special hospitals come from another mould. "They are totally different organisations, run in totally different ways and with totally different problems," says Gunn.

Pamela Taylor, professor of special hospitals psychiatry at the Institute of Psychiatry, and an honorary consultant at Broadmoor, agrees on a need for tight security. But she says: "There also has to be a capacity to get to know patients very well - and I don't mean that in a soppy, simplistic, befriending sense, but so that you can be one step ahead in understanding who is likely to be challenging security and in what sorts of ways."

Contrast that with the language of the Tilt team's recommendations - accepted in full by ministers at a total estimated cost of £55m - as applied to Broadmoor: "A short anti-dash fence should be provided between the administration block and the outer wall adjacent to the gate/reception to reduce the vulnerability of the reception area to such an attack."

In fairness, the team's report did acknowledge that the hospitals had twin security and therapeutic objectives and it called for an increase in therapy and activity for patients, as well as greater security. The team said it "frequently found wards with the majority of patients on the ward either watching television or simply sitting around".

Indeed, the report suggested that once perimeters were upgraded, staff could be freed for other duties by discontinuing routine internal escorting of patients except in cases of identified "high risk" individuals. Clinicians are highly doubtful about this. Mike Shooter, registrar of the RCP, says: "More safety outside the hospitals and less safety inside will make them more dangerous places - not less."

The RCP has sought a meeting with Alan Milburn, health secretary, on its many concerns about the Tilt recommendations. According to Gunn, however, it has been rebuffed in an "almost unheard of" fashion.

Failing such top level talks, negotiations on implementing the security clampdown have taken place with civil servants. One concession is that whereas the Tilt report proposed that all high-risk patients and those on admission and intensive care wards should be locked in at night - "the hours of darkness being the greatest risk time for escapes or concerted action by patients to compromise security" - this is happening only by agreement with clinicians.

Gunn says: "There has been a fudge. The position now is that you have to select patients to be locked up at night on security grounds. That means that it is possible to go on managing the wards as before."

Overall, though, the mood in the special hospitals is tense. "It's a worrying time," says Taylor. "Having been through a phase where the climate was explictly facilitating progressive improvements in clinical treatment and care delivery, to some extent it seems to be getting more difficult to defend that."

fields.headline: iForce puts 200 jobs in pipeline
fields.standfirst:
More net news
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Britain's e-commerce sector will receive a much-needed boost with the creation of 200 jobs from a new e-fulfilment centre in the west Midlands. By Julia Snoddy and John Cassy.
fields.body:
Britain's e-commerce sector will receive a much-needed boost this morning with the creation of 200 jobs from the opening of a new e-fulfilment centre in the West Midlands.

iForce, which handles deliveries for companies including lastminute.com, Sony and Nokia, said the jobs would be filled once the 65,000 sq ft distribution at Pologia Park, Bromford Gate, was fully operational.

"Behind the current turmoil of e-commerce in the UK, there is steady and sustained growth in demand for e-fulfilment services," said chief executive Matthew Pocock. "Both businesses and consumers are making more and more online transactions, and our investment in the West Midlands will enable us to meet the growing demand."

The West Midlands plant will allow iForce to offer customers in the Birmingham area a service called NowNowNow! which guarantees goods are dispatched within three hours of the internet user purchasing them.

One of the main complaints levelled at e-commerce firms has been the poor quality of service, including unreliability of deliveries. By outsourcing their fulfilment requirements firms can concentrate on their core competencies, iForce says.

The company was founded in 1998 and has more than 250,000 sq ft of warehouse space in three locations serving Britain and mainland Europe.

fields.headline: Marie Claire editor resigns
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The world of women's glossies has been rocked by the sudden resignation of Marie Claire editor Liz Jones, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The world of women's glossies has been rocked by the sudden resignation of Marie Claire editor Liz Jones, amid speculation that Ms Jones was forced to resign due to falling circulation.

IPC said Ms Jones was leaving the company "to spend more time writing for magazines and the national press".

She is to be replaced by Marie O'Riordan, group publishing director for Emap's youth titles and a former editor of Elle, prompting speculation that IPC was in negotiations to secure her before Ms Jones was ordered to leave.

A spokeswoman for IPC said Ms Jones had left the company to pursue other interests.

But industry sources say the company is keen to reverse the 11% decline in circulation recorded by the magazine at the last ABCs.

And the magazine notably failed to win any awards at last night's IPC awards dinner.

In a statement, Ms O'Riordan said: "I am delighted to be following Liz Jones as the editor of such a high-profile, award-winning international brand."

Ms Jones said she had been "privileged to work with such a talented and creative group of people".

She has come to public prominence recently as a columnist with her Single File column in the Sunday Times.

fields.headline: Backers abandon Simply Money
fields.trailText: 3pm: Backers of Simply Money, the TV channel fronted by Angela Rippon, have pulled the plug on the venture, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Backers of Simply Money, the personal finance TV channel fronted by Angela Rippon, have pulled the plug on the venture, causing the loss of nearly all 51 jobs.

The channel, which celebrated its first birthday last month, will now be replaced by a QVC-like channel, called Simply Shopping, on April 16.

Staff were told of the decision in a meeting last Thursday and asked to vacate the premises immediately.

They will discover their fate this Friday, when it is expected around 90% of staff will be made redundant.

It is not clear at this stage whether Rippon will present shows on Simply Shopping.

Managing director Ed Hall, currently on a skiing holiday, is also believed to be included in the cull.

A new chief operating officer, John Hodges, has been brought in to run to business and work closely with Simply Money founder George Bayer.

fields.headline: Interactive millionaires
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: ITV and Celador, the British producers behind Who Wants To Be A Millionaire?, are launching a set of interactive games so that fans of the programme can test their own knowledge.
fields.body:
ITV and Celador, the British producers behind Who Wants To Be A Millionaire?, are launching a set of interactive games so that fans of the programme can test their own knowledge.

ITV hopes that the game will help take-up of digital television when it launches on the ITV2 channel in the autumn. Viewers will answer questions via their set top boxes, building up scores but will be playing for "virtual" money.

"If you are one of those people who have sat on the sofa and screamed at the television because you know the answer and the contestant doesn't, you'll now have the chance to play along with them," said an ITV spokeswoman.

fields.headline: Watchdog blasts Sainsbury's advert
fields.trailText: 8.30am: A Sainsbury's advert has been banned for making misleading claims about the store's green credentials, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
An advertising campaign for Sainsbury's has been banned after regulators ruled it made misleading claims about the supermarket's green credentials.

The Advertising Standards Authority upheld complaints stating the print advert, for Sainsbury's fruit and vegetables, was ambiguous and could mislead shoppers.

The advert showed two apples, one beneath the heading "Pesticide", the other beneath the heading "Countryside".

A ladybird was shown crawling on the apple beneath the "Countryside" heading.

The copy stated: "All Sainsbury's British fruit and vegetables are grown with a commitment to using more natural farming methods, like this ladybird, to control pests."

The ASA said the advertisement misleadingly implied Sainsbury's used no pesticides on its fruit.

In fact, Sainsbury's merely has a policy of "encouraging environmentally responsible farming".

The authority asked the supermarket to consult its advisory team before running similar campaigns in the future.

But the ASA threw out complaints about a recruitment campaign for the Metropolitan Police being racist.

The advert showed a young couple standing outside a house with the statement: "This couple just had their new year spoiled by burglars" superimposed over them.

The line: "This is someone who doesn't want to know" was placed over a black man who was shown walking past the house.

And the words: "This is someone who does" were placed over a white woman onlooker.

The advert stated: "You could step in here as a special constable and make a real difference."

The complainants claimed the advert implied white people were more interested in law enforcement than black people.

But the Metropolitan Police argued another advert in the campaign showed an Asian woman as the person who wanted to know and a white man as the person who did not.

A third showed a black man who wanted to help a pensioner and a white man who did not.

The ASA concluded the advert was unlikely to cause serious or widespread offence.

fields.headline: Anti-semites really exist
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Israel and the
Middle East
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The battle on the West Bank between Israelis and Palestinians is now as familiar as the battle in Britain between those seeking a just analysis of this latest war - and Israel's diehard enemies.
fields.body:
The battle on the West Bank between Israelis and Palestinians is now as familiar as the battle in Britain between those seeking a just analysis of this latest war - and Israel's diehard enemies. The difference is that over there Israel has military superiority yet here Zion's critics have media superiority which they use disproportionately.

This pattern is being demonstrated in the Spectator: Lord Gilmour and a posse of well-known journalists attack a lone advocate of balanced coverage of Israel - a typical situation nowadays. Except that this lone defender is the proprietor of the Telegraph-Spectator group, Conrad Black. Since the anti-Zionist lobby is pervasively powerful and since journalists, who have attacked him, continue to write for the Telegraph (making their protestations of "censorship" rather rich), this proxy-Palestinian commando is not particularly courageous. The scene more resembles a gladiatorial show in which a bear is attacked by dogs in the Coliseum.

But their most powerful weapon is the sniggering of the chattering classes when Black claims the press, including the Guardian, is anti-semitic. "How clumsy! How absurd!" They say. "Not that old chestnut again!"

In fact, the chattering classes are being naive. Most critics of Israel are far from anti-semitic. I myself am proud to support Israel - but, like any democracy, she benefits from criticism and I heartily disapprove of her settlements policies. Most of the media blindly follow the fashion that "Israel is bad" out of slavish unoriginality and decent if misguided intentions so those involved in the Spectator affair are doubtless also worthy if confused humanitarians. However I know that others of the most energetic media-campaigners against Israel are, in private, virulent anti-semites.

Whether or not the American press is pro-Israeli or merely fair, the British press is neither. If the Telegraph alone is regarded as Israel-friendly, the Guardian leans towards the Israel-phobic - hence I write this with optimistic trepidation.

The fashionable menu of shameful lies repeatedly offered in respectable newspapers is long: that Israel is disgusting to employ Arab "slave labour" when all capitalist countries (including Britain and especially the Gulf States) employ unskilled workers of different nationalities; that this war is anything other than planned by the Palestinian leadership, as is privately admitted by neighbouring Arab leaders - but not in the British press. There is surely an inverted racism in judging Israel by European standards while never judging the brutal Arab tyrannies, including Arafat's corrupt dictatorship, as responsible for anything.

Most wicked is the implication that Israel is replicating German behaviour: this approaches Holocaust denial in its iniquity by deliberately seeking to minimise what happened and exaggerate what is happening. There is no parallel - moral or otherwise - between the tragic deaths of 300 Palestinians killed while attacking Israel with rocks, guns and busbombs, and the industrial slaughter of 6m men, women and children. These are lies promoted by well intentioned media editors whose decency is used (and mocked) by a small group of rabid anti-Zionists who are in fact real anti-semites.

There is little British anti-semitism. Descended from immigrants from Morocco, Italy and Russia, I awake every day to thank God that I was born Jewish in Britain. But there are anti-semitic polemicists, who privately hold views which they have aired in my presence: Jews are a dirty, impure, urban infestation. Arabs are a clean, rustic, pure race who possess qualities that Jews do not, a view ideologically descending from the TE Lawrence/ Foreign Office school but with racial elements.

Personally, the frequent use of the words "impure Jewblood" wounded me - just as I am now shocked to see editors regularly publishing the same characters' frenzied attacks on Israel. I do not like to see public or press mocked by soi-disant saints "laundering" disgusting views through respectable newspapers.

My aim is not to launch witchhunts, just to warn decent people who unknowingly have some unsavoury bed-fellows. It is time to resuscitate British traditions of scepticism, vigilance of hypocrisy - and fairness. Even for Israel. Most of the water in this well is at least drinkable - but, believe me, there is poison there too.

 The author's Life of Potemkin is published by Weidenfeld and Nicolson

webTitle: Hot shot - Murder in the name of art

fields.headline: Hot shot - Murder in the name of art
fields.standfirst: Special report: Beck's Futures 2001
fields.trailText: Artists can be a nasty lot, especially when big money prizes are at stake. Mostly though, they draw the line at murder. But not John Russell. Last night the painter pulled a revolver on his partner, Fabienne Audeoud, and shot her - what he wanted, it turned out, was the £65,000 Becks Futures prize.
fields.body:
Artists can be a nasty lot, especially when big money prizes are at stake. Mostly though, they draw the line at murder. But not John Russell. Last night the painter pulled a revolver on his partner, Fabienne Audeoud, and shot her - what he wanted, it turned out, was the £65,000 Becks Futures prize.

The "murder" committed in front of the glitterati at the ICA in London was performance art. It was in homage to the late William Burroughs, author of the drug-inspired Naked Lunch, who shot his wife just for the hell of it.

Russell and Audeoud, who paint large canvasses inspired by Grünewald, but with lots more gaping orifices, are one of the early favourites for the prize, the richer little sister of the Turner Prize.

This year, with six of the 10 young artists shortlisted calling themselves painters, and three others photographers, the Becks candidates seem a little on the tame side. The ICA said it saw this as a sign they belonged to a "sincere and unsensationalist" generation of artists, after the headline-grabbing iconoclasm of Brit Art and its hell-raising stars, Damien Hirst and Tracey Emin.

The exhibition is dominated by a huge horse and rider made out of recycled rubbish, a vast, spookier version by the sculptor Brian Griffith of the headless horseman in Tim Burton's film, Sleepy Hollow.

Inevitably, most of the artists, including the youngest, Gemma Iles, a 24-year-old photographer still at art school, have already had their work bought by Charles Saatchi, the advertising guru who dominates the British art scene. The other shortlisted artists are Clare Woods, Dan Holdsworth, Tim Stoner, Simon Bill, Shahin Afrassiabi and DJ Simpson.

The show runs until May at the ICA in central London and then tours galleries in Edinburgh, Liverpool, Newcastle and New York. The winners will be announced on April 10.

webTitle: Macedonia to alter constitution for Albanians

fields.headline: Macedonia to alter constitution for Albanians
fields.standfirst: Macedonia
fields.trailText: The Macedonian president, Boris Trajkovski, is expected to announce by the end of the week a date for the start of wide-ranging talks on changing the country's constitution to accommodate many of the Albanian minority's demands.
fields.body:
The Macedonian president, Boris Trajkovski, is expected to announce by the end of the week a date for the start of wide-ranging talks on changing the country's constitution to accommodate many of the Albanian minority's demands.

The talks may involve mediation by the EU, which would have a representative at the talks.

With the fighting in the hills largely over, and the dispersal of the Albanian gunmen from the mountain villages above Tetovo, the government is quietly celebrating the victory of its two-day offensive.

In his meetings with government officials and party leaders from both communities yesterday, Javier Solana, the EU's foreign policy supremo, urged them not to be triumphalist or use their unexpectedly quick victory as an excuse for delay.

"The president has made it clear he wants to intensify the dialogue," Mr Solana said on a visit to Tetovo to meet leaders of the Albanian minority.

The government is debating whether to accept international mediation for the talks, and what concessions to give.

The prime minister, Ljubco Georgievski, whose party faces elections next year, is from the same party as the president but is known to be more of a hawk.

"I believe President Trajkovski will announce the start of the talks by the end of this week. We have to do it. We cannot play around with Solana and [Nato chiefLord] Robertson," Branko Geroski, chief editor of independent daily Dnevnik, said yesterday.

Mr Geroski said an international presence at the talks would be a way to guarantee the agreement, and provide mediation if problems arose. "We want that sort of role because we need a strong deal which will last," he said.

Tetovo was returning to normal yesterday with most shops open and many people back on the streets. In the hills the army maintained its presence with tanks and armoured vehicles.

The 600-800 gunmen who had emerged in several Albanian populated mountain villages appareared to have melted away, leaving weapons behind. But government officials were aware that the gunmen could re-emerge later if no concessions are made to the Albanian community.

A key grievance is the preamble to the 1991 constitution which describes the country as "the national state of the Macedonian people". This is likely to go, though officials refuse to go into details of possible concessions.

Mr Geroski predicted that the government would allow Albanian to be used as an official language in state institutions, like the courts and government offices, in districts where large numbers of Albanians live. But it would not be official in central government.

Albanian leaders expressed relief that the army's offensive was over. Arben Xhaferi, whose party is in coalition with Mr Georgievski, tried to distance himself from the army offensive. "Troops and weapons did not stop the violence. What did it was the hope provided by the EU that it would intervene in starting political negotiations," he said.

The other main Albanian party, which is in opposition, has not yet lifted its boycott of parliament. "The army and police have destroyed civilian homes, and it is impossible to be in parliament as a democrat at the same time as the forces open fire on civilians," Muhamed Halili, their secretary-general, said yesterday.

The army now has to decide what forces to leave in the mountains. The government plans to buy several helicopters to help patrol its side of the border to coincide with the increase in security by the K-For peacekeeping force.

Yesterday K-For troops detained 18 armed men as they crossed from Macedonia into Kosovo. They were among more than 100 men who crossed the border at midnight. Some said they belonged to the National Liberation Army, the name adopted by the rebels, according to Lieutenant Colonel Thomas Loebbering, a K-For spokesman.

Meanwhile, trouble has flared in southern Serbia, where ethnic Albanian rebels attacked police positions in the Presevo valley area bordering Kosovo on Sunday and Monday, Serb officials said.

fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst:
With the first lambs come three new cases of foot and mouth, and our diarist's anger mounts

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Foot and mouth: free daily email service with latest updates
fields.trailText: With the first lambs come three new cases of foot and mouth, and our diarist's anger mounts.
fields.body:
The signs of spring are now unmistakable, but we don't feel much like celebrating and our grass fields remain as bare as boards. Our first lamb arrived on Saturday, followed by another new calf, a red Limousin cross heifer, on Sunday night. The pied wagtails are back but, according to my diary, 13 days later than last year. They are such cheerful little birds, I cannot help smiling when I see them hopping about on the walls and in the sheds.

The newest calf arrived at 10pm on Sunday and Peter thought all would be well, but as any farmer can tell you, animals are not always predictable. On Monday morning the calf had not suckled at all. Before breakfast we milked out the mother and fed the calf via a specially designed tube. This is not an easy task. This particular cow kicks like crazy when we milk her, but eventually Peter milked out 1.5 litres - enough to fill the small calf.

Peter has just talked to the vet, at the road end. We've been given some medicine for the sickly calf. I hope it helps. Three vets from the practice have now been seconded to Maff in Cumbria and the remaining few are carrying out emergencies only. They will not enter a farm unless absolutely necessary.

Maff insists its goal is to slaughter confirmed cases within 24 hours but in the past week in this region, the farmers have had to wait two to three days for a vet to come and a further two to three days for slaughter.

We all feel this is unacceptable, and fear what happened in Cumbria will happen here. Our local MP, Peter Atkinson, the NFU and the vets are all pushing Maff as hard as they can. We have to keep up the pressure. There is too much at stake.

Michael Jeans, a local farmer from Tranwell, near Morpeth, is also a county councillor and acting group leader for the Conservatives. But if the local elections are held, he won't be able to campaign because he is confined to home with a confirmed case of foot and mouth. He is to lose his 35 cattle and 250 sheep. He told me his animals had been infective for days and he wants action straight away.

Tigger, our terrier, is obviously fed up with the constant news reports and has taken refuge in the coat cupboard next to the Aga. We have lost her several times over the past few days and I think she feels secure in there, away from the tensions affecting us all. We're going to move all the junk out later and put some old jerseys in there for her. The farm where she was born stands alongside a confirmed case, where John and Carol Brown are to lose their animals.

Marmite, Tigger's litter sister, had her first puppies 11 days ago, but much to the children's chagrin we cannot visit them. Carol is very angry that she has not heard anything from Maff officially, but through the efforts of Peter Atkinson, they now know their animals will be taken. John hopes it will be soon - their flock is due to lamb in two weeks.

For us, hopefully by Friday we will have too many lambs to count the number of sheep lambed. The routine of the season will take over. There is little more that we can do. We wonder why they have come and, more importantly, where they have come from.
