fields.headline: When the last cow has gone
fields.standfirst:
When Andrew O'Hagan went to Sainsbury's at the start of his investigation into British farming, talk was of real food and a new breed of rural producer. In the third instalment of this major study, he heads west to find out just what that has meant for one farm in Devon

Special report: what's wrong with our food?
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: When Andrew O'Hagan went to Sainsbury's at the start of his investigation into British farming, talk was of real food and a new breed of rural producer. In the third instalment of this major study, he heads west to find out just what that has meant for one farm in Devon.
fields.body:
The day before I set off for Devon, there was a not entirely encouraging headline in the London Evening Standard: "Stay Out of the Countryside." Just when it seemed there was little room for disimprovement in the predicament of British farmers, news came of the biggest outbreak of foot and mouth disease in more than 30 years - 27 infected pigs were found at Cheale Meats, an abattoir in Essex.

Infected animals were quickly discovered on other farms. Suspicious livestock began to be slaughtered in their hundreds. Such was the smoke from the incineration site in Northumberland that the A69 had to be closed for a time. British exports of meat and livestock (annual export value £600m), as well as milk (400,000 tons are exported each year), were banned by the British government and the EU.

"It is like staring into the abyss," Ben Gill, president of the National Farmers' Union, said. "On top of the problems we have had to face in the last few years, the impact is unthinkable."

The National Pig Association estimates that the relatively small outbreak of swine fever last year cost the industry £100m. The last epidemic of FMD, in October 1967, led to the slaughter of 442,000 animals - a loss of hundreds of millions of pounds in today's terms, only a fraction of which made it back to the farmer in compensation. Last month's ban affected more than half of Britain's farmers and no one doubts that many will be ruined.

The county of Devon seemed dark green and paranoid when I travelled there the day after the ban was introduced. Yet I'd planned my visit as an opportunity to gaze at a vision of farming success. Stapleton Farm, my destination, produces quality brands of yoghurt and ice-cream. It was the one named by the Sainsbury's executives, the day I walked with them around the flagship store on the Cromwell Road, as an example of the new kind of partnership that can exist between supermarkets and farmers. Their optimism seemed hard to recapture now.

Passing through Bideford, Charles Kingsley's "little white town", you get a sudden rush of the way things used to be. Local records tell of how, in the 18th century, a bell would ring in Bideford market at 1pm, calling the local people to buy wheat. Traders were not allowed to buy until after 2pm, to prevent dealers overcharging the poor. The New Market, which opened in September 1960, sold 2,317 animals on its first day - dairy cows, calves, sheep and pigs.

According to a correspondent in Devon Life, Bideford livestock market has weathered several outbreaks of foot and mouth disease. Peter Kivell, a local farmer, remembers the call in the small hours in October 1967, announcing the first case in the area: "I spent the rest of the night wondering how we'd manage."

The low green valleys of the West Country have been subject to far less of the subsidy-mad prairie-isation you see in other counties, yet still there has been a vast downsizing of the rural economy. In 1995, 78,402 animals were sold in Bideford market; in 1998, 48,826. Many farmers now run their farms at subsistence level.

Stapleton Farm is not far from Bideford, nearer Great Torrington, and there isn't a cow to be seen. No livestock, no fields, no manure, no tractors, just a small manufacturing unit that couldn't be doing better. This is the enterprise Sainsbury's put me on to when I asked about the partnerships with farming that mattered to them. This is the new thing.

I found Carol Duncan in a Portakabin she uses as an office. She was surrounded by Sainsbury's invoices and office stationery. Like her husband Peter, she considers herself a modern rural producer. "I was delighted when we managed to get rid of the very last cow off this farm," she said. "That's the thing about cows, you know, they just poo all the time."

Peter's father and grandfather had run the farm in the traditional West Country way; they had livestock and worked the fields through thick and thin. "But from an early age I wasn't interested in that kind of farming," Peter said. "I wanted to be inside reading books. And I was interested in the different things you can do with milk. In the 1960s we farmers needed to diversify. The traditional way had been to stand around waiting for the government price review. I wanted to change things. My father would say: 'Who's going to milk the cows?'

"We started with three churns. Carol was an art teacher and that kept us going through the difficult years. We made yoghurt and started selling it to independent schools - if you're paying £16,000 a year for a school, you want to make sure your children aren't eating rubbish."

"We had to fight for our markets," Carol said. "In 1994 the price of milk in Devon went up by 29%. We had to increase the price of the yoghurt by 5% and we lost some of our German contracts. I went out and fought to get them back. It was horrible: 200-year-old cheesemakers were shut down and hardly a Devon clotted cream-maker was left standing. We thought we were going out of business."

"We started exporting our stuff," Peter said, "to Belgium especially. We supply an upmarket supermarket chain called Delhaize."

"Until this morning," Carol interjected. "We've just been banned from exporting."

"We're hoping it will only be a matter of weeks," Peter said, "but this sort of thing can ruin people. We're praying it doesn't spread."

The Duncans have more than 30 people working at Stapleton - chopping, grating, mixing, packaging, labelling, loading. The old farm buildings where the yoghurt and ice-cream are produced look typical enough among the high hedges of north Devon, yet inside each shed are silver machines and refrigerated rooms that are miles away from the world of cows.

Peter tells the story of the Sainsbury's development manager coming down to see them in 1998 as if relating a great oral ballad about a local battle or love affair. "The woman came down. I thought she seemed so fierce. They had already taken samples of our yoghurt away. They said they liked them. But when the woman came that day she just said: 'I suppose you'd like to see these' and it was the artwork for the pots. They'd already decided we were going into business. I nearly fell off my chair."

Carol laughed. "Yeah, and they said, how many of these could we produce a week?" They started aiming for 10,000 pots a week in a hundred stores. "It was incredibly hard work," Peter said. "We were putting yoghurt into pots by hand and pressing the lids on. Then they wanted more. We had to get better machinery. So it was off to the bank for £80,000. Come February 1999, we were doing 50,000-60,000 pots a week."

"We think Sainsbury's are geniuses," Carol added. "We give them yoghurt and they sell it."

Stapleton Farm processes all its own fruit by hand; the milk comes from three local farms. Recently, they started giving the milk farmers half a penny more per litre, because of the hard time the farmers are having. "It's been a music hall joke for years," Peter said, "about farmers complaining. But now the worst has come true."

"The ladies who work for us are all here to earn money to feed their kids," Carol said. "The farms they live on are struggling. It's a struggle for us, too, but it's our little dream."

The Duncans' dream has been one of survival and self-sufficiency, and being free of that last cow. But as environmentalists, they may have trouble living with the price of their own success: expansion. Supermarkets want to be able to rely on volume and if Stapleton Farm's yoghurt continues to grow in popularity, it will have to get bigger; the charm of its smallness cannot last. The week I met the Duncans, they were reeling from having bought a £68,000 machine that wasn't yet working. Doing well entails spending more, so demand can be met. They are heavily in debt but also rejoicing in their success.

"Starting to do business with Sainsbury's feels like being mown down by a bus," Peter said.

"Yes," Carol said, "but I was so relieved when we got rid of that last cow and that old farm. That's the thing with a lot of the farmers around here: they have the potential to get into tourism, get into the farm cottages side, caravans and all that. Farmers just have the wrong attitude."

"No," Peter said, "not all of them. The problem was the Marketing Boards, which gave farmers the wrong idea. They thought someone would just take their produce away and turn it into money. No other country in Europe was like that. That is why we are so far behind."

Carol heaved a sigh. "I'm so pissed off about the foot and mouth disease. We had a whole lot of ice-cream going into Spain next week. Not now. I hope it doesn't spread to here."

I asked the Duncans if they were worried about having all their eggs in one basket. What if people get fed up with Devon yoghurt? What if Sainsbury's find somewhere cheaper, or better able to meet the volume required? Or if it falls for the new kid on the block? Carol met my gaze evenly. "We'll survive," she said.

In the factory, Peter stopped in the middle of a chilled room, with the sound of clicking going on further along the line, the sound of mass production. "This was a cattleshed when I was little," he said. "I remember it clearly."

We stood beside a pallet of strawberry yoghurts bound for Sainsbury's. It had the special label attached. I asked who paid for the Sainsbury's packaging. "Oh, we do," he said.

That afternoon Tim Yeo, the shadow agriculture spokesman, said the government had responded in chaotic fashion to a chain of farming crises. "I wish he would shut up," Nick Brown replied. "He is trying to make political capital out of a terrible situation." And when I was barely out of the West Country, news broke of another farm where livestock was found to have contracted foot and mouth. The farm was in Devon. And the farmer owned 13 other farms.

fields.body:
Red diversion signs and blue police tape seal off the tumbledown pig unit on the Roman wall which was confirmed yesterday as the source of the foot and mouth epidemic.

The rank smell of pigswill processing still catches at the few passersby on the lane running close to Burnside farm, a grand name for Ronnie and Bobby Waugh's lake of slurry and collection of rusting pens.

"The stench was awful when the work was going on," said one of the volunteers at Heddon-on-the-Wall Women's Institute's Tuesday tea, held as usual despite the village's grim, repeated appearance in reports of Nick Brown's Commons speech. "The Waughs hadn't been there very long, and it wasn't like a real farm - they didn't live on the premises."

The empty smallholding, freely described as "a disgrace" and "a horror story" by locals, is no longer accessible; but for officials conditions there always seemed difficult to monitor. "I've been made a convict and I haven't even been given a chance to reply," he said. "This stuff about my pigswill being contaminated by Chinese restaurant food is ridiculous.

"The last time I saw a Maff official was when our pigs were slaughtered three weeks ago. No one has even asked me about where I got my pigswill, so how can they make assumptions like this?"

One team is looking at a down-at-heel caravan in Crook, county Durham, where father and son Andrew and Kenneth Clement run a swill-collecting business.

The pair, who were fined £600 a fortnight ago for keeping untreated waste on the smallholding, pick up 50 wheelie bins a week from schools, restaurants and even a regional police college. Their phone has been disconnected and the farm cannot be reached because of foot and mouth restrictions.

Other investigators are looking at restaurants in Newcastle-upon-Tyne, particularly the Chinatown area of Stowell Street, where the Waughs' neighbour and fellow-processor Jimmy Brown made a regular collection of leftover food. Among his clients was Tony Chu, who paid £30 a month for the regular disposal of waste food from the Happiness Inn in Percy Street.

"It's a contract we've had for many years," said Mr Chu, 63, who was sceptical about suggestions that contaminated, illegally imported meat from the Far East could have got into the swill.

He said: "I can't speak for all restaurants but I'd find it difficult to believe that any of the ones run by the Chinese community in Newcastle are doing this. If they are, it is a disgrace and should be stamped out."

Mr Waugh, who was called "abrupt and arrogant" by his neighbour Mr Simons, said he had always heated up the swill to "the required temperature of 93.3 degrees and held it at that level for the four hours they lay down in the guidelines".

Back at the WI tea, no one was laying odds on attendance at Heddon's planned British bacon butty morning, which is due to precede a Best Kept Village communal tidy-up on Saturday week.

webTitle: Illegal meat trail leads to infected countries

fields.headline: Illegal meat trail leads to infected countries
fields.standfirst:
Smuggling: Officials say seizures are running at 200 a month

Special report: foot and mouth

Foot and mouth: free daily email service with latest updates
fields.trailText: Thousands of consignments of illegal meat arrive in Britain, travelling in either containers or hand luggage mainly from Africa and Asia - continents with recent outbreaks of foot and mouth disease.
fields.body:
Thousands of consignments of illegal meat arrive in Britain, travelling in either containers or hand luggage mainly from Africa and Asia - continents with recent outbreaks of foot and mouth disease.

Bush rats, antelope, cow's nostrils, monkey meat, elephant, oriental sausages, even dried caterpillars and smoked grubs - as well as other unknown varieties of dried and smoked meat - are smuggled in for speciality ethnic markets.

Larger consignments of pork, lamb, beef and goat from Asia and Africa are also stopped, since they could not pass EU regulations because they come from foot and mouth-infected countries or do not reach hygiene standards. Seizures run at 200 a month, but yesterday public health officials said they needed more powers to search baggage.

Ports and airports throughout the UK have specialist officers looking for illegal meat. The practice is so common that baggage handlers at Heathrow regularly alert customs when they notice blood dripping out of suitcases, according to the Ministry of Agriculture.

Yesterday in a Commons statement, Nick Brown, the minister of agriculture, said illegal meat was the probable cause of the outbreak of foot and mouth, but he refused to give details because of potential prosecution. The problem for investigators is that one tiny piece of infected meat in pigswill that has not been properly treated is enough to trigger an epidemic.

The Association of Port Health Authorities called yesterday for tighter controls on containers ostensibly importing fruit or vegetables but which can be used to smuggle meat. It also wanted the power to inspect hand baggage but the Ministry of Agriculture has so far refused, relying on customs officers to do the checks.

At Gatwick airport, where public health officers have the right to inspect containers, 225 consignments were seized last year totalling 67 tonnes. The main sources were Ghana, Gambia, Sierra Leone and the Ivory Coast. But according to Graham Forbes, principal environmental health officer for Crawley council, the countries involved at Gatwick reflected mainly where the airport's cargo flights came from; there were also seizures from Argentina where there is foot and mouth.

"A major extra source is passenger baggage, but we cannot inspect on our own - only if customs stop people and let us see in the suitcase. It is a loophole the association has been trying to close for years."

Mr Forbes said that, to test whether meat was coming in illegally, he and other officers had visited a market in Hackney in east London, and had seen bushmeat on sale. It had come through Gatwick, but the numbers on the consignment showed it had arrived illegally.

Doug Bloomfield, assistant director of environmental services for Suffolk coastal district council, responsible for Felixstowe, the biggest container port in Britain, said he seized on average one illegal consignment a week. "It can be anything from a few sausages from Asia to 300 to 400 cartons hidden in a container load of something else. Sometimes we have to empty the whole consignment to find things, at other times there are large quantities."

He said the the authorities rarely prosecuted because it was difficult to prove intent. The usual defence was that the meat was unsolicited. Very often consignments were mislabelled or not mentioned at all on the list of contents.

The temptation to smuggle comes partly because "welly meat", as it is called, is popular with West Africans and can fetch good prices. EU regulations ban many meat products like pomos (cows nostrils) or smokies (blowtorched pieces of goat with the skin on) because of BSE. Both can be bought in markets although pomos are sold "under the counter".

Larger consignments of pork, lamb and goat, destined for Chinese, Indian and other Asian restaurants come from meat plants and abattoirs without EU licenses. Plants importing meat have to be inspected and approved by the EU and certified as foot and mouth-free. Each legal consignment has a distinctive number so its origin can be traced. This is costly to the supplier. Even if applications for licences were made, many would fail to meet regulations because foot and mouth in Asia, particularly China, and southern Africa make imports illegal in any event.

Pete Rotheram, secretary of the Association of Port Health Authorities, said more resources were needed. "It is very easy to make illegal shipments, and there is a good chance that they can evade all controls," he said.

The agriculture ministry said it often alerted customs after tip-offs from legal importers losing trade. Last year all flights from Ghana were searched after a complaint from dried fish importers; several tonnes of illegal fish in hand luggage were seized, but this led to a complaint of racial harassment against the ministry.

fields.headline: Country cause
fields.standfirst: Foot and mouth prompts crisis fund
fields.trailText: Foot and mouth prompts crisis fund.
fields.body:
Community foundations are weighing in to help rural groups working to counter the effects of the foot and mouth epidemic.

At least three local foundations in some of the worst-hit parts of the country have set up special funds, or earmarked money for grant-making. People are being invited to contribute to the funds and all contributions should receive match-funding from the government.

Sean McDougall, of the Community Foundation Network, says member organisations are ideally placed to act speedily and effectively in times of crisis. "What sets community foundations apart from other charities is the fact that they support a range of good causes," he says. "And because they have their ear to the ground, they know what's going on and can respond more quickly than other organisations."

The Scottish Community Foundation has established a rural crises fund, to be pump-primed with a quarter of all money raised by the annual Caledonian Challenge, Scotland's largest corporate fundraising event, which involves company teams walking 54 miles of the West Highland Way in 24 hours. Last year, it realised £500,000.

Cumbria Community Foundation has set up a welfare fund, with £20,000 of its own funds and £50,000 from the Francis C Scott Charitable Trust. Other trusts are expected to make contributions.

The County of Gloucestershire Community Foundation is inviting bids from local charities and community groups offering material support or counselling to farmers. Grants of £500-£2,500 will be made within a fortnight of applications closing on April 30.

Robin Gist, who chairs the Gloucestershire foundation, says: "Many rural communities are already facing problems and the foot and mouth disease is yet another burden. We aim to make the bidding process as simple as possible and are always ready to give advice and assistance."

 The Scottish Community Foundation is on 0131-225 9804; Cumbria Community Foundation is on 01900-325801; the County of Gloucestershire Community Foundation is on 01452-522006; the Community Foundation Network is on 020-7422 8611.

fields.headline: Right attacks Jackson's probity
fields.standfirst:
Leading black politician under fire for allegedly raising money for his groups by threats of boycotts
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Leading black politician under fire for allegedly raising money for his groups by threats of boycotts
fields.body:
The Rev Jesse Jackson, still the most prominent distinctively black voice in American politics, is under fire from conservative groups who accuse him of threatening corporations with boycotts over their racial practices unless they contribute to his organisations. Mr Jackson has also been accused of using leverage to get business contracts for friends and relatives.

Mr Jackson has strongly denied threatening boycotts for financial gain for his groups or for his friends or relatives, and his supporters dismiss the attacks as an attempt to neutralise an influential political voice, claiming it is partly a response to his huge success in mobilising the African-American vote for Al Gore and challenging Mr Bush's legitimacy as president.

The attacks started in January when it emerged that Mr Jackson, 59, had fathered a child in an extramarital affair with Karin Stanford, a former director of the Citizenship Education Fund, one of four interconnected groups he is involved with. When she moved to California, the group paid her $35,000 (£24,400) in relocation and consulting fees.

The fund boosted its revenue from $2m in 1998 to $9.8m in 1999 and more than $10m last year, mainly from corporate grants and sponsorships. It is suggested that Mr Jackson's groups approach vulnerable firms - at the time of a merger or facingracial bias claims.

Mr Jackson has long complained that many companies "redline" blacks by not hiring them or refusing them capital.

"Redlining is economic apartheid, so yes, we say, 'If we are your customer or your worker, stop boycotting us or we will boycott you,' " Mr Jackson told the Washington Post.

He said that if the firm then showed its corporate responsibility by supporting groups seeking to end inequality or divested businesses to black entrepreneurs, the action was justified.

Some conservative black groups are also among his critics. "It's so interesting to watch executives who in another context would make rational decisions willingly capitulate to Jesse Jackson," said Gerald Reynolds of the Centre for New Black Leadership.

One episode under scrutiny concerns the time when Viacom Inc. and CBS sought federal permission in 1999 for their $91bn merger.

Mr Jackson said the merger presented a good opportunity for a spin-off for minority ownership, and suggested his associate Percy Sutton, the former Manhattan borough president which owns radio stations across the country.

The spin-off failed to materialise but during the row Viacom became a supporter of the CEF, contributing $377,500.

Another issue raised is the $82m workplace discrimination lawsuit filed by 13,000 black employees or ex-staff of Boeing in the 1990s. In early 1999, Mr Jackson fnegotiated a $15m settlement but some of the employees claimed he had not been tough enough. Boeing then donated $50,000 to the CEF.

Two of Mr Jackson's sons, Yusef and Jonathan, have received beer distributorships from Anheuser-Busch, against which Mr Jackson had helped organise a boycott in the 1980s in protest at their ethnic minority employment record.

Mr Jackson has long been a rightwing target, not least because of his proven ability to mobilise the African-American vote.Last November, 92% of black voters chose Mr Gore.

Mr Jackson's supporters said it was no coincidence that revelations of his infidelity surfaced just before protests against Mr Bush's victory.

Earlier this month a conservative political group filed a complaint with the Federal Election Commission against the Rainbow/Push Coalition, claiming that Mr Jackson had illegally moved Democratic party money through his nonprofit group to cover expenses. No one was available for comment yesterday at the Rainbow/Push office in Chicago.

Rainbow/Push had already published financial records showing that Mr Jackson had spent $614,000 on travel, with the Democratic party contributing $450,000 as part of the get-out-the-vote campaign.

Mr Jackson has weathered storms before. But this time the attacks have intensified. As Mr Bush seeks to win over the black electorate, it is clear that his allies would be more than happy if the leading black voice was silenced.

Two of Mr Jackson's sons, Yusef and Jonathan, have received beer distributorships from Anheuser-Busch, against which Mr Jackson had helped organise a boycott in the 1980s in protest at their ethnic minority employment record. Mr Jackson has long been a rightwing target, not least because of his proven ability to mobilise the African-American vote.Last November, 92% of black voters chose Mr Gore. Mr Jackson's supporters said it was no coincidence that revelations of his infidelity surfaced just before protests against Mr Bush's victory. Earlier this month a conservative political group filed a complaint with the Federal Election Commission against the Rainbow/Push Coalition, claiming that Mr Jackson had illegally moved Democratic party money through his nonprofit group to cover expenses. No one was available for comment yesterday at the Rainbow/Push office in Chicago. Rainbow/Push had already published financial records showing that Mr Jackson had spent $614,000 on travel, with the Democratic party contributing $450,000 as part of the get-out-the-vote campaign. Mr Jackson has weathered storms before. But this time the attacks have intensified. As Mr Bush seeks to win over the black electorate, it is clear that his allies would be more than happy if the leading black voice was silenced.

webTitle: AL Kennedy goes neurotic in America

fields.headline: Not flying but drowning
fields.standfirst:
In the land of the handgun I wake up screaming. But that's not unusual

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: In the land of the handgun I wake up screaming. But that's not unusual.
fields.body:
This month, I've temporarily escaped from the Island of Death and am living in the United States, home of the handgun and George Bush Jnr - the jury is currently out on which does more damage. I suffer, now and then, from slight anxiety and depression, so I've flown to New York for a working holiday, which may seem a little like a haemophiliac taking up therapeutic sword swallowing, but it does make sense to me.

Although flying is, in itself, a source of anxiety, not to mention fatal illness, I did my best to resist its worst effects, filling my bloodstream with soothingly prophylactic aspirin (I may now have a stomach ulcer) coating my entire body with coconut oil and drinking a litre of water every eight minutes for the duration. Washed in untoward radiation, unable to afford my own air supply, and thrumming with suppressed stress, I was fully aware that I could still have contracted untold ghastly in-flight infections. Dengue fever has mutated and is now raging throughout South America, courtesy of air travel, and the recent Canadian ebola scare was also delivered by jet.

But, currently, I feel almost well, even though I realise that New York is crawling with drug-resistant strains of TB. So I feel even better, if I don't inhale. And soon the privatisation of British air traffic control will ensure that I die just after take-off on any subsequent trip, so things will be looking up (and then plunging rapidly down again).

Now that I've arrived safely, being rather closer than usual to George W is, naturally, another worry. Poor Vice President Cheney - a man whose circulatory system resembles the M25 after a hideous cottage cheese spillage - is condemned to toil beside his president (telling him when to breathe, making sure he remembers how to pronounce "neucular desturction") until he reaches his cardiac event horizon and is wheeled out of George's office, feet first.

Even with Cheney in place, Bush has declared taxes, welfare, workplace safety regulations and strikes to be unconstitutional and is trying to reverse legislation that limits the amount of arsenic in drinking water. He may well get away with this, if he can guarantee that his policies only kill the non-voting 50% of the population. Meanwhile, I'm trying to drink only orange juice. I wake up screaming, but that's not unusual.

It has nothing to do with my fretting that grotesque social injustice will soon be blazing across the world's only "hyperpower". And think of the suffering millionaires - all Bush's favourite people are millionaires - as the Dow Jones plummets and their fortunes crash, they're discovering their president can't love them any more. To take my mind off this, I frequently lie down in a darkened room, thus shaving an infinitesimally small fraction off America's terrifying consumption of electricity. Soon the Alaskan wilderness and the relatively unspoiled bits of the Gulf of Mexico will be ravaged in the search for more fossil fuel to burn in more power plants, to produce more greenhouse gasses.

There are, of course, scientists who - like their noble predecessors who were willing to claim that smoking improved your singing voice - will swear on a stack of unrecycled bibles that greenhouse gasses don't produce the greenhouse effect. Those who, like George W, choose to believe them will be able to repent at their relative leisure as factories are lost in successive deluges and workforces and families are swept away by tornadoes, or killed by arsenic poisoning and workplace accidents.

I do, quite reasonably, have nervous palpitations solely associated with the thought that Bush is a monstrously dangerous moron with almost unlimited power. But the neuralgic fun really starts when I consider that his stupidity, though monumental, is more than equalled by his lack of imagination and his greed. He will always seek to protect an unregulated and entirely self-interested global market, now inextricably linked with massive fraud and money laundering, he will always think in the shortest of short terms, ensuring that those of us without amphibious grandchildren can kiss our DNA goodbye.

So why come here to relax? Because, as international annihilation is inevitable, a change of terror is as good as a rest. Bush's "thinking" is perhaps a few degrees more extreme than that of Blair, Hague and the rest, but each is more than content to put their electorates, a variety of designated foreigners and the conditions necessary for sustaining life on earth, at risk. In return, they can look forward to a personally profitable (though brief) future and some interestingly expensive friends they can die with. Meanwhile, I look forward to coming home and trying to guess where uncontrolled cupidity, ineptitude and habitual falsehood will bring about the next Great British Disaster.

webTitle: Girl of 12 on theft charge held in cells all weekend

fields.headline: Girl of 12 on theft charge held in cells all weekend
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: A 12-year-old girl accused of shoplifting spent three days in police cells after her mother refused to collect her and a succession of failures by social services left officers with no choice but to detain her, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
A 12-year-old girl accused of shoplifting spent three days in police cells after her mother refused to collect her and a succession of failures by social services left officers with no choice but to detain her, it emerged last night.

The girl, who cannot be named for legal reasons, was detained at Bluewater shopping centre, in Kent, on Saturday evening and charged with theft. She allegedly stole the items from seven shops during the afternoon. The girl's mother was contacted but, according to Kent police, the woman "refused to attend" and the girl was then denied bail by the police.

Despite repeated requests from the duty solicitor representing the girl, social services in Kent and Lewisham, south-east London, where she lives, failed to arrange for her to be released into the custody of a social worker or to her mother. A Lewisham social worker is alleged to have told the solicitor: "We're not a taxi service."

After spending the weekend in the cells or detention rooms at Bluewater and Gravesend police stations and at Dartford magistrates court, the girl was finally released into the custody of a social worker and returned to her mother on Monday afternoon.

Robin Murray, the girl's solicitor, said: "Where parents fail, through neglect or circumstances, social services are supposed to provide a safety net. Instead they provided a black hole, through which my client fell into a dungeon. I visited her in a detention room, which looks like a cell, smells like a cell and frankly is a cell. She was crying to herself, face down on the bed."

After being detained, the girl, who had travelled to Bluewater with older children, was visited by Mr Murray, who was told an interview had been conducted with an appropriate adult provided by Kent social services in attendance.

He was assured that the girl would be released to her mother or social services, and having told the girl this he left to see other clients at Gravesend police station. Around midnight, however, he was told that the girl was still in custody and had been transferred to Gravesend police station after Bluewater had closed.

On Sunday afternoon, Mr Murray was contacted by the duty inspector at Gravesend police station who, having noted Mr Murray's concerns from the previous evening, informed him that the girl was still in custody. "I called Lewisham social services straight away and was told by the duty social worker, 'We don't operate as an unpaid taxi service, it's not our problem'. "

A spokesman for Kent social services said they had contacted Lewisham social services on Saturday evening and were told that the girl would be taken care of.

Zena Peatfield, Lewisham's director of social care and health, launched an inquiry and said: "It appears in this instance we may have let this girl down very badly indeed."

fields.headline: Floods displace thousands in Mozambique
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mozambique floods
fields.trailText: More than 180,000 people have fled continuing floods in central Mozambique and are living in temporary accommodation centres, according to United Nations and government officials.
fields.body:
More than 180,000 people have fled continuing floods in central Mozambique and are living in temporary accommodation centres, according to United Nations and government officials.

The Zambezi river has remained at between two-and-a-half metres and three metres above flood level for more than five weeks. Rain is continuing upstream in Malawi and Zambia and flood waters are expected to remain at this level for at least a fortnight. So far 81 people have died.

The navy began evacuating people from low ground in January using rubber boats donated for last year's floods. At first many people refused to leave their homes but with their fields still under water and their food stocks exhausted, thousands are now making their way daily by foot or canoe to the more than 70 accommodation centres.

The authorities were well prepared, and evacuations began early. However, Mozambique remains one of the world's poorest countries and it does not have the resources to cope with the growing number of displaced people.

The accommodation centres are largely organised by local government officials, with the help of national voluntary organisations and, increasingly, international non-governmental organisations. But food and other supplies must be brought in by the UN World Food Programme, Unicef, and the International Federation of Red Cross Societies.

There are few paved roads in the flood area, and heavy rains have turned dirt roads to mud. It takes two days for a food lorry to travel the 200 miles from the port of Beira to Caia, the town on the south bank of the Zambezi river used as a food distribution centre.

It takes another day to reach the three accommodation centres further downstream, near Marromeu, which now contain 24,000 people.

At least 80 tonnes of food a day must reach the accommodation centres to feed 180,000 people. Officially, the UN World Food Programme says it is meeting the demand. Privately, however, UN officials admit that the two planes, two heli copters and a small fleet of trucks are not sufficient.

Of the displaced, 155,000 are in the Zambezi valley and the rest have fled floods on two smaller rivers, the Lucheringo river, north of the Zambezi, and the Pungue river, south of the Zambezi. The Pungue rose again at the weekend, cutting the main road between Beira and Zimbabwe for the fourth time this year

Last year's floods - in the south - were the worst for more than 150 years, killing 700 people and displacing 550,000 others. Last year, four cyclones and record rains brought four successive flood crests and rapidly rising and falling water on the Incomati, Limpopo and Save rivers.

This year the floods began in January with heavy rain in Malawi and central Mozambique, and have continued as heavy rain has fallen in Zambia and Zimbabwe.

This year the giant Cabora Bassa dam has been managed to prevent sharp rises and falls in water levels. When there has been a lot of water coming into the Zambezi from the Shire River, downstream of the dam, the dam gates have been closed. With flows from Malawi falling, Cabora Bassa has opened four of its eight gates, but flood waters rose only slightly over the weekend.

The dam management this year is in sharp contrast to the last big flood, in 1978, when dam managers panicked and opened all eight gates, sending a wave down the river which killed at least 45 people.

Joseph Hanlon is the author, with Frances Christie, of Mozambique and the Great Flood of 2000 published by James Currey (Oxford).

fields.headline: Milosevic aides held for corruption
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Eight former associates of the ousted Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic, including two of his top aides, have been detained by police on suspicion of corruption, court officials said yesterday.
fields.body:
Eight former associates of the ousted Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic, including two of his top aides, have been detained by police on suspicion of corruption, court officials said yesterday.

Among those arrested were Uros Suvakovic, a former department head of Serbia's state security and lieutenant of Mr Milosevic's wife Mirjana Markovic, and the former deputy chief of the secretpolice, Nikola Curcic, the Belgrade district court confirmed.

The arrests bring to about 15 the number of former associates in custody. Most prominent is Rade Markovic, head of the secret police for the last three years of the Milosevic regime.

He was arrested a month ago, on suspicion of ordering an assassination attempt on the opposition leader Vuk Draskovic in October 1999. Four of Mr Draskovic's party colleagues died in the attack. Mr Markovic denies the charges.

Mr Curcic was arrested on Saturday, the rest on Monday.

The Belgrade court said Mr Curcic was put under 30-day detention on suspicion of revealing state secrets. Mr Suvakovic, Danilo Pantovic, a former senior foreign and interior ministry official, and Milos Loncar, another federal government official, are being investigated in connection with the purchase of the villa where Mr Milosevic lives.

Four more officials are suspected of embezzling about £350,000 from Serbia's health insurance funds.

webTitle: Jonathan Freedland on Israel in crisis

fields.headline: Killers and losers
fields.standfirst:
The blood of innocents is being spilled in a conflict that generates harsh controversy in the UK

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The blood of innocents is being spilled in a conflict that generates harsh controversy in the UK.
fields.body:
Who wins when a baby girl, just ten-months-old, is shot cleanly in the head? Who wins when the early morning is broken by the sound of a bomb? Who wins when the same city shudders from a second blast just a few hours later?

Certainly not the Israelis, on the receiving end of that treatment yesterday. Not the family of Shalhavet Pass, who have lost a baby daughter. They may have chosen to live on the West Bank, in Hebron, a tiny enclave of 400 Jewish settlers surrounded by 120,000 Palestinians, but their daughter made no choice. As one Palestinian activist put it yesterday, she "was a baby who didn't even know she was a settler".

So the Pass family are not winners. Nor are the citizens of Israel proper - those who have avoided the risks taken by the 400 hardliners of Hebron. They do not live in the heart of occupied territory; they are not driven by ideology. Yet they, too, feel nervous wherever they walk: yesterday's car bomb was left outside a Jerusalem supermarket. Nowhere is safe. In today's Israel a simple bus ride is a gamble with fate. Passengers eye each other cautiously: what if that man, over there, has dynamite strapped to his chest and is about to blow?

So the Israelis are not winning. But are the Palestinians? The sniper who killed Shalhavet: did he gain something for his people or his cause? If so, what exactly? Six months to the day since this intifada began, it's time to ask: what good is coming from it? What is it for?

Palestinians themselves are beginning to ask that question. For they are the ones paying for the uprising which erupted last September - paying for it in their blood, their children and their livelihoods.

Just look at the death toll: more than 420 lives have been lost, but the overwhelming majority of them, 350, have been Palestinian - dozens of them kids. They have seen a 12-year-old boy, Muhammad al-Durrah, shot dead in his father's arms (just like Shalhavet). Each week another Palestinian infant is transformed into a "martyr".

Palestinian lives are made next to impossible. Every attack on Israel brings another clampdown: either the closure of the West Bank and Gaza, choking off economic life in the territories, or "internal closures", cutting off movement between Palestine's cities, towns and villages. The result, says the United Nations, is a Palestinian economy losing $11m a day.

But the biggest problem comes from the Israeli response to Palestinian gun attacks. TV audiences around the world probably believe this intifada is like the last one, back in the late 1980s: a battle of an armed Israeli Goliath against hundreds of young, stone-throwing Palestinian Davids. The current uprising certainly began that way - but it's changed.

Now it is fought less by a mass movement than by an activist minority - using guns. The crack troops are the tanzim, Palestinian fighters who enjoy a half in, half out relationship with Yasser Arafat's Palestinian Authority. It is the tanzim who fire on Jewish settlements and on Israeli army positions. Theirs is a time-honoured, anti-colonial strategy - a guerrilla war designed to make the occupiers' lives so unbearable they eventually have no choice but to leave.

The problem is that, in the process, the tanzim are ruining the lives of their own people. For these fighters tend to use residential Palestinian neighbourhoods as their base, firing from building sites or hollowed-out ruins. The Israelis then hit back at the source of the fire, sending local people cowering into basements and back rooms to avoid getting hurt. Others want to look again at that Clinton-brokered offer, rejected by Arafat last year.

Admittedly, that Camp David plan had deep flaws. The map of the putative Palestine was a swiss cheese, full of holes; and Israel did not accept that 3.7m Palestinian refugees should have the right to return, a move most Israelis believe would amount to national suicide. But the basis of a deal was there, especially in the beefed-up form on offer in January: the Palestinians could've built on it. It would have paved the way for statehood and a share of Jerusalem, including Palestinian control over the Temple Mount or Haram al-Sharif.

So no wonder many Palestinians are looking back wistfully at that offer now. The naive among them think they can still have it, by restarting talks with Ariel Sharon and picking up where they left off. But Sharon is not the same as his predecessor, Ehud Barak: that deal is not on the table. And, with Bill Clinton gone, the Palestinians no longer have a US president obsessed with middle east peace: when they ring Washington now, they'll be lucky to get their call returned.

No, the Palestinian tragedy is to be locked into an uprising that is hurting them more than their enemy - guided by a leadership with a fateful talent for missing history's moment.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Home buyers rush for loans
fields.body:
Home buyers rush for loans

The number of mortgages approved by British banks surged last month as borrowers took advantage of improved interest rates.

The British Bankers' Association said 139,659 new mortgage loans were cleared by its members in February, a 17% rise on the previous month.

The value of mortgage approvals during February was £7.52bn, up 23%.

The BBA believes the approval figure indicates a strengthening of the housing market, although the amount of money lent by banks during February did fall 2% to £5.99bn.

Credit card spending was down 12% to £4.69bn, although demand for personal loans remained robust at £2.6bn.

Bloodstock bust-up

Three senior directors of AIM-listed racehorse dealer the British Bloodstock Agency, including Britain's second-richest woman, last night quit the board after shareholders rejected a plan to take the company private.

Chairman Major Christo Philipson, Major General Guy Watkins and milk cartons heiress Kirsten Rausing resigned immediately, along with nominated adviser and broker Cazenove & Co.

Shareholders rejected a complex offer from two senior managers at the company and will now be consulted on the firm's future. The BBA has a valuation of £3m, which many think is too small to warrant an AIM listing.

AstraZeneca expanding

Anglo-Swedish drugs group AstraZeneca is investing £84m in new laboratories and offices at its research and development site in Alderley Park, Cheshire.

The laboratories are used for research into cancer, cardiovascular diseases and arthritis.

The company said that among the investments would be a DNA archive and genetic research centre as well as a protein and cell production facility.

Leicester City on the move

Leicester City plans a £28m bond issue to help fund a move to a new £37m stadium.

The AIM-listed football club plans to sell its Filbert Street ground and move to a 22-acre site at Freemen's Wharf in the town, which it is buying from Powergen for £7m.

Alkan denies Billiton bid

Alcan, the world's second largest aluminium group, yesterday quashed talk it was planning to bid for mining business Billiton, which is in the process of merging with Australia's BHP.

fields.headline: Curry nation
fields.standfirst: Family firm cooks up work for thousands
fields.trailText: Couch potatoes may be stuck on celebrity chefs but when it comes to cooking a little Eastern promise goes a long way.
fields.body:
Couch potatoes may be stuck on celebrity chefs but when it comes to cooking a little Eastern promise goes a long way.

British appetites for Asian convenience food have grown to such an extent that S&A Foods- which specialises in Indian, Chinese and Thai dishes - is to at least double in size.

The Derby firm yesterday announced a £31m investment in a new factory at Newcastle-under-Lyme, Staffordshire, which will create more than 1,000 jobs next year. A second phase, scheduled for 2003/2004, could add another 1,200 jobs.

S&A Foods was started in 1986 by Indian-born Perween Warsi. Since then her enterprise has grown from a cottage industry supplying her local delicatessen with samosas to a multi-million pound empire. Customers including Asda, Safeway and Waitrose sell ready-meals under their own labels.

Five years ago Mrs Warsi's husband Talib, 54, gave up his work as a GP to become marketing manager.

"We are continually breaking new ground and this site represents the next stage in our rapid development," Mrs Warsi, 44, said yesterday. "It is my vision to see people all round the world enjoying our meals."

The company named after their sons, Sadiq and Abid, has expanded its range, but chicken tikka masala remains the hot favourite. Other best sellers include chicken korma, chicken madras and lamb rogan josh.

S&A's initiative has the backing of the Department of Trade and Industry which is providing some £5m of regional selective assistance.

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers said: "This is a coup for Newcastle-under-Lyme. Today's good news follows hard work to revitalise the area, backed by hard cash from government and underlines our commitment to boosting employment through regional regeneration."

webTitle: Ofgem resumes battle to monitor generators

fields.headline: Ofgem resumes battle to monitor generators
fields.trailText: Electricity generators may be forced to accept monitoring by industry regulator Ofgem of their pricing and other practices, energy minister Peter Hain said yesterday.
fields.body:
Electricity generators may be forced to accept monitoring by industry regulator Ofgem of their pricing and other practices, energy minister Peter Hain said yesterday.

A previous attempt to have generators sign a "market abuse condition" as part of their licences was shelved after a negative ruling by the competition commission in December last year.

Two large generators, British Energy and AES Corporation, had refused to accept the condition, alleging it left the regulator with too much power.

The latest draft from Ofgem to the Department of Trade and Industry has had a positive response from Mr Hain.
He said: "I don't want to leave the [wholesale power] market open to, unlikely, market abuse."

The minister was speaking as a new wholesale electricity market got off to a positive start. The new trading arrangements, Neta, have brought commodity-style trading to a market worth around £7.5bn a year. Computer systems that caused problems in the run-up to the launch performed properly, said the National Grid, which controls the system.

There had been fears that a breakdown could trigger California-style blackouts in the run-up to a general election.

Neta has been introduced to try to pass on some of the price cuts resulting from privatisation. It allows generators and
suppliers to enter contracts directly with large-scale consumers and replaces the "pool" system which was widely believed to favour generators over suppliers and customers.

Ofgem chief executive Callum McCarthy says generating costs have been cut by up to 40% but little of this was passed on to electricity customers until Neta began to take shape.

Mr McCarthy and Mr Hain marked the start with a visit to St Thomas' hospital in London, where officials have already signed a deal with Yorkshire Electricity which they say should save the hospital 13% on its energy bills. National health service administrators said arrangements already in place would save the service £15m a year.

webTitle: BT and AT&T revive talks on business services merger

fields.headline: BT and AT&T revive talks on business services merger
fields.trailText: BT, where the top management is under fire from shareholders, has restarted talks with AT&T, the US group, which could lead to the spin-off of its international business services division.
fields.body:
BT, where the top management is under fire from shareholders, has restarted talks with AT&T, the US group, which could lead to the spin-off of its international business services division.

Neither BT nor AT&T would comment on a report in yesterday's Wall Street Journal that they were discussing a full-scale merger of their business services divisions. However, wide-ranging talks are understood to have been revived by two new members of the management team.

Wall Street bankers and analysts believe that AT&T will try to buy back BT's share in Concert, its flagging joint venture for multi-national busi ness clients, if the merger plans fail to take off.

The catalyst for the talks was the continuing poor performance of Concert, which makes little profit on revenues of about £5bn. Phillip Hampton, BT's chief financial officer, and David Dorman, the AT&T president who was in charge of Concert until a recent promotion, are behind the new round of talks.

Both companies have announced restructuring in recent months. In October, AT&T announced it would turn its four main business units - consumer services, business services, wireless and cable - into separately traded companies.

BT also planned to float its wireless division as part of a move to reduce its £30bn of debt. It is expected to try to raise funds through a rights issue, but the price may be the heads of top management including chairman Sir Iain Vallance and chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield.

Adam Quinton, an analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York, said the US group was far more likely to be able to buy out its partner in the joint venture than would BT.

"BT is more desperate when it comes to its balance sheet, and its shareholders certainly wouldn't be happy with them spending any more money right now."

Merger talks between the two broke down last year after a failure to agree on price and management positions.

fields.headline: BMW beats its own record
fields.standfirst: Focus on premium car market pays off for German motor manufacturer
fields.trailText: Focus on premium car market pays off for German motor manufacturer.
fields.body:
BMW, the German luxury car group that abandoned its disastrous six-year Rover experiment a year ago, yesterday bucked the trend of the global car market by posting a sales increase of more than 8% in the first quarter and promising even bigger profits than last year's record high.

The group, which introduces its high-profile new Mini in UK showrooms on July 7, declared pretax earnings of 1.58bn euros for last year despite losing a further 762m euros at Rover, including Land Rover, in the months before the two were sold to the Phoenix consortium (now MG Rover) and Ford respectively.

Underlining a shift in strategy to focus "uncompromisingly" on the premium car market, Professor Joachim Milberg, chairman, drew a line under the Rover experience of moving into the volume car business and disclosed that the experiment had cost BMW a net 4.1bn euros (£2.7bn) - lower than last year's estimate of 4.6bn euros.

Prof Milberg said that BMW would invest up to 7% of sales, entirely from cash flow, into its global business with savings from Rover helping to fuel the £1bn being put into the Oxford plant, home of the new Mini, the Hams Hall engine plant near Coventry and the new Rolls-Royce plant at Goodwood, due to open in 2003.

The UK plants, according to Ernst Baumann, human resources director, have been set the target of increasing productivity by 10% a year to close the gap with BMW's German factories. Oxford, which produced the R75 before its transfer to MG Rover's Longbridge plant, now achieves 70% to 75% of German levels.

Last year BMW's sales came in at a record 35.4bn euros, more than offsetting the drop in sales caused by the exit from Rover and Land Rover, but Prof Milberg said this year would see a further rise in sales and deliveries despite the economic slump in the US.

"In the US car market the downswing of the economy will slow down developments as opposed to the record performance in 2000," he said. "But we assume that 2001 will only be a transient slump in the ongoing growth of the US car market, the growth trend as a whole thus remaining stable."

Prof Milberg, whose plans assume a continuing weakness of the euro against the dollar, said that the US economy should begin to show signs of recovery next year and the car market might turn out to be better this year than earlier estimates of just 15.5m sales. BMW sales, he said, had held up well in the first quarter.

Prof Milberg, who is negotiating to build a new plant in Shanghai, China, and plans to double US output of the X5 sports utility vehicle to 80,000, said: "BMW's strategy clearly shows that our focus is on profitable growth, with profitable coming first and growth following next. Size alone cannot be an objective for the BMW group."

That was the failed strategy with Rover which, in Phoenix/MG Rover hands, has received a £500m dowry from BMW - repayable over 50 years. The bulk of the dowry has been paid, with £78m due next year.

Under the complex transfer agreement with Phoenix, MG Rover is due to repay the loan through either 25% of annual profits or £25m a year.

webTitle: Notebook: Milberg goes for volume profit-making

fields.headline: Milberg goes for volume profit-making
fields.standfirst: Just don't mention Rover
fields.trailText: Notebook: Just don't mention Rover.
fields.body:
BMW's six-year experiment with moving into the volume car market via Rover continues to cause problems with history in Munich. For many insiders it is as if the period 1994-2000 never existed, airbrushed out of the official record along with Messrs Pischetsrieder and Reitzle, architects of a failed strategy that nearly drove BMW into the hands of VW, Ford or General Motors.

Professor Joachim Milberg, the chairman who braved a political storm in the UK to exit Rover, is hailed as the new Von Kühnheim, the German group's saviour. Yesterday Prof Milberg and his finance director, Helmut Panke, drew a historic line under the Rover experience. No, Milberg said, BMW would not "delete the Rover lesson" as it was part of its overall development - back to Von Kühnheim's strategy of eschewing mass production for premium output. With Rover, BMW had tried to do both but the British brand was "too weak" to succeed.

Putting aside the fact that Milberg was saying the opposite in Geneva, just a month before ditching Rover, and that the dual strategy was flawed from the start, BMW has indeed turned a fresh corner. Its independence guaranteed for now, the German group is producing more cars than ever; it is making excellent profits and even sees little downside in the current US slump.

It is promising better sales and earnings this year. It is, Milberg claimed, "the only multi-brand car manufacturer in the world not operating in the mass market".

Judging by the figures, though, the cost has been substantial. Even with a skillful jiggle of the balance-sheet and the €3bn sale of Land Rover to Ford, Panke has still managed to produce a net loss over six years of €4.1bn or £2.7bn. But the accounts, even after the sale of Rover and of Land Rover, remain incomplete. BMW's £500m dowry to Phoenix is not fully paid, while repayment of that loan, in instalments over 50 years, is yet to begin.

Then, BMW is still selling off the Longbridge engine plant and the Swindon body-pressing facility so the net cost may yet prove significantly less than Panke's figure yesterday. And, in a sense, BMW has got off scot-free: its reputation, especially in the UK, remains untarnished. It can embark on Milberg's "uncompromising premium brand strategy" - selling hundreds of thousands of cars designed and built to customers' specifications. It's worked well, in the past as well as now, and a US downturn is hardly likely to blow it off course. We are talking about a temporary blip - just like Rover.

Busy as a banker

This newspaper's banking expert, Jill Treanor, is on holiday this week - holiday that had been held over from last year, since Treanor was too busy covering the Lloyds/Abbey bid to take time off. It had been the same the year before, what with Bank of Scotland trying to take over NatWest, only to be pipped by Royal Bank of Scotland.

That is two years lunching middle-aged men, taking late night calls from desperate bankers and fretting about the competition. But that is life. Sometimes it is very busy.

Yet in the world inhabited by Sir George Mathewson, deputy chairman of Royal Bank, hard work is a special thing, requiring extraordinary awards. It is considered entirely justified that he and his colleagues should trouser bonuses worth £2.5m simply because the bank succeeded in taking over NatWest.

The award is not linked to the merits of the takeover, which has yet to prove its worth in terms of sustained shareholder value, and so the National Association of Pension Funds is now recommending that as punishment its institutional shareholder members vote against the re-election of two Royal Bank non-executive directors (Sir Iain Vallance and Sir Angus Grossart).

Sir George's response? Well, according to yesterday's Financial Times, the matter "frankly, was not worthwhile talking to shareholders about."

And the size of the bonus "wouldn't have given you bragging power in a Soho wine bar." In any case, "we had a team who gave eight months of their life."

These are crass and insensitive statements, guaranteed to repulse customers and alienate Royal Bank's lower-paid staff.

Sir George seems to have forgotten what his job is. He is not paid to be a corporate financier, landing a bonus every time he rings the big bell; he is charged with running a bank for the benefit of its shareholders.

He and his colleagues should apologise and transfer the award into a long-term, performance-led incentive scheme.

As for bragging in a Soho wine bar, our diarist, Richard Adams, has been dispatched to check the verity of the statement but had yet to return to the office last night.

fields.headline: Great outdoors benefits Maiden
fields.trailText: Maiden, the billboard group, yesterday broke through the gloom in the advertising market when it reported a 22% growth in bookings during the first three months of the year.
fields.body:
Maiden, the billboard group, yesterday broke through the gloom in the advertising market when it reported a 22% growth in bookings during the first three months of the year.

Ron Zeghibe, Maiden chief executive, said he had seen nothing yet to cause "any panic". Advance bookings for April suggested it would be an even stronger month for the company. Bookings have already reached 93% of the record first half of last year.

Mr Zeghibe said Maiden had in part been a beneficiary from the dire first few months of the year for ITV, which is expected to see advertising revenues fall by 8% in the first quarter.

"Outdoor is by far the cheapest way of reaching a mass audience and the trends have been playing into our favour for some time."

Maiden reported pretax profits of £13m for 2000, more than double the previous year, on a 21% increase in sales to £86m. Margins were up from 11% to 19%, reflecting the higher prices Maiden was able to charge for billboards. Shares in the group rose 5p to 530p.

Mr Zeghibe said uncertainty surrounding the general election was unhelpful, with other advertisers unwilling to commit until a date is named. The effect could outweigh the benefit of the political parties' marketing budgets.

The company wants to begin building its presence in mainland Europe.

webTitle: Plague upon the Old English houses

fields.headline: Plague upon the Old English houses
fields.trailText: The misfortune that has befallen pub group Old English Inns in the last six months was compared to the seven plagues of Egypt yesterday after the company warned that its full-year profits - already due to take a hit from last year's flooding - would be further hurt by the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
The misfortune that has befallen pub group Old English Inns in the last six months was compared to the seven plagues of Egypt yesterday after the company warned that its full-year profits - already due to take a hit from last year's flooding - would be further hurt by the foot and mouth crisis.

Andrew Holland, an analyst at house broker ABN Amro, knocked 15-20% off his profit forecast for OEI. He said the group's pubs and hotels were in rural towns and villages where concern about the spread of foot and mouth had led to a decline in visitors.

After a poor business period during the heavy rainfalls and floods of last autumn, OEI had been experiencing better trade when the foot and mouth outbreak struck.

"Virtually anything that could have gone wrong for them has gone wrong for them," Mr Holland said. "I have a huge amount of sympathy. They were washed out by the floods, with a lot of pubs in affected areas; now they're having to face foot and mouth - they might as well expect a plague of locusts next."

Colin Mayes, chief executive of OEI, said: "We have a lot of pubs and hotels in Devon which are badly affected, though thankfully we don't have any in the Lake District.

"We have also been hit by delayed races at Cheltenham. We have a lot of pubs in the area that have lost out - even if it goes ahead over Easter we will be hit because we would expect to do well that weekend regardless."

OEI said it had sold 22 pubs which were not trading well or were in flood-affected regions, for almost £11m. Mr Mayes said this was part of a programme to reorganise OEI's estate of 142 pubs. Quieter village locals were being sold and the group would concentrate on larger pubs and hotels in market towns. The shares closed down 5.5p at 76p.

fields.headline: Euro loss for Honda
fields.trailText: Honda, the Japanese car maker, yesterday disclosed that it expected a 50bn yen (£285m) loss on its European operations for the past year, and blamed the weakness of the euro.
fields.body:
Honda, the Japanese car maker, yesterday disclosed that it expected a 50bn yen (£285m) loss on its European operations for the past year, and blamed the weakness of the euro.

Honda, which makes the Civic at its plant in Swindon, said it would not break even in Europe until April 2002.

The company's executive vice president, Koichi Amemiya, said: "We had initially hoped to turn our European operation to profit in the 2001/02 year, but such a recovery will be delayed into the next year."

The euro's weakness against the pound has proved a headache for Honda by making its British-made cars less competitive in the eurozone. Honda said its consolidated net profit for the year ending on March 31 would total 230 billion yen (£1.3bn), up 4.5 per cent from earlier estimates.

fields.headline: Jet setting becomes time travel
fields.standfirst: Sage of Omaha is bringing the timeshare business model to the rarefied world of corporate globe trotting
fields.trailText: Sage of Omaha is bringing the timeshare business model to the rarefied world of corporate globe trotting.
fields.body:
Warren Buffett spent Monday relaxing in the living room of his Boeing business jet, watching Tiger Woods' latest golf triumph by satellite relay on a 42-inch television screen as he crossed the Atlantic Ocean.

If he chose, America's second-richest man could have made a call on one of eight telephones, had a shower in one of two bathrooms, taken a snooze in a queen-size bed or held a meeting in the conference room.

The legendary financier, known, as the Sage of Omaha, likes to travel in comfort: he admits that he hardly ever slums it on commercial airlines. This week, he is on a three-day tour of seven European cities to promote NetJet, the corporate aircraft firm which his investment company, Berkshire Hathaway, bought for $725m (£500m) three years ago.

NetJet is one of the leaders in a rapidly growing market for executive jets. In the US, most top business people, sports stars and entertainers feel they need their own transport. Aircraft are still frowned upon in corporate Britain, as the engineering company Tomkins will bear witness, but Mr Buffett reckons they will soon take off on this side of the Atlantic: "I can't conceive of a Europe without thousands of owners 10 years from now."

Aunt Katie's share

NetJet, which has a fleet of 338 aircraft, has snapped up 40% of all the new corporate jets built over the past four years, largely because it offers "fractional ownership" - a kind of timeshare deal on private aircraft. Customers buy an eighth or a 16th of a jet, entitling them to a certain number of flying hours.

Fractional ownership appealed to Mr Buffett as soon as he encountered it. "I literally hadn't heard of it until six or seven years ago.

"Now both my sisters are in it and my kids are in it - although they've got very small shares."

Even Mr Buffett's 94-year-old Aunt Katie has a slice of ownership of a NetJet corporate jet. Other fans included Pete Sampras, Arnold Schwarzenegger and Martina Hingis, as well as companies such as General Electric, Gillette and Texaco. Timeshare on aircraft is becoming ever more popular as companies dispose of their own fleets because of uncertain economic conditions.

So sure is NetJet of the potential of its proposition that it is investing $400m in 50 new mid-range Citation aircraft. With 2,400 "owners" on its books worldwide, Netjet had aircraft allocated to 92 countries last year.

Mr Buffett reckons selling corporate planes is as promising in business terms as Coca-Cola. "Production of Coke started in Atlanta in 1884 and now it is in 200 countries, with 1.1bn servings sold per day. NetJet's somewhere on that scale, between 1bn and 1.1bn a day."

'Admiral's barge'

There are at present about 2,000 corporate jets in operation across Europe, although companies are shy of discussing the subject, fearing that will provoke the assumption that the aircraft are used for frivolous trips. Turkey farmer Bernard Matthews' ownership of two aircraft has raised eyebrows, but the aviation industry insists that management abuse is rare.

Graham Forbes, chief executive of the General Aviation Manufacturers and Traders Association, says: "The concept of the admiral's barge is dead. The idea that a chief executive would have a jet for his own use is pretty much gone."

He says corporate planes can actually make life tougher for employees, because companies allow them less travelling time: "I've heard of people being expected to go to South Africa and back in one day. The companies take the view that once you get on a private aircraft, it's just another office - it's working time."

One of the few British companies that is open about its aircraft ownership is BP, which says it has "a couple" of aircraft which it accidentally inherited when it bought the US group Amoco.

"With the acquisition of Amoco, we have a number of sites which are difficult to connect to each other, so we have kept a couple of their planes," a spokesman says.

One of BP's aircraft was damaged last year when it skidded off a runway in Cape Cod, careered across a four-lane highway and crashed into a wall. It was carrying the group's deputy chief executive, Rodney Chase, who was shaken but unhurt.

Brian Humphries, who runs Shell's fleet of corporate jets, says executives have to make a strong case for use of one of the oil company's aircraft. They are largely used for particularly tight schedules or for trips to places which are not accessible by commercial flights: "Shell has had corporate aircraft since 1927. We use them a lot now for going to places in the former Soviet Union."

Mr Humphries, who is also head of the European Business Aviation Association, says "break even" for a corporate aircraft usually occurs with four passengers on board; that number makes a private plane as cheap as business class commercial fares.

For pop stars and sports people the advantages of a small aircraft are privacy and security. There is also personal service: Tiger Woods likes a supply of Big Macs available to him when he flies with NetJet.

For companies, the issue is flexibility. Mr Forbes says: "Just imagine you've got to take a sales team to a particular place. If you're travelling on a scheduled flight, you've got a limited range of destinations - you may well have to change somewhere.

"On a scheduled flight, a great deal of time is taken up going through terminals. If you regard your sales team as a cost, it's better for them to waste less time and get on a smaller plane."

Stock market indicator

The aviation industry points out that in the US planes are considered no more unusual as business assets than computers and shredders. In Britain attitudes are beginning to soften. Even the government is beginning to take a different view. A report by the Department of Transport three years ago concluded that good access for business aircraft was one of the three most important factors in encouraging inward investments to a region, and airports such as Manchester and London City have been encouraged to open up to corporate customers.

NetJet's total revenue was $1.8bn last year. The company does not disclose its profits but for Mr Buffett the company has advantages other than financial returns. The billionaire financier jokes that the company acts as a great stock market indicator: "If any company cancels a plane and I find out about it early, I know it's a good stock to short [sell]."

fields.headline: At this price?  UltraFrame
fields.trailText: UltraFrame, the conservatory roof maker, has warned that its pretax profits for the six months to April are likely to hit a glass ceiling after months of poor weather and flooding slowed business.
fields.body:
UltraFrame, the conservatory roof maker, has warned that its pretax profits for the six months to April are likely to hit a glass ceiling after months of poor weather and flooding slowed business.

"The extraordinary weather, in particular the high levels of rainfall, has, in the first half of our financial year, had a serious impact on the rate of installation of conservatories," the company said in a statement to the stock exchange. The announcement comes three months after a similar profit warning, which also cited heavy rainfall as a factor.

Poor weather is not the only explanation for UltraFrame's warning. The company, based in Clitheroe, Lancashire, said profits would be hit by a programme of "heavy investment in the infrastructure of the business". Finance director James Henry said these are not one-off exceptional costs, but an ongoing expense the company would continue to shoulder in order to grow. Growth for the six months to April was likely to be 2%, compared with 32% for the same period the previous year. Yesterday, the shares fell 49.5p to close at 354p.

UltraFrame insists it has a strong order book in the run up to its traditionally busier six-month period, though some of this will be a backlog of delayed work. The company cites independent market research that forecasts a 10.8% growth in the domestic market for conservatories during 2001. Robert Palmer, author of the research, concedes this was his subjective opinion. Mark Hake, an analyst at Merrill Lynch who yesterday dropped his "buy" rating on UltraFrame to "neutral", said: "Experience has taught me over the years that if a business suffers a shortfall during one half of the year for whatever reason, it is seldom likely to make it up in the following six months.

"I cannot be 100% certain that UltraFrame's slowdown is entirely due to the weather - there may be some underlying slowdown, though it is too early to say." UltraFrame has a lot to prove.
