fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: Harry Ramsden's, the chain of fish and chip restaurants, is planning to abandon its traditional beef dripping, used to fry its famous fish and chips, in favour of vegetable fat.
fields.body:
 As promised yesterday, some news (perhaps what the editor wistfully refers to as a "scoop", who knows?) that could change the face of British industry - the fish and chip industry, specifically. Harry Ramsden's, the chain of fish and chip restaurants, is planning to abandon its traditional beef dripping, used to fry its famous fish and chips, in favour of vegetable fat. But Maurice Gammell, the company's chairman (nicknamed the Big Fish by staff - "He thinks he's Cod," said one), denies that the move has anything to do with foot and mouth and/or the availability of dripping. "We've been working on this for two years," he said, citing talks with edible oil companies about trying to get a blend that matched the unique flavour of dripping. "It's almost like distilling a malt whisky - it takes a long time." The new cooking fat means that at last vegetarians will be able to eat Britain's most famous chip. The new fat is being tested at two secret locations and the company expects to go worldwide within a year. Unless the F&M outbreak turns nasty, in which case, Maurice says: "We could roll this out very quickly, in a month."

 More foot and mouth fallout, I'm afraid, and even websites are catching it. Emap, the magazine and radio group, yesterday announced the closure of Countrywalking.com.

 Another foot and mouth infection arrives, carried by a letter from medical herbalist Paula Newman to minister Nick Brown, suggesting a cure for F&M: grapefruit seed extract. Before you scoff you should know that the US department of agriculture found that the extract does kill the virus. Then again, so does light. Paula might have helped her case if she hadn't printed the letter on bright yellow paper and forwarded copies to the Queen, Richard Branson, Tony Blair, Princess Anne and Bob Geldoff, among many others.

 There are bigger questions, such as: is the US economy going into recession? Yes, according to Dr William Mullis, a top cosmetic surgeon from North Carolina. He says the number of inquiries about breast implants is sagging, suggesting people are tightening their belts. "Before the recession in the early 1990s there was a sharp decrease in breast implant operations - and the same thing is happening now. It's a sure-fire barometer."

 The Post Office is gearing up for its managerial transformation into Consignia: last week engineers were busy blanking out the words "The Post Office" on the clocks at the Old Street headquarters, in preparation for the big launch next week. On Monday the engineers were called back to the same clocks, this time to put them forward an hour to conform with British Summer Time. That's the sort of private sector efficiency Consignia is striving for.

 Yesterday I outlined (thanks to a reader) the difference between the Guardian, and Guardian, the US manufacturer. One makes float glass, the other prints a daily newspaper. What, I asked, was float glass? Now, thanks to a flood of replies, I know that it is a technique for making glass, pioneered by Pilkington in either the 1950s or 1960s, involving plate glass floating on molten tin. "Shame on you," writes Richard Hadden, one of the many float glass fans. "In case you are wondering, I'm not some sort of glass industry nut, righting vitreous injustices wherever I find them!" Of course not. Actually, Richard works for a computer games maker, nGame, and would like to meet a venture capitalist with lots of money.

 Yesterday's item about the two women who bought tickets to a VIP celebrity bash on Lastminute.com, only to find it was a student's party, was originally attributed to The Register website, but the name got lost in editing. Sorry.

fields.headline: Icelanders advance on Arcadia
fields.trailText: Iceland has loomed large in the career of Stuart Rose. Not only was he boss of the frozen food retailer but now his new employer, Arcadia, the Dorothy Perkins and Top Shop owner, is being stalked by a consortium of Icelandic investors.
fields.body:
Iceland has loomed large in the career of Stuart Rose. Not only was he boss of the frozen food retailer but now his new employer, Arcadia, the Dorothy Perkins and Top Shop owner, is being stalked by a consortium of Icelandic investors.

Yesterday, Arcadia revealed that A Holding, a consortium of four companies put together by Baugur, Iceland's biggest retailer, had increased its stake to 20%.

Predictably the news got the market very excited with Arcadia shares ending the day up 21.5p, or 13%, at 186.75p on hopes that Baugur might use the consortium as a platform for a bid.

But Jon Asgeir Johannesson, chief executive of Baugur, said such the speculation was wide of the mark. "We are not going to make a bid," he said, explaining that the consortium had taken the stake because it thought Arcadia was an excellent investment. "We believe the management of Arcadia are capable of turning round the company."

But Mr Johannesson admitted that Baugur, which has a Swedish subsidiary that runs franchised Arcadia stores, wanted to work more closely with the company on an international basis. Arcadia is due to release the conclusions of its strategic review in April.

In the wider market, the melt-up continued with billions more being returned to share values following data that suggested the US economy might avoid a full blown recession.

Figures released by the Conference Board, a US business research operation, yesterday revealed that US consumer confidence had risen for the first time in five months during March, an indication, traders said, that the Federal Reserve's reduction in interest rates was working.

Extending its three-day recovery to 414 points, the FTSE-100 closed up 151.5 points at 5,728.1.

The banking sector, which was hammered in last week's market rout, spearheaded the advance with Lloyds TSB putting on 44.5p to 699.5p, Bank of Scotland gaining 38p to 690p, and Royal Bank of Scotland moving forward 69p to £15.14.

Telecom stocks also chipped in, with gains from the likes of Vodafone, up 7p to 213p, BT, 27.5p higher at 547.5p, and Marconi, 21p better at 410p, adding 30 points to the blue chip index.

Other strong performers in cluded United Business Media , a riser of 38p to 660p after UBS Warburg started coverage of the media group with a "buy" rating, and fund management group Schroders, which gained 90p to £11.10.

Elsewhere, the FTSE Techmark 100 rose 35.06 points to 2,034.14 as the bargain hunters moved in.

The gains even extended to second line companies, with the FTSE mid 250 closing up 51.9 points at 6,052. Fire protection specialist Kidde rose 2p to 59p on news chief executive John Harper had acquired 10,000 shares at 60p each and buyers came for jeweller Signet, up 4.75p to 59.75p, ahead of today's figures.

Not everything was going up of course. Ad agency WPP fell back 23p to 762p after Goldman Sachs forecast global advertising growth would slow to 3% in both 2001 and 2002.

Meanwhile, Powergen eased 13p to 723p as the widely rumoured offer from German power group E.ON failed to materialise and IT group Logica, down 32p to £11.30, was unsettl ed by a bearish research note.

Starting coverage with a "neutral" rating, WestLB Panmure warned that the shares could have difficulty outperforming given the sluggish growth in its key markets.

There was also plenty of bad news in the smaller companies world. The fallout from the foot and mouth epidemic claimed another victim, Old English Inns, off 5.5p to 76p, and Aukett, which claims to be Britain's largest architect, fell 5.25p to 9.25p after warning that pretax profits would come in well below expectations.

webTitle: Michael Odell on a black music anthology

fields.headline: Ragtime to riches
fields.standfirst: Black musicians were once marginalised and exploited, then they conquered the world. Where do they go now, asks  Michael Odell
fields.trailText: Black musicians were once marginalised and exploited, then they conquered the world. Where do they go now, asks Michael Odell.
fields.body:
In 1928 the singer and street-corner evangelist Blind Willie Johnson recorded a song called Dark Was the Night. It was the sound of a broken man, befuddled by moonshine, playing a smashed instrument with work-worn stumps. There are no lyrics, only terrible guttural moans from a man born just too late to have known slavery.

This is one of the most remarkable tracks on Back To Black: 100 years of Black Music, a 10-CD, 220-track journey from ragtime to UK garage, masterminded by 1980s hip-hop impresario Morgan Khan. The journey really ends on the penultimate track, Goldie's stark, haunting Inner City Life. Decades apart, on different continents, Johnson and Goldie give voice to the same nervous, ravaged life experience.

"The struggle" informs much of this amazing boxed set, and the pining, searching tone is consistent, whether applied to harsh life or cruel love. It's the mode of delivery that changes and dazzles. From ragtime through swing, blues and jazz to rock and soul, disco and rap, the turbulent story is marked by incredible music.

Of course, "black music" means "African-American music". And by that Khan and his 35-strong selection panel mean modern music. Nine of the CDs cover the postwar era, when radio and the music industry proper took off. Its underpinnings - slave song and gospel - are mostly assumed. Even so, boxed sets usually collect works of an artist or label and this is a plucky attempt at an objective historical overview.

Early on, the clumsily named vaudevillian acts such as Bessie Smith with Buck & His Band predominate. And yet Smith's 1933 Gimme a Pigfoot resonates down the years. With her rasping lament, "Give me a pigfoot and a beer 'cos baby I don't care!", you feel it's only the choice of snackfood that separates her from the "girl power" generation.

But the black music century gathers pace as aspirations rise and music biz infrastructure, such as radio and labels, arrives. By the time covered by the second CD - 1946 to 1953 - the groups are marketed under snazzier monikers: the Clovers, the Orioles, the Coasters. Listen to Clyde McPhatter's Money Honey and then flick forward to the Wu-Tang Clan's C.R.E.A.M. (Cash Rules Everything Around Me). The only difference is McPhatter's bluesy, fatalistic response to hard times. The Wu-Tang Clan exercise an altogether tighter fiscal policy, reinforced with mastery of kung-fu.

One part of the black music story is of cowed, duped minstrels evolving into the "gettin' paid" entrepreneurs of rap. If only the early black rock'n'rollers had been more hard-headed. By the time we reach a selection of the famous "race records" that inspired everyone from Elvis to the Beatles and the Stones, the scale of white debt to black R&B is clear. The implication of including Big Mama Thornton's Hound Dog is obvious: Elvis was cruising to icon status on black talent.

And yet, you could imagine a broader, more radical interpretation of what constitutes the black canon. Why not, for example, include Elvis's All Shook Up or Don't Be Cruel, the compositions of black musician Otis Blackwell? Are black, backroom contributions to be written out of history because they were interpreted by a white man? Why include Booker T and the MGs' Green Onions when the group was half white and the Stax label white-owned? Later in this collection the definition of black music will slide dramatically.

Before that, though, we're in the era of "classic soul", and the period of civil rights, assassinations, the Vietnam draft (black men comprised more than 30% of front-line forces) passes in an embarrassment of love songs. Diana Ross and the Supremes, the Four Tops, the Temptations and Stevie Wonder all contribute to what writer Nelson George has called "black gold, black oil". But soul's social voices are missing: Sam Cooke, Gil Scott Heron and Curtis Mayfield. Cooke especially is an essential bridge between gospel and the emergence of soul. What's more, his epochal A Change is Gonna Come would have provided the essential soundtrack to the social tremors of the 1960s. But despite personal appeals from the compilers, his estate wouldn't play ball.

By the time we reach the "disco inferno" CD, black music is no longer resonating with social concern or even sounding particularly underground. Sister Sledge, Donna Summer, Chic, Barry White and Rose Royce are familiar for a reason. Disco, black music's least militant and most escapist form, is where the white mainstream has always felt most comfortable. And yet these party tunes were a response to the Nixon/Ford-era recession in the black neighbourhoods.

In the 1980s and 1990s, the next time things got tough in the ghetto, white folk would catch one line of the black soundtrack before gathering the family and leading them down into the cellar. And yet when we reach "Black Pop & Hip-Hop Culture", it's all a bit ragged. Sadly, all music history is written by licensing lawyers and their willingness to release tracks. Here we have to make do with some ropey late LL Cool J (Phenomenon) and Public Enemy's Do You Wanna Go Our Way? The lawyers also explain the absence of Prince.

More importantly, the rules of engagement have changed. So far this history has celebrated black music without troubling itself over the weak-ass, white pop it inspired. Then, suddenly, it's reclaimed and something to be celebrated. And who do we have taking their place in the pantheon of greats? Gabrielle! Eternal! You check the CD notes' claims about the "powerful political and sociological subtext" of the music, then try to find it in Billy Ocean's Caribbean Queen. Is this really one of the most important 220 recordings in the last century? "I think there was almost a punch-up over that one," says Khan. "But we felt we should honour what Ocean achieved as a global pop star."

This raises an important question. Since so many black artists now "cross over", should we still be talking about a separate black music? And what about white artists making black music? Eminem might at first appear to be hip-hop's Elvis, the rock'n'roll whitewash replayed. And yet we can hardly claim he has toned down his act for white sensibilities. And with Dr Dre pulling the strings, we can hardly moan that the wrong guys are getting paid. He's black-owned. He's a black act. He's a trophy of black music's final victory, many years after Blind Willie Johnson sat on the porch thrashing his busted strings.

"It's the big debate," says Khan. "I don't know if anyone will be able to do this in 100 years. With integration, with equality, maybe the black urban form is now the mainstream. The last 100 years were unusual, to say the least. I don't know if we'll see the same intensity again."

 Back To Black is out now on Universal/MWA.

webTitle: Profile of Hamlet actor Sam West

fields.headline: That Hamlet moment
fields.standfirst: Doubt, cynicism, moral confusion ... Sam West has no trouble getting into the mood for his next role. He talks to  Lyn Gardner
fields.trailText: Doubt, cynicism, moral confusion ... Sam West has no trouble getting into the mood for his next role. He talks to Lyn Gardner.
fields.body:
The media likes to portray actors as rather dim, decorative things. But all genuinely interesting actors bring a large dollop of intelligence to their roles. The great ones match brainpower with instinct: part of what they do is as mysterious to them as it is to us watching.

Watching Sam West play Richard II for the Royal Shakespeare Company last year, you caught a glimpse of that. West's Richard was a man too bright and aware to be the kind of king he was born to be. His tragedy was to discover that divine right is a prison. Only in death does he finally behave like a king. West made you understand the tragedy of that journey.

It was an astonishing performance, given that his previous Shakespearean experience amounted to playing Hal in Henry IV and Octavius in the National's derided Anthony and Cleopatra. His reward is now to get a crack at Hamlet, a man who you could say is too intelligent for his own good.

As the son of Timothy West and Prunella Scales, Sam West has acting in his blood, yet he fears he may be too naturally analytical to be an actor. "I have a talent; I don't think that I have a gift for it," he says. "Those that have a real gift are often unashamedly subjective in their approach. They are not interested in talking about The Cherry Orchard in general because as far as they are concerned the play is about Dunyasha or whoever it is they are playing. I admire that. But I am not like that at all. I take the view that doing your homework can't do any harm. I want to know everything about the world of the play."

It shows. When West arrives from rehearsals for Steven Pimlott's RSC production of Hamlet, he proceeds to give a dazzling masterclass. It is hard to get a word in as he dissects the play, quoting not just his own part but everyone else's, and throwing in little asides on 17th century Catholic and Protestant theological attitudes to revenge and redemption. Before long he is demolishing the critical Tower of Babel that surrounds the play and analysing some of the 20-odd productions that he has seen.

It sounds more like a director talking. West laughs, admits that he can get carried away and points out that he directed his own production of Hamlet for the RSC's fringe festival last summer. "In the absence of better solutions, I will be nicking some things from that," says West. He admits that it took him a while to adjust from directing the play to being in it. "I find myself thinking more and more like a director, and I know I have to watch that. You do have to make a choice. You can't be an actor and a director, especially not at the same time."

He is enjoying being part of the RSC, after what he admits were "too many years in TV limbo" playing damaged upper-class people in the Merchant Ivory mould. "In TV and film I am already considered old at 34, while in theatre it is possible to be at the start of a classical career, although I am wary of saying that. I love it that in the theatre you get employed because people think that you have the potential to play a role, whereas in TV and film they only cast you because they know that you can do it.

"A friend, the actor Leigh Lawson, said to me that the only time in his career when he didn't feel he should be somewhere else doing something else was when he was with the RSC. It has been like that for me. I find it moving that I've spent a year in a company of young actors speaking 400-year-old language with no apology and an almost revolutionary zeal. The zeitgeist is so much about not caring, about it being cool to mumble and be back footed. But you can't do that when you are speaking verse, and there is something that makes you feel happy to know that you are going out there and giving people pleasure." He pauses. "Small dollops of pleasure. The number of people who will have seen Richard II during its entire run is smaller than the Saturday afternoon gate at Cardiff City."

If West has one regret about doing Hamlet now, it is that we are living in a Hamlet age. "It must have been thrilling to have been David Warner and played Hamlet in a Lear age, a world where you've got something to kick against," he sighs. He is referring to the 1965 production that cast Warner as a spokesman for a generation that was challenging the entrenched views of its parents. But what exactly is a Hamlet age?

"A Tony Blair age," says West. "If Tony Blair isn't good casting for Claudius who smiles and smiles, who is? Oh yes, this is very much a Hamlet age. Doubts, cynicism, moral relativism, these are the norms now. It is hard to notice the bitterness in Denmark because there is so much sugar coating the pill. Hamlet is a character that exists in opposition, but it is hard to stand up to something that seems quite liberal. He is a man for our times because he distrusts himself. fields.bodyText: The media likes to portray actors as rather dim, decorative things. But all genuinely interesting actors bring a large dollop of intelligence to their roles. The great ones match brainpower with instinct: part of what they do is as mysterious to them as it is to us watching. Watching Sam West play Richard II for the Royal Shakespeare Company last year, you caught a glimpse of that. West's Richard was a man too bright and aware to be the kind of king he was born to be. His tragedy was to discover that divine right is a prison. Only in death does he finally behave like a king. West made you understand the tragedy of that journey. It was an astonishing performance, given that his previous Shakespearean experience amounted to playing Hal in Henry IV and Octavius in the National's derided Anthony and Cleopatra. His reward is now to get a crack at Hamlet, a man who you could say is too intelligent for his own good. As the son of Timothy West and Prunella Scales, Sam West has acting in his blood, yet he fears he may be too naturally analytical to be an actor. "I have a talent; I don't think that I have a gift for it," he says. "Those that have a real gift are often unashamedly subjective in their approach. They are not interested in talking about The Cherry Orchard in general because as far as they are concerned the play is about Dunyasha or whoever it is they are playing. I admire that. But I am not like that at all. I take the view that doing your homework can't do any harm. I want to know everything about the world of the play." It shows. When West arrives from rehearsals for Steven Pimlott's RSC production of Hamlet, he proceeds to give a dazzling masterclass. It is hard to get a word in as he dissects the play, quoting not just his own part but everyone else's, and throwing in little asides on 17th century Catholic and Protestant theological attitudes to revenge and redemption. Before long he is demolishing the critical Tower of Babel that surrounds the play and analysing some of the 20-odd productions that he has seen. It sounds more like a director talking. West laughs, admits that he can get carried away and points out that he directed his own production of Hamlet for the RSC's fringe festival last summer. "In the absence of better solutions, I will be nicking some things from that," says West. He admits that it took him a while to adjust from directing the play to being in it. "I find myself thinking more and more like a director, and I know I have to watch that. You do have to make a choice. You can't be an actor and a director, especially not at the same time." "In TV and film I am already considered old at 34, while in theatre it is possible to be at the start of a classical career, although I am wary of saying that. I love it that in the theatre you get employed because people think that you have the potential to play a role, whereas in TV and film they only cast you because they know that you can do it. "A friend, the actor Leigh Lawson, said to me that the only time in his career when he didn't feel he should be somewhere else doing something else was when he was with the RSC. The zeitgeist is so much about not caring, about it being cool to mumble and be back footed. "Small dollops of pleasure. The number of people who will have seen Richard II during its entire run is smaller than the Saturday afternoon gate at Cardiff City." "It must have been thrilling to have been David Warner and played Hamlet in a Lear age, a world where you've got something to kick against," he sighs. He is referring to the 1965 production that cast Warner as a spokesman for a generation that was challenging the entrenched views of its parents. But what exactly is a Hamlet age? "A Tony Blair age," says West. "If Tony Blair isn't good casting for Claudius who smiles and smiles, who is? Oh yes, this is very much a Hamlet age. Doubts, cynicism, moral relativism, these are the norms now. It is hard to notice the bitterness in Denmark because there is so much sugar coating the pill. Hamlet is a character that exists in opposition, but it is hard to stand up to something that seems quite liberal. He is a man for our times because he distrusts himself. webTitle: Intifada drives two peoples into vortex

fields.headline: Intifada drives two peoples into vortex
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The chubby face of Shalhevet Pass, the baby girl killed by a sniper's bullet this week, looked out from the front pages of Israeli newspapers yesterday, piling pressure on the hardline prime minister, Ariel Sharon, to move with force now to stop the Palestinian uprising.
fields.body:
The chubby face of Shalhevet Pass, the baby girl killed by a sniper's bullet this week, looked out from the front pages of Israeli newspapers yesterday, piling pressure on the hardline prime minister, Ariel Sharon, to move with force now to stop the Palestinian uprising.

The intifada against Israel's occupation of parts of the West Bank and Gaza Strip marks a dismal milestone today: six months since Mr Sharon's early morning stroll around a disputed holy site in east Jerusalem set a torch to smouldering Palestinian resentments against the grindingly slow peace negotiations with Israel.

Now, with more than 430 dead - and Shalhevet Pass, aged 10 months, joining the daily catalogue of horrors that have seen Jewish settlers the targets of drive-by shootings, and Arab protesters mown down by automatic fire or shelled in their homes - there is a growing sense that both peoples stand at a crossroads.

Israelis heartily want the uprising to end. But does Mr Sharon bow to the clamour of Jewish settlers, led by the enclave in Hebron where Shalhevet was picked off in her pushchair, to invade Palestin ian-ruled territory? (Similar demands are coming from local army commanders.) Or, does he resist popular pressure and chart a more restrained course, turning his back on a 50-year personal history of dealing harshly with Israel's Arab neighbours?

For the Palestinians, the choice is equally stark. Do they stop shooting, and if they do what do they gain? On the southern fringes of the Gaza Strip, the most active military front in the uprising, the field commanders of the uprising now openly admit they have lost their way.

"We as Palestinians don't know the aim of the intifada. Is it to enhance negotiations or is it to improve the situation in the West Bank and Gaza?" said Mohammed al-Athamna, a colonel in military intelligence in Rafah. "Even the people shooting have no great political understanding. They themselves do not know why they are shooting."

Amid a growing realisation among leaders of Yasser Arafat's Fatah movement that the Palestinians are trapped in senseless violence, last week saw an extraordinary meeting in Rafah, a dusty town of open sewers and mean refugee shanties shoved up against the Israeli-controlled security strip on the border with Egypt.

Eight senior members of Mr Arafat's Palestinian Authority, and Fatah - including the deputy chief of security for Gaza, the Rafah governor, and security officials - decided to call a halt to shooting attacks from Rafah on two adjacent army camps, and on a strip of Jewish settlements opposite Khan Yunis refugee camp.

The March 21 meeting was seen as a test case - if Fatah could persuade its own men to hold fire in Rafah then it would work to do the same in Hebron and elsewhere.

It was a bitter decision. Along the border, Israeli bulldozers have ploughed into fields and homes to create a 70-metre security strip, and there is regular sniper fire from the high tower of the army camp where sentries can look right into people's homes.

On most nights for the last six months, there has been shooting and shelling from the army base against the gunmen they believe are hiding in civilian homes. Several families have collected bucketfuls of shrapnel, and hung up wind chimes made of teargas canisters in their back gardens.

"The intifada has done nothing for me," said Tamam Abdel Ahl, aged, 63. Three of her sons have been wounded in the yard. "May Allah take this catastrophe away from me."

It was this kind of popular pressure from the civilians who have taken the brunt of Israeli reprisals that is pushing Fatah to rein in the gunmen.

"We have come to a dead end, and the next step depends on the Israelis," said Rashid Abu Shabak, the deputy chief of security in the Gaza Strip.

To get Fatah's militiamen in Rafah and elsewhere to hold fire their leaders will have to persuade them that there will be some reward: that the army will lift its siege of towns, stop razing crops, and rein in the extremist Jewish settlers -and that Mr Sharon will negotiate.

Prospects for that were destroyed by the sniper's bullet that killed Shalhevet, and the seemingly inevitable Israeli reprisals to come.

Opinion in Israel's media yesterday strongly favoured a forceful move from Mr Sharon. "A murder like this must have a price," Alex Fishman, a security analyst, wrote in Yediot Ahronoth, the largest daily.

Elsewhere, Mr Sharon's advisers were quoted as saying that the gloves would come off at the end of the week - after the Arab summit now on in Amman, and the 25th anniversary of the Palestinians' Land Day on March 30.

The killing of Shalhevet Pass could well provide the pretext Mr Sharon has been waiting for to revert to past form.

Mr Arafat is stuck too, unable to issue public orders against shooting without compromising his political survival - especially if Mr Sharon intensifies Israel's military actions. Increasingly, the Palestinian gunmen are operating outside established control.

"I can't stop any work as long as there are violent acts on the other side," said Mahmoud Hussein, the top Fatah man in the Rafah region. "We are completely aware that the intifada cannot achieve everything, but if I move away from the familiar path, I will be seen as an outsider."

For all the war-weariness, Israel and the Palestinians are heading inexorably towards a new burst of bloodletting.

fields.headline: 'Israelis seem more unmoved than ever'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Yesterday was another normal day in Israel. People rushed to work. The roads were jammed with traffic. The bustle on the streets of Tel Aviv was typical. Two weeks before Passover Israel's cities and towns are in full gear: this is the shopping season.
fields.body:
Yesterday was another normal day in Israel. People rushed to work. The roads were jammed with traffic. The bustle on the streets of Tel Aviv was typical. Two weeks before Passover Israel's cities and towns are in full gear: this is the shopping season.

People browse in the shops and malls. Others sit around in cafes and restaurants enjoying the spring sun. In Jerusalem, a car bomb explodes near a shopping centre. Four people are injured.

Six months after the Palestinians launched a new round of political violence Israelis seem more unmoved than ever. The intifada is designed to persuade the Israeli public to end 33 years of occupation of the West Bank and Gaza and the continued daily humiliation of the 4m Palestinian inhabitants. The Palestinian Authority, led by its president Yasser Arafat, believed that if Israelis paid a heavy price in casualties and obstruction of daily life they would force their government to change its policy.

The Palestinians, for their part, were ready to carry even a heavier burden: the human cost of this battle of attrition is high. Seventy Israeli civilians and servicemen have been killed and hundreds wounded in dozens of car bombs, suicide attacks and drive-by shootings in the occupied territories and inside Israel. On the Palestinian side, 350 have been killed and thousands injured at the hands of Israeli troops.

Yet the achievement of the Palestinians' goals has never been more distant.

Last month, Israelis elected the warrior Ariel Sharon as prime minister, leading a national unity cabinet. Instead of tiring or caving in, the Israeli reaction to the never ending attacks is surprising. It is an unusual response for a nation known for over reacting. This time the Israelis showed restraint and a sense of proportion.

The result is a sharp contrast between the perception abroad of Israel as a society under siege and the domestic reality of the relative tranquility of daily life. Most Israelis, especially the younger generation, desire nothing more than to lead a normal life.

True, Israel is not a homogeneous society.It has at least two faces. Tel Aviv represents one - secular, pluralist, vital and tolerant. Israel's other face is Jerusalem, its proclaimed capital, a city where political tensions, intoler ance, sectarian, religious and ideological divisions reign.

Yet both cities represent a deeply held and sincere wish of the average Israeli to live and let live, like any modern, western society.

But the "normality" of much of daily life might very soon be disrupted. The second terrorist attack - this time by a suicide bomber who failed to detonate his bomb inside a bus, but who killed himself and injured several passengers - could change this fragile reality.

The public is still calm, despite sensational press reports and television images and the nearly hysterical tone of radio reports. But the pressure of the media is growing . As prime minister, Mr Sharon may yet be pushed to return to the old patterns of harsh responses and vengence seeking.

Yossi Melman is a commentator with the Israeli daily newspaper Ha'aretz

The price of conflict

 At least 435 people have been killed and thousands injured since the intifada's revival in September last year

 Of the dead, 357 have been Palestinian, 59 Jewish Israelis and the remainder Israeli Arabs or foreigners

 The youngest person to die was a Jewish girl, aged 10 months, shot on Monday night in Hebron

 The UN recently estimated the cost to the Palestinian economy inflicted by Israeli blockades at $1.2bn (about £800m) in the intifada's first four months. Current losses are $8m-12m a day

 Blockades stop a majority of the 130,000 Palestinan workers who had jobs in Israel travelling to work

 In Gaza, unemployment is more than 50% now

 Israel is refusing to release more than $60m in taxes collected on behalf of the Palestinian Authority, arguing that Yasser Arafat's government is responsible for the violence

 About 65,000 orange and olive trees farmed by Arabs have been uprooted by Israeli bulldozers around Jewish settlements

by Nick Dastoor

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: SA school rape 'widespread'
fields.body:
SA school rape 'widespread'

South African schoolgirls are being raped and sexually assaulted by classmates and teachers at an alarming rate, the US organisation Human Rights Watch reported yesterday.

It interviewed 36 victims of sexual violence. Most said they had had a hostile or indifferent response when they complained to the school authorities, and many had dropped out of school.

Reuters, Johannesburg

Executed after 36 years

Robert Lee Massie, who spent more than 30 years on and off Death Row for murders in 1965 and, while on parole, in 1979, was executed by lethal injection in San Quentin prison, California, yesterday.

He waived legal appeals to save his life, as he had done on the first occasion, when he was spared by the 1972 supreme court ban on capital punishment.

Reuters, San Quentin

Royals win back £1.6m antiques

The Hungarian supreme court has ordered the return of furniture, paintings, china and other antiques worth £1.6m to the Bavarian royal family.

Lajos Kulcsar, acting for the Princes Ludwig and Rasso, grandsons of Ludwig III, King of Bavaria, said the 1,400 items were listed by the Nadasdy Museum in Sarvar, western Hungary, as a "Bavarian collection". The family had lands in Hungary between 1870 and 1945, when they were confiscated by the communists.

AP, Budapest

Fake Pokemon posed a threat

The Italian police have seized 15,000 fake plastic figures from the computer games Pokemon, Digimon and Dragonball at Fiumicino airport, Rome.

A spokesman said the toys, imported from China but with "Made in the European Union" stickers, were "totally unsafe and dangerous for children. A 41-year-old Italian was arrested yesterday.

Reuters, Rome

fields.headline: Eight dead in Belgian crash
fields.trailText: Belgium went into mourning yesterday when its worst train crash for 25 years killed at least eight people, one a child, and seriously injured dozens more.
fields.body:
Belgium went into mourning yesterday when its worst train crash for 25 years killed at least eight people, one a child, and seriously injured dozens more.

A commuter train from Leuven, about 15 miles from Brussels, collided head-on with an empty train which appears to have ignored a red light.

The death toll could rise, since many of the injured were said to be in a critical condition.

Some reports put the number killed at twelve.

Some passengers were trapped for several hours. Both drivers and one other railway official were killed.

The force of the collision was such that some of the carriages were thrown into the air.

Rescue workers were still struggling to recover the bodies from the mangled wreckage near the village of Pecrot yesterday afternoon, hours after the accident occurred during the rush hour.

The state railway company, SNCB/NMBS, said it tried desperately to warn the driver of the empty train that he had passed a red light and was heading towards the commuter train at about 60mph. He failed to respond.

"We tried as a last resort to cut off the power, but unfortunately it was done too late," a spokeswoman said.

A local resident, Anna-Marie Choumuerthe, said: "There was a noise like two giant tin cans crashing together.

"I went out to see what happened and heard and saw people at the windows screaming."

Another, Ameile Jassont, said: "I saw a black cloud of smoke rise up. The train was rocking back and forward, tottering"

The train is thought to have been carrying about 80 people.

The death toll could have been much higher if the two trains had come off the rails and toppled on to a row of houses.

King Albert, Queen Paola and the prime minister, Guy Verhofstadt, rushed to the scene.

The last big rail crash in Belgium killed 18 people in 1974.
fields.bodyText: Belgium went into mourning yesterday when its worst train crash for 25 years killed at least eight people, one a child, and seriously injured dozens more. A commuter train from Leuven, about 15 miles from Brussels, collided head-on with an empty train which appears to have ignored a red light. The death toll could rise, since many of the injured were said to be in a critical condition. Some reports put the number killed at twelve. Some passengers were trapped for several hours. Both drivers and one other railway official were killed. The force of the collision was such that some of the carriages were thrown into the air. Rescue workers were still struggling to recover the bodies from the mangled wreckage near the village of Pecrot yesterday afternoon, hours after the accident occurred during the rush hour. The state railway company, SNCB/NMBS, said it tried desperately to warn the driver of the empty train that he had passed a red light and was heading towards the commuter train at about 60mph. He failed to respond. "We tried as a last resort to cut off the power, but unfortunately it was done too late," a spokeswoman said. A local resident, Anna-Marie Choumuerthe, said: "There was a noise like two giant tin cans crashing together. "I went out to see what happened and heard and saw people at the windows screaming." Another, Ameile Jassont, said: "I saw a black cloud of smoke rise up. The train was rocking back and forward, tottering" The train is thought to have been carrying about 80 people. The death toll could have been much higher if the two trains had come off the rails and toppled on to a row of houses. King Albert, Queen Paola and the prime minister, Guy Verhofstadt, rushed to the scene. The last big rail crash in Belgium killed 18 people in 1974.

webTitle: Barak's failures lead all shades of British Jewry to trust in Sharon

fields.headline: Barak's failures lead all shades of British Jewry to trust in Sharon
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Jewish community in Britain seems to have swung behind Ariel Sharon's new government in Israel, after six months of watching the Palestinian uprising.
fields.body:
The Jewish community in Britain seems to have swung behind Ariel Sharon's new government in Israel, after six months of watching the Palestinian uprising.

But while there is near-unanimity that his predecessor, Ehud Barak, was a disappointment, there is also a division in attitudes, a Guardian straw poll of leaders and opinion-formers found.

While many have hardened their opinions in the past six months, believing that most of the blame for the collapse of the peace process lies with the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, others have redoubled their efforts to rebuild the peace process.

Even many on the liberal left are prepared to give Mr Sharon the benefit of the doubt, in spite of his hardline background.

Simon Plosker, a spokesman for the Board of Deputies, said it was too early to make a judgment about Mr Sharon but British Jews would support the government of national unity in its effort to end the violence.

He said: "It is safe to say there is immense disappointment with what has happened, and immense anxiety. Many people have concluded that the Palestinians have resorted to violence as a strategic aim."

There was repeatedly expressed concern that the British press, and in particular the Guardian, had failed to report fairly what was happening, showed a pronounced bias against Israel, and tended to treat the Palestinians as the underdog.

Mr Plosker said the great majority of the Jewish community believed the coverage was slanted, had not portrayed the reality on the ground, and sought to blame Israel for the whole situation.

Unhappiness with press coverage prompted the formation of the Britain Israel Communications and Research Centre, to try to redress the balance.

Its spokesman, Brian Kerner, a conservative in British politics but liberal left in the Israeli context, said: "My own opinion has changed totally. I have gone from being leftwing to supporting a rightwing government.

"Barak offered everything and got a kick in the head for doing so. By offering so much, it encouraged violence.

"The Palestinians respond to strength rather than anything perceived as weakness. The government now is totally united and I think they [the Palestinians] respect it and, frankly, that is very sad.

"[Sharon] has not put a foot wrong so far. There has been restraint. I find it odd that I am now supporting a man a few months ago I would not have considered."

Matthew Reisz, editor of the Jewish Quarterly, said: "I felt very pleased when Barak won the election and I was disappointed with what he achieved. He failed to sell policies to the Israeli electorate or the Palestinians. I think that there has been a backlash is not surprising."

Vivien Lichtenstein of British Friends of Peace Now said: "Whatever understanding there was within much of the Jewish community for the condition of the Palestinians seems to have disappeared. That's very disappointing and worrying."

Rabbi Kathleen Middleton of the Liberal synagogue in St John's Wood, London, said: "I think the intifada has polarised opinion a lot more. Some people who were doveish have hardened their views but others have been working to do more for peace."

webTitle: Israel too harsh, Annan tells Arabs

fields.headline: Israel too harsh, Annan tells Arabs
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, yesterday accused Israel of inflicting "collective punishment" on the Palestinian people by paralysing their economy and spreading anger and despair across the occupied territories.
fields.body:
The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, yesterday accused Israel of inflicting "collective punishment" on the Palestinian people by paralysing their economy and spreading anger and despair across the occupied territories.

In a strongly worded address to the Arab summit in the Jordanian capital, Amman, Mr Annan said the world had every right to criticise Israel for its continued occupation of Palestinian and Syrian territory and for "its excessively harsh response to the intifada".

By cutting off communities in the West Bank and Gaza, Israel was preventing the delivery of medicine, food and fuel, he said.

Mr Annan also reminded the summit that "Israel has a right, enshrined in numerous UN resolutions, to exist in safety within internationally recognised borders". Arab grievances would fare better, he said, "if many Israelis did not believe that their existence was under threat".

Mr Annan, attending his first Arab summit, urged a return to the peace process. "There is no solution to be found in violence, and no sense in postponing the day when the parties return to the table," he said.

The Arab heads of state aim to forge a common policy towards the six-month-old intifada.

Summits are supposed to be the highest and broadest expression of the Arab will, and the slogans adorning Amman reflect that. They welcome the leaders to Jordan, their "second home", to Amman, the city "which unites and does not divide", and extol the notion that "Arab solidarity means Arab security"

Curiously absent from the debate yesterday was any reference to Palestine or the intifada. Instead, Iraq has been dominating the pre-summit diplomacy, and still threatens to throw the conference into disarray.

The kings and presidents are expected to come up with little more than general declara tions of support for the intifada, as well as renewed calls for international protection for the Palestinians. The last time the Arab leaders met, in October, they pledged £700m in aid; only a fraction has so far been delivered.

In his speech to the conference, the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, said that the Arab world was now looking for "new and flexible means to guarantee the delivery of [financial] assistance _ quickly".

The gathering has drawn 14 heads of state and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, in the first "ordinary" Arab summit since the 1990-1991 Gulf war.

The Arab states are supposed to meet once a year but thanks to divisions following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, they did not manage a summit for a decade.

Notably absent were the Iraqi president, Saddam Hussein, Kuwait's Emir, Sheikh Jaber al-Sabah, and Saudi Crown Prince Abdullah, who usually deputises for the ailing King Fahd.

webTitle: Protesters harry German nuclear waste cargo

fields.headline: Protesters harry German nuclear waste cargo
fields.standfirst: Hit and run attacks keep 20,000 police engaged
fields.trailText: Thousands of protesters were gathering in the north German town of Dannenberg last night as a heavily guarded train carrying nuclear waste edged its way towards the point where the waste will be transferred to lorries for the remainder of its journey to the nuclear dump in Gorleben.
fields.body:
Thousands of protesters were gathering in the north German town of Dannenberg last night as a heavily guarded train carrying nuclear waste edged its way towards the point where the waste will be transferred to lorries for the remainder of its journey to the nuclear dump in Gorleben.

A group in masks dragged large concrete cylinders across roads leading to Dannenberg in an attempt to disrupt the security operation mounted by the biggest police deployment since the second world war: up to 20,000 officers equipped with water cannon, helicopters and night-vision aids.

The campaigners formed a long line along a ridge overlooking the Dannenberg terminal. Opposite them were ranged police officers in full riot gear, flanked by a water cannon.

Throughout the day demonstrators in various parts of Germany managed to break on to stretches of the railway line on the train's tortuous 375-mile journey from the French border.

They succeeded in delaying, but not stopping, its progress.

The 60 tonnes of nuclear waste in six sealed containers was diverted to avoid the university city of Göttingen, where hundreds of people briefly occupied the tracks. Dozens of people were arrested along the route.

The biggest confrontation of the day occurred at the village of Wendisch Evern, where several hundred protesters broke through the police lines to occupy part of the railway. Within seconds they had linked arms.

On the field above the police succeeded in wrestling some of them to the ground, blocking others.

Among those dragged away by the police was a young child clutching a teddy bear. Protesters chanted "Is this democracy?" One police officer lost his patience and shouted "Just walk!"

Veit Bürger of Greenpeace said the protesters, adopting new tactics, were divided into small scattered groups, "all of whom are trying to get at the line".

The police claimed that the protesters numbered only 2,000.

The authorities had tried to stop them getting on the tracks, the police spokesman, Wolfgang Klages, said, but the route was too long to have hundreds of officers at every point. "In some places, we have to react."

Watched by Franziska Lohmann, 25, and her infant son, who live near by, police special forces in black face masks were trying to disengage a group of Greenpeace activists dangling in harnesses from the underside of a bridge over a tributary of the Elbe.

Eventually they resorted to a chainsaw to sever the steel wires, and one of the protesters fell with a loud splash into the shallow water below.

For the most part the police were restrained, and appeared reluctant even to draw their batons.

But last night they said that two demonstrators had been injured. The protest organisers put the figure at five.

France and Germany agreed in January to resume the shipments, and the German environment minister, Jürgen Trittin, a leading member of the Green party, has defended the decision on the grounds that safety precautions have been tightened since the previous administration suspended the shipments in 1998 because of radioactive leaks from some containers.

From the end of the rail line in Dannenberg, flatbed trucks will take the six containers, each with about 10 tonnes of radioactive waste sealed in 28 glass casks, to the hotly opposed Gorleben nuclear waste dump.

Unloading of the containers is expected to take up to 12 hours, during which time they will be measured for radioactivity.

The shipment contains waste left over when spent nuclear fuel from German power plants was reprocessed at a French plant.

The decision to allow the shipment put the Greens, the junior partners in the coalition federal government, in a tough position, facing accusations of betrayal from some of their core supporters.

webTitle: Israel vows to avenge killing of baby

fields.headline: Israel vows to avenge killing of baby
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel's prime minister Ariel Sharon vowed last night to take decisive action to avenge the death of a baby girl killed by a sniper's bullet and a twin bombing in Jerusalem yesterday.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg  in Hebron, West Bank
fields.body:
Israel's prime minister Ariel Sharon vowed last night to take decisive action to avenge the death of a baby girl killed by a sniper's bullet and a twin bombing in Jerusalem yesterday.

As the parents of 10-month-old Shalhevet Pass refused to bury their daughter until Mr Sharon invades Palestinian-ruled land near the Jewish enclave of Hebron, rightwing politicians called for a tough response to a suicide attack on a bus in the French Hill settlement, northern Jerusalem, which killed the bomber and injured more than 30 people.

"Considering the events which have taken place, we should have no more restraint," said Jerusalem's rightwing mayor, Ehud Olmert.

However, Israeli soldiers may find themselves accused of lacking any restraint following the death of an 11-year-old Palestinian boy near Hebron yesterday.

A cousin said the boy was watching a firefight between Palestinian gunmen and Israeli soldiers when he was shot from the Israeli position. Doctors in Hebron hospital said Mahmoud Ismail Daraweesh was shot in the heart.

The Israeli army said it had no information on the death near Dura, south of Hebron, but confirmed that its soldiers had traded fire with Palestinian gunmen at the nearby Al-Fawwar refugee camp.

Mr Sharon did not immediately reveal his hand yesterday. "I know how to deal with this, and when to deal with this," he told Israel Radio before entering deliberations with his security cabinet last night. "The first priority of my government is to restore security to the citizens of Israel. Be patient, and watch the results."

The French Hill blast came barely five hours after four people were lightly injured by a pipe bomb in a car that exploded during the morning rush hour in the industrial area of Talpiot, the latest in a spate of bombings inside the Jewish state.

"I heard a strong boom, and came outside. Then I saw lots of black smoke, and the body of the bomber," said Lily Avias, who lives in French Hill. "It was cut in half."

But the explosions, which were claimed by a variety of Palestinian militant organisations, failed to dislodge the attention of Israelis from the death of Shalhevet Pass.

In Hebron, the local army commander, Colonel Noam Tibon, said he had asked Mr Sharon for permission to invade the spiny ridge of Abu Sneineh, the Palestinian-ruled neighbourhood that is the suspected source of the gunfire that killed the baby. "The solution is to take the hill," he d said.

Re-occupying Palestinian-ruled land would represent a dangerous escalation in the six-month intifada, and put Israel on a collision course with the international community. It is also inconvenient for Mr Sharon because of the Arab summit under way in Jordan.

But the Jewish settlers, who claim rabbinical sanction for delaying the infant's burial in defiance of religious custom, are demanding precisely that. "I think today the blood is very hot in Hebron, and sometimes people are looking for some kind of friction," said Col Tibon. "The whole situation now is very dangerous ... the main problem now is friction, people seeking revenge."

The morning after Shalhevet's death brought ugly scenes to Hebron, where 400 Jewish settlers live in mutual hatred with 120,000 Palestinians. Amid the clatter of gunfire from the hills of Abu Sneineh, settlers stomped over the shells of the Palestinian-owned market stalls that they had torched overnight. In one shop, schoolgirls painted a memorial mural to the dead baby in fiery reds and oranges, with a passage from the Song of Songs: "Love is stronger than death". An Islamic trust building was also burnt.

An armour-clad policewoman blinked back tears as a woman settler accused the security forces of failing to protect the enclave, screaming: "Do you want me to come back with Shalhevet's bloody shirt and rub it in your face?".

A young settler wearing a T-shirt with Hebrew letters reading: "I only buy from Jews" joined a charge up the hill to Abu Sneineh before being beaten back by cordons of security forces.

Mr Sharon has been a deep disappointment to the settlers of Hebron for his failure to unleash the full might of the Israeli army against Palestinian militias.

"Sharon talks big, but we are not interested in talk, we want him to act big. There is a limit to how much we can wait, and he is pushing our patience," he added.

There were similar demands at the junction of French Hill yesterday where onlookers crowded for a view of the bus which the suicide bomber had tried to board before setting off the lethal cargo strapped to his waist.

"I think the government should close off the territories until the Palestinians feel the pinch in their pockets and are starving," said Mike Ebra, a resident of the militant Jewish settlement of Ofra.

Others who witnessed the blast pleaded for understanding. "I think we have to make peace the best way," Lily Aivas, a court clerk on maternity leave, said. "Otherwise, they are killed, and we are killed."

webTitle: The saints preserve us - and a pope

fields.headline: The saints preserve us - and a pope
fields.trailText: The mortal remains of Pope John XXIII have survived uncorrupted in their tomb for almost 38 years - a divine indication of sanctity for his admirers and a tribute to the properties of Formalin for the more scientifically minded.
fields.body:
The mortal remains of Pope John XXIII have survived uncorrupted in their tomb for almost 38 years - a divine indication of sanctity for his admirers and a tribute to the properties of Formalin for the more scientifically minded.

The discovery was confirmed yesterday by a Vatican official who was present on January 16 when the papal coffin was opened for inspection.

The pope's face was found to be intact, "with his eyes closed and his mouth slightly open, with features immediately bringing to mind the familiar physiognomy of the venerated pontiff", according to a report on the inspection, which was carried out in preparation for the removal of Pope John's tomb from the crypt to the basilica of St Peter's.

"The remains of Pope John were found in their entirety and some have detected the sign of God's favour or of a sanctity that is now unquestioned," Cardinal Virgilio Noe said yesterday.

Cardinal Noe, archpriest of St Peter's, said many saints' bodies had been preserved from decay while others had decomposed. Scientists said Pope John's body had been preserved because it was treated with Formalin before burial and sealed without oxygen in a triple coffin.

Pope John was beatified by John Paul II in September. Newspapers reported yesterday that a young man from Umbria had recently been cured of cancer after praying for Pope John's intercession. If recognised as a miracle, the episode could speed up Pope John's path to sainthood.

webTitle: 'Butcher of Bastille' begs to be forgiven

fields.headline: 'Butcher of Bastille' begs to be forgiven
fields.trailText: One of the bloodiest serial killers in French history yesterday confessed before a hushed Paris court to the rape and murder of seven young women, then broke down in tears and begged forgiveness.
fields.body:
One of the bloodiest serial killers in French history yesterday confessed before a hushed Paris court to the rape and murder of seven young women, then broke down in tears and begged forgiveness.

For the past 10 days, in a courtroom drama that has enthralled France, Guy Georges, the so-called "butcher of the Bastille", had either denied DNA evidence that linked him incontrovertibly to at least three of the crimes, or refused to speak altogether.

He finally gave in to the persistent pleading of his lawyer, Alex Ursulet, to "tell the truth for the sake of the victims' mothers, and of your own father, wherever he may be". The son of a French woman and an American army cook, Georges, 38, never knew his father.

"Did you kill Pascale Escarfail, Cathy Rocher, Elsa Benady, Agnès Nijkamp, Hélène Frinking, Magali Sirotti and Estelle Magd?" asked Mr Ursulet, pausing after the name of each of the victims - all aged between 19 and 27 - for the accused to utter an almost inaudible "yes".

Georges, whose killing spree prompted near-panic in the heavily student-populated bedsit-land of Paris's 10th and 11th arrondissements for months before his arrest in March 1998, then turned to the families sitting opposite.

"I ask for your forgiveness," he repeated three times. "I ask for the forgiveness of my family, of my little sister, of my father, of God, if there is a God. I ask forgiveness of myself." He then broke down and wept.

Georges, who spent his childhood in a string of children's homes and foster families, had a long record of instability and violence, having attempted to murder two of his foster-sisters while an adolescent.

He was sentenced to 10 years for rape at the age of 22, and committed his first murder - that of the 19-year-old Escarfail, in Paris in 1991 - while on parole.

His modus operandi was almost invariably the same: the apparently charming killer would follow his young victim home, talk his way into her flat, tie her up with adhesive tape and rape her. He then either slit or stabbed her throat, and left his signature on the crime by neatly slicing the front of her bra in two.

The bungled investigation into the killings led to heavy criticism of French police methods, and to claims that at least two and possibly three of the murders could have been prevented: almost unbelievably, Georges was in prison for various sex offences for all but 17 months between the first murder in 1991 and the last, in 1997. Each time he was out, a rape and murder took place.

The results of a DNA test caried out following the murder of Benady, in 1995, were never compared with samples taken from the scenes of four subsequent murders, and it was only after one of Georges' four surviving rape victims gave a detailed description to police, allowing them to issue an identikit picture, that he was finally arrested.

The trial is due to end on Friday. In perhaps its most moving moment, Georges last week appealed to one of his foster mothers, Jeanne Morin, to accept that he was innocent. "Mother, I love you!" he cried. "Me too, my son," Ms Morin replied. "But my heart is empty after all the harm you have done to these poor families."

fields.headline: Somali gunmen kidnap three Britons
fields.standfirst: Somali gunmen kidnap three Britons
fields.trailText: Three British UN staff were among nine international aid workers to be kidnapped by heavily armed gunmen in Somalia yesterday as fighting erupted throughout the capital, Mogadishu.
fields.byline: James Astill  in Nairobi and  Rebecca Allison
fields.body:
Three British UN staff were among nine international aid workers to be kidnapped by heavily armed gunmen in Somalia yesterday as fighting erupted throughout the capital, Mogadishu.

Militiamen attacked and ransacked the compound of the aid agency Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in Karaan, northern Mogadishu, seizing three staff, six UN foreign workers and a Somalian Unicef worker during a two-hour gun battle.

At least eight MSF armed guards were killed when fighting broke out at the gates of the compound as the foreign aid workers' convoy was heading out to visit a polio vaccination programme early yesterday. The UN team is monitoring MSF's work.

A Foreign Office spokesman confirmed last night that three Britons were among the UN staff abducted: "We do not have an embassy there. The UN are the people on the ground and they are dealing with the situation."

Last night, the interior minister in the Somali provisional government, Dahir Dayah, told Reuters he had sent government forces on what he called a rescue mission.

Five of the aid workers - two Spanish and one French MSF worker and two Unicef employees - were safe in a house in northern Mogadishu, MSF and UN spokeswomen said.

"Our understanding is that they are safe and that they can leave when the security situation calms down," said Samantha Bolton, a spokeswoman for MSF in Nairobi.

The other UN staff, from Britain, Algeria, the US and Somalia, were split into two groups and were in separate locations said to be controlled by the Mogadishu warlord Musa Sude Yalahow. It is not known in which groups the Britons are being held.

The incident began when gunmen attacked the MSF office compound with machine guns, anti-aircraft guns and anti-tank rockets, before looting computers, radios, furniture, and even door and window frames.

At least 20 local staff and foreign aid workers fled. Dr Abdikarin Assayr, a Somali doctor working for the World Health Organisation, was shot. He was taken to a Red Cross hospital, along with more than 30 others who were wounded.

The attack was reportedly a continuation of fighting the previous day between the guards, a local clan militia, and a rival faction loyal to Mr Yalahow, one of a handful of warlords opposing the new UN-sponsored transitional government set up in October. It has now degenerated into a confrontation between the fledgling government and Mr Yalahow.

Abdulkadir Mohamed Mohamud, an aide to Mr Yalahow, said yesterday he was holding the hostages in areas his faction controls to show the world that Somalia's new government has not brought peace.

"All I want to show the international community is that Mogadishu is not a safe place. We'll release them soon," he said.

"It is outrageous that a team trying to do humanitarian work was attacked," said Kevin Farrell, acting UN humanitarian coordinator for Somalia. "We need to be able to work in a safe environment. Conflicts like this only derail our efforts to help the Somali people in any meaningful way."

fields.headline: No 1848
fields.standfirst: Nasdaq
fields.trailText: Nasdaq.
fields.body:
The Nasdaq? A reasonably priced, attractive, pine coffee table from Ikea? No, you're confusing it with the Narvik bedside cabinet.

So what is it? It's an acroynm for the National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotation.

Eh? A stock market, based in the US, specialising in hi-tech companies such as Microsoft.

As in that bit of the business news where viewers' eyes glaze over upon hearing " ... and the Nasdaq also fell as a big smell of fear went through Wall Street"? The same.

Yawn ... has it fallen by another 0.9% in choppy trading? Probably, but the exciting news is that Nasdaq has bought a controlling chunk of Easdaq, its European counterpart and potential rival, for $70m (£49m).

Meaning what? It's another sign of rampant globalisation. And so on.

But what about the world stock market meltdown? We're still waiting for that, but Nasdaq is the place where the dot.com bubble came and went. Last year its index peaked just below 5,000.

And now? It's below 2,000.

Shares listed on Nasdaq lost 60% of their value in the space of a few months? Yep, and worse. Such as Priceline.com - which went above $90 (£63) per share in March 2000.

And now? You can pick up a Priceline share for about two bucks.

So why does Nasdaq want to spend $70m on its European clone? "This transaction begins to put into place the third of our global trading platforms," according to its chairman, Frank G Zarb.

Frank G Zarb? That is his name. And the chairman of Easdaq is Stanislaus Yassukovich.

I hope you're not leading up to a cheap joke at their expense. Certainly not.

Not to be confused with: the Titanic, the South Sea Bubble, the Narvik bedside cabinet.

Don't say: Last year's dot.coms are this year's dot.bombs.

webTitle: G2's rough guide to Tirana, Albania

fields.headline: Having a ball in Albania
fields.standfirst: Around 1,000 English fans will descend on Tirana for tonight's World Cup qualifier. But what to do after the final whistle?  Rory Carroll offers a rough guide to an unlikely holiday destination
fields.trailText: Around 1,000 English fans will descend on Tirana for tonight's World Cup qualifier. But what to do after the final whistle? Rory Carroll offers a rough guide to an unlikely holiday destination.
fields.body:
Albanian nationalists have it rough. That their dream of uniting all Albanians into one country is opposed by the world is bad enough. But the real snag is the country. In the considered opinion of Albanians scattered throughout the Balkans, it sucks.

Crime, chaos, corruption, concrete brutalism: no thank you, they say, and the nationalists weep. Visiting English football fans, accustomed to desperation, may prove more receptive to its charm. The one thing to remember on a whistlestop tour is to hold tight.

1 Some years back a man was beheaded with an axe in a hotel lobby in the capital, Tirana. His dad had killed a rival clan member in a northern village 40 years earlier and so the clan extracted pay-back under Hakmarrje-Akmaria, the code of revenge. The venerable Law of Lek, a compendium of tribal customs which specifies when it is permissible to kill enemies, has bubbled back into popularity since communism collapsed in 1991.

Hike north into the mountains, seduce a spouse, and rest assured a revenge cycle will pursue your descendants for generations to come. Once all the men are killed, a female can swear virginity, dress and act like a man, thus becoming an honorary male, and take up where the lads left off.

2 For nightlife in Tirana, the former Enver Hoxha museum has been turned into a disco, a western import which the late communist dictator would have liquidated on sight. Now known as Dulla, the Ugly One, Hoxha seized power in 1944 and effectively sealed off the country for almost half a century.

British attempts to infiltrate rebels were betrayed by Soviet spy Kim Philby, leaving Hoxha free to experiment. He dumped his Soviet Union partners in 1961, turned to China and instigated his own cultural revolution before going it totally alone. Check out his humble mansion near Rruga Ismail Qemali street, now open to the public. A colossal gold-leaf-covered statue in central Tirana was pulled down in 1991.

3 Head out of Tirana in any direction and soon you will find a concrete mound, resembling an igloo, mushrooming from the earth. Slits for machineguns would give any occupant a 360-degree field of vision. Look around and you will spot another, and another, and another bunker, dotting into the horizon.

Hoxha, convinced Albania was strategically vital to east and west, built 750,000 bunkers. Dismantling them is too expensive so they remain, ready-made shelters for locals should today's match start riots.

Top tips for aspiring drunks: beware rural open spaces. Some have stakes planted decades ago to impale paratroopers.

4 If they don't kill you, the pollution might. The textile mill formerly known as Mao Zedong competes with oil wells to belch into the city of Berat. Follow the Shkumbin river to Elbasan and the Chinese-made Steel of the Party mill vies with the cement factory to shroud Roman and Ottoman fortresses in soot. From mountain peaks the views are stupendous, just try not to inhale on the way up.

5 Vora, the main southern port, curves into a bay beloved by smugglers. The roar of engines at dusk is a fleet of semi-inflatables being prepared for the dash to Italy - a terrifying, dangerous often lethal trip for illegal immigrants and asylum seekers. Yours for US$1,000.

Alternatively cruise the seafront bars with the locals: young men in tracksuits with chunky jewellery and older men in suits, all with buzz-cuts.

Buy a veteran seadog a beer and hear about the good old days, when seamanship beat the coastguards, not guns. In this town it is the police who wear balaclavas.

6 Coming back into the capital is the former palace of King Zog, who died before Star Trek could appropriate his name. Aka Ahmed Zogu, he was the head of the armed forces and made the inspired decision to drop the U in 1928 after crowning himself king. Cosying up to Benito Mussolini only encouraged Il Duce, and Zog fled to England in 1939 after Italy invaded. The king ended his days sipping tea at the country retreat of a sympathetic toff.

7 Visitors were once inspected by border barbers who snipped away excess hairiness. No longer. Albanians are keen to recover traditions of hospitality. It is up to England fans to know how to respond.

A host will usually offer water and coffee, which is to be slurped, to show appreciation. There is no beer but plenty of raki, which is to be sipped. Merriness must not arrive too soon - the family has to be introduced. First the granny, who will sit and commentate on the brothers, sons, nephews, sisters, daughters and nieces who stream in in that order.

Kebabs and vindaloo you will not have. Cheese, yoghurt, meats and fruit if you are lucky. A large knife is offered as a symbol of trust. It is not a challenge.

According to the Blue Guide author, James Pettifer, guests should offer a bottle of whisky, preferably Johnnie Walker Red Label or Bells.

Final Tip: Albanians shake their heads to mean yes.

fields.headline: The sleeping giant
fields.standfirst: Wenlock Edge
fields.trailText: Country diary: Wenlock Edge.
fields.body: The vernal equinox blew in on a bitter wind, blasting buds and new leaf, leaving an exhausted space where the vernal green should be. Next day came snow to fill the gap, not so much novel and freaky but sour, like quicklime, bedding down across the fields of the dead or soon to be. Down the lanes of Wenlock Edge, lesser celandines are flowering in the hedge banks; small birds sing from blackthorn and damson, where blossom buds begin to fatten. The drains and ditches are still swelling and the record wetness continues. Through the leafless trees on top of the Edge, flashes of snow remnants show like scraps of plastic. Looking up from a damp lane, across empty fields which seem to be waiting for the inevitable encroachment of the epidemic, to the long wooded scarp snaking away into grey drizzle, a compelling thought begins to form. The unspeakable, a whisper harboured by the woods, trickles down from snow-melt and rain run-off. The wild will out. When the sheep and cattle are gone and the grip of agriculture which shaped this is wrested by one crisis too many, the wild will slowly reclaim the landscape. Seed and root, leaf and wing will push down from the Edge and out from stream banks and hedges; the forest in waiting will make its return journey from obscure corners in the land. Here and in other places across the country, wild Nature is gathering for an opportunity denied for generations. Unless agriculture retaliates against Nature with even greater violence, as it did after the last foot and mouth epidemic in the 60s, and despite the cost in human misery and the destruction of innocent creatures, the wild will out, eventually.

fields.headline: Take five
fields.standfirst: The daily news quiz
fields.trailText: The daily news quiz.
fields.body:
Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. Send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders (www.bordersstores.com).

C1 The latest impression of Jesus has shown him to be

(a) Olive-skinned and curly-haired.

(b) A freckly redhead.

(c) Blond and blue-eyed.

(d) A lady.

C2 Jesus Christ, Superstar is

(a) A Gay Dad album track.

(b) The new Ang Lee film.

(c) A rock opera.

(d) Jesus's autobiography.

C3 Which of the following is not a band?

(a) Jesus Jones.

(b) Jesus Lizard.

(c) Jesus And Mary Chain.

(d) Jesus Poochie Boots.

C4 Elvis, Jesus & Co. are

(a) Caterers to the stars.

(b) Guerrilla film-makers.

(c) Hip fashion designers.

(d) Improvisational comedians.

C5 Jesus used to wear

(a) Adidas trainers.

(b) Kitten heels.

(c) Thigh-high waders.

(d) Sandals.

 Entries must reach Take Five, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER by Wednesday April 4. The winner will be notified by April 13. One entry per person. No purchase necessary.
