fields.headline: Ye olde bleedin' obvious
fields.trailText: Victorians Uncovered | Partners In Crime | Hard Bastards
fields.body:
Almost in spite of itself, Victorians Uncovered (Channel 4) remained, for the most part, engaging and serious. Even with the manic violins eek-eek-eeking on the soundtrack and the reconstructions of Ye Olden Times (complete with stick-on whiskers), the story of how one campaigning journalist, no angel himself, provoked outrage at the selling of young virgins into prostitution shone through.

That William Stead's campaign resulted in mixed fortunes for him - praise, then prison, and then his last assignment, a press trip on the Titanic - and an increase in the age of consent for girls, simply added to the bittersweet poignancy of the tale. Yet there was still something irritating about Victorians Uncovered - the title. It's not classy or clever, not even in a postmodern way. It's just dumb.

Considering the cheap voyeurism intrinsic to Ibiza Uncovered, which revealed that funseekers in the Balearics had sex and went clubbing, and to Greece Uncovered, which divulged that Hellenic holidaymakers went at it like randy goats after consuming buckets of ouzo, it seems tackily inappropriate that a documentary exposing child abuse on a grand scale in 19th-century Britain even nods - however knowingly - in that direction.

"Here's poor orphan Elspeth, drugged with chloroform, being raped by an old man!" Lisa I'Anson could enthuse. "Check out how 13-year-old girls are imprisoned in brothels! They won't be getting any sleep tonight!" Hilarious, no? No. All that Victorians Uncovered does have in common with its nearly namesakes is its obvious basis - that Victorian Britain had a dark side - presented as revelation. Coming soon: Vatican Uncovered ("The Pope really is a Catholic") and Bears Uncovered ("They shit in the woods.")

Blurring that fiction/reality line in a good way, Partners In Crime (Channel 4) wins the prize for being the documentary most resembling a drama, namely The Cops. And seeing as it looks awfully like an exceptional documentary, this is definitely a Good Thing.

Examining the cogs, levers and fan belts of the criminal justice machinery in Nottingham, Partners In Crime was an altogether gripping, dramatic documentary. Neither judgmental nor sentimental, it was involving and insightful. It is often daft to say a documentary was honest, but Partners In Crime felt genuinely truthful and all the more powerful for it. To seem so unmediated and fresh, an enormous amount of mediation, editing and thought must have gone into its making. This means it was exemplary television.

Roy Shaw's lollipop-man looks may be deceptive, but the title of the programme which featured him wasn't. Hard Bastards (Channel 5) is based on the book of the same name by Kate Kray, former wife of Ronnie, and profiles some of Britain's hardest men.

Once deemed the most dangerous man in the UK penal system - he was certified insane and banged up in Broadmoor - these days Shaw is a legitimate businessman. Well, he's a car dealer. He has, says Kray, "got it all" - "a string of birds, a lovely family and a nice gaff in Epping Forest". In this gaff, he has a Forever Friends clock and a couple of toy trolls with pink hair, so still a bit of a question mark over the sanity thing.

With the clear implication that here was an ordinary decent criminal - "The geezer whose throat I cut was a grass", he explained - Hard Bastards was amoral and superficial. A Lock, Stock Timewatch, it contained a little too much affection and warmth for a man who spent most of his life terrorising folks and once threw his estranged wife's boyfriend from a balcony. Obviously documentaries should never be broadcast from the moral high ground, but the tone of Hard Bastards was guaranteed to induce priapism in gangster chic aficionados and eye-rolling boredom in normal people.

I don't want to be too horrible about Shaw (after all, he keeps an iron bar - which he "took off a coloured" in a pub - by his bed) but in the end, the predictably conspiratorial timbre of Hard Bastards did him a disservice. It painted him as nothing more than a badly drawn caricature who one day will perhaps be played in a film by Frank Butcher. Any depth or uniqueness the man possessed was ignored in favour of a sketchy, nice-one-geezer rendering of his life. Crime may well pay, but the exchange rate isn't great.

fields.headline: Watch out, watch out
fields.trailText: Rod Liddle's diary: Watch out, watch out.
fields.body:
If they postpone the General Election now I think the Today Programme will have to go ahead with its coverage anyway. We'll just pretend it's all still on.

So much has been planned. There are battle buses booked to follow the party leaders around the country, special live presentations from crucial constituencies, and a Today Election Desk preparing to sear the political obfuscations and perfidies every day with the righteous napalm of truth.

Yes, I know. Bet you can't wait. But don't worry, we've also got an Anti-Election team who will subtly undermine their colleagues working on the campaign with a diet of foreign news and non-political stories. Divide and rule, always the best management tool, I find.

Meanwhile, our essayist Will Self is attempting to gain accreditation to the Conservative Party campaign - a difficult thing, as it doesn't officially exist, just yet. Still more difficult when you consider what happened last time he was accredited and got into a bit of bother with drugs. By and large, we're all agreed, you shouldn't really jack up on the Prime Minister's plane, it's bad form. But Will's clean, these days, so I'm sure there won't be any trouble.

We've persuaded John Humphrys to present the programme pretty much every morning during the campaign. It's been a good year for John; he's been winning awards almost every week. I was slightly surprised he didn't pick up anything at the Brits, frankly.

Not that everybody will be delighted by John's omnipresence for four weeks. Recently he was attacked by the journalist Donald Macintyre for poisoning the Well Of Democratic Debate.

Donald's suggestion was that there is too much contempt and cynicism in John's questioning, that he "despises politicians too much for the listeners' - and the voters' - good." I never hear contempt in John's voice, apart from when he's talking about middle managers, health and safety executives, and people who put piped music in lifts.

But I do hear frustration from time to time, incredulity and even hilarity. There are two favoured techniques for avoiding an answer to the difficult question. The first is to repeat, time after time, a statement which usually bears no relation whatsoever to the question. That's used a lot. The second is to filibuster endlessly, to talk reams and reams of utter gibberish, like a contestant on a special version of Just A Minute, until it's time for the eight o'clock news, or Start The Week. In both cases, the presenter has to be heard to attempt, at least, to keep asking the question and to demonstrate that it is not being answered. That's what John does.

And I've been down to the Well Of Democratic Debate, and the blokes standing around with cans of paraquat looked more like politicians than journalists, to me.

webTitle: TV and radio: Satellite, cable and digital pick of the day

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Carlito's Way | Twelve Monkeys | Husbands And Wives | Le Dner De Cons | The Day Today | International Football
fields.body:
Films

Carlito's Way (Brian De Palma, 1993) 9pm, The Studio De Palma and Al Pacino had combined before to gruesome effect in Scarface, a hysterical, near three-hour account of a rabid cocaine smuggler. Pacino, in the meantime, has quietened down and developed Godfatherly gravitas. His Carlito is a crook trying to go straight via a Bermuda car-rental business, but with Sean Penn as his coke-addict lawyer, it's only a matter of time before the guns are out - which is when De Palma comes alive.

Twelve Monkeys (Terry Gilliam, 1995) 9pm, Carlton Cinema Brilliant but flawed science fantasy inspired by Chris Marker's 60s time-travelling conundrum, La Jetée. Bruce Willis is touchingly hangdog and quip-free as a man sent back through time to trace the origin of a virus which has wiped out most of mankind. Brad Pitt is the loopy leader of the Army of the 12 Monkeys, suspected source of the tragic disease; Madeleine Stowe is the doc helping Willis in his quest. At times incoherent, but it is dark and doomed and full of the visual chaos theory that was Gilliam's Brazil.

Husbands And Wives (Woody Allen, 1992) 1.50am, Sky Cinema Wry, witty observations on love and marriage, with Allen's candid hand-held cameras focused on failing couples. His English professor and Mia Farrow (now there's a couple) are falling apart, and casting envious eyes at friends Sydney Pollack and Judy Davis, who are finding fulfilment with others: a loving exposure of emotional foibles.

Le Dner De Cons (Francis Veber, 1998) 1.50am, Sky Premier A delightfully funny and nasty Gallic farce. Thierry Lhermitte plays the unutterably smug Brochant, who is highly amused by his "idiots' dinner parties", to which he and his friends each invite a buffoon to make an object of ridicule. Brochant's guest - the staggeringly dim matchstick-model maker Pignon (Jacques Villeret) - looks like being the star of the evening, but instead he manages, naively and obliviously, to demolish Brochant's complacent life. A real gem.
Paul Howlett

Comedy

The Day Today 9.40pm, Play UK Satisfying news squelch from 1994, with hallucinatory Paxman Chris Morris and his verbwhore team (Steve Coogan, Doon Mackichan, Patrick Marber etc) laying waste to the reportage landscape. It's an often brilliant parody that hasn't aged badly; if anything, it seems more real and appropriate in the digital multiverse: exactly the sort of show we actually want another chance to see.
Richard Vine

Sports

International Football 7pm, Sky Sports 1 & 2 The England game may have been rudely stolen by terrestrial Channel 5, but nothing is going to stop Sky from showing a spectacular evening of international football. Scotland take on San Marino at Hampden Park exactly one month after the European minnows let in 10 goals against Belgium, while over on Sky Sports 2 Spain, humbled by England last month, host the world and European champions France in a friendly.
Simon Burnton

webTitle: TV and radio: Radio pick of the day

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: The Working Wise campaign | High Resolution | Night Waves
fields.body:
For the next three days, recognising that most people will need more than one skill during their working life, the Working Wise campaign on Radio 2 offers information and advice. It's introduced by Jimmy Young (12noon, Radio 2) in a discussion with the Education and Employment Secretary, David Blunkett. The campaign will continue with inserts in the network's regular programmes.

There's a bacterium in a Pennsylvania laboratory which, until scientists managed to revive it last year, had spent 250 million years in suspended animation - 10 times longer than any previous example. This mind-boggling hibernation had seen it through a complete rotation of the galaxy. In High Resolution (9.0pm, Radio 4), Adam Hart-Davis considers whether such survival mechanisms could by used by astronauts undertaking the decades of travel required to explore the planets.

The current tourist guide to Belgrade lists such varied attractions as A Midsummer Night's Dream by V Sheakspire, Sleeping Beauty by PI Chaicovski, and D Verdi's opera Attila. Only this last, with its opening scene of Attila jubilant among the city's ruins, could be thought remotely relevant to Serbia's recent past. As Belgrade continues to endure post-war deprivations, Sarah Dunant tries to discover for Night Waves (9.30pm, Radio 3) whether its cultural scene offers more relevant responses to the fall of Milosevic.

fields.headline: Sonia Arova
fields.standfirst: Ballerina with the 'grand manner' whose stage was the world
fields.trailText: From 1955 onwards, the Bulgarian-born ballerina Sonia Arova, who has died of cancer aged 74, was a regular guest artist with Ruth Page's Chicago Ballet.
fields.body:
From 1955 onwards, the Bulgarian-born ballerina Sonia Arova, who has died of cancer aged 74, was a regular guest artist with Ruth Page's Chicago Ballet. She thus danced with Rudolf Nureyev, in the Don Quixote pas de deux, when he made his sensational New York debut in 1962 with Page's company.

Arova had known Nureyev from his first visit to Copenhagen, shortly after he arrived in the west, to seek out the great Danish dancer Erik Bruhn, and the great teacher Vera Volkova. For a short while, the three dancers, together with the ballerina Rosella Hightower, formed a small experimental group, which had enormous success in Cannes and Paris. Arova also danced with Nureyev and the Royal Ballet, notably in Swan Lake, when the critic Richard Buckle described her as possessing "the grand manner".

Born in Sofia, she was enrolled in the Bulgarian state opera and ballet school at the age of five, and showed such promise that her teachers advised her mother to take her to Paris for further training. The family arrived when Sonia was 11; they lived in one room, and her father sold his stamp collection to pay for her lessons. She trained with the Imperial Russian ballerina, Olga Preobrajenska.

In June 1940, her piano teacher, a British citizen, advised the family to flee to England and, disguised as her teacher's son, Sonia was smuggled into the country on a fishing boat. She never saw her father again. Her mother and sister joined her eight years later.

She studied at the Cone Ripman (now Arts Educational) School outside London during the blitz, and made her professional debut with Mona Inglesby's International Ballet in 1942. In 1947, she joined the shortlived, but excellent, Metropolitan Ballet, where she met Erik Bruhn, who became a close friend. She also danced with Ballet Rambert, was a guest with Les Ballets des Champs Elysées, appeared with the London Festival Ballet, the American Ballet Theatre, the Australian Ballet and the Washington Ballet.

The 1960s were the years of her greatest triumphs. From 1966, she was ballerina and director of the Norwegian Ballet in Oslo, where her husband, the American dancer Thor Sutowski, became a principal. For her services Arova was knighted by King Olaf V, and so used the title of dame.

From Oslo, the couple moved in 1970 to Hamburg, where Arova became artistic director of the state opera ballet, and, a year later, began a five-year directorship of the San Diego Ballet. Subsequently, they moved to Birmingham, Alabama, to teach at the School of Fine Arts, one of the best American ballet academies, and then began a long assignment with the regional ballet company there.

In 1997, Arova and her husband returned to San Diego to join their daughter, Arianna. Arova taught and became artistic adviser to the California Ballet. She also taught in Germany and Australia, but San Diego remained her home base.

 Sonia Arova, ballerina, artistic director and teacher, born June 20 1927; died February 4 2001

fields.headline: Chung Ju-yung
fields.standfirst: Business tycoon who drove South Korea's industrialisation and established links with the north
fields.trailText: As the founder and driving spirit of Hyundai, South Korea's largest industrial conglomerate, Chung Ju-yung, who has died of pneumonia aged 85, personified his country's ascent from poverty to global success.
fields.body:
As the founder and driving spirit of Hyundai, South Korea's largest industrial conglomerate, Chung Ju-yung, who has died of pneumonia aged 85, personified his country's ascent from poverty to global success. He devoted his last years to opening contacts with North Korea, but he also saw Hyundai fall into debt and criticised as outmoded, and witnessed his sons battling for his mantle. He was, nonetheless, a larger-than-life figure, whose passing marks the end of an era.

Born to northern peasants in Japanese colonial Korea, Chung had little schooling. In his teens, he ran away to Seoul, learning several trades before, in 1946, founding Hyundai - the word means "modern" in Korean - as an engineering and construction firm. American military contracts during the Korean war were an early boost. But Chung and Hyundai really took off after General Park Chung-hee seized power in 1961, and began South Korea's forced-march towards industrialisation, which rewarded favoured firms with cheap credit and expansion opportunities.

Chung built Hyundai into a conglomerate of 86 firms - making everything, as it boasted, "from chips to ships". It built Korea's first cars, and its first motorway (against World Bank advice) from Seoul to Pusan. In the 1970s, Chung countered the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries' oil shock by making Hyundai and Korea a major world force in construction.

Ever the nationalist, he played a key role in Seoul's successful outsider bid to host the 1988 Olympics. His chutzpah and energy were legendary. When the US army wanted cemetery grass to look green for a visit by President Eisenhower, he transplanted 30 truckloads of barley shoots. In 1971, he got a loan from Barclays bank to launch a shipbuilding venture by waving a 500-won note with a picture of an ironclad warship made in 16th-century Korea. Because Hyundai's dockyard was too small, its first tanker was built in two halves. When the pieces would not fit together, Chung had them welded, set up a shipping business to use the vessel - and made another, which did fit, for his foreign client.

In retirement, he built a huge ranch on reclaimed land. Needing 200,000 tonnes of rock to block the tidal flow, he scuttled an old tanker as the basis for a dyke.

An avowed Confucian, Chung embodied his creed's virtues and vices. For more than 30 years, his six sons were summoned to breakfast with him at 5.30am, by which time he had been up for two hours, reading the papers and placing calls. He expected the same punishing work ethic of everyone. Fiercely authoritarian, he was said to hit managers and hated trade unions, an approach that led to pitched battles at Hyundai's shipyard at Ulsan.

A country by now democratising found such attitudes distasteful. Chung was criticised for his vast wealth, estimated to be more than $4bn, and for hypocrisy on family values. It was widely believed that his sons had several different mothers.

Running Hyundai bred Chung's political ambition, although, in the 1992 presidential election, he polled only 16% of the vote. Hyundai was punished by the withdrawal of state bank loans, and began to falter. Increasingly, its boss's empire-building and autocracy looked outdated.

Even after Korea's financial crisis of 1997-98, Hyundai was reluctant to reform. Power struggles between three of Chung's sons merely hastened the process of breaking up the group. Hyundai Motor is already spun off under a rebellious eldest son, Chung Mong-koo, leaving the third son, and their father's favourite, Mong-hun, with the debt-ridden construction and chip businesses. Only loans from state banks have saved Hyundai from following its rival Daewoo into collapse.

That rescue was a reward for Chung's key role in the peace process with North Korea. He first went north in 1989, but neither regime was ready for compromise. A decade later, he symbolically drove 500 cattle across the demilitarised zone between the two Koreas as a gift, met the northern leader Kim Jong-il, and began tourist cruises to the scenic Diamond mountains (Kumgang-san), which have since taken more than 300,000 southerners to the north. These gestures paved the way for last year's summit.

fields.headline: Guy Serbat
fields.standfirst: French resistance leader with a long memory of injustice
fields.trailText: Behind the pseudonym of Commandant Raymond Cayrol, Guy Serbat, who has died aged 83, was one of the most distinguished leaders of the French resistance.
fields.body:
Behind the pseudonym of Commandant Raymond Cayrol, Guy Serbat, who has died aged 83, was one of the most distinguished leaders of the French resistance. He went on to become professor of linguistics at the Sorbonne, specialising in Latin.

In 194, as a member of the French Communist party (PCF) - and a former army captain - he was ordered to join the party's resistance group, Franc Tireurs et Partisans (FTP), formed to combat occupying German forces.

Serbat wrote for the FTP's clandestine newspaper, France D'Abord, in which ideology and tactics were explained. Since all France was suffering from the occupation, every Frenchman was deemed to have the right to kill a German. As a slogan, "À chacun son Boche" shocked the internationalism of some leftwing believers, but encouraged partisans to kill individual German soldiers - a gesture that usually led to terrible reprisals.

Ordinary Frenchmen were urged, when they had finished their days' work, to fight the enemy. They should tend their firearms, or seek to acquire them; they should keep in touch with other partisans, and find out what was happening. The time for insurrection would come when allied forces invaded France, and partisans began industrial strikes or uprisings in working-class districts.

Serbat commanded the FTP southern divisions, including the regions of Toulouse, Montpellier and Marseilles, and had responsibility for the Alpine areas. But what happened on the plateau of Les Glières, in Haute Savoie, was against his principles.

Despite the fact that farm raids for food supplies had made the FTP unpopular in the area, it was decided to construct a stronghold on the plateau. Two months after it began in January 1944, the base was destroyed by the Germans, with heavy resistance losses. Serbat described the original idea as a strategic error that had given the Germans the opportunity to attack when it was essential that resistance forces should always have the initiative.

What followed was to haunt Serbat for the rest of his life. All the regional FTP leaders were arrested and interrogated in Lyons by the notorious Gestapo chief, Klaus Barbie. Serbat escaped because he was still dealing with the after-effects of the battle. He believed that the torture and deaths of the resistance leaders were due to the actions of one Lucien Iltis, a communist and former Soviet agent who had been captured by the Gestapo in 1940 and turned into their special agent, working with the resistance under the name of Boulanger.

After being denounced by a former Gestapo officer in 1946, Iltis was tried but, mysteriously, allowed to go free. Serbat did not forget and, in 1984, when Barbie himself was on trial in Lyons, he insisted on giving evidence, in spite of being ill. The judge ruled him out of order, since Iltis was not on trial.

After the war, Serbat resumed his Latin studies, completed his thesis and, on being appointed to the Sorbonne chair, created the Institute for Grammatical Information and organised its publication series. He was director of the collection Linguistique Nouvelle, published by the Presses Universitaires. He left the PCF in 1956, and was married to Anréa Rivière.

webTitle: Meet the Bliggers - Brit Lit It Girls (and boys)

fields.headline: Meet the Bliggers - Brit Lit It Girls (and boys)
fields.trailText: Zadie Smith, 25
fields.body:
Zadie Smith, 25

The winner of the Guardian First Book award has been shortlisted for just about every literary prize on the planet for her "breathtaking" debut novel, White Teeth, a dazzling romp through multicultural north London. Her youth has also helped turn her into an international publishing sensation. So far her beauty has not been a hindrance.

Jenny Colgan, 28

Her first novel, Amanda's Wedding, a twentysomething urban comedy, earned her a £1.2m advance from HarperCollins which included a film rights deal with Warner Brothers.

Classified by snooty critics as another one of the trivial "Chick Lit" brigade, she coined the alternative term Bliggers, meaning Brit Lit It Girls. Bliggers, she claims, are between 25 and 35 and rather than writing aspirational Bridget Jonesy nonsense, are trying to reflect the real-life dilemmas of urban, professional women. Currently living in LA where she is working on her third novel.

Louise Bagshawe, 29

While Jenkins seems to court publicity, Bagshawe runs from it. There was a sharp intake of breath when she landed a £70,000 two-book deal at just 23. But it was money well spent because her debut novel, Career Girls, sold over 200,000 copies as did her next three books. Last year she was valued at £2m.

Jake Arnott, 40

A little old to be truly classified as a handsome young thing, nonetheless Arnott was well-preserved enough to adorn newspapers and magazines everywhere when his first book, The London Firm, was published to great acclaim two years ago. As one reviewer declared: "It doesn't matter he's no young prodigy. He's 38, so what? Those eyes, that look - part brute, part boy."

Tobias Hill, 30

Went to Hampstead comprehensive in London with Zadie Smith, though no one has yet thrown any big-money advances his way despite his Byronic good looks. This may be because he made his name as a poet, who publishers seem to believe deserve to starve. Embarrassingly good reviews for his novels, Underground (1999) and The Love of Stones, seem to have made little difference.

Amy Jenkins, 34

Having taken telly by storm by creating the cult series This Life, and becoming a staple of every glossy magazine in the country, her literary career has yet to reach the same heights. Despite receiving a £600,000 two-book deal on the strength of one chapter of her first novel, Honey Moon, it was a critical disaster. Sales, despite blanket coverage, have been very disappointing.

Alex Garland, 31

The richest and most successful of the new generation of British writers. Son of a well-connected cartoonist, his first novel, The Beach - about the dark side of a lotus-eating year backpacking in Thailand - was reprinted 25 times in less than a year. He was described by one critic as a publisher's dream: clever, young and startlingly handsome.

webTitle: Laguna's crash survival award does not include pedestrians

fields.headline: Laguna's crash survival award does not include pedestrians
fields.trailText: Renault yesterday became the first motor company to produce a model awarded full marks in tough crash survivability tests.
fields.body:
Renault yesterday became the first motor company to produce a model awarded full marks in tough crash survivability tests.

Renault's new Laguna was given a five-star rating by the European New Car Assessment Programme, reflecting a big leap forward in car safety.

However, road safety campaigners were dismayed that the advances in passenger safety design had not been matched by similar protection for pedestrians.

The Laguna, launched in the UK a month ago, performed exceptionally well in front and side impact tests, as well as in NCAP's new head protection test, which involves crashing the car at 17mph on to a narrow pole with a sideways blow. The force involved in such a crash can be more than five times the minimum amount required to cause a serious brain injury.

The Laguna's body structure and eight airbags, including one fitted into the ceiling to protect front and rear passengers, has reduced the force to less than a fifth of the minimum injury value.

Max Mosley, NCAP chairman, said: "We are delighted with the performance of the new Renault Laguna.

"Some manufacturers said that it would be impossible to achieve the fifth Euro NCAP star, but in less than a year since its introduction Renault has succeeded in setting a benchmark in crashworthiness."

But in pedestrian safety tests the car was awarded only two stars out of five.

The NCAP report concluded: "Pedestrian protection unfortunately has not improved in the same manner as occupant protection."

Edmund King, executive director of the RAC Foundation, said: "Renault and the other manufacturers should now concentrate on improving pedestrian safety, which is the one area which has not seen dramatic improvements in the last few years."

Zoe Stow, chairman of the road crash victims group Roadpeace, said: "We welcome any advances in safety but design is only part of the equation.

"It doesn't matter how many safety features a car has if a speeding driver hits a pedestrian."

webTitle: New image in hunt for sex attacker

fields.headline: New image in hunt for sex attacker
fields.trailText: A revolutionary face recognition system is being used by detectives hunting a serial sex attacker who has evaded capture for more than two years.
fields.body:
A revolutionary face recognition system is being used by detectives hunting a serial sex attacker who has evaded capture for more than two years.

The man, dubbed the beast of Bozeat after the location of an attack in Northamptonshire in January last year, has also been linked by DNA evidence to sexual assaults and attempted rapes in Cambridgeshire and Hampshire.

Police have released a conventional artist's impression of the suspect and the attacks have been featured on Crimewatch UK, but officers have come no closer to an arrest.

Now they are confident an image generated by Stirling University's new EvoFIT system will provide the breakthrough.

The new likeness was developed with the help of the victim in Bozeat. So accurate was the final image that the woman, who had been pushed into a hedge and sexually assaulted, reacted with "real terror" as it brought back memories of her ordeal.

Within hours of issuing the image yesterday, Northamptonshire police began receiving calls from the public about the man. Detective Chief Inspector Paul Spink, who is leading Operation Mallard, said: "We have managed to find out in more detail about the way he looked, and in particular his hair."

With £50,000 funding from the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council, the Stirling team, led by the psychologist Peter Hancock, has been working on EvoFIT for more than three years. It works on the principle that people are good at recognising faces but not good at accurately describing features.

To create a photofit, a witness describes the shape of the face, then chooses between different features, which are pasted on until a rough likeness of the subject emerges.

With EvoFIT, witnesses look at computer-generated images, starting with random face shapes and features, and are asked to select the ones most closely resembling the subject. Each time the witness makes a selection, a new generation of increasingly detailed photographs is created, combining the characteristics of those chosen. The best match is saved until an accurate image of the subject evolves.

People with information on the suspect should call police on 01604 700700.

fields.headline: Pilot suspended over logbook 'fake'
fields.trailText: A British airline pilot has been suspended amid claims that some of his qualifications may have been faked, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
A British airline pilot has been suspended amid claims that some of his qualifications may have been faked, it emerged yesterday.

Irregularities were allegedly found in the logbook of Airtours first officer Stuart Gibson, 30, when he applied for a promotion.

The civil aviation authority (CAA) has launched an investigation which will look back over the career of Mr Gibson, who is believed to have served in the RAF before joining Airtours.

If the allegations are proved Mr Gibson, who flew mainly Airbus 320s, could be charged under article 83 of the air navigation order. If guilty he could receive a two-year jail term and/or an unlimited fine.

Mr Gibson began working for Airtours in 1999. His logbook, a record of his whole career, seemed to indicate that he had appropriate qualifications and experience.

The irregularities were discovered only when the airline invited its more junior pilots to apply for command posts. After Mr Gibson applied for promotion, a routine check of his logbook was made and concern raised over the accuracy of some entries. It is believed the investigation will look at the number of hours Mr Gibson claimed to have flown before joining Airtours.

The CAA's safety regulation group is responsible for setting commercial aviation standards in Britain. This role includes ensuring that pilots are adequately trained and that their flying hours are regulated. Maintaining a logbook is the responsibility of a pilot but is subject to spot checks by the CAA.

A spokesman said: "The CAA is investigating a pilot for a British airline in connection with alleged irregularities relating to a pilot licence application."

Mr Gibson was not available for comment.

webTitle: Navy petty officer admits two murders

fields.headline: Navy petty officer admits two murders
fields.trailText: A petty officer who had been in the Royal Navy for more than 20 years yesterday pleaded guilty to the murders of two young men.
fields.body:
A petty officer who had been in the Royal Navy for more than 20 years yesterday pleaded guilty to the murders of two young men.

Allan Grimson, 42, admitted killing naval rating Nicholas Wright, 18, from Leicester and barman Sion Jenkins, 20, from Newbury, Berkshire. Their bodies were discovered four miles apart at the side of country lanes north of Winchester, Hampshire, in December 1999.

Anthony Donne QC, prosecuting at Winchester crown court, read out how Grimson, of Portsmouth, had described his feelings after killing Mr Wright. Mr Donne said that in a police interview Grimson had said he had punched the air in triumph and also gave out a roar after hitting Mr Wright with a baseball bat, slitting his throat and slicing off his ear.

He had told officers: "It was a feeling of power, a good feeling. I felt good about it. It was better than sex that feeling, better than an orgasm."

Earlier Mr Donne had explained that Grimson had met the young recruit Mr Wright on a fire-training course in Portsmouth in November 1997. Grimson had given Mr Wright his phone number to see if he wanted a lift back home to Leicester.

Later that month Mr Wright told a navy friend, Peter Green, about Grimson's proposition and Mr Green had called Grimson a "poof" in Joanna's nightclub in Portsmouth. There had been a scuffle between Grimson and Mr Green resulting in a navy police investigation on Grimson to which Mr Wright gave a statement.

But on December 12, 1997 Mr Green said he saw Mr Wright talking to Grimson, which he thought strange, in Joanna's nightclub but the teenager had seemed happy. It was that night, Mr Donne said, that the petty officer and the teenager took a taxi ride back to Grimson's flat.

Mr Donne said Grimson had told Mr Wright he wanted to go upstairs but he refused and the older man became angry. He punched him in the face, ripped down his trousers and hit him on the buttocks with a baseball bat.

Grimson told officers that Mr Wright had said: "Why don't you kill me?" and Mr Donne said: "The defendant in his own words said he 'just lost it'.

"He struck him severely, with hard blows to the head, cut his throat with a carving knife, and threw him in the bath.

The next day, Mr Donne said, Grimson wrapped Mr Wright up in bin bags and dumped him in the countryside near Winchester.

Grimson explained the killing had not been sexual but one of control and power. Grimson had then said he had wrapped up the body of Mr Wright while naked and had felt a "tingling" sensation.

Grimson said the killing had been followed by a second sensation of achievement. He told police he felt he needed an audience and he wanted to show them he had done it.

The court heard Grimson was interviewed for four days from December 1999 at Alton police station in Hampshire.

Mr Donne went on to describe the last moments of barman Sion Jenkins, who was killed a year later in 1998.

Officers had asked Grimson if he had killed again, and he said yes. Mr Donne said Mr Jenkins, 20, had had a brief spell of five weeks in the Royal Navy. He had then moved to Portsmouth. He was working as barman in the Hog's Head in Portsmouth when he was spotted by Grimson. They met up at Joanna's and he had asked Mr Jenkins, who was drunk, if he wanted to leave.

Again they caught a taxi to Grimson's flat. Mr Donne said Grimson told Mr Jenkins it was time but Jenkins said no. The court heard Grimson then got angry and told Mr Jenkins if he did not have sex with him he would hurt him, and punched him. The pair had sex. In the morning Mr Jenkins had said he wanted to leave. Grimson said he wanted the same feeling he had experienced killing Mr Wright.

He bound Mr Jenkins in the bath and put a towel over his head, he said, to avoid the mess of the previous killing.

fields.bodyText: A petty officer who had been in the Royal Navy for more than 20 years yesterday pleaded guilty to the murders of two young men. Allan Grimson, 42, admitted killing naval rating Nicholas Wright, 18, from Leicester and barman Sion Jenkins, 20, from Newbury, Berkshire. Their bodies were discovered four miles apart at the side of country lanes north of Winchester, Hampshire, in December 1999. Anthony Donne QC, prosecuting at Winchester crown court, read out how Grimson, of Portsmouth, had described his feelings after killing Mr Wright. Mr Donne said that in a police interview Grimson had said he had punched the air in triumph and also gave out a roar after hitting Mr Wright with a baseball bat, slitting his throat and slicing off his ear. He had told officers: "It was a feeling of power, a good feeling. I felt good about it. It was better than sex that feeling, better than an orgasm." Earlier Mr Donne had explained that Grimson had met the young recruit Mr Wright on a fire-training course in Portsmouth in November 1997. Grimson had given Mr Wright his phone number to see if he wanted a lift back home to Leicester. Later that month Mr Wright told a navy friend, Peter Green, about Grimson's proposition and Mr Green had called Grimson a "poof" in Joanna's nightclub in Portsmouth. There had been a scuffle between Grimson and Mr Green resulting in a navy police investigation on Grimson to which Mr Wright gave a statement. But on December 12, 1997 Mr Green said he saw Mr Wright talking to Grimson, which he thought strange, in Joanna's nightclub but the teenager had seemed happy. It was that night, Mr Donne said, that the petty officer and the teenager took a taxi ride back to Grimson's flat. Mr Donne said Grimson had told Mr Wright he wanted to go upstairs but he refused and the older man became angry. He punched him in the face, ripped down his trousers and hit him on the buttocks with a baseball bat. Grimson told officers that Mr Wright had said: "Why don't you kill me?" and Mr Donne said: "The defendant in his own words said he 'just lost it'. "He struck him severely, with hard blows to the head, cut his throat with a carving knife, and threw him in the bath. The next day, Mr Donne said, Grimson wrapped Mr Wright up in bin bags and dumped him in the countryside near Winchester. Grimson explained the killing had not been sexual but one of control and power. Grimson had then said he had wrapped up the body of Mr Wright while naked and had felt a "tingling" sensation. Grimson said the killing had been followed by a second sensation of achievement. He told police he felt he needed an audience and he wanted to show them he had done it. The court heard Grimson was interviewed for four days from December 1999 at Alton police station in Hampshire. Mr Donne went on to describe the last moments of barman Sion Jenkins, who was killed a year later in 1998. Officers had asked Grimson if he had killed again, and he said yes. Mr Donne said Mr Jenkins, 20, had had a brief spell of five weeks in the Royal Navy. He had then moved to Portsmouth. He was working as barman in the Hog's Head in Portsmouth when he was spotted by Grimson. They met up at Joanna's and he had asked Mr Jenkins, who was drunk, if he wanted to leave. Again they caught a taxi to Grimson's flat. Mr Donne said Grimson told Mr Jenkins it was time but Jenkins said no. The court heard Grimson then got angry and told Mr Jenkins if he did not have sex with him he would hurt him, and punched him. The pair had sex. In the morning Mr Jenkins had said he wanted to leave. Grimson said he wanted the same feeling he had experienced killing Mr Wright. He bound Mr Jenkins in the bath and put a towel over his head, he said, to avoid the mess of the previous killing. Grimson picked up the baseball bat and took some practice swings before he landed what Mr Donne described as a "sickening thud" on the head of Mr Jenkins. He landed six more blows on his head killing him. But Grimson said he had not got the same thrill out of killing the barman. Press Association

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: US airman's body found
fields.body:
US airman's body found

A body near the wrecked F-15C fighter jet that crashed one mile south-east of Ben Macduin, in the Cairngorms, was yesterday believed to be one of two missing US aircrew from Lakenheath air base, Suffolk, who had been on a low-flying training mission over Scotland.

Taxi driver found in dock

Police are investigating the death of a taxi driver found floating in Middlesbrough's Teesport dock. Abdul Rashid, discovered 16 hours after he went missing, had head injuries.

Schools meet sports target

Nearly 70% of schools have met the government's target of at least two hours of PE and sport a week for pupils, according to a poll of 350 schools. The percentage using free time for school sports was between 55% and 75%. In the 11-14 age group, 87% exceeded expectations in PE.

Nine held over carnival death

An inquiry into a death at the Notting Hill Carnival last summer has led to the arrest of a man aged 27 and eight teenagers, including a 16-year-old girl. No one has been charged with the murder of Abdul Bhatti, 28, who was attacked by a gang. The nine arrested will appear before west London magistrates tomorrow charged with violent disorder.

Fidelity of Irish husbands

Northern men are most likely to cheat on their wives, the Irish are most likely to be faithful, and twice as many men as women cheat on their partner, according to a survey by Woman magazine.

fields.headline: Foot and mouth: In brief
fields.trailText: • Some people have been so upset by images of animals being slaughtered and dumped in mass graves that they are becoming vegetarian. The Vegetarian Society said it had 100% more calls from members of the public this month than in January.
fields.body:
 Some people have been so upset by images of animals being slaughtered and dumped in mass graves that they are becoming vegetarian. The Vegetarian Society said it had 100% more calls from members of the public this month than in January.

 British farmers are buying up land in Australia, cashing in on a favourable exchange rate on the Australian dollar. Farmers from England and Scotland flew in this week for an auction of a 10,000-acre Queensland farm. Thanks to British interest, land prices in the state's outback have risen steeply, but they are still a fraction of the cost of land in the UK.

 The Cheshire Show became the latest exhibition to be cancelled due to the foot and mouth outbreak, after a third case was confirmed at a farm near Northwich.

 An organic farmer and former publisher, Peter Kindersley, is seeking a judicial review the policy of slaughtering healthy animals. A judge sitting in private will decide whether a full hearing should follow. Mr Kindersley and his wife, Juliet, farm 2,000 acres at Lambourn, Berkshire, with beef, sheep, poultry, pigs and cereals.

 Disneyland Paris has sent away all animals vulnerable to the disease, including sheep, goats, pigs and deer, as a precaution.

fields.headline: Varying visions of Christ
fields.trailText: It says much for the historically unequal relationship between Europe and the rest of the world that we are surprised that Christ may have looked like a middle-eastern Jew (Is this the real face of Christ, March 27).
fields.body:
It says much for the historically unequal relationship between Europe and the rest of the world that we are surprised that Christ may have looked like a middle-eastern Jew (Is this the real face of Christ, March 27).

To mark 2,000 years of Christianity, the National Gallery organised Seeing Salvation, an exhibition on the depiction of Christ in art. I do not recall Neil MacGregor as the curator of that exhibition making any concession to the fact that the oldest artistic depiction of Christ, from the Egyptian and Ethiopian Coptic Christian traditions, are anything but the blond-curled, blue-eyed white man so beloved of Hollywood and European art.

It was to counter the ubiquity of this portrayal of Christ that at the same time as the National Gallery's exhibition I organised a small exhibition at Birmingham Museum exploring the contemporary popular portrayal of Christ as an indigenous figure in many parts of the non-European Christian world.

Although Black Christ proved to be a huge success, particularly with the sort of audiences that museums do not usually get, I was somewhat perturbed by the fact that even most black and Asian visitors (Christians and atheists alike) had never imagined Christ to look anything but white.

From my own childhood in a Christian missionary school in India I recall that all the images of Christ depicted him in the European art tradition. Not only the man but the physical landscape, clothes and even the food were neutered of their middle-eastern context. Is it any wonder that Christianity with its white Son of God image is regarded as the handmaiden of European colonialism?

Raj Pal
Oak House Museum, West Bromwich
Roger@tatoud.fsnet.co.uk

 So the reconstructed face of any old first century Palestinian is the face of Jesus Christ? Is this the same as white racists saying that all black people look the same? Jeremy Bowen is convinced he can perceive the historical Jesus when 2,000 years of rationalist endeavour from Reimarus on have failed - producing the epithet common in theology that such endeavours are like looking down a well and seeing your own reflection.

How interesting therefore that a hardened journalist and news presenter should perceive Jesus as a political activist and hero who challenged the status quo and was executed as a result!

Paul Brazier
London
P.H.Brazier@btinternet.com

 Is the Guardian about to undergo a Damascus Road conversion? As a Church of England minister, I was delighted to see a picture of Christ gracing your front page accompanied by the crucial question with which I regularly challenge non- believers: "Who is this man?" If you would like to publish my sermon notes regularly in full, do please let me know.

Rev David Baker
Romford

 The answer to your question is: He's Henry Hymos. He and I did a Saturday job in Brent Bros men's outfitters in Wood Green c.1969.

Dr AM Platman
Beckenham

 No, it's not. It's my uncle Mick.

Glenda Young
Sunderland
glenda@cwcom.net

 Five days too soon, or a future DNA research project? Either way I'm sure Graham Chapman would have found it amusing (just look at those eyes!)

Val McKenzie
Salisbury
The.Mckenzies@btinternet.com

fields.headline: Some women are awful
fields.trailText: Elizabeth Mahoney, in her review (March 26) of Martha Gellhorn's radio play For Richer For Poorer, seems to believe that to depict an unsympathetic or "bad" woman betrays feminism. "What a stinker, what an anti-feminist piece," she wrote, for a role model such as Gellhorn to have perpetrated.
fields.body:
Elizabeth Mahoney, in her review (March 26) of Martha Gellhorn's radio play For Richer For Poorer, seems to believe that to depict an unsympathetic or "bad" woman betrays feminism. "What a stinker, what an anti-feminist piece," she wrote, for a role model such as Gellhorn to have perpetrated.

Martha Gellhorn's life was indeed feminism in action. But she thought of herself as a writer, not a "woman writer". She was outraged by the awfulness of awful people. Some awful people are women. How does it serve feminism - which is about rights; or art - which is about truth - to pretend otherwise? It was a sharp and funny play.

In any case, feminist or not-feminist is only one, limited way of appraising a creative work, or a person. Another question one might ask is whether something or someone is worthwhile or worthless; perceptive, or unbelievably stupid.

Victoria Glendinning
London

 Katie Roiphe (Why we all want a happy ending, March 27) summarises Jane Austen's plots as "the man who pursues and the woman who is pursued". She should read the books again to see that the point is precisely the opposite.

John Reynolds
Wadhurst, E Sussex

 Re: Lines to live by (G2, March 27):

What lines must I quote

To be lyric'ly pc?

What's foul to thee,

May be meet to me.

Jean Lavelle
Settle, N Yorks
lavelle@honeymire.freeserve.co.uk

webTitle: Letters: Log on to keep the Tories out.com

fields.headline: Log on to keep the Tories out.com, the democratic way
fields.trailText: There is no need for "deals behind closed doors" to deny voters choice (Letters, March 27). The voting system already does that.
fields.body:
There is no need for "deals behind closed doors" to deny voters choice (Letters, March 27). The voting system already does that.

Most seats are a two-horse race between the Tories and one other party. A vote for Labour in Kingston & Surbiton says "Hurrah for Blair!" but makes a Tory comeback more likely. Voting Lib Dem in neighbouring Wimbledon says "Hurrah for Kennedy!" but is likely to lead to a Tory replacing the Labour MP.

There are many differences between the two parties. The rare individuals for whom both are possible winners have an interesting decision to make. For the rest of us, tactical voting is the responsible exercise of our rights under a flawed system. To oil the wheels, we will be following the example of nader trader and voteswap.org in the US. They nearly kept Bush out and succeeded in depriving him of a clear mandate.Our website will show the 1997 results and advice on where the anti-Tory vote should go in each seat. You'll also be able to pair up with a tactical voter from the other party via email. Campaign leaflets for your seat will be available to download.

This is not about pacts in smoke-filled rooms. It's about bringing individual voters together to make a difference. That's what I call democracy.
Jason Buckley
Campaign director
jb@tacticalvoter.net

 Your leader about tactical voting (March 26) is wrong. There is an obvious reason for a pro-PR Labour voter to vote for the Liberal Democrat candidate where he or she has a chance of beating the Tories and Labour has not.

But the reverse no longer applies. Blair has reneged on the commitment to a referendum which he and his party made in 1997. Instead we have nothing more than "perhaps" and "depends".

What is needed is for New Labour to get worried that their weakness on PR will lose votes, not gain them. If Liberal Democrat votes go up in all kinds of seats, electoral reform will suddenly reappear on the political agenda.
Tony Greaves
House of Lords

 If the problem with calling an election during the foot and mouth crisis is not the election itself, but the election campaign, then there is a clear solution. Let the government call an election and pledge not to campaign. All of the other parties would be bound to follow and we could elect the next parliament on the basis of experience. Money that would have been spent on the campaign could be donated, by both major parties, to schools, thus fulfilling part of their election pledges early.

Who knows, we might find we like it too.
Alan Craig
Shadforth, Durham
alan@shadforth.u-net.com

 If our general election was based on a fixed four year term, would the Tories still be so keen to urge the government to postpone May 3?
Brian Lynch
Attleborough, Norfolk
brian.lynch@unisonfree.net

fields.headline: Old Eros
fields.trailText: I read with pleasure and amusement John Sutherland's account of the amorous adventures of John Bayley (This man is irresistible to younger women, G2, March 14).
fields.body:
I read with pleasure and amusement John Sutherland's account of the amorous adventures of John Bayley (This man is irresistible to younger women, G2, March 14). Searching for analogies to the imagined reactions of male readers, Prof Sutherland invokes the example of WB Yeats who, he says, "was in his 70s" and quotes, as if by connection, some lines from Sailing to Byzantium.

While Yeats was concerned with the gap between young lovers and the ageing poet who observed them, he was only 62 when the poem was first published in 1927. The poem as quoted refers to the soul clapping "its hand"; yet, whatever the physical infirmities or disabilities produced by age, Yeats envisaged that the soul would be exempt from such frustrating limitations.

Timothy Webb
Bristol

fields.headline: Rape laws in question
fields.trailText: If a verdict of rape within marriage is determined solely by the woman's consent on that one occasion, why should it be different for a woman who is not married (Leader, March 27)?
fields.body:
If a verdict of rape within marriage is determined solely by the woman's consent on that one occasion, why should it be different for a woman who is not married (Leader, March 27)? Or is the implication that a woman who refuses a second session is being so perverse that her wishes can be overridden with impunity?

Julian Dunn
Oxford
eisendora@compuserve.com

 Sadly, even the church is no longer exempt from "motivation which isn't commercial" (One for mum, March 27). The Anglican church I regularly attend chose Mothers' Day to launch their fourth Gift Day in as many months. I suppose it goes without saying that the clergy are all male.

Manchester

Sarah Wren
Film officer, Tower Hamlets
pressoffice@perky.theguardian.com

London

fields.headline: Jobs miracle - or misery
fields.trailText: I cannot accept Larry Elliott's claim that "the battle between capital and labour over money" is a thing of the past, and that all that workers are now concerned about is leisure time and flexibility (Phoenix effect will work well for us all, March 26).
fields.body:
I cannot accept Larry Elliott's claim that "the battle between capital and labour over money" is a thing of the past, and that all that workers are now concerned about is leisure time and flexibility (Phoenix effect will work well for us all, March 26).

How can this be squared with Madeline Bunting's excellent article (It's time for a living wage) in the same edition? Or the fact that the biggest issue for anti-poverty campaigners in the US is now the "working poor" who constitute over 70% of the 30m people in poverty in the US?

The key fact which Larry Elliott overlooks is that the so-called "jobs miracle" in the US, and increasingly in the UK, is built on the backs of millions of low grade, low paid and part-time jobs which fail to pay a living wage. Leisure time and flexbility may increasingly be the preoccupations of some, but when you're having to work 80 hours a week just to make ends meet, frankly, are you likely to have much energy left to care about such things?

Niall Cooper
National co-ordinator, Church Action on Poverty
churchaction@cwcom.net

 Madeleine Bunting rightly deplores widening differentials between top directors and those with minimum earnings. The only answer is to move power from directors to employees as a whole, starting by giving the latter rights as shareholders, to include decisions on remuneration policy. The role of government would be not enforcement but to advise on differential ratios according to company size. All this would require radical changes in company law. Which party will be bold enough to make a start?

Frank Whitehead
Henfield, West Sussex

Leisure time and flexbility may increasingly be the preoccupations of some, but when you're having to work 80 hours a week just to make ends meet, frankly, are you likely to have much energy left to care about such things? Niall Cooper National co-ordinator, Church Action on Poverty churchaction@cwcom.net  Madeleine Bunting rightly deplores widening differentials between top directors and those with minimum earnings. The only answer is to move power from directors to employees as a whole, starting by giving the latter rights as shareholders, to include decisions on remuneration policy. The role of government would be not enforcement but to advise on differential ratios according to company size. All this would require radical changes in company law. Which party will be bold enough to make a start? Frank Whitehead Henfield, West Sussex

fields.headline: Crisis in Macedonia
fields.standfirst:
Nato and the EU are getting the message


Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText: Javier Solana yesterday walked arm in arm across Tetovo's main square with its (Albanian) mayor. The EU chief's promenade was meant to show the town is safe from the snipers lodged in the mountains around.
fields.body:
Javier Solana yesterday walked arm in arm across Tetovo's main square with its (Albanian) mayor. The EU chief's promenade was meant to show the town is safe from the snipers lodged in the mountains around and to show solidarity with Macedonia's principal ethnic minority. Perhaps Mr Solana was there in person in lieu of the money, jobs or legal migration opportunities the EU promised but has not delivered. Nor was there in his pocket anything like a considered EU analysis of the short-to medium-run future of the lower Balkans. But at least he was there; and Nato's general secretary, George Robertson, with him. At last Nato and the EU have woken up to the fissile material smouldering on the Macedonian hills.

The weekend show of strength by the Macedonian army worked, and the Skopje government gets some breathing space. Nato forces should do their best to extend it. Within K-For's sphere of competence, soldiers and the international police need to do a better job of checking the movement of people into and out of Macedonia along its border with Kosovo. Excuses about terrain will not wash. For generals throughout the world, porous borders are the military future.

Tighter policing should give Skopje an envelope within which to redress imbalances at home. Civilians suffered during the operations around Tetovo: justice and compensation should follow if loyalties are to be won. An enthusiastic drive towards more inclusive, pluralist and power-sharing politics in Skopje would count for more. Albanians are represented in the government of Macedonia but they have community grievances. Some kind of "round table" discussion with Albanian leaders inside and outside the recognised ranks might identify them. Constitutionally, the Macedonian ethnic entity needs to recognise Albanian numbers. They in turn need to be ascertained by a new census.

There are hard men who say history tells them of the invincibility of the ethnic factor - there is no stopping place short of some greater Albanian nation-state. (These tend to be the same people who so opposed Nato's intervention in Kosovo, on the grounds that the Milosevic regime was the hand of history in its massacre of Kosovars.) Of course "history" offers no such single or emphatic lesson. On the contrary, what the post-1945 experience of decolonisation, ethnic and nationalist conflict around the world shows is that sooner or later insurgents - terrorists - do sit down with those against whom they took arms and vice versa. And then they talk. In Macedonia, the "national" liberation army has a political wing. Some of its goals are accessible within the framework of a Macedonian state even if not the one presently constituted. But to get anywhere near them demands long (years-long) political conversation.

Skopje has resolved not to deal bilaterally with insurgents, which is understandable. The good offices of neighbours are in short supply; it is hard to see Athens or Sofia let along Belgrade or Tirana being anything but instrusive. That leaves Mr Solana and Mr Robertson and their ambassadors. But the Bush doctrine means Nato is constantly looking over its shoulder to see if the Americans are packing their bags; so what we are left with is the EU. Forget, for the time being, the promise of a European army. In Macedonia the EU should engage in concerted (and commercially generous) diplomacy. In the Balkans the consequences of inaction have been shown, again, to be far heavier than the short-run costs of active involvement.

fields.headline: Fair warning
fields.standfirst: Policy and practice don't always converge when it comes to equal opportunities.  Raekha Prasad reports
fields.trailText: Policy and practice don't always converge when it comes to equal opportunities. Raekha Prasad reports.
fields.body:
Conventional wisdom suggests that policy leads to action. So when Kensington and Chelsea council recently won glowing praise for its services for ethnic minority residents, and for the rigour with which it records the borough's ethnic make-up, many would have assumed that the west London borough had successfully married policy and practice.

Yet the council, in common with 44% of local authorities in England and Wales, does not have an equal opportunities policy. It does have a declaration, which states that any discrimination is unacceptable, and a string of training and monitoring measures led by an equal opportunities working party. But its success begs the question of whether equal opportunities can be achieved without an equal opportunities policy.

Kensington and Chelsea's shining assessment by a social services joint review team lends support to the view that policies are little more than lip service. "What really inspires confidence in people about a council is their day-to-day experience of it, not a fairly standard form of words," the borough says in a statement.

Peter Smith, equality policy officer at the Local Government Association (LGA), says equal opportunities policies can vary considerably. Some focus exclusively on staff, while others concentrate on service delivery. "If council staff are not made fully aware of the policy, and trained in how to put it in place, then it's purely a paper exercise," he agrees.

As might be expected, authorities with big ethnic minority populations are more likely to have an equal opportunities policy. Fewer than half all district councils have policies, compared to almost 80% of metropolitan boroughs. But there are several exceptions.

Redbridge, in east London, has one of the highest young black and ethnic minority populations in the country - at more than 40% of all under-18s - yet it has no policy. Its own joint review found it lacked "philosophy and vision" in meeting residents' racial and cultural needs.

On the other hand take Leicester, where more than half of all children under 16 are from black and ethnic minority communities. Leicester not only has an equal opportunities policy, but has, on paper, put in place all other advised equality criteria, such as ethnic monitoring and Commission for Racial Equality (CRE) codes.

Yet according to its joint review, it has fallen well short of providing a good service to its ethnic minority residents. Planning information addressing population diversity was found to be "poor"; relations with some of the minority populations was "underdeveloped"; and the range of culturally appropriate services was "restricted". In addition, senior council staff did not reflect the local population, awareness training had slipped and black and Asian staff felt "unheard or unable to challenge what they experience as prejudice in their working lives".

Pressure on councils to marry policy and practice is about to intensify. From April 2, an extension of the Race Relations Act to public authorities will mean that, for the first time, residents will be able to bring a case against a council if they have evidence to show they have been poorly served on grounds of race or ethnicity. Councils will be required to have due regard to the need to "eliminate unlawful racial discrimination and to promote equality of opportunity and good relations between persons of different racial groups".

Specific duties, in relation to publishing race equality schemes, staff employment, training, monitoring, and service delivery will come into force in November, allowing six months for compliance by May 2002. The CRE will have enforcement powers, including compliance notices and court enforcement orders.

The changes clearly recognise that, for many authorities, left to their own devices, race equality is a matter of good intentions but little more. A recent LGA survey found that of the 57% of councils that had an equal opportunities policy, fewer than a third monitored them and more than 70% had not incorporated into their policy the Stephen Lawrence inquiry report's definition of institutional racism. Almost half these councils had not adopted the CRE's "standard" - a checklist of specific measures to create equality.

Ethnic minorities are also under-represented among local authority staff. The Lawrence inquiry found that, contrary to popular perception, local government employs only 4.4% black, Asian and ethnic minority people, compared to 5.4% in the economy as a whole. Only 3% of councillors are black or come from an ethnic minority.

"Many organisations went into entrenchment in the climate of the late 1980s and early 90s and very little progress was made," says Gurbux Singh, who chairs the CRE. "If an authority has a statement, but is not monitoring its residents or its workforce, not identifying gaps and taking action to remedy the shortfalls, then frankly I don't think it's worth anything.

"The new duty will change that. Race will have to seep into the core values of the institution. The responsibility is placed with the management of the organisation rather than being at the whim of political will."

This cultural shift will have "serious implications" for inspection bodies, Singh argues. "Race will have to take a mainstream position within the joint review."

fields.headline: Where time is money
fields.standfirst: Secret volunteer economy remains the backbone of charities
fields.trailText: Secret volunteer economy remains the backbone of charities.
fields.body:
The public seems increasingly convinced that voluntary organisations are staffed by paid professionals - and many people are unhappy about it. Yet new research suggests that two-thirds of the work of Britain's biggest charities is provided by volunteers.

The study attempts, for the first time, to put a monetary value on the volunteer effort harnessed by charities. It is based on a survey of 156 groups which, between them, had more than 2m volunteers giving a few hours of their time each week. This amounted to the equivalent of 224,000 full-time workers.

The analysis was undertaken by the Institute of Volunteering Research for the Directory of Social Change (DSC), the voluntary sector research and training body, and was funded by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.

Luke FitzHerbert, of the DSC, points to two examples of how volunteers remain the backbone of leading charities. St John Ambulance volunteers provide the equivalent of £14m a year in labour at the national minimum hourly wage rate of £3.70. At £10 an hour - a more realistic market rate - the figure rises to £37m. By contrast, St John's donated income is put by the DSC at £9m.

The Samaritans, meanwhile, have just under 20,000 volunteers to answer telephone calls from people in distress. Their annual value is estimated at £11m at £3.70 an hour, or £31m at a rate of £10. The charity's donated income is put at £4m.

FitzHerbert says his findings are not precise because many charities do not keep detailed figures of hours worked by unpaid helpers. But this does not detract from the conclusion that volunteering represents an enormous "saving" to the country, if the alternative was to pay staff.

The Salvation Army told the DSC it had 55,000 active members, as well as many other volunteers, but could not quantify their hours. Taking the national volunteering average of four hours a week, FitzHerbert reckons such help is likely to be worth at least three times as much as the £67m a year the charity receives in donations.

The point of the research, he says, is to persuade charities to record in their annual reports the value of contributions made by supporters in terms of time - as well as money. The charity commission recently removed a suggestion along these lines from its guidance to charities. FitzHerbert believes it should be reinstated.

He feels also that putting an albeit crude figure on the value of voluntary effort will help counter the inaccurate belief that big charities are becoming primarily professional organisations.

Simon Armson, chief executive of the Samaritans, says the research is useful. "Too often the contribution made by volunteers gets overlooked in economic terms."

For all the good intentions of the survey, though, charity leaders may be worried lest it is interpreted as a call for volunteers to be paid.

Lewis Martin, chief executive of St John Ambulance, strikes a note of caution. "It may be possible to estimate the financial value of the hours provided by our volunteers," he says. "However, it is important to point out that we are a charity with a mission to provide voluntary first aid, transport and care support to local communities - and there are many motivators for people to volunteer which are not based on financial gain."

fields.headline: Open challenge
fields.standfirst: Mind names new chief executive
fields.trailText: Mind names new chief executive.
fields.body:
Leading mental health charity Mind today announces the appointment of a new chief executive, Richard Brook, who moves across from the supported housing sector.

Brook will take over in early summer from Judi Clements, who has led Mind for nine years but is standing down on health grounds. She, too, formerly worked in housing.

As chief executive of the Christian Alliance Housing Association, 44-year-old Brook is responsible for an organisation with 180 staff and a £4m turnover, working with homeless young people and vulnerable parents. He was previously director of care and community services at the Shaftesbury Society.

Although the latter is also a Christian group, and Brook is a practising Christian, he insists: "I might come from a faith-based perspective, but Mind is an open organisation, working with people from diverse communities, and that will continue."

Brook is a qualified social worker, having worked in Glasgow, Bedfordshire and east London before switching to the housing sector. He is a member of the board of Open Door, a London-based mental health and ex-offenders' charity, and was treasurer and then chair of Newham Mind, east London, in the late 1980s.

He is aware of recent controversy within Mind over regional restructuring, which has involved closure of some local offices, but thinks that the reasons for the changes are now better understood.

"I am confident from my discussions with trustees that what they have put in place will serve Mind well into the medium term," he says. "We need now to be able to look to the challenges that lie ahead, in particular the new [mental health] legislation which should be coming through after the election."

Mind has been lobbying to strengthen the advocacy provisions for service users in the mental health white paper, as well as voicing concern about the proposed extension of compulsory treatment to the community and the planned detention of people with "dangerous" severe personality disorders.

"We'll need to see whether the sort of campaigning Mind has been doing has altered the proposals in any way," says Brook, who hopes to take up his new post - advertised at £60,000 - in mid-June.

webTitle: Call for internet equality for youngsters in care

fields.headline: Call for internet equality for youngsters in care
fields.trailText: Every problem estate should have a fully funded and professionally staffed internet cafe, according to children's charity NCH, which today launches a campaign to highlight the fact that disadvantaged youngsters have most to gain from IT yet often have little access to it.
fields.body:
Every problem estate should have a fully funded and professionally staffed internet cafe, according to children's charity NCH, which today launches a campaign to highlight the fact that disadvantaged youngsters have most to gain from IT yet often have little access to it.

But vulnerable children are also likely to be most at risk of abuse of the internet once they know how to use it, warns NCH.

Several children's charities, together with ministers and police representatives, are today taking part in a Home Office summit on internet safety and young people. Although ministers have pledged to close the digital divide by 2005, NCH argues that the government is not doing enough to ensure equal, and safe, access to IT for youngsters in care. So as well as running the campaign, called IT OK, the charity is setting up its own unit to advise and influence policy development.

Among NCH's first batch of ideas is a call for all foster parents to be given computers, free of charge, with training and continuing support. They would then be able to offer similar help to young people being cared for in their homes.

Young carers, who have to stay at home to look after siblings or parents, should meanwhile be given computers on loan - with free access to distance learning programmes - so they can keep up with school and college work. And fully funded IT systems should be installed at centres for disabled children and young offenders.

To protect vulnerable young people from "cyber risks", NCH has come up with a nine-point checklist for social care, health and education professionals. This includes a contractual requirement that staff use computers only in connection with their work with young people; and instructions to check that hard drives of second-hand computers do not contain pornographic material.

Deryk Mead, NCH chief executive, says: "New tech presents huge opportunities, as well as big risks, for children and NCH believes that, with the right approach, IT can be OK."
