fields.headline: School's out
fields.standfirst: Eileen Fursland on the children of asylum seekers who are denied an education while they await dispersal
fields.trailText: Eileen Fursland on the children of asylum seekers who are denied an education while they await dispersal.
fields.body:
In a south London tower block, four-year-old Ali and five-year-old Aisha share one room with their mother, Fatma. An uncertain future awaits them. Fatma has no money to buy the children toys, or even pencils and paper. They don't go to school, so Fatma has to choose between closeting them in the room with her, or letting them play in the corridors and public areas of the tower block, where groups of young men hang about most of the day. There's an anarchic feeling about the place. Tensions are running high and it is plainly not a healthy environment for two young children.

The family has been there for three weeks already and Fatma has no idea how long it will be before they are moved on - nor where they will be moved on to. They could be waiting days, weeks or even months. She can expect to be given 24 hours' notice that they are moving.

The local social services department is unaware of the children's existence. In fact, Aisha and Ali are not covered by the United Nations convention on the rights of the child, as it has been adopted by Britain. This is because they and their mother came to Britain from Turkey, seeking asylum. They are in emergency accommodation with other asylum seekers, awaiting "dispersal" to another part of the country.

Although families are supposed to stay in emergency accommodation for a few days only, in practice many remain there for weeks or months. Often this is because of the nature of the system, where lost paperwork, long drawn-out decision-making and general confusion are the norm. Sometimes it is because asylum seekers fear being "dispersed". They have heard stories of grim conditions, racial abuse and attacks, isolation and lack of social, legal and language support in the dispersal areas.

The net result is that an unknown number of children languish in a kind of limbo for weeks or months, living in accommodation designed for a seven-day stay, often going without books, toys, and educational facilities.

Stephanie White, a volunteer who works with asylum seekers and refugees in London, is concerned that there is no one to champion the cause of such children. "I know of several children who have been living in 'temporary' accommodation for at least four months," she says. "Many of the long-stayers are particularly vulnerable; children with medical problems or whose parents have medical problems. However, even if the system worked perfectly, there would always be a certain number of children in each hostel at any one time. These are traumatised children who are entitled to a safe place to play while they wait to be dispersed."

Jill Rutter, education policy adviser at the Refugee Council, says: "One of our key concerns is that families are spending too long in emergency accommodation, where all they get is three meals a day. There are no play facilities for children in emergency accommodation, and parents are stuck there with their kids for 24 hours a day."

The charity would like to see the government provide funding to give children living in emergency accommodation a safe place to play with shared toys and facilities. Alasdair Mackenzie, coordinator of Asylum Aid, another charity working with asylum seekers, agrees: "The lack of education, play facilities and child protection would be a less acute problem if children really were passing through emergency accommodation in a few days, as planned. But plainly, as the system isn't working and that isn't happening, these are all issues the government needs to address."

On paper, all children here as dependants of asylum seekers are entitled to receive schooling. "It is government policy that asylum seekers' children of compulsory school age are given the same opportunities to benefit from what schools can offer them," a Home Office spokesperson confirms. But as Jill Rutter says: "The children waiting to be dispersed have theoretical rights to education, but they are not encouraged to approach local schools because the disruption to schools would be enormous."

Children are therefore normally allocated a school place only once they have left emergency accommodation. There are one or two isolated examples of good practice: the local education authority (LEA) in Croydon, south London, provides English classes and an induction to education for children and their parents in emergency accommodation. But funding for such initiatives is scarce.

Last year, £1.5m additional funding was committed to support the education costs of children of asylum seekers dispersed to local authorities in the so-called "cluster" areas. But schools in London and the south-east - the areas where many children end up staying for long periods - did not qualify. The funding runs out at the end of this month and there has so far been no announcement about the next financial year.

Even when families approach a school or LEA, however, it may be some time before their child can be offered a place: the Refugee Council's best estimate is that 2,000 children who are either seeking asylum or have been granted refugee status are on school waiting lists. The number who are not even on a waiting list is unknown.

On paper, asylum seekers and their dependants are also entitled to receive medical treatment under the NHS. But, in practice, it is not always so easy. Asylum seekers in temporary accommodation could be moved on at any time. This, and language problems, makes signing on with a GP difficult and, in a crisis, help can be hard to come by.

"Some of the families have told me that local doctors won't accept them," says Sirtaj Rahman, manager and outreach worker with the Finsbury Park Homeless Families Project, which works with refugee families in north London. She was present at a hotel one day when a woman asylum seeker had terrible back pains and was unable to stand. "She desperately needed a doctor and her family were all crying. They called for an ambulance four times, but the ambulance refused to come. They said they wouldn't come to the hostel any more because too many people had been calling when there wasn't any emergency. I had to find some money and give it to them, and then her husband and family carried her out to a minicab which took her to hospital."

So who is looking out for children of asylum-seeking or refugee families? Social services departments are only responsible for unaccompanied children and are struggling to cope with them. Neither the national asylum support service (NASS), which is responsible for the dispersal programme and for supporting asylum seekers until their claims are decided, nor the Refugee Council has the resources to address the specific needs of children in emergency accommodation.

White thinks it is high time that named individuals were made responsible. "At the moment," she says, "it's impossible to find out where the buck stops."

fields.headline: A pub with no fear
fields.standfirst: How 'do-gooders' and hostile locals joined forces in Sheffield
fields.trailText: How 'do-gooders' and hostile locals joined forces in Sheffield
fields.body:
Five years ago, people living in one of Britain's most deprived areas tried to run a group of community workers off their estate. It was an ordeal for the small band of church-sponsored volunteers, but it proved the catalyst for a radical rethink on how the estate could be regenerated.

Back in 1996, tenants living near a boarded-up pub in Sheffield's Burngreave district were furious that "do-gooders" were moving in. A group of Baptists setting up shop in what had been The Furnival pub was not going to help local people convince the brewery to reopen its doors. They wanted a pub again, not a community centre.

The initial confrontation between an angry crowd of tenants and the four community workers was the first time Jane Grinonneau met Josie Stocks. Grinonneau was the Baptist minister leading the team that had moved into the pub to set up a "faith-based neighbourhood resource". Stocks was at the front of the crowd of men and women who wanted the team out.

It was the start of a relationship that was to see the two women, from wholly different backgrounds, working together for the benefit of the community. "It took time for us to gain the trust of the people on the estate", says Grinonneau. "But because we persevered - and they persevered with us - we started to get somewhere. We started to listen to what the community was saying, rather than telling them what we thought they should do. We began to realise that much of what's said about regeneration doesn't have a place on an estate like this. It had nothing to do with the lives of people living here."

The community workers won the confidence of Stocks and her neighbours. "They started to ask us what we wanted, rather than take it for granted," she says. "Lots of social and community workers come along thinking they know it all. Jane soon realised we would work with her and her team, but only if they listened to us."

Now the two women who stood face-to-face five years ago work side-by-side at Verdon Street Enterprises, a community-based initiative centred on The Furnival community cafe and a row of converted shops. The enterprises include a launderette, a healthy housing project, a citizen's advice centre and a nearly-new shop. Local residents, many of them teenagers, are involved in skills training. There is a credit union and a joblink scheme. Funding from varied sources has financed 10 full-time posts, with many more part-time workers and volunteers getting involved in a range of schemes. It is evidently part of the community and the community is evidently part of the project.

Not only do the two women work together, they are also near-neighbours. Stocks has lived one minute's walk from The Furnival for the 18 years she has been on the estate; Grinonneau moved into one of the many empty flats when she went to work there. She felt she had to, and she has been proved right. Living alongside the people she was there to help has given her a fresh insight into the problems of regeneration.

While many clamour for regeneration "from the bottom up", Stocks and Grinonneau believe that merely giving a say to people at the bottom does not empower them. Those at the top have already drawn up the strategies and the structures before those at the foot of the pile are consulted.

"The typical regeneration strategy is for people who already know what is best for communities to dictate to them from a great distance what the desired outcomes are of that regeneration," says Grinonneau. "Questions are asked as to why people in communities don't participate. Well, why should they when they are neither seen nor heard?"

Stocks argues that those in charge of deciding how an area is regenerated should spend time living there. "Those who have got the advantage need to be among those who haven't," she says. "They have to be willing to learn the language. They have to be willing to be there and listen."

Burngreave is one of the New Deal for Communities projects. The statistics show why: the suicide rate among women is 60% higher than the national average; 82% of children live in families that have no wages; and 44% of households have a net weekly income of less than £200. Up to £50m could be on its way to the area. Paradoxically, though, The Furnival cafe faces the loss of its funding.

"We have had all sorts of funding these past five years and we have had a good crack of the whip," says Grinonneau. "But it does seem somehow ironic that New Deal is about listening to communities and, just as the first of the £50m comes to Burngreave, Josie - the woman who for the past five years has taught us what we needed to know - could well be out of a job."

fields.headline: Art of survival
fields.standfirst: As England's much-maligned special hospitals face up to yet another reorganisation, the man formerly in charge of them, Charles Kaye, argues that the siege mentality must be lifted
fields.trailText: As England's much-maligned special hospitals face up to yet another reorganisation, the man formerly in charge of them, Charles Kaye, argues that the siege mentality must be lifted.
fields.body:
Over the past 12 years, life in the English high security hospitals could be likened to existence in a disputed stronghold in a protracted civil war. The hospitals - Ashworth, Broadmoor and Rampton - have undergone three management reorganisations; been subject to two statutory inquiries; witnessed escapes, suicides, murders and a nurses' strike; and been accused of racial intolerance and ill-treatment of patients.

The units have seen many managers and clinical leaders arrive with enthusiasm, later to depart downcast if not disgraced. There have been repeated calls for the hospitals to be closed. They have been savaged by the media and have opened doors, only to close them again. They have been told they are unmanageable and hopelessly institutionalised. They have been ordered to become part of the NHS, but then classified as equivalent to category B prisons.

Patient numbers have fallen from 1,715 in 1989 to 1,292 in 1999, but demand for admission remains high, with "waiting lists" in operation. The units have been declared incompetent in their handling of personality disordered patients, yet then proposed as the site for a "new approach" for just such patients.

In the middle of this maelstrom, the hospitals somehow continue to function and even make optimistic noises - now generally in muted tones - about their future. And, even more surprisingly, many dedicated staff still feel it worth working in such a turbid environment. There is surely no theory of management, or of psychiatric or psychological practice, which would seriously suggest that such a random battering was an appropriate way to define a service for patients with the most severe psychiatric illnesses - potentially or actually dangerous - or to motivate staff to provide that service.

In part, the story represents the changing priorities of society, nicely reflected in the purpose and content of the two statutory inquiries into Ashworth, on Merseyside. The first, led by Sir Louis Blom-Cooper QC in 1992, was the last in a long line of formal inquiries into abuse and ill-treatment in large psychiatric hospitals. It produced vignettes of corrupted professional standards and it advocated liberal remedies, rooted in respect for the individual. The second, chaired by Peter Fallon QC in 1999, investigated allegations of criminal behaviour and loss of control by professional staff. It devised a recipe of tighter control and exclusion of undesirable individuals. Fallon reflected the current public mood: increasing distrust of doctors; growing desire for revenge and explicit punishments; greater accountability; and, above all, aversion to risk.

Yet the recent history of the "specials" also reflects the dedicated efforts of groups and individuals to introduce change within the institutions, and in their relationship with the NHS, the criminal justice system and other agencies. This work is, in many ways, at the frontiers of knowledge and professional competence. There is success and achievement, but it cannot be guaranteed and is not always understood. Among peer groups, such uncertainty can usually be accepted; but to the public and political audience, it is a matter for scepticism. What is risk to the professional is seen by the general public as danger and threat.

Within these difficulties, staff also share the fear and anxiety: their vulnerability, personal and professional, is very real - and largely discounted. What they can do is not generally valued and what they are unable to achieve is written in headlines. Unfortunately, it is now impossible for the hospitals to operate out of sight, since they are established as a rich reservoir of material; they share the stigma that they attach indelibly to their patients. "Crazed killers" are good copy - whether they are being mollycoddled or let free. So what lies in store for the specials? Another decade of criticism and obloquy? What incentives are to be offered to staff to retain their commitment?

Reviewing the painful haemorrhage of effort to improve the hospitals - the closure of which ministers have firmly ruled out - it becomes obvious that change cannot be achieved by taking them in isolation. We have a national forensic service started almost 30 years ago: it is no longer realistic or fair to pretend that the problems in a high-security hospital are phenomena solely of their own making, unrelated to the way in which the balance of the national service is operating. In reality, high security has been acting as a lightning conductor, earthing the shocks and protecting the rest of the forensic establishment.

What is required is a vertical reassessment of forensic care, pursuing issues right through the spectrum of facilities - including the all-important contribution of the independent sector. Starting next week, each of the three specials is to be merged with other mental health services to form new trusts. By placing high-security and medium-security units under one command - immediately, in the cases of Broadmoor in Berkshire and Rampton in Nottinghamshire, and at a later date at Ashworth - there is the possibility of reviewing thoughtfully the inter-relationship of these previously and artificially separate facilities.

Such a sea change will need to cut through the rivalries, insecurities and contempt which often characterise present arrangements. And it will need to be measured primarily not in the superficial trappings of management speak - divisions, directorates and boards - but in real change in clinical practice. Psychiatrists in particular, and clinical teams in general, will need to behave and work on a patient-focused basis, giving up their territorial preoccupations. One service, one staff and shared standards.

Within three years, we should expect to be able to measure progress by criteria which will include: a "life care plan" for each patient; quality measures for physical conditions, clinical expertise and use of control techniques; and a guarantee that no patient need wait longer than three months for transfer or discharge once the next step is formally agreed. None of the three units should have more than 300 resident patients.

It may be unrealistic to expect the general public, the media or even the politicians to see secure care as anything other than a social sump, embarrassment or target. But the NHS and all the caring professions have a responsibility to act with different expectations and better information. They have the capacity to lift the siege, and create and sustain a better service.

 Charles Kaye was chief executive of the former special hospitals service authority from 1989-96. A fuller version of this article appears in the current issue of Criminal Behaviour and Mental Health, published by Whurr (020-7359 5979).

fields.headline: A green and pleasant land
fields.trailText: George Cadbury and his brother Richard were greatly influenced by Ebenezer Howard, founder of the garden city movement.
fields.body:
George Cadbury and his brother Richard were greatly influenced by Ebenezer Howard, founder of the garden city movement.

The first conference of the Garden City Association was held at Bournville in 1901. In attendance were Lord Leverhulme, who had created Port Sunlight just outside Liverpool, and the Rowntrees, who would lay out the village of New Earswick, near York, in 1902.

The following year, Howard's company, First Garden City Ltd, founded Letchworth in Hertfordshire. Hampstead Garden Suburb was on site in north London a few years later.

There was a certain amount of enlightened self interest behind the initiatives set up by the Cadburys, the Rowntrees, Leverhulme and (earlier) Sir Titus Salt, who founded Saltaire, near Bradford. They would have a compliant and healthy workforce on hand.

Alone among these benefactors, George Cadbury was interested in setting up a balanced community which included tenants who did not rely on him for work. Bournville has always had residents with no connection to the factory. Today, they are in the majority.

fields.headline: Poetic justice
fields.standfirst: Dylan Thomas collaborating with Quakers? Sounds unlikely. But, as Chris Arnot  discovers, the hard-drinking poet and the abstemious Cadburys shared an interest in housing for the poor
fields.trailText: Dylan Thomas collaborating with Quakers? Sounds unlikely. But, as Chris Arnot discovers, the hard-drinking poet and the abstemious Cadburys shared an interest in housing for the poor.
fields.body:
It seems unlikely that the Cadbury family ever mixed socially with Dylan Thomas. Cocoa was hardly his favourite tipple, and the Birmingham chocolate makers were staunch Quakers. They would have been appalled by the poet's predilection for strong drink. He, in turn, would have found the Cadburys insufferably priggish.

And yet there was a collaboration of sorts between them. In 1945, Thomas narrated his own script for a film called When We Build Again. It was a typically lyrical and passionate plea for postwar Britain to be free of poor housing and foul air. The message could apply to any big city, but it just so happened that most of the footage was shot in Birmingham - perhaps because the film was financed by Cadburys and based on a book of the same name, published four years earlier by the Bournville Village Trust.

Set up by George Cadbury to administer his garden suburb four miles from the city centre, the trust celebrates its centenary this year. It recently commissioned a film to publicise its work, from a company called First City Productions. Managing director David Wilkins was rummaging through the trust's archives when he found Thomas' wartime gem, gathering dust.

"As soon as I turned up the volume and his voice came crackling through, I knew it sounded vaguely familiar," says Wilkins. "It soon became evident that the script was of a quality rarely found in corporate films. There were phrases straight from my own school days."

Certainly the line about miners - "coal black, flocking back from the midnight-coloured underground of the pits" - is a bit of a give away. Over pictures of children in the slums, Thomas intoned: "The citizens of tomorrow play in filth of their inherited nursery - the gutter." He finished with a rousing speech steeped in the collectivist political ethos of the times: "There must be no uncontrolled building, no more ugly houses and straggling roads, no stinting of effort when we build again. Nothing is too good for the people. The people are the greatest asset that any nation possesses. They are its courage and its strength and the future will belong to them."

Stirring stuff. A pity, then, that nobody seemed to be listening. The failure of so much municipal postwar housing has been well chronicled. "You only have to look around here," says Wilkins, whose company is based between the city centre and a god-forsaken former council estate where unwanted "units" of accommodation are on sale for £1 each.

Across town, in similarly deprived Nechells, a small part of the inner city has recently been transformed into a mini-Bournville, as the Village Trust continues its founder's philosophy of trying to improve the living conditions of the poor. Concrete high-rise 1960s flats have been torn down and replaced with redbrick houses and maisonettes with gardens, built to a high standard.

Sports and leisure facilities have been included in the scheme. It was always the Cadbury way to emphasise the benefits of exercise: "A child brought up in the back streets of our cities is handicapped in mind, body and spirit," George Cadbury wrote to Lloyd George in 1916. He went on to point out that children of 12 born and raised in Bournville were, on average, two and a half inches taller and with three-inch bigger chests than those from the slums of Birmingham.

"Although people aren't starving in the streets today, the need is just the same as it was in George's day," says the trust's director of estates, Alan Shrimpton. He is, though, conscious that the Nechells development is small-scale, involving just 59 households - an example of what could be done, rather than a wholesale solution to the problems of the inner city.

There is more scope to create what he calls "Bournville Mark Two" on a much larger site in Telford. On land owned by English Partnerships, the trust is building a brand new Shropshire village. There will be 750 homes (to rent and for owner-occupation) together with offices, a community centre and - believe it or not - a pub. "We've been persuaded that it's needed for what the planners call social glue," says Shrimpton, doubtfully.

Dylan Thomas would have approved. George Cadbury most certainly would not. The nine Cadburys who still sit on the trust's 12-strong board have softened only slightly the family's hard line on alcoholic drink which he laid down 100 years ago. Rumour has it that he would evict tenants if he found alcohol on the premises. Not true, Shrimpton assures me. But he goes on to add with a grin: "It is said that residents used to carry bottles around in violin cases for fear of being spotted."

The original Bournville today still has its idyllic village green, flanked by twee half-timbered shops, red telephone boxes and a church with a carillon that chimes out popular hymns at regular intervals. But there is no public house and no off-licence around the green or anywhere else in the garden suburb. "The residents have consistently voted to stay dry," Shrimpton says. There is a feeling, he concedes, that licensed premises might add to the problems of vandalism and burglary that have seeped into the social fabric of Bournville.

These usually quiet avenues of sturdily-built semis are not divorced from the realities of city life. Half of the trust's 7,000 properties here are owner-occupied and the other half are to let on the basis of social need. The vast majority of incoming tenants are on housing benefit. Grants of up to £250 are made available by the trust so that tenants can buy carpets, a cooker and that essential of Bournville life - a lawnmower.

"We're still paternalistic and we make no excuse for that - social engineering still sits comfortably with us," proclaims Shrimpton, a Cadbury man through and through. Both his parents worked at the factory - his father from the age of 14 until 65 and his mother until she married. "Girls", as women were traditionally referred to in Bournville, were expected to give up work and become home-makers as soon as they tripped down the aisle. Until well after the second world war, it was customary to see women surreptitiously removing their wedding rings on their way to work.

George Cadbury, who lived until 1922, thought nothing of issuing his tenants with "suggested rules of health". They were advised, for instance, to "breathe through the nostrils with the mouth closed, especially at night", and to furnish their "sleeping apartments" with single beds. "Double beds are now little used in civilised countries, except the United Kingdom," he assured them. Cold baths were recommended. Eating between meals was not.

No snacking on chocolate, then. And certainly no "intoxicating liquors". Perhaps it was just as well that the Cadburys never mixed socially with Dylan Thomas.

fields.headline: Giant strides
fields.standfirst: Sectarianism has blighted sport in Northern Ireland, but a mahor break with tradition is proving to be really cool. Laura Haydon on the unifying force of ice hockey
fields.trailText: Sectarianism has blighted sport in Northern Ireland, but a mahor break with tradition is proving to be really cool. Laura Haydon on the unifying force of ice hockey.
fields.body:
Twelve-year-old Eamonn stands in the middle of the roaring crowd and beams with delight. He and his friend, Dean, are clearly having the time of their lives. Eamonn and Dean have come to Belfast's new Odyssey Arena to cheer on their heroes, the Belfast Giants ice hockey team. Asked what they like best about this North American sport, the answer comes straight back: "The fights!"

Eamonn and Dean are among a group of children, of all religions and none, on a visit organised by the local police as part of a community relations project. Before the arrival of the Giants, a cross-community trip to a sporting event here would have been near impossible. Traditional sport in Northern Ireland has been riven by tribal divisions. But the arrival of big league ice hockey has changed all that. At these games, fights are all part of the spectacle, but the violence stays strictly on the ice and the vast crowds of spectators are united in support of their team.

The Belfast Giants were formed last year to play in the UK's ice hockey Superleague. The team - whose members are all Canadian, save for a lone American - got off to a sluggish start but rallied in December, when the arena opened and the Giants began playing at home. Support for the team surged as it won nine consecutive home games at the beginning of the year. Attendance has exceeded all expectations, the averagie 6,500 crowd being a near sell-out and making the Giants the best supported team in the league.

"I'm very proud," says John, a 40-something dad draped in a Giants shirt and scarf and flanked by his son, Stewart. "It's only our first season and I'm over the moon to finally have a sport everybody loves. There isn't the tribalism there is in football. With us only having the one team that's for all of Belfast, everybody supports them, and I think that's important."

At the merchandising kiosk, queues have built as fans snap up goods ranging from rubber pucks to Giants shirts, hats and jackets. Kiosk supervisor Marion Livingstone says: "Belfast has been crying out for something like this. Soccer's been hijacked on either side of the divide; if you supported one team you were either a Catholic or a Protestant. But it hasn't come into this. It's a sport for all."

The near-universal popularity of the Giants is not fortuitous, but the result of a carefully orchestrated marketing campaign. The team's communications director, Peter Collins, has worked hard at selling ice hockey as a game for everyone. A telling slogan - "In the land of the Giants everyone is equal" - appears on the cover of the programme sold at each game, as well as on the team's website.

The team's name is another masterful piece of marketing. It refers to the legendary giant Finn McCool, whose footsteps, so the story goes, created the extraordinary geological formation which is known as the Giant's Causeway - one of Northern Ireland's top tourist attractions. According to myth, McCool's giant stride created a similar rock formation over the sea in Scotland, where many Northern Ireland Protestants have family links. As a Scottish-Irish hero, McCool (depicted as a flaxen-haired action man on the souvenir shirts worn by fans) is an icon embraced by both communities.

Despite all this, Collins denies that his initial aim was altruistic. "It's part of our job to create a product on the ice," he says. "I hate to use that term, but it is a business at the end of the day and you have to make money."

He echoes Livingstone's feeling that the game is filling a gap in the market. "We're in a special position in that we don't have fully professional soccer or rugby league in Northern Ireland, whereas the ice hockey Superleague is the highest professional level in the UK," he says. "So we are unique in that we have no natural competitors who can take custom away from us."

The family-friendly environment created at the Odyssey, allied to the game's fast and furious qualities, have also been factors in the sport's soaring popularity. "The puck can travel at up to 95-100 miles an hour; the players can skate at 35 miles an hour," says Collins. "It's a combination of the speed, the aggression and the sheer razzmatazz of a North American approach that can draw you into the game."

Since the Giants began playing at home, children have been flocking to Northern Ireland's only public ice rink at Dundonald, on the edge of Belfast. The Giants may not have set out to unite people, but now that they have, they are doing what they can to reinforce the effect by running weekly coaching sessions for young people. "It's amazing," says Steve Roberts, who plays left wing for the Giants. "We started out with about 25 and now there's 127."

As Roberts leaves the ice at the end of the training session, attended by boys and girls as young as five, a dozen or so crowd round him hoping for an autograph. Alan, 11, has been turning up to the sessions for the past eight weeks. "When I went and saw my first Giants game, I just wanted to start playing," he says. Sarah, 13, is equally enthusiastic. "I loved roller-blading and street hockey, so this was the next step," she says. "The Giants have brought it all together: the fact that we have our own ice hockey team now."

The Giants now plan to start a junior league for those really serious about the game. However, Jerry Keefe, a Bostonian of Irish extraction who plays centre for the team, admits it will probably be many years before the Belfast team is fielding any home-grown players. "All of us who play started when we were three or four," he says. "You do have to get on the ice when you're young. But eventually I think you'll see some pretty good players coming out of Northern Ireland."

In the shorter term, the popularity of ice hockey in Belfast looks assured. Despite criticism of the Giants for going ahead with fixtures during the foot and mouth crisis, Northern Ireland's political leaders are quietly proud of the achievements of the team, which finished sixth in the Superleague table.

For the team, and for its proud new fans from all religious communities, the next season cannot come soon enough.

Related articles

fields.headline: Capture the common good
fields.trailText: Enter our photography competition and you could win £2,000.
fields.body:
The Common Good, the Guardian's special series last week highlighting the work of public servants, has prompted a huge response. Now we are running a competition to find photographs that best capture the nature and value of public service.

If you have a camera and work in public service, you could win the £2,000 first prize - and have your work printed in the Guardian.

The competition will be judged by Alan Rusbridger, Guardian editor, Eamonn McCabe, Guardian picture editor, and Richard Sennett, professor of sociology at the London School of Economics.

Send entries - which can be in colour or black and white, prints, slides or digital - to Eamonn McCabe, Public Images, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Closing date for entries is Thursday, April 12. We will do our best to return any pictures if you enclose an sae.

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: Space case
fields.body:
Space case

The idea that local councillors are democratically constrained by the lack of postmodern architecture that would ensure true "democratic spaces" is, I am afraid, slightly wide of the mark (People's palaces, March 21).

Case studies are instructive: Birmingham is a good starting point. Consider the evidence. First, in opposition to 96% of service users, their immediate families and the wider community (who spent £10,000 on an independent survey of citizens), the Labour group decides to privatise 30 residential care homes.

Second, the decision was made at a private sitting of the Labour group on a weekend at a theatre in the city centre that the public knew nothing about (does that qualify under the democratic space thesis?). Obviously, the dominant Labour members on the social services committee were whipped to ignore the democratic rights of service users.

Third, the original proposals were discussed at a private sitting of the committee. The report was written by consultants Deloitte Touche. The public had not been involved. The document notes the fact that carers in the homes would be profoundly affected by the restructuring, a direct result of their gender and ethnicity.

I could go on. Reality: politics is not about "space." It's about institutional power, the control of networks and resources. Most of all, it's about the fear of democracy by elites. Start from that point and one can rationally determine that other, more significant changes in the polity are required.

Mark Oley, Birmingham

Up in alms

You paint a rather rosy picture of life in almshouses (Des res charity, March 14). The fact is many tenants are subject to a rather arbitrary process at the whim of the local Lord and Lady Bountiful.

Decisions are taken by trustees, with little or no reference to the tenants. In my mother's case, this led to a decision to build new kitchens at exorbitant cost, ignoring the wishes of the residents - a group of relatively frail older people - who had asked for central heating and showers. The subsequent mismanagement and cost overruns were then passed on to the tenants in the form of a 60% increase in annual rents.

Nick Morgan, Ainderby Steeple, North Yorkshire

High priority

You were right to highlight the role that GPs could play in helping people overcome drug misuse (Dose of good sense, March 21).

DrugScope has long argued that the natural first port of call for those with drug problems is often the family doctor. However, recent research shows that medical students get an average of six hours' formal training on substance misuse in five years, despite the growing numbers of people taking illegal drugs and the growing numbers reporting to services with problematic use.

DrugScope has worked with the Department of Health to ensure GPs and primary health care staff are competent to provide drug treatment. But in order for more doctors to have the necessary confidence to deal with this complex area, medical schools also need to make it a much higher priority.

Annette Dale-Perera, director of policy and practice, DrugScope

Hunting controversy

It is only natural for an executive director of TMP Worldwide to defend headhunting (Letters, March 21). However, my partner's past experience bears out the criticism.

Working for a leading firm, he found that most headhunting efforts went into buttering up clients rather than selection processes. Flattering councillors that they had made a brilliant decision by employing headhunters was a large part of the job.

He was party to discussions about boosting salary to increase commission - a practice encouraged by the regular use of performance-related pay in his firm.

Despite my partner's qualifications in occupational psychology, he found little science in the selection processes of headhunters. They had few imaginative insights into the potential of individuals and used "old boy" networks extensively. Reality checks on previous experience were rare.

One of the best regarded local authority chief executives was only kick-started in her rise because councillors ignored advice from recruitment consultants and chose her for an executive role. Local authorities need to break away from a culture of dependency on consultants and use their own imaginations and ideas.

Christine Humphreys, Tring, Herts

 We are currently carrying out a study of women chief executives in local government and, among many other issues, we have looked at the contribution that headhunters can make.

Where local authorities use consultants, it seems that women have a more equal chance of being appointed. Our research shows that headhunters help to ensure that more blatant forms of discrimination do not occur during the selection process.

We have picked up stories of disgraceful prejudice which remain in a few parts of local government, but these are less likely when recruitment consultants are involved.

The other role that consultants can play, we have found, is to encourage women to apply for senior positions. We do not know how to put a price on greater equality in employment. fields.bodyText: Space case The idea that local councillors are democratically constrained by the lack of postmodern architecture that would ensure true "democratic spaces" is, I am afraid, slightly wide of the mark (People's palaces, March 21). Case studies are instructive: Birmingham is a good starting point. Consider the evidence. First, in opposition to 96% of service users, their immediate families and the wider community (who spent £10,000 on an independent survey of citizens), the Labour group decides to privatise 30 residential care homes. Second, the decision was made at a private sitting of the Labour group on a weekend at a theatre in the city centre that the public knew nothing about (does that qualify under the democratic space thesis?). Obviously, the dominant Labour members on the social services committee were whipped to ignore the democratic rights of service users. Third, the original proposals were discussed at a private sitting of the committee. The report was written by consultants Deloitte Touche. The public had not been involved. The document notes the fact that carers in the homes would be profoundly affected by the restructuring, a direct result of their gender and ethnicity. I could go on. Reality: politics is not about "space." It's about institutional power, the control of networks and resources. Most of all, it's about the fear of democracy by elites. Start from that point and one can rationally determine that other, more significant changes in the polity are required. Mark Oley, Birmingham Up in alms You paint a rather rosy picture of life in almshouses (Des res charity, March 14). The fact is many tenants are subject to a rather arbitrary process at the whim of the local Lord and Lady Bountiful. Decisions are taken by trustees, with little or no reference to the tenants. In my mother's case, this led to a decision to build new kitchens at exorbitant cost, ignoring the wishes of the residents - a group of relatively frail older people - who had asked for central heating and showers. The subsequent mismanagement and cost overruns were then passed on to the tenants in the form of a 60% increase in annual rents. However, recent research shows that medical students get an average of six hours' formal training on substance misuse in five years, despite the growing numbers of people taking illegal drugs and the growing numbers reporting to services with problematic use. DrugScope has worked with the Department of Health to ensure GPs and primary health care staff are competent to provide drug treatment. But in order for more doctors to have the necessary confidence to deal with this complex area, medical schools also need to make it a much higher priority. Annette Dale-Perera, director of policy and practice, DrugScope Hunting controversy It is only natural for an executive director of TMP Worldwide to defend headhunting (Letters, March 21). He was party to discussions about boosting salary to increase commission - a practice encouraged by the regular use of performance-related pay in his firm. fields.headline: Deadly forces
fields.standfirst: When the cameras have gone and media interest has ended, the real job of disaster relief must begin, explains Didier J Cherpitel
fields.trailText: When the cameras have gone and media interest has ended, the real job of disaster relief must begin, explains Didier J Cherpitel.
fields.body:
Global figures on the number of people killed by so-called natural disasters are intriguing. Television coverage, concerns over climate change, accelerated soil erosion and the growth of mega-cities would all suggest that things should be getting worse. But statistics show that natural disasters - drought, floods, hurricanes, volcanic activity - now kill about 100,000 people every year, compared to a regular toll of more than 3m annually in the first 30 years of the 20th century. So is there really a crisis? And, if so, what is it?

Nothing, of course, is that simple. Most disasters do not kill instantly. They wreak havoc by destroying livelihoods rather than lives. A graph for the number of people affected - rather than killed - by disasters shows a totally different picture. The figures jump up and down from year to year depending on whether there is a major flood in China or a hurricane in the Americas, but the trend is ever upward. Fifty years ago an average of around 50m people a year were affected, today it is 200m.

The massive killers of the early 20th century have been tamed, but at a price. Famine in India or China no longer kills millions. Cyclones in the Bay of Bengal no longer drown hundreds of thousands. Pandemics no longer lay Europe to waste. But while direct loss of life has been averted, millions are now forced to live on marginal lands where chances of escaping the poverty trap disappear every time a flood or storm surge hits.

Those who crowd into the mega-cities of the developing world searching for employment, or attempting to escape from persecution and fear, end up in the most disaster-prone parts of the city: on garbage tips, on unstable steep land, in the river valleys regularly hit by flash floods or in malaria-infested marshes.

Disasters are first and foremost a major threat to development, and specifically to the development of the poorest and most marginalised people in the world. Disasters seek out the poor and ensure they stay poor. The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies annual publication, the World Disasters Report, has highlighted the chronic and rapidly increasing vulnerability of poorer countries to disaster.

The relationship between disasters and the environment is evolving and gradually being better understood. It is an insidious one. Take, for example, the flooding along the Mekong river in 2000. These were the worst floods in decades and came on top of high- level flooding in 1999 and 1998. Why? The monsoon season started early and carried on longer than expected.

But was this just a statistical anomaly, or evidence of climate change? All the climate models suggest that southeast Asia will see more rainfall and higher river levels as a result of global warming: so what happened in 2000 is likely to become the norm, not the exception. The upper reaches of the Mekong catchment in Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam are all subject to extensive logging, much of it illegal and tied up with the funding of paramilitary activity and the opium/ heroin trade. This has led to more rapid runoff and increased flash floods which exacerbate the normal annual flooding.

Those on the flood plains who lose their livestock to the waters, watch them recede with a sense of fatalism. They have been driven two notches further down the ladder to inescapable poverty. For them, investment in local disaster mitigation and preparedness is no more than a pipe dream. A more realistic expectation is that they will fell what few standing trees remain, to sell for firewood. Disaster forces people further into poverty and poverty forces the exploitation of the environment. Governments see their development efforts literally being washed away.

This vicious cycle can be broken, but only if the governments of disaster-prone countries concede that disasters are a major determinant of development, not just unpredictable dips on the development curve. In Vietnam, for instance, this is beginning to happen: disaster mitigation is now a major political and economic issue. In many places, environmental destruction is a key determinant of the movement of people, whether from the destruction wrought by building new large dams or removing rainforest, or from the reduction in the carrying capacity of the land as pastureland erodes to scrub and wasteland.

When people flee and are forced to live in controlled camps, whether as international refugees or internally displaced persons, a whole series of micro-environmental issues come into play. In Africa, the destruction of forest cover around refugee camps is a real cause for concern, as is the exploitation of habitat reserves for game. Erecting fences and keeping the refugees hemmed in, however, is no solution. They fell the trees to survive, because they need the wood to sell or for cooking.

Refugee camps are mini-cities and yet they are run and financed as though they were temporary roadside shelters. They will continue to pose an environmental threat until host governments and the international community are willing to accept the true cost of displacement generated by the environment, war or famine.

Yet disasters sometimes highlight environmental issues which might otherwise go unpublicised. The sheer scale of the destruction and misery often prompts action where years of hidden suffering have failed. After the disaster, there is an opportunity to do things better: to build earthquake-resistant housing; to resettle people away from landslides; to reforest upland catchments; to change agricultural practice. The opportunity is there, but it can easily be missed.

The media focus and the relief efforts around disasters are soon over: they come and go in days or weeks. The challenge for aid agencies and community groups is to keep the government focused on the issues long enough to change economic policy.

In many ways, this is the real relief effort, not the delivery of shelter and food. Relief from floods next year and the year after will not come from emergency deliveries. It will come from changed agricultural practice, access to credit, more integrated landuse planning and a whole host of issues which require a sustained will to improve the lives of the most vulnerable. Generate that and you generate the chance to change the face of disasters.

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Short shrift
fields.body:
Short shrift

Less than one month after Tony Blair promised the UK would "lead the world" in protecting the environment, Clare Short's international development department has had second thoughts and has quietly withdrawn its measly £500,000 funding of wildlife and biodiversity schemes in Britain's six poorest overseas territories.

This is bad news for impoverished former colonies such as Anguilla, Turks & Caicos Islands, St Helena, Tristan da Cunha, Pitcairn and Montserrat, all of which have island ecosystems that support wildlife found nowhere else.

Development pressure is intense in all of them and include a planned airport on Pitcairn, a cruise-ship port for Turks & Caicos, and American holiday homes in the Caribbean mangrove swamps. The RSPB is not impressed: "We're losing species before we even know what was there, so the work we and our partners had planned is very urgent," says Jim Stevenson. "The trouble is there are no votes in the overseas territories."

DfID is unrepentant: "We remain committed to our overseas territories," says a spokesman, a bit lamely. "We're involved in a range of environmental activities."

Dud spud

So farewell the GM spud. Monsanto, a biotech company, has given up selling novel potato seeds to US and Canadian potato farmers. Launched in 1995, Monsanto's NewLeaf potato was advertised to farmers as a way to greatly reduce their spending on pesticides, but NewLeaf never caught on and captured only a little more than 5% of the potato seed market.

It seems that farmers didn't like paying Monsanto's premium prices. "But potatoes are a great niche product," says Monsanto. "We hope some day we can come back to it." Hmmmm.

Rules of the game

Even the dimmest young person travelling to a third world country for the first time will probably realise after an hour or two there that new cultures are a minefield. People get offended if you haggle too aggressively, if you take photos at inappropriate times, if your clothes are too minimal or, shame, if you kiss someone in the street.

But how can you learn the cultural "rules"? Try going to Tourism Concern's national young travellers' conference on ethical travel on April 7-8 in Hulme Hall, Manchester.

To book a place or get programme details, contact Tourism Concern, tel: 020-7753 3330; email: info@tourismconcern. org.uk; or visit their website at www.tourismconcern.org.uk

fields.headline: Energy drive
fields.standfirst: Report shows green measures don't mean cuts in jobs
fields.trailText: Report shows green measures don't mean cuts in jobs.
fields.body:
Environmentalists have long predicted that greening the world's economy will create more jobs than it destroys. Now they have hard evidence, namely a report that documents a green employment boom across the industrialised world.

The study, by the World Watch Institute in Washington DC, estimates that 14m jobs have been created as a direct result of tightening environmental regulations. New job opportunities now exist in a host of buoyant industries, including recycling, goods remanufacture, energy and materials efficiency, and alternative energy development.

Often the demand is so great that people cannot be trained fast enough to fill vacancies that require specific new skills. The rapid development of wind power in Europe, for example, has created great demand for wind meteorologists, as well as for more conventional jobs such as structural engineers, metal workers, and computer operators.

Crucially, the report also refutes the arguments of modern day Luddites, led by the fossil fuel lobby, who argue that environmental gains must be shunned because they cost jobs. It concludes that, to date, "actual job loss due to environmental regulations has been extremely limited" in Western countries.

In the US, for example, annual lay-offs due to the closure of polluting plants have averaged a minuscule 1,000-3,000 workers since the 1970s - less than 0.1% of the 2m Americans laid off most years. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, whose membership includes Britain, reports a similar picture here.

"The losers are likely to be far outnumbered by the winners in the economic shift towards sustainability," says researcher Michael Renner, the report's author. "Contrary to popular belief, alternatives to heavy natural resource use offer substantial employment opportunities."

The report, entitled Working for the Environment: A Growing Source of Jobs, found rapid jobs growth in the following sectors:

Wind power: The wind turbine industry doubled in size between 1997 and 1999 to account for 86,000 jobs worldwide, and by 2020 it may account for 10% of all electricity generation.

Recycling: The worldwide recycling industry processes more than 600m tons of materials a year, has an annual turnover of $160bn and more than 1.5m employees.

Remanufacture: In the US, remanufacturing of used products and product parts, led by Xerox and Canon, is already a $53bn a year business. The Product-Life Institute in Geneva estimates that it accounts for roughly 4% of GDP across the European Union.

Solar power: The US solar photovoltaic industry directly employs almost 20,000 people and indirectly supports 150,000 more jobs in diverse industries such as glass and steel manufacture, electrical and plumbing contracting and architecture. European solar thermal companies employ more than 10,000; and the European industry is expected to grow by at least 70,000 people by 2010.

Energy efficiency: In Germany, 100,000 jobs have been generated by the production, installation and maintenance of more efficient heating and insulation systems. The UK's plans to improve energy efficiency in buildings and boost renewable energy supplies in order to combat climate change will produce an estimated half a million new jobs while reducing annual carbon emissions by 206m tons.

The report points out that resource-based industries - such as mining, logging and fossil fuel extraction - are providing a dwindling number of jobs while remaining among the most polluting human activities. In the US, for example, six industries - mining, utilities, paper, metals, oil refining and chemicals - account for 84% of all toxic pollutants but less than 3% of private sector jobs.

The authors acknowledge that the remaining workforces of such industries will be severely hit over the decades ahead as the world adopts more widespread sustainable technologies. "But", says Renner, "delaying policies in order to mitigate climate change and rein in other forms of environmental degradation would be a far greater job killer than embracing such policies in a proactive fashion."

fields.headline: Hives of industry
fields.standfirst: Oxford's low-tech plan to protect endangered bees
fields.trailText: Oxford's low-tech plan to protect endangered bees.
fields.body:
Oxford University has set up a company aiming "to take the sting out of bee-keeping" and help bees devastated by intensive farming and the varroa parasite brought from the Far East.

Most of the businesses the university has established to exploit its research are at the cutting edge of technology. But the nest boxes produced by the Oxford Bee Company are made from recycled cardboard and biodegradable plastic. Chris O'Toole, director of the university's bee systematics and biology unit, has designed them to attract a species immune to varroa, the red mason bee (Osmia rufa).

The boxes look simple, but their dimensions mimic precisely the favourite nest sites of broody bees. O'Toole says that because his "bee heavens" save females vital time and energy finding and preparing places to nest, they are quickly occupied.

Unlike honey bees, the red mason is solitary and produces no honey. With no hives to protect, it does not sting but it is a highly effective pollinator; 500 will do the work of 60,000 honey bees, according to O'Toole. He calculates that two £18 nest-kits will house enough insects to pollinate a one-hectare orchard.

He admits to "shamelessly exploiting" the traditional British love of animals in a bid to make suburban gardens bee-friendly. "We put out nest boxes for birds, bats, hedgehogs and dormice, so why not bees?" he says. "This species is suffering because the countryside has been sanitised and much of its natural habitat has been lost. Eighty per cent of our crops depend on pollination by bees. It would be catastrophic if they disappeared."

A quarter of Britain's 267 species of wild bee are officially endangered, and at least 10 have become extinct since Victorian times. On the continent, where the parasites are becoming resistant to the chemicals used to protect against varroa, honey bees are even more threatened. The result is that farmers and growers can no longer be confident that valuable fruit and vegetable crops will be pollinated.

The Department of Trade and Industry has high hopes for the company's export potential, and is subsidising its attendance at trade fairs.

fields.headline: Technology equality
fields.standfirst: Safe and easy access to IT is key issue for youngsters in care
fields.trailText: Safe and easy access to IT is key issue for youngsters in care.
fields.body:
Every problem estate should have a fully funded and professionally staffed internet cafe, according to children's charity NCH, which today launches a campaign to highlight the fact that disadvantaged youngsters have most to gain from IT yet often have little access to it.

But vulnerable children are also likely to be most at risk of abuse of the internet once they know how to use it, warns NCH.

Several children's charities, together with ministers and police representatives, are today taking part in a Home Office summit on internet safety and young people. Although ministers have pledged to close the digital divide by 2005, NCH argues that the government is not doing enough to ensure equal, and safe, access to IT for youngsters in care. So as well as running the campaign, called IT OK, the charity is setting up its own unit to advise and influence policy development.

Among NCH's first batch of ideas is a call for all foster parents to be given computers, free of charge, with training and continuing support. They would then be able to offer similar help to young people being cared for in their homes.

Young carers, who have to stay at home to look after siblings or parents, should meanwhile be given computers on loan - with free access to distance learning programmes - so they can keep up with school and college work. And fully funded IT systems should be installed at centres for disabled children and young offenders.

To protect vulnerable young people from "cyber risks", NCH has come up with a nine-point checklist for social care, health and education professionals. This includes a contractual requirement that staff use computers only in connection with their work with young people; and instructions to check that hard drives of second-hand computers do not contain pornographic material.

Deryk Mead, NCH chief executive, says: "New tech presents huge opportunities, as well as big risks, for children and NCH believes that, with the right approach, IT can be OK."

 Further details: www.nch.org.uk/itok

fields.headline: Front... to back
fields.trailText: No holds barred
fields.body:
No holds barred

A leisure centre in Finsbury Park, north London, is offering a skills course to children so that they don't injure their friends when imitating WWF wrestling stars.
Islington Gazette, 1.3.01 (A Milton, London N16)

Dramatic cure

Actors from a theatre in Colchester have been enlisted by a GP from Walton-on-the-Naze, Essex, to teach young doctors how to listen and respond to their patients.
East Anglian Daily Times, 9.3.01 (John White, Clacton-on-Sea)

Reet clever

Students at Hull University's Scarborough campus are being offered a humanities course on Yorkshire culture, ranging from the Brontës to Mel B, the Leeds-born Spice Girl.
Yorkshire Post, 7.3.01 (John Rossington, Bradford)

Sowing doubt

A judge at Nottingham crown court dismissed a case against a man whose garden sprouted five cannabis plants from hemp seed he had scattered for his racing pigeons.
Nottingham Evening Post, 12.3.01 (K Rimmer, Nottingham)

Early learner

A six-week-old baby from Biggin Hill, Kent, has won a course of driving lessons on a raffle ticket bought for him by his father.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 9.3.01 (David Spilsbury, Birmingham)

Kitchen sink drama

A woman in Llanelli, south Wales, had to dial 999 when her washing machine vibrated across the kitchen floor and trapped her against the sink.
Worcestershire Evening Mail, 12.3.01 (Simon Harley, Redditch)

Bright stars

Forty victims of a power blackout in a street in Paignton, Devon, were put up for the night at a four-star seafront hotel in Torquay.
Western Morning News, 15.3.01 (Nicola Neale, Sidmouth)

Plans dashed

A thief stealing a stereo from a car in Peterborough asked passers by to call the police after he got his hand stuck behind the dashboard.
Ad Hoc, 9.3.01 (Francis Harvey, Exeter)

Back to the start

A scrapyard in Woodford, Essex, has sold a man the back seat of an Escort car in which he courted his wife 15 years ago.
Sunday Independent, 18.3.01 (Ray Rose, Plymouth)

Signs of distress

Rush hour traffic in Bristol was brought to a standstill when drivers became confused by diversion signs in Welsh put up at roadworks.
Asphalt Now, spring 01 (Peter Gate, London SE23)

Up before the beak

The owner of a flock of geese on farmland near Preston, Lancashire, faces a charge of disturbing the peace because their honking is annoying a neighbour.
Metro News, 14.3.01 (Nasira Asghar, Stockport)

Stored information

A crime prevention officer in Huddersfield, Yorkshire, has been given an office at the local B&Q store.
Yorkshire Post, 6.3.01 (Peter Tapper, Burnley)

Should have known

The audience at a theatre in Rotherham, Yorkshire, were given their money back when a clairvoyant booked to give a demonstration of her skills failed to turn up because of a mix-up over the date.
Rotherham Advertiser, 16.3.01 (Keith Billington, Rotherham)

Blank looks

An art exhibition in Birmingham has only written descriptions of paintings and sculptures so that visitors have to use their imagination.
West Midlands Metro, 19.3.01 (Karen Barnes, Stratford-upon-Avon)

 Cuttings, preferably from local papers, which reflect interesting or amusing aspects of life in Britain, must be sent on a postcard (with source) to: Society, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. £15 will be paid for each one used.

fields.headline: Culture shock and team bonding
fields.standfirst: Supporters of the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering are trekking across China to raise funds and awareness. And, as Gary Williams reports in the first of a series of diary entries, volunteers are already signing up for next year's adventure
fields.trailText: Supporters of the British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering are trekking across China to raise funds and awareness. And, as Gary Williams reports in the first of a series of diary entries, volunteers are already signing up for next year's adventure.
fields.body:
Having spent the past eight months recruiting our merry band of trekkers, it was great to finally meet them together as a group. What an amazing bunch of people: foster parents, social workers, students, adoptive parents.

Which is not to say that these are all dyed in the wool British Agencies for Adoption and Fostering (BAAF) people. They are however, all committed to improving the situation for children. Participating in this charity trek means they can help BAAF improve the life chances for children in care in the UK while also - I hope - having one of the most memorable trips of a lifetime.

When I gave out the sunflower yellow China Trek 2001 T-shirts at the airport, it was to lighten my luggage but without hesitation everyone put theirs on, which had an immediate effect. People started coming over to ask us what we were doing and this continued throughout the flight - I think we even managed to enlist a few trekkers for China Trek 2002.

I spent the flight sitting next to Avril. She and her husband have been fostering for some years as well as having adopted a small child. I was fascinated to learn from her what it is like to be on the emergency foster rota, which means you might have a traumatised child delivered to your house at 11 o'clock at night. In her years of experience, she has never had a child cause a fuss or even cry on their first night.

Avril explained that many of the children who came to her had often been through so much they had little expectations on arrival and would simply be glad to have some toast, a hot drink and find refuge in bed. A timely reminder of why we are here.

Beijing. After the months of planning we've finally arrived and I'm glad to see the group are thrilled by this new landscape where things seem so familiar and yet so different. There are thousands of people on bikes in the streets just as there are thousands of bird kites flying in the sky, everything is so Chinese - but what did I expect, Blackpool?

Dinner at the hotel. Our first proper meal together as a group, and what fantastic food. I breathe a sigh of relief as the group's vegetarians and vegans announce themselves pleased with the range of food they can tuck into. And then another culture shock - straight from Saturday night 1970s TV - a group of young western dancers in vivid costumes arrive to cheer up our meal yet further. They're clearly designed for and delight their local audience, and it doesn't take long before a large group have their noses pressed against the outside of the hotel window.

Dinner is followed by a whirlwind trip to the stunning Tianamen Square and then a stroll around the night food market where a mind-boggling variety of foods - scorpion, caterpillar or sparrow kebabs - are prepared as you wait. Everyone seems happy to have already eaten but I am sure once our confidence has grown we will be back here later in the trip.

At the end of the day I collapse into bed and reflect on what a wonderfully funny, intelligent and committed group we have assembled here. I can see already they will work well together and this should stand us in good stead for the challenges that still lie ahead of us.

 Gary Williams is head of marketing at BAAF

fields.headline: Asking runaways why
fields.standfirst: Nearly 130,000 children run away from home every year. Most end up on the streets - penniless, lonely and vulnerable.  Diane Taylor  asks former runaways what drove them to it
fields.trailText: Nearly 130,000 children run away from home every year. Most end up on the streets - penniless, lonely and vulnerable. Diane Taylor asks former runaways what drove them to it.
fields.body:
"It's so cold on the streets and so frightening," says Marie, a 20-year-old student who ran away from a Birmingham care home just before she was 16. She felt that she had no choice but to run away because the stepfather who had sexually abused her as a child, which led to her going into care in the first place, kept following her. He would appear and sit next to her as she sat on the bus to school, and hang around the care home.

"When I was 12 he was jailed for the abuse for a while, but it was all over the papers and everyone knew what he had done to me," she says. "In the end, I couldn't stand it and felt the only thing I could do was run away."

She finished her GCSEs, took a job washing up in a restaurant for three weeks to save enough money for a train ticket to London, and then ran.

"The worst thing was that no one would listen to me," she recalls. "I was scared and nervous when I got on the train, but I felt I couldn't go back to the situation I had left behind. Kids will only run away if the situation they are in is so bad that living on the streets seems like a better option. Something has got to be really wrong to make a young person do a thing like that."

Marie was so terrified when she arrived at Euston station that she simply walked the streets for three days - too frightened of what might happen if she lay down and closed her eyes. "I felt so alone in the world," she says. "Nobody in my care home bothered to report me missing. The streets are full of homeless young people crying out for love."

Marie was one of an estimated 129,000 young people who run away each year. The commonest reasons for children taking flight include desperation at not being listened to, rows with parents over the amount of freedom they are allowed, bullying at school, and drug problems or abuse at home.

A new paper from the Social Exclusion Unit, Consultation on Young Runaways, highlights the problem and puts a variety of solutions to the problem out to consultation. By the age of 16, one in nine children will have run away for at least one night, with a quarter of those ending up sleeping rough. Some have to survive through begging, stealing or prostitution, and many are sexually abused on the streets.

While children like Marie, who have been in care, make up a large proportion of runaways (approximately four in 10), the report finds that 21% are fleeing stepfamilies, and 13% one-parent families, compared to 7% who live with both birth parents. But, contrary to stereotype, poverty was found not to be a significant factor leading to young people running away: those from leafy suburbs are just as likely to flee as those from deprived inner-city areas. The majority of runaways are aged between 13 and 16 and are more likely to be girls than boys (although boys tend to run away earlier and more often). It is not only a problem of troubled adolescence: an estimated 18,000 children under 11 also run away each year, of whom about a third are under eight. Shockingly, a further 18,000 children a year are thrown out by their parents. The report also notes that the longer runaways are away, the more vulnerable they become.

There is no national network of services in place, so emergency organisations like Childline find it very hard to refer children who phone in a crisis to appropriate local services. The report proposes a series of measures both to prevent young people from running away in the first place, and to provide decent support services when they do.

Plans include an interview for each young person who has run away to identify the reasons for fleeing, and to try to tackle them rather than just dumping the children back in the situation from which they have fled; a network of refuges so that young people are not forced to live rough; and the establishment of a named person in each area to co-ordinate services for runaways.

Chris, now 20, ran away from numerous care placements about 20 times. He believes that refuges are essential, but also that fundamental changes in the care system are necessary. "I was frightened on the streets," he recalls, "but I also felt free. I shoplifted to survive. I received no support in care. Nobody listened and I was bullied. For me, living on the streets was better than that."

Much of the data in the government's new report comes from research carried out by the Children's Society, which has been working with young runaways for the past 20 years. The charity's Penny Dean welcomed the report, but is urging the government to implement some of the proposals - such as providing children with interviews - right away rather than await the outcome of the three-month consultation process. A Social Exclusion Unit spokesman has responded that this would not be possible.

"I really hope the government won't delay over this," says Dean. "Young runaways are a very hard to reach group who need a lot of support. A lot of these young people view statutory agencies with mistrust, and we need a mechanism to draw together expertise from the voluntary sector to deliver the services young people want."

She condemns the lack of funding for refuges - Centrepoint in London is the only one in Britain - and argues that, although the concept of children's refuges was established in the 1989 Children Act, the money to run them has not been forthcoming from the government. Without such refuges, there is no safety net to protect children from the dangers of the streets. Besides the government recommendations, the Children's Society is calling for more early intervention to prevent running away; support and mediation for parents and children where families have divorced, separated or reformed, and more ethnically sensitive services.

Dorit Braun, of Parentline Plus, expresses concern about the number of children who run away from stepfamilies. Jealousy of a parent's new partner can fuel conflict between children and adults in stepfamilies, she says. "Many children do adjust well, but a small minority don't. The young people and the adults in a stepfamily need to be given time to understand each other. The dynamics of a stepfamily are much more complex than those in an intact family, and stepparents can be viewed by children as interfering and making a difficult situation worse."

The government has highlighted a small project in Gloucester called Astra (Alternative Solutions to Running Away), which employs just three part-time workers, as a model of good practice. The project works with young people who have run away to prevent recurrences. Staff listen to young people's concerns and then try to work with them, their parents and other agencies (such as schools and social services) to find solutions with which both the young people and their parents or carers are happy. Police estimate that the project has reduced the number of repeat runaways by 61%.

One former runaway, Sally, 14, says the project has helped her resolve a difficult situation with her mother: "My mum didn't like my friends, the way I dressed or the fact that I wore make-up, and she didn't like me going out. One day, I just didn't go home from school. I was scared because I didn't know where I could go. In the end, I stayed at a friend's house. Astra talked to my mum and talked to me. Now she gives me a bit more freedom, I understand her better and she understands me better."

Now that Marie is settled in London, studying for a university degree and living in a flat that a Children's Society-supported tenancy project helped to secure for her, the days of trudging around the capital's West End with nowhere to go seem very far off.

"I love my home," she says. "I've got my own front room, my own bedroom, a cat, friends and a normal life. I don't ever want to go through what I went through again. And if young people like me had more rights, they wouldn't have to either."
