fields.headline: Running battle to plug gaps
fields.trailText: The coincidence of the two events could not have been more poignant. Last Thursday morning, the prime minister launched a new drive to protect runaway children. In the afternoon, a team of child specialists, who had run the Children Society's refuge for runaways in Leeds, met for a farewell party following its closure late last year.
fields.body:
The coincidence of the two events could not have been more poignant. Last Thursday morning, the prime minister launched a new drive to protect runaway children. In the afternoon, a team of child specialists, who had run the Children Society's refuge for runaways in Leeds, met for a farewell party following its closure late last year.

Where once there were four refuges for such children, now there is only one - Centrepoint, in London. The stark statistics in last week's report from the social exclusion unit (SEU) set out the dimensions and the risks. By the age of 16, one in nine children has run away for a night. Most find a temporary home with family or friends but 25% sleep rough, 13% suffer physical harm, and 8% sexual assault. One in 14 ends up surviving through begging, stealing, drug dealing or prostitution.

Runaways, as exasperated charity workers have noted, are "everybody's concern but nobody's responsibility". They fall through the welfare net, crossing geographical as well as service boundaries. But now a national strategy, with Downing Street's backing, is promised. There is delight at the Children's Society, which has campaigned on the issue for 20 years.

But will the new consultation process still further delay developments which ought to be happening now? We do need a national network of services for runaways, but we need a preventive strategy too. Four out of five run because of problems at home - parental conflict, physical or sexual abuse. Most want to go back but with the conflict resolved. Childline can help, but it needs more child-centred agencies to which it can refer callers. Wider provision of school support (mentors, peer groups, counsellors) is one front. More child advocates and family mediators are other options.

We need more flexible safe places: refuges, yes - but they are incredibly expensive. Emergency foster homes and even B&B with foster carers could help. Post-runaway services can stop repeat runners. These include family group conferences, mediation, plus independent interviews by child advocates.

Whitehall also needs to look at why we have had to wait so long. The initial refuges were set up by bending the law. Technically, the Children's Society could have been prosecuted for "harbouring" runaways. This was changed by the 1989 Children Act, but still no statutory refuges emerged - nor state funds for charitable refuges. State agencies did not refer the children: ipso facto, no state money. It was absurd. They were unsustainable without state aid. Children continued to turn to them. Only when the last two announced closure was one saved. As Tony Blair noted: "We must find a better way."

fields.headline: The Guardian graduate jobs email
fields.trailText: In a week that saw radical songwriter and sixties top cat Bob Dylan turn 60, here is this week's Subterranean Homesick Blues Email from The Guardian's graduate section Rise - the next move for radical young professionals.
fields.body:
In a week that saw radical songwriter and sixties top cat Bob Dylan turn 60, here is this week's Subterranean Homesick Blues Email from The Guardian's graduate section Rise - the next move for radical young professionals.

For those still looking to sell out to the corporate world, we take a look at the best graduate jobs offered by Guardian Unlimited Jobs - the website devoted to finding you the best vacancies. Hey, it ain't me babe.

We also review last Saturday's Rise and take a sneak preview of next week's issue. In addition we've included a link to a past article featured in Rise that we think is worth a second read in Rise Gold.

If you were too busy playing Dylan's Blood on the Tracks album at the weekend, this is what you missed in LAST WEEK'S RISE (Saturday 24 March)

If you are starting to fill in job applications and are struggling with the personal statement sections, Irene Krechowiecka has some good advice for you. Apparently it's not what you say, but how you say it.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,462101,00.html?bnv=email.grad

There was also our guide on how to survive working nights. More than 17% of us work nights and it can be hard. However, avoid the coffee maker and get plenty of exercise and you might quite like it.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,462098,00.html?bnv=email.grad

There was advice on how to clear your debts before you get to Lord Dylan's age, and the ever-fabulous Sixty Seconds column talked to community pharmacist Nick Trollope.

NEXT WEEK'S RISE offers our exclusive league table of the employers that graduates most want to work for. Ian Wylie offers his tips on how to pass the GMAT tests required for some MBA courses and there's a look at secondments in the first year of work. And just to prove we look after both mind and body at Rise, there is even a look at how detoxing can improve your effectiveness.

This week's RISE GOLD is a look at how to survive your first job. Ian Wylie offers his graduate starter guide and suggests it pays to remember that you are starting at the bottom, and the only way is up.
http://www.theguardian.com/Archive/Article/0,4273,4035759,00.html?bnv=email.grad

THIS WEEK'S TOP TIP
If you are desperate to get into postgraduate study but don't have the funds, try getting one of the many little-known-about bursaries that are kicking around. For example, there is a cheeky £1,000 for anyone studying religion and education in Northern Ireland - now's the time to get on the bursary trail.

THIS WEEK'S HOTTEST JOBS

Chocolate lovers look no further. Cadbury Trebor Bassett is looking for grads to start its 12 month structured impact development programme which it says will "test your entrepreneurial flair to the max". £16K and a "company vehicle". Just warn your dentist.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100109721,00.html?bnv=email.grad

If you know all about low pay and have a 2.1 or better, Middlesex University is looking for researchers to work on a project entitled "Low Pay and Pensions: planning for old age in a world of insecurity". Doesn't mention the salary.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100110697,00.html?bnv=email.grad

International Power is offering a very attractive £24K to sign up to its grad scheme. The company generates power around the world and could send you out to one of its sites. You have to have a 2.1 or better, and be prepared to spend a month working at a power station.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100110153,00.html?bnv=email.grad

Fidelity Investments has just been voted one of the 50 best companies to work for by the Sunday Times - so it can't be all bad. It's looking for grads with degrees in any subject to join its IT department and training's provided - you'd hope so anyway.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100110140,00.html?bnv=email.grad

If your thoughts are turning away from a proper job and more towards having a great summer, Buckswood is looking for grads to work at its kids' summer camps in the south east and is promising good pay.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100110670,00.html?bnv=email.grad

In the beginning was The Word - and that word was youth TV. Now Planet 24, the company behind that show, and more recently The Big Breakfast, has launched a graduate scheme. Prepare to enter the scary world of daytime TV.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100110359,00.html?bnv=email.grad

If you quite fancy becoming a PA but haven't got the secretarial experience, read on. A recruitment company is looking for someone to look after a "delightful" chairman. You'll be organising his travel and diary arrangements "as well as all aspects of his hectic personal life". Does that mean dry cleaning?
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100110553,00.html?bnv=email.grad

Want to become a big game hunter in the City? hwc consulting is looking for a trainee head hunter with a sound academic background. More pin stripe than safari suit, perhaps.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100110499,00.html?bnv=email.grad

And finally, if you are a foot fetishist or simply someone who likes shoes, Hobbs is looking for retail management trainees to manage its shops in the future. Budding Imelda Marcoses get a 50% discount.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100110301,00.html?bnv=email.grad

fields.headline: Best is yet to come
fields.standfirst: Critics say the 'best value' initiative has failed in its first year to transform local services, but the director of inspections tells Steve Brown that patience will bring real rewards
fields.trailText: Critics say the 'best value' initiative has failed in its first year to transform local services, but the director of inspections tells Steve Brown that patience will bring real rewards.
fields.body:
Birthdays are usually a time for celebration. But as the government's "best value" initiative, introduced to transform town hall services across the country, next week reaches its first anniversary, those charged with monitoring the new initiative are hardly in a mood to party.

A report from the audit commission's best value inspection service earlier this month called for councils to demonstrate a "step-change in performance" in year two of the new regime. Councils were accused of lacking ambition in what they could achieve with best value. They were still said to be shying away from competition and "making a priority of keeping services in-house". And some council officers were found to be showing signs of a "compliance mentality", concerned more with satisfying inspectors than with ramping up service levels.

But it is not all bad. Wendy Thomson, the commission's director of inspection, says the first year has produced a "mixed story". The need for greater pace and real improvements does not mean the commission is completely dissatisfied with progress. "What we are incredibly pleased with is that we do have, for the first time, a comprehensive performance management system," she insists. "That has never been there before. And actually there is an incredibly high degree of understanding and knowledge of it."

Thomson points to earlier initiatives such as best value's predecessor, compulsory competitive tendering. "It took a long time before people knew what CCT was," she says. In comparison, she argues, best value has almost become part of everyday language, at least inside town halls. Add to this the successful publication of 410 best value performance plans on time last March, which she describes as an "humongous enterprise", and councils can feel some sense of achievement.

These successes are unlikely to cut much ice with the public or with ministers, impatient to see their policies delivering the transformation they promised. But Thomson says visible proof of the impact of best value on public services will take time.

Under best value, councils have to review all their services over a five year period. That means that councils will, on average, review just 20% of their services each year. It will take well over two years before major changes can be implemented and any movement in performance can be measured. And this is just one-fifth of a council's output.

Thomson says that there needs to be recognition that transformational change takes time. "You need to have patience," she says. "You just have to stick with it."

Inspectors usually go in when councils have completed a best value review. With more than 600 inspections planned for the first year and just over 60 reports published by mid-March (although reports are now appearing almost daily), it is undoubtedly early days to be making sweeping judgments about best value. But it is already clear that there is substantial room for improvement. Some 28 services have been assessed as one-star, or "fair", and a further 32 have been given a two-star, or "good", rating. Just three councils have won three-star "excellent" ratings, and one authority, Stockport, has received a no-star "poor" rating for its housing allocations service.

But it is the inspectors' second judgment, on a council's likelihood to improve, that is being watched most avidly. A two-star service that is unlikely to improve may well be seen as more problematic than a "fair" service where improvement is a good bet. And, alarmingly, about half the councils inspected so far were assessed either as not being in a position to improve or as unlikely to improve.

Although further no-star ratings are believed to be lurking in the wings, Thomson dismisses as a "conspiracy theory" the suggestion that the commission is sitting on the worst reports. However, a number of damning reports are expected over the coming weeks - unless they fall foul of the purdah that will be imposed if a May general election is called.

But can the inspection service point to any clear cases where improvements are being made as a result of the efforts of inspectors, and not just because of the best value review process? Thomson points out that inspectors are playing different roles in different places. But she says it is the "complacent middle" where they are having most impact. "There are some districts in this country that have never had any external challenge at all," she says. "It is a shock for them to have people come in and question [their practices]."

According to Thomson, Stockport provides a good example of a fundamental difference made by the inspection service. The inspectors' assessment of the housing allocation service was at odds with the council's own best value review. "[The] Stockport [report] described in pretty horrific detail a council doing terribly badly," she says. It produced a list of weaknesses requiring "urgent" attention, including not having a published summary of its allocations policy and failing to implement the commission for racial equality's code of practice for rented housing. Thomson's point is that the self-review failed and, without the inspectors' involvement, many of the problems would not now be being addressed.

The council's dire assessment was tempered by the inspectors' conclusion that the service would probably improve, partly because the council moved swiftly following an early preview of the report to put in place a revised action plan to address the exposed weaknesses.

Thomson insists that inspectors do not revel in finding poor performance. "We are not interested in getting publicity for kicking people," she says. "We're interested in getting change. [Stockport] convinced us that they were going to do something and introduce radical change. That is more important than me getting publicity on the Today programme. Naming and shaming is pretty easy to get publicity for, but it doesn't actually change very much."

Many councils remain unconvinced of the need for such rigorous inspection, seeing it as a further example of central government's lack of trust in town halls. But it is the inspectors' powers to recommend intervention and bring in a third party to run a failing service that authorities find alarming.

Thomson, however, seems keen to avoid the inevitable legal wrangles that would follow any such recommendation. "We are erring on getting people's consent," she says. "We believe that if you've made the case for change, and they've accepted it, you get a lot more action that way than if you write a command-and-control note."

This reluctance to use its most extreme weapon - recommending intervention - is best demonstrated in the inspection service's response to the problems facing Hackney, the east London borough torn apart by severe financial problems and hamstrung by political in-fighting. A special report last November, triggered by the district auditor's concerns over the borough's best value performance plan, concluded that the council could not improve its governance arrangements alone - although it recommended that accountability for the running of the council should remain with elected councillors and officers. Again, Thomson says that an approach built on consensus was the right way forward.

"Hackney agreed with our assessment and agreed to do what we said, including bringing in extra capacity to achieve change," she says. "It didn't require a lot of strong-arming."

A number of inspections so far, including that of Stockport, have been of reviews undertaken voluntarily before best value officially got under way and before any guidance had been issued on how to conduct reviews. So it is, perhaps, not surprising to find criticisms of the review processes. But it is clear the inspectors will be looking for major improvements in future, particularly in the application of the "four Cs" of best value: challenge, comparison, consultation and competition.

"Competition and challenge need to get more rigorous in some places in year two," says Thomson. There are signs of a changing culture towards competition; Liverpool and Sheffield are dramatic examples of shifting attitudes, but the change is more widespread. "Everyone is talking about partnerships with the private sector now. No one did a few years ago."

Perhaps the biggest change that inspectors will be looking for is a realisation that it is results that matter. "People think we'll be interested in process and compliance with procedures," she says. "But we are surprising people and saying that unless it has resulted in change, it's inadequate."

Cleaner streets, higher standards of housing and better local services - these are the things that the public wants to see. According to Thomson, the inspection service aims to ensure it gets them.

webTitle: Racist abuse mars England U-21 win

fields.headline: Racist abuse mars England win
fields.standfirst: Greening 68pen
fields.trailText: Jonathan Greening's second-half penalty secured victory yesterday, but the match was marred by the racial abuse of England's black players.
fields.byline: Richard Williams  at the Qemal Stafa stadium
fields.body:
An official complaint went to Uefa from the Football Association last night following the persistent racial abuse of two of England's black players during yesterday's match here in Tirana.

The baiting of Darius Vassell and Shola Ameobi led an FA spokesman to insist on immediate action rather than "the customary platitudes", a demand made more urgent by the fact that tonight's senior match between the two countries will be at the same venue.

The FA spokesman Paul Newman said: "There is no reason why it should be acceptable to have any player from any country abused in this way. We will be urging the removal of any fans who repeat this kind of abuse during tomorrow's game."

Jonathan Greening's second-half penalty decided yesterday's match, which was prefaced by the sacking of the Albanian coaches and the rejection of the designated pitch by Howard Wilkinson, the England coach, who saw his players fail to capitalise on a series of chances but afterwards praised their application throughout a match of many stoppages.

Greening and Luke Chadwick, the two Manchester United wingers, teamed up to tear apart the right flank of the Albanian defence time and again throughout the first half, but no concrete reward was forthcoming until the 68th minute, when Greening accepted Chadwick's quick throw-in and raced into the area, only to be tripped by Ardit Beqiri. Worse, the wing-back's unwise decision to dispute the decision by racing up to the referee and bumping chests produced an immediate red card.

Nevertheless Albania deserved credit for holding England to the narrowest of margins, particularly since their coaching staff had been dismissed in the hours after Friday night's 8-0 defeat in Germany. Hito Hitaj, the tech nical director of the national federation, picked up the reins on Sunday, brought in three new defenders and took some satisfaction from a much improved performance, although his post-match summary referred to "problems within Albanian football which can't be solved in the short term".

Wilkinson's reasons for satisfaction, besides the contribution of two of the three-man Old Trafford contingent, included another composed performance from John Terry, who wore the captain's armband for the first time in the 4-0 win against Finland on Friday and again looked comfortable in the role.

The England coach had insisted on a change of venue after his players had been unable to train properly on the scheduled pitch at the Selman Stermasi stadium, which he described as "horrendous". At Tirana's main stadium no more than a few hundred spectators had assembled to greet the players, the crowd outnumbered not only by the attendant police but by those who bypassed the system and clustered on the skeletons of the half-built apartment blocks that overlook the ground.

Albania (5-3-2): Mustafa; A Beqiri, E Beqiri, Malaj, Sheta, Muka (Gjondedaj, 79min); Bulku, Babamusta (Dhembi, h-t), Merxha (Demiraj, 71); Besballov, Rizvanolli.

England (4-1-4-1): Weaver (Man City); Young (Tottenham Hotspur), Rigott (Derby; Bramble , Ipswich, 25), Terry (Chelsea), Barry (Aston Villa); Davis (Fulham); Christie (Derby; Ameobi , Newcastle, 57), Wilson (Man Utd; Parker , Charlton, 57), Greening, Chadwick (both Man Utd); Vassell (Aston Villa).

webTitle: Eriksson honeymoon could turn into holiday from hell in Albania

fields.headline: Eriksson honeymoon could turn into holiday from hell in Albania
fields.trailText: Sky TV's Clare Tomlinson joins the dots for clues as to how the Eriksson reign will pan out after this frenzied opening period.
fields.body:
After a friendly kickabout at Villa Park and, despite an agonising finale, three valuable points when things got serious at Anfield, we are beginning to get a sense of our new Swedish bride. Sven-Goran Eriksson will be re-examined every time he picks a team, but right now the clear impression is that we want this foreign marriage to work.

Eriksson is so different from previous incumbents. Where Kevin Keegan was volatile and hyper, Eriksson is laid-back and relaxed. Where Glenn Hoddle was minutely interested in every element of the itinerary, Eriksson is content to leave such details to his administration staff. Where Terry Venables took direct charge of training sessions, Eriksson stands to the side, observing.

Where previous coaches railed against international week's national pastime, "Guess the England team", Eriksson merely smiles and shrugs off direct questions. But so far no one has trumpeted his line-up.

He rarely reads the newspapers and when he does his choice is broadsheet rather than tabloid. Paranoid he is not. He doesn't care what went before or how his predecessors coped.

He gives nothing away. Asked to describe his style of management, he directs you to ask the players. When told they think he is studious and serene, he smiles - and changes the subject.

Within the England camp this smile is a regular feature of life. I witnessed it myself last week as I enjoyed a cup of tea at the squad's Cheshire HQ with my former colleagues from the FA's media department. He walks about the hotel, beaming and relaxed, his disposition approachable and informal.

There are no mood swings with Eriksson. The players know where they stand and their respect for him is unmistakable. To a man, they praise his ability to communicate and are clearly enjoying the atmosphere of calm he engenders.

And curiously, this tranquillity seems also to pervade the media battalions. There has been a quiet acceptance of reduced access to the coach and a resigned recognition that, when he does give a press conference, little new will be forthcoming.

As with many of his predecessors, dealing with the media is not a part of the job Eriksson relishes. After my 10-minute, one-on-one interview for Sky Sports pre-Finland - the first of his media commitments that day - he looked genuinely shocked when I suggested that he still had well over an hour of questioning to face.

Yet he loves the interest that the game inspires in this country. He thrives on our passion for football in the same way as the Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger.

When he first came to England, Arsène constantly exhorted me, as his press officer, to reduce his media commitments, but was fascinated by the nation's insatiable appetite for the sport. Mostly because it matched his own. When managing Monaco, he would come over here at Christmas just to see some matches and escape the French league's winter break.

And just as Wenger took stock of the situation at Highbury before gradually imposing his own ideas and personality, Eriksson too has been observing and evaluating before making adjustments.

Ultimately Eriksson's tenure as England coach will be judged in the same way as all his predecessors. Results are everything, performances a bonus which make the ride easier.

Yet after mere months here and only two games in charge, there is a feeling of some optimism regarding his selection policies. He is determined that players should be deployed in positions familiar to them; a simple strategy perhaps, but one that had previously been mislaid.

Intriguingly, it appears that we can look forward to some continuity. Had Steven Gerrard not succumbed to the inevitable, there was even the possibility that we might have seen an unchanged side in Albania tonight. But then injuries have always been the bane of the England coach's life and luck is perhaps as crucial a factor as judgment.

By all accounts the Albanians were unlucky not to earn a draw in Germany at the weekend. Yet England expects nothing less than three more qualifying points. Anything short of that would not just end Eriksson's honeymoon, it might even put the Swede's serenity to the test.

Clare Tomlinson is a Sky TV football reporter

fields.headline: England can pass Wisdom test
fields.trailText: Nicky Butt will join Paul Scholes in midfield as replacement for Steven Gerrard in what is likely to be the only change tonight. David Lacey looks ahead to the game.
fields.body:
Sir Norman Wisdom, who made a career of pratfalls and is a legend in Albania, turned up at England's training session yesterday to meet a squad of players for whom he must be as remote a figure as Bud Flanagan or Arthur Askey.

Which was just as well since Sven-Goran Eriksson's relatively youthful England side were unlikely to be seeking inspiration from an 86-year-old English comedian, one of whose most successful films was Trouble in Store.

Whatever trouble England encounter during tonight's World Cup qualifier is likely to be self-inflicted, even though Albania are no pushovers; all their team have played abroad, and the narrowness of Saturday's 2-1 defeat in Germany will have put England on their guard. But as Eriksson said: "This is a game we should win. We can't make mistakes if we want to get to the World Cup."

Quite so. Saturday's edgy 2-1 victory over Finland began the salvage operation necessary after the 1-0 defeat by Germany last October which prompted Kevin Keegan's resignation, and England can ill afford a repetition of the poor marking and deep defending that nearly cost them further points at the weekend.

Tonight's team is likely to show only the change forced by the predictable withdrawal of Steven Gerrard with his back problem. "It will not be a revolution," said Eriksson. "Apart from Gerrard it will more or less be the same side."

Thus Nicky Butt will almost certainly join Paul Scholes in midfield to give Manchester United five representatives in the team, as many from one club for a competitive game as England had for a World Cup qualifier with Luxembourg in 1977, when Ron Greenwood included a Liverpool quintet.

That night England won 2-0, and they beat Albania by the same score on their only previous visit here, a World Cup match early in 1989 when Bobby Robson needed respite after his team's flop in the 1988 European Championship.

For Eriksson the ovens are barely on gas mark one, although yesterday he was asked by an Albanian journalist if his job would be in jeopardy should England lose. "We'll have to see after tomorrow" was the polite reply.

Eriksson knows that, provided the Football Association keeps its promise and nerve, even a failure to qualify for next year's World Cup would be regarded as part of the learning process for better things expected from the 2006 tournament in Germany. A bad result tonight, though, and the media's patience will have run out by tomorrow morning.

Yet if England can get their game together earlier than they did against Finland and avoid a similarly fraught finish, another two-goal win is probable, with the critical daggers staying sheathed.

Eriksson is no more likely to criticise individual members of his squad than a mother whose baby bawls at a funeral. There are, however, a number of improvements from Saturday which he will expect.

"We need to move the ball more quickly and make better runs," he said. "And in the last 15 minutes against Finland we were struggling and needed to keep the ball upfield more."

Albania are unlikely to apply the physical pressure which, combined with the skills of Jari Litmanen, would have denied England their win had David Seaman not been in excellent form. At the same time Eriksson is aware of the Albanians' ability to strike swiftly from defensive positions.

Butt's resilient qualities could be important here; as Eriksson said, "he runs for 90 minutes and tactically he is very good. He is not good to play against".

Geri Cipi, who is likely to switch from marker to libero to make up for the loss of Rudi Vata, Albania's suspended captain, caught the England coach's eye when he watched the Germany game on TV. England will also need to alert themselves to Bledar Kola's creative skills and Igli Tare's combination of height and technique up front.

Rio Ferdinand and Sol Campbell need to decide who is in charge. David Beckham will be expected to captain the side with the sense of leadership which did so much to regain the initiative at Anfield and retrieve a 1-0 deficit. Andy Cole may not be expected to score, having failed to break his England duck in 12 attempts, but will surely get further chances.

Yesterday Norman Wisdom clearly wanted to be photographed shaking the captain's hand but Beckham, who knows his caption writers, was having none of it. Never mind. Should England screw up tonight the whole squad can record Don't Laugh At Me 'Cos I'm A Fool.

England (probable, 4-4-2): Seaman; G Neville, Ferdinand, Campbell, Powell; Beckham, Butt, Scholes, McManaman; Cole, Owen.

fields.headline: Albania 1 - 3 England
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Albania: 1-Foto Strakosha; 2-Altin Lala, 5-Ervin Fakaj, 4-Arian Xhumba, 3-Geri Cipi, 6-Besnik Hasi, 9-Bledar Kola, 7-Arjan Bellai, 10-Fatmir Vata, 8-Alban Bushi, 11-Igli Tare. Substitutes: Beqaj, Rraklli, Muka, Duro, Skela, Dede, Fortuzi.

England: 1-David Seaman; 3-Ashley Cole, 5-Rio Ferdinand, 6-Sol Campbell, 2-Gary Neville; 4-Nicky Butt, 11-Steve McManaman, 7-David Beckham (captain), 8-Paul Scholes; 10-Michael Owen, 9-Andy Cole. Substitutes: Phil Neville, Nigel Martyn, Wes Brown, Jamie Carragher, Emile Heskey, Teddy Sheringham, Robbie Fowler.

Referee: Alain Hamer (Luxembourg).

1 A late change for England marks the debut of Arsenal's Ashley Cole, who comes in for Chris Powell. Nicky Butt of course replaces the unjured Steven Gerrard. England get the game underway but it is Albania who set the early running when they break down their left with Bushi.
2 MacManaman tries some early movement down the England left but is ushered out of play.
5 Albania doing a reasonable job of pinning England back in the opening minutes before the away side win the first corner of the match from a Beckham inspired break down the right. Beckham takes and - surprise, surpise - Andy Cole spurns the first chance of the game.
9 Beckham free-kick wide on the right; played towards Campbell on the far post but he is unable to knock it back with any conviction.
10 Another corner to England; Campbell rushes in at the near post but it is Cole who gets the knock-down - to no avail.
14 Albania free-kick some 30 yards out; no threat to Seaman.
15 MacManaman plays in Ashley Cole wide on the left; Albania clear after a slip-up in the area that almost lets in MacManaman.
16 A moment of danger for England when Albania pressure the England area with Tare. The crowd find their voices as a result.
17 A half-chance for England when Albania keeper Strakosha misses a cross completely only for Andy Cole to be poorly positioned for the unexpected chance that resulted.
21 After a couple of minutes of what could politely be called upped tempo, the game has settled down into a fairly dull affair. England need to hang on to the ball and grind out the openings, especially now that Strakosha has revealed himself as a weak link in goal.
23 Vata tries to get away on the right and acts well to win a free-kick 25 yards out. Ferdinand clears. Albania don't give up as Tare tries to play in Kola.
25 Albania doing their bit to make a match of it by pinning England back in their own half. Campbell limps off injured to receive treatment on the sideline.
28 Strakosha makes a right hash of things again when he tries to beat Scholes to a Beckham ball into the six-yard box and gifts England a corner. Beckham takes but Strakosha punches clear.
29 Substitution Brown on for the injured Campbell.
30 Brown gives away a free-kick with his first touch of the game, 25 yards out and square on to goal; unclear why Brown was penalised. Tare takes the free-kick and fires over the bar.
32 England free-kick 25 yards out. Beckham takes, curls it beautifully around the wall and Strakosha redeems himself with a cracking save.
36 Owen strides through the midfield before finding Beckham on the right; Beckham's cross is cleared by Cipi. Two corners in succession for England, neither of which come to anything. England utterly unable to make things happen in the final third.
39 Beckham corner on the right, Ferdinand up... another corner. Beckham plays it back to Neville for a one-two but Albania intercept and clear.
42 Booking Lala for a foul on Tinky-Winky. Beckham takes the free-kick from 25 yards, but Strakosha again does well to get down at the near post and save.
45 Two minutes extra to play. Albania free-kick 30 yards out, Kola takes but it is deflected wide. Half-time.

46 Substitution Heskey on for MacManaman. Albania get the second 45 underway. Owen caught offside as he and Cole make an early push upfield.
48 Neville sets off on a run up the right, but his ball into Andy Cole is poor - Xhumba clears.
49 Concerted pressure from England before Hasi breaks through midfield to give Albania some respite.
50 Andy Cole wins a free-kick just over 20 yards out. Beckham takes straight at the wall. Comes out to Scholes who fires it into Heskey at the far post; Strakosha gets a fingertip to it to deny Heskey.
52 Shocking behaviour by the linesman when England are denied a corner and almost a throw-in before the ref steps in.
53 England corner, Albania clear.
55 Hairy moment for Engalnd when Vata fires in from distance and Seaman has trouble holding the ball after a deflection.
57 Kola breaks and looks for Bushi on the right as Albania pressure again.
58 Still Albania dictating the pace of the game as Ferdinand forces things wide for a corner. Brown clears, Beckham finds Ashley Cole up on the right for the Arsenal player to loop it over the top for Owen to chase - too far.
81 England denied a penalty after Cipi crashes into Butt and flattens him in the box.
63 Albania running around with increasing confidence as Bushi has a crack from distance.
65 England corner, Beckham from the left, Strakosha spills before claiming.
67 Expect headlines filled with the words "false dawn" should England fail to improve on their display so far.
69 Beckham gets into area but is stopped in his tracks. The ball comes to Andy Cole on the by-line and he fires it across goal for Strakosha to deny Heskey on the far post.
73 Increasingly desperate for England as Albania push up again.
74 GOAL: Albania 0 - 1 England Butt plays Owen through into the area for the Liverpool player to jab past Strakosha with his right foot. About time.
76 A great ball in by Beckham; all it needed was a touch by Andy Cole at the far post. Did it get it? Did it heck.
78 Albania's second corner of the night, Beckham clears.
79 Heskey tries to feed Andy Cole through on goal by Cifi cuts out the chance.
80 Lala causes a momentary panic in the England area when England make a mess of clearing the ball.
82 Substitution Muka on for Kola. Booking Neville for time-wasting, apparently while waiting for Albania to complete the substitution.
84 Substitution Sheringham on for Owen.
85 GOAL: Albania 0 - 2 England Scholes plays in Andy Cole on the left of the area. Cole drifts along the by-line and lays it back for Scholes to shoot into the roof of the net from close range.
87 Booking Andy Cole
Substitution Rraklli on for Fakaj.
90 Five minutes extra to play. And what happens GOAL: Albania 1 - 2 England Indecision by Ferdinand allows Rraklli to get a late consolation to leave England hanging on for the dying moments. And if that wasn't enough, Rraklli finds the net again in the next minute only to be ruled offside. And then, would you believe it... GOAL: Albania 1 - 3 England. Andy Cole finally breaks his duck when he puts away England's third. Full-time.
Fraught for England at the end, and by no means an easy or pretty game, but it's the points that count.

England get the game underway but it is Albania who set the early running when they break down their left with Bushi. 2 MacManaman tries some early movement down the England left but is ushered out of play. 5 Albania doing a reasonable job of pinning England back in the opening minutes before the away side win the first corner of the match from a Beckham inspired break down the right. Beckham takes and - surprise, surpise - Andy Cole spurns the first chance of the game. 9 Beckham free-kick wide on the right; played towards Campbell on the far post but he is unable to knock it back with any conviction. 10 Another corner to England; Campbell rushes in at the near post but it is Cole who gets the knock-down - to no avail. 14 Albania free-kick some 30 yards out; no threat to Seaman. 15 MacManaman plays in Ashley Cole wide on the left; Albania clear after a slip-up in the area that almost lets in MacManaman. 16 A moment of danger for England when Albania pressure the England area with Tare. The crowd find their voices as a result. 17 A half-chance for England when Albania keeper Strakosha misses a cross completely only for Andy Cole to be poorly positioned for the unexpected chance that resulted. 21 After a couple of minutes of what could politely be called upped tempo, the game has settled down into a fairly dull affair. England need to hang on to the ball and grind out the openings, especially now that Strakosha has revealed himself as a weak link in goal. 23 Vata tries to get away on the right and acts well to win a free-kick 25 yards out. Ferdinand clears. Albania don't give up as Tare tries to play in Kola. 25 Albania doing their bit to make a match of it by pinning England back in their own half. Campbell limps off injured to receive treatment on the sideline. 28 Strakosha makes a right hash of things again when he tries to beat Scholes to a Beckham ball into the six-yard box and gifts England a corner. Beckham takes but Strakosha punches clear. 29 Substitution Brown on for the injured Campbell. 30 Brown gives away a free-kick with his first touch of the game, 25 yards out and square on to goal; unclear why Brown was penalised. Tare takes the free-kick and fires over the bar. 32 England free-kick 25 yards out. Beckham takes, curls it beautifully around the wall and Strakosha redeems himself with a cracking save. 36 Owen strides through the midfield before finding Beckham on the right; Beckham's cross is cleared by Cipi. Two corners in succession for England, neither of which come to anything. England utterly unable to make things happen in the final third. 39 Beckham corner on the right, Ferdinand up... another corner. Beckham plays it back to Neville for a one-two but Albania intercept and clear. 42 Booking Lala for a foul on Tinky-Winky. Beckham takes the free-kick from 25 yards, but Strakosha again does well to get down at the near post and save. 45 Two minutes extra to play. Albania free-kick 30 yards out, Kola takes but it is deflected wide. Half-time. 46 Substitution Heskey on for MacManaman. Albania get the second 45 underway. Owen caught offside as he and Cole make an early push upfield. 48 Neville sets off on a run up the right, but his ball into Andy Cole is poor - Xhumba clears. 49 Concerted pressure from England before Hasi breaks through midfield to give Albania some respite. 50 Andy Cole wins a free-kick just over 20 yards out. Beckham takes straight at the wall. Comes out to Scholes who fires it into Heskey at the far post; Strakosha gets a fingertip to it to deny Heskey. 52 Shocking behaviour by the linesman when England are denied a corner and almost a throw-in before the ref steps in. 53 England corner, Albania clear. 55 Hairy moment for Engalnd when Vata fires in from distance and Seaman has trouble holding the ball after a deflection. 57 Kola breaks and looks for Bushi on the right as Albania pressure again. 58 Still Albania dictating the pace of the game as Ferdinand forces things wide for a corner. Brown clears, Beckham finds Ashley Cole up on the right for the Arsenal player to loop it over the top for Owen to chase - too far. 81 England denied a penalty after Cipi crashes into Butt and flattens him in the box. 63 Albania running around with increasing confidence as Bushi has a crack from distance. 65 England corner, Beckham from the left, Strakosha spills before claiming. 67 Expect headlines filled with the words "false dawn" should England fail to improve on their display so far. 69 Beckham gets into area but is stopped in his tracks. The ball comes to Andy Cole on the by-line and he fires it across goal for Strakosha to deny Heskey on the far post. 73 Increasingly desperate for England as Albania push up again. 74 GOAL: Albania 0 - 1 England Butt plays Owen through into the area for the Liverpool player to jab past Strakosha with his right foot. About time. 76 A great ball in by Beckham; all it needed was a touch by Andy Cole at the far post. Did it get it? Did it heck. 78 Albania's second corner of the night, Beckham clears. 79 Heskey tries to feed Andy Cole through on goal by Cifi cuts out the chance. 80 Lala causes a momentary panic in the England area when England make a mess of clearing the ball. 82 Substitution Muka on for Kola. Booking Neville for time-wasting, apparently while waiting for Albania to complete the substitution. 84 Substitution Sheringham on for Owen. 85 GOAL: Albania 0 - 2 England Scholes plays in Andy Cole on the left of the area. Cole drifts along the by-line and lays it back for Scholes to shoot into the roof of the net from close range. 87 Booking Andy Cole Substitution Rraklli on for Fakaj. 90 Five minutes extra to play. And what happens GOAL: Albania 1 - 2 England Indecision by Ferdinand allows Rraklli to get a late consolation to leave England hanging on for the dying moments. And if that wasn't enough, Rraklli finds the net again in the next minute only to be ruled offside. And then, would you believe it... GOAL: Albania 1 - 3 England. Andy Cole finally breaks his duck when he puts away England's third. Full-time. Fraught for England at the end, and by no means an easy or pretty game, but it's the points that count.
